questions.text: An elderly man is diagnosed with a slow-growing tumor in the deep perineal pouch. Which of the following is not a content of this structure?
questions.solution:
The root of the penis, which consists of two crus and one bulb, is the content of the superficial perineal pouch.

The deep perineal pouch is used to describe the space enclosed between the endopelvic fascia and the perineal membrane and includes the following contents:

Males Common to both Females
  • Dorsal nerve of the penis
  • Artery of the penis
  • Origin  of the branches of the penile artery
  • Bulbourethral glands
  • Urethra
  • Deep transverse perinei
  • Sphincter urethrae
  • Origin of the urethral artery
  • Dorsal nerve of the clitoris
  • Artery of clitoris
  • Origin  of the branches of the artery of the clitoris

questions.text: Identify the marked artery.
questions.solution:
The artery marked is the posterior inferior cerebellar artery. This artery branches out from the vertebral artery and it is the largest branch of the vertebral artery.

The following image shows the circle of Willis.

Related Pearl: Circle of Willis

questions.text:
Which of the following is required for the cannulation of a newborn?
  1. 22G needle
  2. 24G needle
  3. 5-mL syringe
  4. Adhesive tape
  5. Normal saline
questions.solution:
For cannulation in newborns, we would require a 24G needle, 5 mL syringe, adhesive tape, and normal saline.

Also, for a peripherally inserted central catheter (PICC), we use a 24G needle for >1 kg neonate, and for <1 kg neonate, we use a 28G needle. We need to avoid using 1 mL syringes for flushing as it may lead to catheter rupture; preferably, use 5 or 10 mL syringes. Flushing of the cannulation is done using 0.9% sodium chloride or so-called normal saline (NS).

Dressing change: We change PICC line dressing only when visibly soiled, damp, or loosened. For making it easier and sterile, two persons should perform a dressing change.

questions.text: A second-year resident performs the tuning fork tests on a patient with hearing loss. The Rinne test is positive in both ears and Weber is lateralized towards the right. What is the interpretation?
questions.solution:
The patient has left-sided sensorineural deafness.

Rinne's test is positive on both ears implying that there is no conductive hearing loss. But there could still be sensorineural hearing loss in either or both ears.

Weber's test lateralized towards the right indicates either right-sided conductive hearing loss or left-sided sensorineural hearing loss. Since there is no conductive deafness which was inferred from Rinnes's test, the interpretation here is left-sided sensorineural hearing loss.

questions.text: Which of the following condition leads to the development of wing beating tremor?
questions.solution:
Wing beating tremor is seen in Wilson's disease.

In Huntington's chorea, rapid jerky movements are seen and Sydenham's chorea is seen in Rheumatic disease. In Parkinsonism, the type of tremor is called resting tremor because they disappear on movement.

Wilsons disease:

The autosomal-recessive disease is caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene, which encodes a membrane-bound, copper-transporting ATPase.

Clinical symptoms:

  • Hepatitis and cirrhosis
  • Behavioral disturbances
  • Wing beating tremor( shown in the image below)

 

  • Ophthalmic characteristics:
    • Deposition of copper in the posterior capsule of the lens resulting in sunflower cataract
    • KF ring 

Diagnosis:

    • Presence of KF rings
    • Decreased serum ceruloplasmin (copper-containing enzyme/ferroxidase) levels
    • Measured hepatic copper levels in liver biopsy
    • Increased 24-hour urine copper excretion

The gold standard for diagnosis: Liver biopsy with quantitative copper assays

Treatment: Trientine and Zinc is the first choice of a drug regimen to be used for treating mild hepatic decompensation in Wilson’s disease.

questions.text: What is the most probable nerve to be injured based on the clinical image given below?
questions.solution:
The above image shows winging of the scapula, which is caused by injury to the long thoracic nerve.

When the patient is asked to push against a wall with both hands, the medial border of the scapula on the affected side becomes prominent and this is known as ‘winging of scapula’.

Scapular winging is almost always caused by damage to one of three nerves that control muscles in your arms, back, and neck:

Nerves Muscles Type of winging
Spinal accessory nerve

Trapezius and sternocleidomastoid

 The superior angle of the scapula becomes more prominent (lateral winging)
Long thoracic nerve

Serratus anterior

 The scapula is pulled upwards and towards the spine by the unopposed action of the trapezius (medial winging)
Dorsal scapular nerve Levator scapulae, rhomboid major, and rhomboid minor Similar to serratus anterior but mild winging

questions.text: Which of the following is a gram-positive organism that shows the following appearance on Ziehl-Neelsen staining?
questions.solution:
The image showing filamentous, branching acid-fast rods is suggestive of Nocardia.

Nocardia appears as filamentous organisms with extensive hyphae-like branching. They are gram-positive, catalase-positive, and produce urease. They are weakly acid-fast because they stain with carbolfuchsin (routine acid-fast stain) and retain when decolorized with 1-4% sulfuric acid instead of the stronger acid-alcohol decolorant.

Acid-fast staining is based on the principle that tubercle bacilli resist decolorization with acids after staining with aniline dyes. Acid fastness is attributed to the variety of fatty acids, alcohols, and lipids in the tubercle bacilli. Acid-fast organisms usually contain mycolic acid, which is acid-fast in the free state.  The steps to carry out acid-fast staining as modified by Ziehl and Neelsen are:

  1. The slide is stained with carbolfuchsin along with the application of heat.
  2. It is then decolorized with 20% sulphuric acid. Later methylene blue is used for counterstaining.
  3. The acid-fast bacteria retain the fuchsin color, while other organisms take up the counterstain.

Other options:

Option B: The image given below is a smear with Ziehl-Neelsen staining showing non-branching and acid-fast Mycobacterium tuberculosis bacilli.

 

Option C- Mycobacterium leprae bacilli are less acid and alcohol fast than the tubercle bacillus; therefore, alcohol is removed from the hydrating and dehydrating steps and 5% sulphuric acid is used as a decolorizer in place of acid/alcohol solution. The image below shows Mycobacterium leprae on ZN staining.

Option D: Actinomyces are gram-positive, anaerobic, and filamentous bacteria that are non-acid-fast in contrast to Nocardia.

The following image shows the filamentous gram-positive stained actinomyces:

questions.text: A patient with a history of contact with COVID 19 comes to the opthalmology clinic with complaints of redness,photophobia, epiphora and malaise.Examination under strict precautions was done , however there was no blurring of vision or increase in IOP and fundus was normal. Which part of the eye can be most likely to be affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
This is a probable case of COVID conjunctivitis and the affected part is conjunctiva. 

Conjunctivitis and keratitis are the only reported ocular signs of COVID-19 to date but research and studies are going on.

Covid Conjunctivitis:

  • The pathophysiology of SARS-CoV-2 associated conjunctivitis is not completely understood.
  • The disease occurs in three stages- viral replication, immune hyperactivity, and then tissue destruction.
  • It may also be an inflammatory response to the systemic disease in a form of conjunctival injection and tearing.
  • Starts as redness of the eye with a follicular reaction like any other viral conjunctivitis.
  • It may resolve by itself or progress to involve coarse epithelial keratitis, pseudomembranous conjunctivitis and bilateral hemorrhagic, pseudomembranous conjunctivitis, or pseudodendritic keratitis.
  • Tender lymphadenopathy can be seen.
  • Cells in conjunctiva die either by viral-mediated lysis or by immune reactions and resulting in the release of the virus into tears. 
  • Diagnosis is by RT-PCR confirmation of COVID 19 infection.
  • Treatment is supportive as it subsides after the COVID infection.

questions.text: A very tall patient with a thyroid swelling and elevated calcitonin is posted for surgery. He has long, slender fingers and toes. Which preoperative screening is recommended in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with a thyroid swelling, elevated calcitonin and features of marfanoid habitus (long slender fingers) is suggestive of MEN 2B syndrome. Such patients are to be screened for pheochromocytoma by measuring urinary catecholamines.

A thyroid swelling with elevated calcitonin indicates a medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC). MTC can either be sporadic (80%) or familial (RET gene mutation).

MTC can be inherited as a part of autosomal dominant (AD) syndromes such as:

  • Familial MTC
  • MEN 2A
  • MEN 2B

It is necessary to pre-operatively screen for pheochromocytoma in suspected cases of MEN 2 syndromes. If patients are found to have a pheochromocytoma, this must be operated on first.

Note: Serum calcium is measured to screen for parathyroid adenoma in MEN 2A.

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

Known as Sipple’s syndrome

Chromosome 10 / RET gene

Associated conditions :

  • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
  • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
  • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

Known commonly as MEN 3

Chromosome 10/ RET gene

Features

  • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
  • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
  • Associated abnormalities (40–50%)
    • Mucosal neuromas
    • Marfanoid habitus
    • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
    • Megacolon

questions.text:
Abuse of which of the following drugs will lead to the finding as shown in the image below?
  1. Heroin
  2. Cocaine
  3. LSD
  4. Mescaline
  5. Cannabis
questions.solution:
The given image shows circular depressed skin popping scars in this patient. Among the given options, opioid abuse and cocaine abuse are the most likely causes of the skin popping scars in this patient.

Skin popping is a method of injecting illicit drugs into the skin. Drugs like heroin, cocaine, barbiturates can be injected intradermally or subcutaneously with the goal of achieving slower absorption, decreased risk of overdose, and easier administration than with intravenous drug use.

LSD and mescaline (hallucinogens) and cannabis are not taken through injections, but by oral route or through smoking.

Head-to-toe examination in cases of substance abuse becomes important to look for such skin findings. One other such interesting finding seen in patients with cocaine abuse is that its long-term use can result in cocaine nose, with perforation of the nasal septum, as seen in the image below.

questions.text: A man has been arrested and booked under Sec. 304-B of the Indian penal code. Which of the following offenses has he been accused of?
questions.solution:
He has been accused of and arrested for dowry death. Section 304-B of the Indian Penal Code (I.P.C) deals with dowry deaths.

This legal provision comes into effect when the untimely demise of a woman occurs by burns/bodily injury or any other cause apart from normal circumstances within the first 7 years of her marriage. Evidence of cruelty or harassment by her spouse or relatives of her spouse in connection with demands for dowry must be shown. An individual accused of dowry death (cognizable, non-bailable) is liable to imprisonment from 7 years to life. 

Other options:

Option A: Death by rash or negligent act not amounting to culpable homicide is punishable (imprisonment for up to 2 years with/without fine) by Sec. 304-A IPC. 

Option C: Culpable homicide is punishable by Sec. 299 IPC. It is an offense wherein the accused intentionally causes death or bodily injury likely to cause death.

Option D: Grievous hurt is punishable by Sec. 320 IPC. Grievous hurt refers to any hurt that endangers life, or which causes the victim to be in severe bodily pain, or unable to follow his ordinary pursuits for a period of twenty days. This includes emasculation, permanent privation of the sight of either eye, permanent privation of the hearing of either ear, the privation of any member or joint or the destruction or permanent impairment of the power of any member or joint, permanent disfiguration of the head or face, and fracture or dislocation of a bone or tooth.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a mechanism of action of the device given in the image below?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Multiload Cu250, which is one of the copper-containing IUCDs. Formation of the cervical mucus plug is not the mechanism of action. However, progesterone-containing IUCDs can alter the cervical mucus along with the local effects.

The various mechanisms of action of a copper-containing IUCD are:

  • Preventing sperm motility and viability within the uterine cavity by causing a localized inflammatory response.
  • Provokes uterine contractility through prostaglandin release and increases the tubal peristalsis. The egg moves more rapidly into uterine cavity before the development of chorionic villi and thus is unable to implant.
  • Leucocytes infiltrate the endometrium and engulf the fertilized egg.
  • Enzymatic and metabolic changes in the endometrial tissue interfere with the implantation of the fertilized ovum

Some IUCDs like CuT-380A are effective for up to 10 years. Copper IUDs are helpful for emergency contraception if placed within 5 days of unprotected intercourse.

Contraindications for use of copper T include

  • Wilson disease 
  • Sensitivity to copper 
  • Pregnancy or suspected pregnancy 
  • Acute pelvic inflammatory disease or STI at the time of insertion
  • A congenital uterine abnormality that distorts the shape of the uterine cavity making insertion difficult
  • Suspected pregnancy
  • Confirmed or suspicion of uterine or cervical malignancy/neoplasia 
Abnormal uterine bleeding of unknown origin
 
Other options:
Option A: Impair sperm motility - Copper ions released from the device create a toxic environment for sperm, reducing their motility and viability.
Option B: Increase the motility of tubes - The IUD can increase uterine contractility, which may affect overall reproductive tract motility.
Option C: Enzymatic changes to prevent implantation - Copper ions alter the endometrial environment, potentially interfering with implantation.

questions.text: Identify the parasite whose microfilaria is given in the image below:
questions.solution:
Image showing sheathed microfilaria with a pointed tail, free of nuclei is suggestive of Wuchereria bancrofti. 

The female filarial worms, which belong to the phylum Nematoda, give birth to larvae known as microfilariae. Some of the microfilariae retain their egg membranes and are known as sheathed microfilariae. They can be further differentiated on the basis of the arrangement of nuclei in the tail.

Wuchereria bancrofti causes lymphatic filariasis and is the most common cause in India. Classical filariasis is due to obstruction of lymphatics by the adult worms resulting in lymph stasis. This leads to leakage of lymph into the tissues causing hard pitting (brawny) edema. It can present as acute adenolymphangitis, hydrocele, or elephantiasis which is shown below.

Investigations:

Demonstration of the microfilaria in peripheral blood, chylous urine, hydrocele fluid, etc is done.  The specimen of choice is peripheral blood. Night blood samples between 10 pm and 4 am are preferred. This is because the microfilaria shows nocturnal periodicity.

DEC provocation test: In this test, a small dose of DEC is given 20-50 minutes before sample collection so that the microfilaria appears in the blood even during the daytime. 

The image below shows the life cycle of Wuchereria bancrofti.

Related Pearl: Filarial worms and their morphology

questions.text: A child who was stung multiple times after disturbing a bee hive developed symptoms of shock, respiratory failure, and vascular collapse within minutes. Which of the following is the principal mediators of this reaction?
questions.solution:
Anaphylaxis following a bee sting is an example of IgE-mediated reaction or Type 1 hypersensitivity and the principal mediator involved here is histamine.

Immediate (Type I) hypersensitivity reactions refer to allergic reactions or allergies. It is a rapid immunologic reaction that is triggered by the binding of an antigen to an IgE antibody on the surface of mast cells. It occurs in a previously sensitized individual. These reactions are induced by environmental antigens (allergens) that stimulate strong TH2 responses and IgE production in genetically susceptible individuals. 

Activation of TH2 cells is mediated by IL-4 and in turn, TH2 cells produce IL-4, IL-5, and IL-13. These cytokines act on B cells to stimulate IgE and activation of eosinophils. IgE coats mast cells by binding to the FcεRI receptor. Re-exposure to the allergen leads to cross-linking of the IgE and FcεRI which in turn causes activation of mast cells releasing powerful mediators. The principal mediators are:

  • Histamine
  • Proteases
  • Prostaglandins
  • Leukotrienes
  • Cytokines like TNF, IL-1, and chemokines.

The clinical manifestations may be local or systemic and range from mildly annoying rhinitis to fatal anaphylaxis. It occurs in two phases: 

  • The immediate phase is characterized by vasodilation, vascular leakage, smooth muscle spasm (in asthma), or glandular secretions. These changes occur within minutes after exposure to an allergen and subside in a few hours.
  • Late-phase reaction is characterized by infiltration of tissues with eosinophils, neutrophils, basophils, monocytes, and CD4+ T cells. Late-phase reaction sets in 2 to 24 hours later and may last for several days.

Image: Sequence of events in immediate (type 1) hypersensitivity.

Related Pearl: Disorders Caused by Immediate Hypersensitivity

Clinical Syndrome

Clinical and Pathologic Manifestations

Anaphylaxis (may be caused by drugs, bee sting, food)

Fall in blood pressure (shock) caused by vascular dilation; airway obstruction due to laryngeal edema

Bronchial asthma

Airway obstruction caused by bronchial smooth muscle hyperactivity; inflammation and tissue injury caused by late-phase reaction

Allergic rhinitis, sinusitis (hay fever)

Increased mucus secretion; inflammation of upper airways, sinuses

Food allergies

Increased peristalsis due to contraction of intestinal muscles

questions.text: The histopathological section of the cardiac tissue of an 82-year-old man shows some pigmentation, as seen below. Intracellular accumulation of which of the following is likely to be seen in this case?
questions.solution:
Intracellular accumulation of lipofuscin (brown lipid) is seen in this patient. 

Lipofuscin or lipochrome is also known as the wear-and-tear pigment. It is an insoluble, brownish-yellow, granular intracellular material, which accumulates in various tissues like the heart, liver, and brain. It is seen in normal ageing patients. Accumulation of the brown pigment in large amounts can give a characteristic appearance to the tissue called brown atrophy.  

It is derived from lipid peroxidation of polyunsaturated lipids indicating free radical injury. Not injurious to the cell or its functions. It is seen in cells undergoing slow, regressive changes. The image of lipofuscin is given below.

Option B: Anthracosis leads to accumulations of carbon/coal dust pigment which is seen as black accumulations in the tissues of the lungs and not the heart. The following image shows anthracosis with deposition of black carbon particles, within the cytoplasm of macrophages.

Option C: Melanin is brown-black in color which occurs as a result of oxidation of tyrosine in melanocytes, as shown in the following histopathology of a lymph node. 

Option D: Hemosiderin is a haemoglobin-derived, golden-yellow to brown, granular or crystalline pigment. It is one of the major storage forms of iron and can be seen in iron-overload states like hemochromatosis. The following image shows extensive intra-alveolar hemosiderin deposition following pulmonary haemorrhage.

questions.text: Immediately following vaginal delivery, the patient went into a state of shock. On abdominal examination, the fundus of the uterus could not be felt and per vaginal examination revealed no obvious source of bleeding or clots. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture of shock immediately after delivery and absent uterine fundus on abdominal examination is suggestive of uterine inversion. 

Uterine inversion is a condition in which the uterus is turned inside out partially or completely. It causes postpartum collapse which is acute in onset and occurs immediately after delivery.

Causes:

  • Spontaneous- Atony with a sharp rise in intra-abdominal pressure
  • Mismanagement of 3rd stage of labor - Delivering a yet-to-be-separated placenta (Creede’s method)
  • Fundal pressure while the uterus is relaxed

Features:

  • Shock appears immediately after delivery. Mainly neurogenic due to tension on the nerves due to stretching of the infundibulopelvic ligament. Haemorrhage after detachment of placenta
  • The degree of shock is out of proportion to the amount of bleeding
  • Per abdomen examination: Fundus of the uterus is not felt. 
  • A pear-shaped mass protrudes outside the vulva

The following steps are done to reposit the inverted uterus.

  • Discontinue uterotonics
  • Administration of IV crystalloids through large-bore IV cannulas to address shock.
  • Repositioning is tried after confirming that the inverted uterus is not firmly retracted or contracted. If the placenta is attached to the uterus, it is never removed before repositioning. The palm and the fingers are used to push up the uterine fundus along the vaginal axis.
  • Administer tocolytics such as terbutaline, magnesium sulphate, and nitroglycerin to relax the uterus for repositioning if the initial attempt has failed.
  • Oxytocin infusion is started and tocolytics are stopped after repositioning. Await spontaneous expulsion of the placenta.
  • The position of the uterus is maintained while applying bimanual compression.
  • Surgical intervention is needed if repositioning fails or can't be done.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman appears uninterested in taking care of her 5-week-old baby. Her sleep is disturbed and she feels fatigued. She is irritable and complains of having suicidal thoughts. The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of a postpartum female with complaints of disturbed sleep, fatigue, and suicidal thoughts is suggestive of postpartum depression. 

Postpartum depression is characterized by a depressed mood, excessive anxiety, insomnia, anhedonia, and a change in weight, usually within the first 12 weeks postpartum.

There may be associated thoughts of suicide or of harming the baby, which is not present in postpartum blues.

A minimum of 5 symptoms of major depressive disorder (SIGECAPS - Sleep, interest, guilt, energy, concentration, appetite, psychomotor activity, and suicidal ideation) along with anhedonia must be present.

Symptoms should persist for > 2 weeks to make the diagnosis of post-partum depression.

Disturbed sleep and fatigue, are common physiological postpartum findings.

Other options:

Option B: Postpartum blues typically develop within one week of delivery. Symptoms include changes in mood, sudden crying outbursts, and a lack of interest in the baby.

Option C: Post-partum psychosis is a psychiatric emergency and usually has a mean time of onset is 2-3 weeks postpartum. The predominant symptoms are hallucinations, delusions, suicidal thoughts, and thoughts of harming the baby. The onset of psychotic symptoms is usually preceded by signs such as insomnia, restlessness, labile mood, and agitation. Lithium, often in combina­tion with an antidepressant, is the treatment of choice.

Option D: Episodes of delirium in the postpartum period are characterized by a fluctuating level of awareness or attention. In this patient, there is no altered sense of awareness.

Related Pearl: Postpartum mood disorders

Disorders and features Incidence and timeline Harmful thoughts Treatment

Postpartum blues:

Depressed affect, tearfulness and fatigue

30-75%

Starts 2-3 days after delivery. Resolves within 10 days.

 No thoughts of harming the baby Support and follow up

Postpartum depression:

Depressed affect, anxiety and poor concentration

10-15%

Starts within 12 weeks from delivery and persists for ≥ 2 weeks. 

 Thoughts of harming the baby often present CBT and SSRIs 

Postpartum psychosis:

Mood-congruent delusions, hallucinations

 0.1-0.2% Thoughts of harming the baby or self Hospitalization, atypical antipsychotics and ECT for refractory cases

questions.text: Cytochrome oxidase is inhibited in all of the following poisonings except:
questions.solution:
Cytochrome oxidase is a hemoprotein, which is the terminal component of the respiratory chain carriers (complex IV) in mitochondria. The action of cytochrome oxidase is inhibited in carbon monoxide, cyanide, and hydrogen sulfide poisoning, resulting in prevention of cellular respiration.

Hemoproteins are metalloproteins that have a typical heme prosthetic group. They are present in myoglobin, hemoglobin, and other cytochromes. Cytochrome oxidase contains two molecules of heme, each having one Fe atom that oscillates between Fe3+ and Fe2+ during oxidation and reduction. It also contains two atoms of copper, each associated with a heme unit.

Complexes  of ETC  :

Complex I: NADH-CoQ oxidoreductase

Contains - FeS, FMN, Coenzyme Q

Inhibitors – Rotenone

Complex II: Succinate-CoQ reductase

Contains - FeS, Coenzyme Q

Inhibitor - Carboxin

Complex III: CoQH2-cytochrome c oxidoreductase

Contains - cytochrome c, b, C1, and FeS

Inhibitor - Antimycin A

Complex IV: cytochrome oxidase

Contains - Cytochrome a, a3, and Copper

Inhibitor - Cyanide, Azide, Carbon monoxide

Complex V (informally): ATP Synthase

Inhibitor - Oligomycin

Note: MELAS (mitochondrial encephalopathy, lactic acidosis, and stroke) is an inherited condition due to NADH-Q oxidoreductase (Complex I) or cytochrome oxidase (Complex IV) deficiency.

questions.text: An elderly woman who is a known case of uncontrolled diabetes and having a prior history of COVID-19 infection, presents with a black, foul-smelling discharge from the nose, eye pain, and diplopia. The culture of this discharge on Sabouraud's agar would reveal colonies showing which of the following?

choices.text: Broad hyphae with acute angle branching
Septate hyphae with acute angle branching

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of mucormycosis. The culture of the discharge on Sabouraud's agar will reveal colonies showing broad hyphae with irregular branching.

Mucormycosis is an opportunistic infection caused principally by species of Rhizopus, mucor, and lichtheimia. It is seen in patients with diabetes mellitus, long-term corticosteroid use, severe burns, and immunodeficiencies.

The common clinical form is rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis in which there is an invasion of the blood vessels in the nasal cavity, eyes, and brain causing infarction, and necrosis. This is responsible for the black foul-smelling discharge seen in this patient. 

Diagnosis can be made by staining them with 10% potassium hydroxide and culture. On Sabouraud agar at 30-37°C, they appear as grey-white colonies with a thick cottony, fluffy surface. Under the microscope, they appear as irregularly branched broad hyphae.

The below image shows broad-based irregularly branched hyphae seen in mucormycosis.

Intravenous administration of amphotericin B is the treatment of choice for invasive mucormycosis. Surgical debridement and control of underlying predisposing causes should also be done.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: A public health worker had a category III dog bite. He had previously taken pre-exposure prophylaxis two months ago. What is the management of choice?

choices.text: Wound treatment and immediate vaccination. RIG is not required.
Wound washing and immediate vaccination. Half dose of RIG to be given since he had a pre exposure prophylaxis.
Only wound treatment to be given.

questions.solution:
This patient needs only wound treatment. Vaccination & RIG is not recommended.

Management of a new dog bite in a previously immunized individual with either pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) or post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) is as follows:

  1. Category I: Wound treatment only
  2. Category II/III: Only Wound treatment if the individual was immunized < 3 months. If > 3 months, wound treatment + vaccination (ID or IM) on days 0 and 3. RIG is not indicated.

Therefore, this patient had taken pre-exposure prophylaxis two months ago & came with a category III bite. He must receive only wound treatment.

World Rabies Day is the global day of action and awareness for rabies prevention. September 28th, 2020 will be the 14th World Rabies Day, and this year’s theme is End Rabies: Collaborate, Vaccinate.

Related Pearl: Rabies vaccines and immunoglobulins (WHO guidelines)

According to the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, GOI:

Individuals with WHO category II or III exposures should receive PEP without delay.

One ID dose is 0.1 mL of vaccine and one IM dose is an entire vial of vaccine, irrespective of the vial size.

Should a vaccine dose be delayed for any reason, the PEP schedule should be resumed (not restarted).

Rabies Immunoglobulin(RIG): 

  • RIG provides a passive immunization and is administered only once, as soon as possible after the initiation of PEP and not beyond 7 days after the first dose of vaccine.
  • Vaccines should never be withheld regardless of the availability of RIG.
  • Max dose: hRIG - 20IU/kg , eRIG - 40IU/kg body weight.
  • WHO has recommended the use of Monoclonal Antibodies (mAb) as a “cocktail” containing at least two antibodies against RABV, as alternatives for RIGs in PEP.
  • All of the rabies immunoglobulin, or as much as anatomically possible (but avoiding possible compartment syndrome), should be administered into or around the wound site or sites. The remaining immunoglobulin, if any, should be injected intramuscularly at a site distant from the site of vaccine administration. Rabies immunoglobulin may be diluted to a volume sufficient for all wounds to be effectively and safely infiltrated.
  • Prioritization of RIG allocation: Multiple bites>Deep wounds>Bites to head, neck, and hands>Patients with severe immunodeficiency>The biting animal is confirmed or probable rabies>Bites, scratches, and exposure of mucous membranes caused by a bat.

(PrEP)Pre-exposure prophylaxis

  • PrEP considered in remote, rabies-endemic areas where access to PEP is difficult, the dog bite incidence is >5% per year or vampire bat rabies are known to be present.
  • Pre-exposure rabies vaccination consists of three intramuscular (IM) or intradermal (ID) doses are given on days 0, 7, and 21 or 28. For adults, the vaccine should always be administered in the deltoid area of the arm; for young children (under 1 year of age), the anterolateral area of the thigh is recommended. Rabies vaccine should never be administered in the gluteal area. Administration in this manner will result in lower neutralizing antibody titers.
  • For exposed or re-exposed patients who can document previous complete PrEP or PEP the following guidelines would be applicable:
    • Proper wound management should be done.
    • There is no need for the administration of RIG.
    • One site ID or IM vaccine administration on days 0 and 3.
    Only adequate wound washing would be required in case of re-exposure where the animal bite victim has documented proof of complete PEP or PrEP within the last three months.
    • People who have previously received full post-exposure treatment with neural tissue vaccines (NTV) or vaccine of unproven potency or cannot document complete PEP or PrEP treatment should be treated as a fresh case and given full PEP.

questions.text: A young female patient developed uterine prolapse soon after delivery as shown below. What would be the most appropriate management in her case?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate management of uterine prolapse in the postpartum period is ring pessary with pelvic floor exercise. 

Uterine prolapses following delivery should be managed conservatively for the first few months postpartum. Surgery may be advised, if the prolaspe does not improve with conservative management.

The image below shows the various degrees of uterovaginal prolapse.

Related Pearl: Management of Uterine prolapse

Congenital/ Nulliparous (young) uterine prolapse: Sling/ cervicopexy

Uterovaginal uterine prolapse:

Age/condition Desire for pregnancy Desire for menstruation Surgery
<40 No Yes Fothergill's operation
>40 No No  Ward Mayo's vaginal hysterectomy
>60(medically unfit for hysterectomy)        -      - Le Forts repair
Prolapse during pregnancy /puerperium     -       - Ring Pessary

questions.text:
A 30-year-old female is brought to the emergency with burns sparing the chest, back, and face but involving both lower limbs circumferentially, genitalia, abdomen, and painful erythema in both palms. The burns blanch on touch. Based on the 2018 ATLS guidelines, what fluid resuscitation plan will you choose? (Patient weight: 50 kg)

ATLS- Advanced trauma life support

choices.text: 2.75L over 8 hours, followed by 2.75L over 16 hours
4.5 L over 8 hours, followed by 4.5 L over 16 hours
6 L over 8 hours, followed by 6 L over 16 hours
9 L over 8 hours, followed by 9 L over 16 hours

questions.solution:
The given image shows 2nd-degree burns as evident from the moist appearance of the skin, associated with pain and blanching on touch. The total volume of fluid needed is 5.5 liters of which 2.75L is given in the first 8 hours and 2.75L is given in the next 16 hours as indicated by 

Step 1: Calculating % of burns using the Wallace rule of nines

  • This includes only 2nd and 3rd-degree burns.
  • Right lower limb + left lower limb and anterior-posterior lower torso+ genitalia = 18 + 18 + 18 + 1= 55%

STEP 2: Calculating fluid using resuscitation formula for thermal burns

According to ATLS 10th ed. 2018 guidelines, the fluid resuscitation formula for thermal burns is 2ml/kg/TBSA% given IV.

Fluid requirement = 2ml x body weight x TBSA

                          = 2ml x 50 kg x 55 %

                          = 5.5 litres.

One-half of the calculated fluid need is given in the first 8 hours, and the remaining half is given over the subsequent 16 hours.

The rate of infusion for IV resuscitation fluid should be as constant as possible; sharp decreases in infusion rates can lead to vascular collapse and an increase in edema.

Superficial (epidermal) burns are excluded from this calculation.

Related Pearl: Wallace's rule of 9

Related Pearl: Burns – Formulae for Fluid Calculation(Updated according to ATLS 10th edition 2018 guidelines)

This formula gives the total fluid requirement for 24hours. Half of this volume is infused in the first 8 hours, and the remaining half is infused in the next 16 hours.

Note:

The goal of resuscitation is to maintain the fine balance of adequate perfusion as indicated by urine output. It is important to understand that formulas provide a starting target rate; subsequently, the amount of fluids provided should be adjusted based on a urine output target of 0.5 mL/kg/hr for adults and 1 mL/kg/hr for children weighing less than 30 kg.

Related Pearl: Degrees of Burns

  First-degree Second-degree superficial (partial-thickness) Second-degree deep (partial-thickness)

Third-degree (full thickness)

Depth Epidermis Epidermis + superficial dermis Epidermis + most of the dermis (most skin appendages destroyed) Entire dermis + subcutaneous tissue Involves connective tissue, muscle, possibly bone
Colour/texture Red Red, edematous, and blistered Pale, mottled Hard, leathery Pale, dry, charred
Blanchable (capillary refill)  Yes Yes No No No

questions.text:
According to IADPSG, what is the cut-off value of fasting blood glucose for the diagnosis of gestational diabetes mellitus?

IADPSG- International Association of Diabetes and Pregnancy Study Group
questions.solution:
According to IADPSG, the cut-off value of fasting blood glucose for the diagnosis of gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) is >92 mg/dl.

Gestational Diabetes Mellitus (GDM) refers to any degree of glucose intolerance having its onset or first recognition during pregnancy. 

For IADPSG criteria, an oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) is done in the fasting state using 75 g of glucose, and gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) is diagnosed if any one of the following cut-offs is met i.e.

  • Fasting: >92 mg/dl 
  • 1 hour: >180 mg/dl  
  • 2 hour: >153 mg/dl

Earlier, a two-step approach was being used to diagnose GDM. In this, the first step (screening) is a 50-gram one-hour glucose challenge test (GCT). The patients having a positive result of >140mg/dl, are candidates for the OGTT. A 100-gram, three-hour oral glucose tolerance test (GTT), is the diagnostic test for gestational diabetes mellitus. GDM is diagnosed if two or more values are positive.

Diabetes in Pregnancy Societies of India(DIPSI) recommends a 1-step procedure with 75 g oral glucose without regard to the time of the last meal. A venous plasma glucose value at 2 hours >140 mg/dL is diagnosed as GDM.

Some complications of GDM include:

  • Maternal
    • Hypertension, preeclampsia
    • Hydramnios
    • Increased operative interventions
    • Future development of diabetes mellitus
  • Fetal and neonatal
    • Fetal macrosomia
    • Congenital anomalies
    • Metabolic abnormalities such as hypocalcemia, hypomagnesemia, hyperbilirubinemia, and neonatal hypoglycemia.
    • Respiratory distress syndrome
    • Subsequent childhood and adolescent obesity

 

Screening is usually done at 24-28 weeks of gestation. Early diagnosis and treatment are important to prevent complications.

questions.text: A middle-aged male presents with dull aching epigastric pain. He gives a history of acute abdominal pain following an episode of binge drinking 5 weeks back which was managed conservatively. On examination, he appears icteric and a firm mass was palpable in the epigastrium. His CT scan is given below.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a history of acute pancreatitis, epigastric mass, and the CT image showing a cyst is suggestive of pancreatic pseudocyst. The capsule of the cyst is composed of collagen and granulation tissue, and it is not lined by epithelium. Hence, it is called a pseudocyst.

Pseudocysts are post-inflammatory cysts that arise following an attack of mild acute pancreatitis. Formation of a pseudocyst requires 4 weeks or more from the onset of acute pancreatitis. They are also the most common complication of chronic pancreatitis.

Pseudocysts are usually solitary and most commonly seen in the lesser omental sac. The most common artery involved is the splenic artery.

 Complications of pancreatic pseudocyst include:

  • Abscess
  • Systemic sepsis
  • GI bleeding
  • Fistula formation
  • Peritonitis
  • Obstructive jaundice
  • Bowel obstruction
  • Hemorrhage into the cyst
  • Hemoperitoneum

Pancreatic pseudo­cysts can be distinguished from cystic neoplasms by having high amylase levels and absence of mucin and low serum carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) levels.

Related Pearl: Causes of acute pancreatitis

Common causes

  • Gallstones - most common
  • Alcohol
  • Post-ERCP (Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography)
  • Blunt trauma, abdomen
  • Post-operative (cardiothoracic, upper gastrointestinal, biliary)
  • Hypertriglyceridemia
  • Sphincter of Oddi dysfunction

Uncommon causes

  • Hyperparathyroidism
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Deficiency of apolipoprotein CII
  • Pancreas divisum
  • Periampullary diverticulum
  • Vasculitis
  • Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP)
  • Connective tissue disorders
  • Ischemic–hypoperfusion states
  • Hereditary pancreatitis
  • Cystic fibrosis
  • Renal failure

Drugs

  • L-Asparaginase
  • Steroids
  • Sulfonamides
  • Tetracycline
  • Valproate
  • Azathioprine
  • Anti-retroviral drugs
  • Estrogens
  • Thiazide diuretics

Rare causes

  • Autoimmune
  • Infections (mumps, coxsackie B, cytomegalovirus, parasite)
  • Malnutrition
  • Scorpion bite

Related Pearl: Clinical features of acute pancreatitis

Symptoms:

  • Acute onset of epigastric pain, which is severe, constant, and refractory to usual doses of analgesics.
  • Typically radiates to back
  • Relieved in the sitting forward position
  • Nausea, repeated vomiting, retching, and hiccups

Signs:

  • Hypotension, tachycardia, and tachypnea
  • Grey Turner sign (A): bluish discoloration of the flanks
  • Cullen’s sign (B): bluish discoloration around the umbilicus
  • Fox sign: discoloration below the inguinal ligament
  • Pleural effusion (left > right): dullness on percussion, decreased breath sounds

Related Pearl: Laboratory findings in acute pancreatitis

  • Elevated serum amylase and serum lipase
    • Serum amylase level rises immediately and peaks in few hours and returns to normal in 3–5 days
    • Serum amylase level lacks specificity.
    • Serum amylase levels do not correlate with the severity of pancreatitis.
    • Serum lipase is more specific, and it is more useful when the patient presents 24–48 hours later.
  • Hyperglycemia
  • Hypocalcemia, hypoalbuminemia
  • Leukocytosis
  • Elevated serum levels of hepatic enzymes like alanine aminotransferase (ALT).
  • Azotemia, due to prerenal acute renal failure in case of severe fluid loss

questions.text: A 55 year old postmenopausal woman came with complaints of irregular bleeding, breast tenderness, and abdominal pain. Abdomino-pelvic ultrasound revealed an adnexal mass. A biopsy from the mass revealed the following picture. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with biopsy showing gland-like structures, called Call–Exner bodies are suggestive of granulosa cell tumor.

Granulosa cell tumors are ovarian sex-cord stromal tumors made up of cells closely resembling the granulosa cells of the ovarian follicle. The majority of the time it is seen in post-menopausal women. 

These tumors are usually unilateral. In adult women, they may be associated with proliferative breast disease, postmenopausal irregular bleeding, breast tenderness, endometrial hyperplasia, and endometrial carcinoma. The presence of this tumor in prepubertal girls may lead to precocious puberty. Occasionally, granulosa cell tumors produce androgens, masculinizing the patient

The cut section is soft and has a yellowish reticular or trabecular appearance with interstitial hemorrhage. On microscopy, Call- Exner bodies are seen which are small, distinctive, glandlike structures filled with an acidophilic material that resemble immature follicles.

Other options:

Option B: A yolk sac tumor/endodermal sinus tumor is an aggressive malignant germ cell tumor of the ovaries. Most of the yolk sac tumors have Schiller-Duval bodies and they are pathognomonic.

Option C: Krukenberg tumor is the carcinoma of the stomach that metastasize to the ovary. It is characterized by mucin-producing signet ring cells. 

Option D: Seminoma is the most common type of germ-cell tumor. The histological image shows sheets of uniform cells with clear cytoplasm and a central nucleus, with a prominent nucleolus giving a fried-egg.

questions.text: A man was brought to the emergency department with a history of assault by a mob using heavy blunt objects and sharp objects. On examination, crushing of the hair bulb was seen. Identify the type of wound.
questions.solution:
The type of wound in which the crushing of the hair bulb is seen is a lacerated wound.

Cut lacerations may be produced by blunt weapons or heavy relatively sharp-edged weapons such as axe, hatchets, and choppers. Scalp lacerations can be found in association with bruising and abrasions. Fascial strands, hair bulbs, nerves, and vessels, that run in the depth of the wound, are irregularly torn and crushed.

Margins are irregular, ragged, and uneven. The ends are pointed or blunt. The edges of lacerations, especially over the skull are undermined. The depth of the wound varies according to the thickness of the soft parts at the site of the injury and the degree of force applied.

Medicolegal importance of laceration:

  • The type of laceration indicates the cause of the injury and the shape of the weapon.
  • Foreign bodies found in the wound may indicate the circumstances in which the crime was committed.
  • The age of the injury can be determined.
Other options:
Option A: An incised wound is clean-cut, regular, and well-defined. Bruising does not occur when caused by light-cutting weapons but bruising and some irregularity of the margins may be present when heavy and not-so-sharp-edged weapons like a shovel, Kassi, axe, tangi, etc. have been used.

Option C: Chop wounds are caused by a blow with the sharp cutting edge of a fairly heavy weapon like an axe, sword, or hatchet. The margins of the wound depending on the condition of the weapon, a sharp margin with slight bruising is seen with a sharp-edged weapon, and a ragged and bruised margin is seen with a blunt edge. Undermining occurs in the direction towards which the chop is made.

Option D: Avulsion or shearing laceration is a lesion where the skin separates or peels off by tearing from the underlying tissues. It is due to shearing force delivered at an acute angle. Commonly seen in road traffic accidents.

questions.text: A 3‐month‐old child comes to OPD with widespread peeling and erosion as shown in the below image. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS).

Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome/Ritter's disease is an exfoliative dermatosis where the superficial epidermis is stripped off revealing a tender and erythematous body surface.

Children under the age of 6 years and neonates are most commonly affected by the generalized form of SSSS, while the localized form is more frequent in older children and adults.

The initial infection may be a small lesion such as impetigo, throat, or gastrointestinal tract infection. The serine protease exfoliative toxins - ETA and ETB, targeting the cell adhesion protein desmoglein 1, are responsible for the separation of keratinocytes just below the granular layer in the epidermis. Cell necrosis does not occur in SSSS, unlike toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN).

After the initial infection, the patient may develop fever, irritability, and skin tenderness followed by a widespread erythematous eruption. It is usually accentuated in the flexures, axillae, and groins, and progresses rapidly to form superficial blisters. Dislodgement of the intact superficial epidermis by a shearing force, indicating a plane of cleavage is called the Nikolsky sign. Thus, Nikolsky's sign is positive in SSSS.

The tender skin wrinkles and desquamates, leaving extremely painful raw areas. The condition usually heals within 7–14 days, with hyperpigmentation in localized forms.

Swabs and cultures of blister fluids do not usually grow the staphylococci in SSSS, since it is toxin-mediated. Blood cultures may be positive in adults. A skin biopsy will confirm the split in the granular layer of SSSS. Tzanck preparation from a freshly denuded area in SSSS will show a number of epithelial cells with large nuclei but no inflammatory cells, while in TEN, there are only a few rounded epithelial cells but many inflammatory cells.

Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome usually settles when treated with appropriate systemic antibiotics.

  • First-line agents: Parenteral penicillinase‐resistant antibiotics such as flucloxacillin or clindamycin
  • If MRSA is suspected: Parenteral vancomycin or tobramycin

Early administration of antibiotics is necessary for early recovery and low mortality. However, in adults, the overall mortality rate is higher.

Related Pearl: Vesiculobullous Disorders

Disease Clinical Manifestations Histology Immuno-pathology Autoantigens
Pemphigus vulgaris       Flaccid blisters, denuded skin,oro-mucosal lesions Acantholytic blister formed in suprabasal layer of epidermis  Cell surface deposits of IgG on keratinocytes- fish net pattern Dsg3, Dsg1 in patients with skin involvement
Pemphigus foliaceus       Crusts and shallow erosions on the scalp, central face, upper chest, and back Acantholytic blister formed in superficial layer of epidermis  Cell surface deposits of IgG onkeratinocytes Dsg1
Bullous pemphigoid     Large tense blisters on flexor surfaces and trunk  Subepidermal blister with eosinophil-rich infiltrate Linear band of IgG and/or C3 in epidermal BMZ  BPAG1, BPAG2
Dermatitis herpetiformis      Extremely pruritic small papules and vesicles on elbows, knees, buttocks, and posterior neck Subepidermal blister with neutrophils in dermal papillae  Granular deposits of IgA at the tips of dermal papillae Epidermal trans-glutaminase
Linear IgA disease     Pruritic small papules on extensor surfaces; occasionally larger, arciform blisters  Subepidermal blister with neutrophil-rich infiltrate  Linear band of IgA in epidermalBMZ BPAG2
Epidermo-lysis bullosa acquisita Tense bullae and erosions  Subepidermal blister  IgG and C3 DEJ – Continous and linear  Type VII collagen

 The images below shows clinical pictures of pemphigus patients.

  • Image A - oral erosions in a patient with pemphigus vulgaris
  • Image B - heavily clotted and crusted lesions around the mouth in a patient with paraneoplastic pemphigus
  • Image C - skin lesions found on the trunk in a patient with pemphigus vulgaris
  • Image D - skin lesions on the trunk in a patient with pemphigus foliaceus

questions.text: A newborn on routine head-to-toe examination was found to have ambiguous genitalia. Further investigations confirm a deficiency of 21-hydroxylase enzyme. What is the mode of inheritance of the given clinical condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of congenital adrenal hyperplasia. It includes a group of autosomal recessive disorders, each of which involves a deficiency of an enzyme involved in the synthesis of cortisol, aldosterone, or both.

The most common form is known to occur due to the deficiency of 21-hydroxylase, resulting from mutations or deletion of CYP21A.

questions.text: Which of the following may be seen in ulcerative colitis?
questions.solution:
Pseudopolyps and mucosal bridges are seen in ulcerative colitis (UC).

In UC, regenerating mucosa often bulges into the lumen to create pseudopolyps and the tips of these polyps may fuse to create mucosal bridges.

Granulomas, strictures, and mural thickening are features of Crohn's disease and not UC.

Features characteristic to ulcerative colitis:

  • Proctocolitis/backwash ileitis
  • Mucosa and superficial submucosal involvement
  • Broad-based ulcers
  • Pseudopolyps and mucosal bridges
  • Toxic megacolon

Related Pearl: Difference between Ulcerative Colitis and Crohn's Disease

ULCERATIVE COLITIS CROHN'S DISEASE
Proctocolitis/Backwash ileitis Affects any part of the GIT, most commonly the iliocecal region
Mucosal disease Affects the full thickness of the bowel wall (transmural)
Confluent disease in colon and rectum Skip lesions are characteristic
Strictures and fistulas are not common They are more commonly associated with strictures and fistulas.
Granulomas are not common Granulomas are the hallmark of Crohn's disease
Not associated with perianal disease Associated with perianal disease

It does not usually affect the terminal ileum.

 When symptoms affect the terminal ileum, symptoms may mimic appendicitis.
Resection of the colon and rectum is curative. Recurrence is common after resection.

questions.text: The microscopic finding as shown in the hair strand image is due to the deficiency of which of the following enzyme?
questions.solution:
Microscopic analysis of the hair shaft showing trichorrhexis nodosa and longitudinal breaks and is seen in Argininosuccinic aciduria due to the defect in the enzyme argininosuccinate lyase.

It is a defect in the hair shaft characterized by thickening or weak points (nodes) that cause the hair to break off easily.

Trichorrhexis nodosa can also be caused by other disorders such as:

  • Hypothyroidism
  • Iron deficiency
  • Menkes' kinky hair syndrome

questions.text: A 9-month-old boy presents with progressive pallor and abdominal distension. Red cell distribution width is normal.  The peripheral smear is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical history and peripheral blood smear showing target cells and aniso-poikilocytosis, along with the normal red cell distribution width(RDW), are suggestive of thalassemia.

Thalassemia is a hemoglobinopathy that arises due to deficient synthesis of the globin chains. Depending on the chain affected, it is classified into α-thalassemia and β-thalassemia.

β-Thalassemia arises due to the deficient synthesis of β-chains. Normal adult RBCs have HbA, along with HbA2 and fetal haemoglobin (HbF) in small amounts. There is a deficit in the synthesis of HbA with an elevation of HbA2 and HbF levels in β-thalassemia. 

α-Thalassemia is caused by deficient synthesis of α-chains. It can also present as an α-thalassemia trait, with trivial hematologic abnormalities. Excess of β- and γ-globin chains form Bart hemoglobin (γ4) in fetal life and HbH (β4) after birth. Severe deficiency leads to hydrops fetalis.

Ineffective erythropoiesis leads to bone marrow hyperplasia and extramedullary hematopoiesis, which can involve the liver, spleen, and lymph nodes. In β-thalassemia major, anemia manifests 6 to 9 months after birth. HbF levels are markedly elevated. The presence of bony anomalies such as frontal bossing, prominent facial bones, and dental malocclusion is typical.

The image below shows thalassemic facies (frontal bossing and maxillary hyperplasia) in a child with thalassemia major. 

Laboratory findings: Infants with severe β-thalassemia diseases experience increasing anemia following the newborn stage. The RBCs exhibit microcytosis, hypochromia, and target cells. Usually observed are nucleated RBCs, a distinct anisopoikilocytosis, and relative reticulocytopenia. Without transfusions, the Hb level frequently drops to 6 g/dL in a gradual manner.

The RDW shows the size difference in the red blood cells. Low RDW means all the red blood cells are small and uniform in size, while a large RDW means that the cells vary in size. It is normal in case of thalassemia as all cells are uniformly small in size. It increases in iron deficiency anaemia because of presence of small and normal sized RBCs.

High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) confirms the diagnosis of thalassemia. It shows the absence of HbA and high levels of HbF.

Other options:

Option A: Glossitis, stomatitis, darkening of the skin on the knuckles and terminal phalanges, and enlargement of the liver and spleen are characteristics of megaloblastic anemia. Peripheral smear in megaloblastic anemia is characterized by macrocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils (shown below).

Option B: Iron deficiency anemia has high RDW. Peripheral smear shows microcytic hypochromic anemia along with target cells.

Option D: Megaloblastic anemia has a particular subtype called pernicious anemia. It is caused by insufficient vitamin B12 absorption through the gastrointestinal pathway, leading to vitamin B12 insufficiency. Macro-ovalocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils are frequent observations in the peripheral smear associated with megaloblastic anemia. Neutrophil hypersegmentation is an early symptom of the disease and typically occurs beyond 3 to 5 lobes.

Related Pearl: Differential Diagnosis of Microcytic Anaemia

Serum Ferritin <30 µg/L Normal/Increased Increased
TIBC Increased Normal Decreased
Transferrin saturation <15% Normal Normal/Decreased
Transferrin Receptor-Ferritin Index High (>2) Normal Low (<2)
MCV Decreased Markedly Decreased May be low or normal
RBC count <5 million/µL >5 million/µL Normal
Mentzer Index ≥13 <13 N/A
RDW-CV(%) >15 <15 Normal/Increased

TIBC: Total iron-binding capacity 

Related Pearl: Thalassemia syndromes

Normally each individual carries 4 functional alpha chain genes and 2 functional beta chain genes. Alpha and beta-thalassemia are inherited disorders in which there is reduced production of alpha-globin or beta-globin chains, respectively.

  • Alpha thalassemia: Gene deletion is the most common cause of reduced α-chain synthesis.
  • Beta +- thalassemia: The most common cause is splicing mutation.
  • Beta 0- thalassemia: Chain terminator mutations are the most common cause.

questions.text: Which of the following viruses shows genetic change similar to the influenza virus?
questions.solution:
Rotavirus exhibits genetic reassortment/antigenic drift similar to that of the influenza virus.

Rotaviruses appear as cartwheel-shaped structures with short spokes radiating from them. 11 segments of double-stranded RNA constitute the genome. Influenza viruses have a linear, segmented, single-stranded RNA. Reassortment of the genome occurs readily due to the presence of this segmented RNA.

Other options:

Option B - Adenovirus contains double-stranded DNA. It has icosahedral symmetry, with structures known as fibers extruding from the vertices. 

Option C - Ebola viruses are filamentous viruses with nonsegmented single-stranded RNA as genetic material.

Option D - Rabies viruses belonging to the family Rhabdoviridae are bullet-shaped viruses, with nonsegmented single-stranded RNA.

questions.text: You notice the presence of the following type of lesions over the arms and around the chin in a newborn baby at birth. Microscopic examination of theses lesions will reveal:
questions.solution:
The above image showing multiple vesiculopustular lesions distributed over arms in a newborn baby at birth is suggestive of transient Pustular Melanosis. Microscopic examination of these lesions will reveal Neutrophils.

Transient Pustular Melanosis:

  • These are benign lesion seen predominantly in black neonates.
  • They contain neutrophils and is present at birth as a vesiculopustular eruption around the chin, neck, back, extremities, and palms or soles; it lasts for 2-3 days.
  • No therapy is required

Other Normal findings in a newborn:

  • Erythema toxicum: small white papules on an erythematous base, which are usually present on the face, trunk, and extremities. They contain eosinophils and may persist for a week.
  • Subconjunctival hemorrhage.
  • Mongolian spots: Slate-blue, demarcated areas of pigmentation seen over the buttocks and back.
  • Vaginal bleeding in the newborn at 2–3 days of age and enlargement and secretion of the breasts in both sexes.
  • Hymenal tags
  • Physiological phimosis

 

Related Pearl: Benign findings in a newborn

1. Erythema toxicum – small, white papules on an erythematous base that usually present on the face, trunk, and extremities. They contain eosinophils and may persist for a week. 

 

2. Mongolian spots – Slate-blue, demarcated areas of pigmentation seen over the buttocks and back. This is also called dermal melanocytosis. 

 

3. Pustular melanosis – Benign lesions seen predominantly in black neonates, contains neutrophils, and is present at birth as vesiculopustular eruption around the chin, neck, back, extremities, palms and soles.

 

4. Sebaceous Hyperplasia - White-Yellow papules on nose of a newborn due to hyperplastic sebaceous glands

 

5. Milia - Pearly opalescent white, epidermal inclusion cysts usually over the face.

 

6. Epstein Pearls - nests of epithelial cells, that appear as whitish/yellowish spots on hard palate. Usually, resolve by 3 months.

 

7. Cutis Marmorata - Transient lacy reticular vascular pattern of skin caused due to exaggerated physiologic vasomotor response on exposure to low environmental temperature.

 

8. Sucking Blisters - Solitary or scattered superficial bullae present at birth on the upper limbs of infants, which are caused by vigorous sucking on the affected part in-utero.

 

9. Vaginal bleeding in the newborn at 2–3 days of age and enlargement and secretion of the breasts in both sexes.

10. Hymenal tags

11. Physiological phimosis

12. Conjunctival hemorrhage

13. Peeling of skin (especially in post terms)

questions.text: In Integrated child development services (ICDS), intersectoral coordination is seen with which organization?
questions.solution:
In Integrated child development services (ICDS), intersectoral coordination is seen with NHM(National Health Mission).

The ICDS overlaps with many of the programs of NHM of which the Anemia Mukt Bharat Scheme  is an example, where prophylactic iron and folic acid is given to children, adolescents, women of reproductive age, and pregnant women, irrespective of anemia

ICDS:

The blueprint for the scheme was prepared by the Department of Social Welfare in 1975. The Government of India decided to expand the project to cover 100 areas by 1978-79. Two major evaluations were conducted in 1978and 1982. The positive results of these evaluations formed the basis for the government's decision to accelerate the expansion of ICDS in 1982.  

Other options:

NACO(National AIDS Control Organization): prevents the transmission of HIV,  decreases the morbidity and mortality associated with it and minimize the socio-economic impact resulting from it.

NLEP(National Leprosy Eradication Programme) : is a centrally sponsored Health Scheme of the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Govt. of India.

UNDP (United Nations Development Programme): It is the main source of funds for technical assistance. Its main objective is to help poorer nations develop their human and natural resources to their potential.

Related Pearl: Integrated child development services (ICDS)

questions.text: A 68-year-old  female patient, who is a known case of poorly controlled diabetes presents to the clinic with complaints of hazy vision. Which of the following types of cataracts can be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The typical appearance of a diabetic cataract is a snowflake cataract.

Increased levels of blood glucose also lead to high levels of glucose in the aqueous humor. The excess glucose in the aqueous humor metabolizes into sorbitol and diffuses into the lens causing overhydration. This phenomenon is responsible for cortical opacities in a distinct pattern causing snowflake cataracts.

Other options:

Option A: Sunflower cataract is seen in Wilson's disease and is caused due to copper deposition in the lens.

Option B: Breadcrumb appearance of cataracts is seen in patients with inflammatory conditions such as iridocyclitis, pars planitis, and choroiditis.

Option C: Christmas tree cataract is seen in patients with mytonic dystrophy.

 

Related Pearl: Diseases and Associated Cataracts - Images

Wilson's Disease/Chalcosis: Sunflower Cataract

Diabetes mellitus:  Snowflake cataract

Blunt trauma: May present as rosette-shaped cataract

Myotonic dystrophy - Christmas tree cataract

questions.text: The peripheries will be warm and capillary refill will be brisk in which of the following types of shock?
questions.solution: In distributive shock (eg: sepsis, anaphylaxis, high spinal cord injury), the periphery will be warm and capillary refill will be brisk due to low peripheral vascular resistance (vasodilation).

questions.text: Which test is performed to detect reversible myocardial ischemia?
questions.solution:
Thallium scan is performed to detect reversible myocardial ischemia.

  • Infarct appears as a cold spot on Thallium perfusion scanning.
  • Reversible ischemia will be cold on exercise and normal on rest while irreversible infarct will reveal cold spot during rest as well as exercise. Hence thallium determines the reversibility of a lesion.
  • In Tc, pyrophosphate scanning infarct shows the hot spot.
  • MUGA (multi gated acquisition scan) is a nuclear medicine test designed to evaluate the function of right and left ventricles of the heart, thus allowing informed diagnostic intervention in heart failure.
  • Uses of MUGA scan:
    • Assess the degree of damage to the myocardium following a MI.
    • Used in patients undergoing chemotherapy (e.g. anthracyclin) to assess whether the drugs are having an adverse effect on cardiac function.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents with irregular periods, acne & excessive hair growth. What is the first line management?
questions.solution:
The first line of treatment for this woman with signs and symptoms of polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) such as irregular periods, acne & excessive hair growth (hirsutism) is lifestyle modification.

PCOS is an endocrinopathy seen in women of reproductive age, affecting multiple systems. A weight loss of 10% through lifestyle modifications such as diet and exercise are considered first-line.

The Rotterdam criteria are used to diagnose PCOS. The presence of any two of the three components of this criteria establishes the diagnosis of PCOS:

  • Clinical/biochemical hyperandrogenism (hirsutism, acne)
  • Menstrual abnormalities (oligomenorrhea/amenorrhea), anovulation, infertility
  • Polycystic ovaries on ultrasonography.

Sonographic criteria for polycystic ovaries include ≥ 12 small cysts or an increased ovarian volume (> 10 mL) or both. 

Management:

  • Weight reduction and lifestyle changes are considered the first-line treatment for infertility in obese women with PCOS.
  • Clomiphene citrate is the first-line pharmacological choice for ovulation induction in PCOS (Option B).
  • Gonadotropins are second-line.(Aromatase inhibitors like letrozole are now not used to treat infertility in these patients)
  • Patients with PCOD are more prone to developing insulin resistance which can be controlled with metformin (Option C). 
  • Oral contraceptive pills (OCP), preferably fourth-generation are used to treat menstrual abnormalities. It also reduces acne and further hirsutism (Option D).
  • Anti-androgens are useful in treating hirsutism. OCP with cyproterone acetate is prescribed for PCOS patients with hirsutism. 

Surgical options include laparoscopic ovarian drilling or puncture of not more than four cysts in each ovary. It restores endocrine levels and improves fertility. Surgery is indicated only in the case of

  • Failure of medical therapy
  • Hyperstimulation
  • Infertile women
  • Previous pregnancy losses

questions.text: Which of the following micro-organisms is most commonly associated with the finding shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The image shows violin-string adhesions associated with chlamydial infections. It is also seen frequently with gonorrheal infections.

Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome refers to inflammation of the liver capsule with adhesion formation. This is due to perihepatitis in pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) caused by gonococcal and chlamydial infection. It results in violin-string adhesions between the liver and the diaphragm or liver and anterior abdominal wall. The condition is characterized by right upper quadrant abdominal pain with a pleuritic component, sometimes referred to the right shoulder.

The diagnosis can be made through laparoscopy or laparotomy via direct visualization of violin string-like adhesions.

questions.text: A diagnostic test has specificity of 0.80 and sensitivity of 0.90 when the prevalence of the disease in a population is 30%. What is the negative predictive value of the test?
questions.solution:
The Negative Predictive value is 95%

For convenience, assume the total population in this scenario is 100.

Total diseased population would then be 30 and disease free would be 70.

Since sensitivity is 0.90, total true positives (TP) would be 27.

Since specificity is 0.80, total true negatives (TN) would be 56.

The hypothetical table would be:

 

Disease +

Disease -

Total

Test +

27 (TP)

14 (FP)

41

Test -

3 (FN)

56 (TN)

59

Total

30

70

100

 Negative predictive value (NPV) = TN/(FN + TN) x 100 = 56/59 = 0.949 = 95%.

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ Accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Speciifity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: The composition of breast milk varies at different points of lactation to suit the baby’s needs. Which statement is false about breast milk composition?

choices.text: Mature milk is thicker with all the essential nutrients for growth.
Foremilk is watery and is rich in proteins and sugar.
Hindmilk is richer in fat and provides more energy.

questions.solution:
Mature milk is thinner (not thicker) with all essential nutrients for growth. 

Type of Breast Milk

Watery and thinner compared to transitional milk

Watery to quench baby’s thirst
Rich in all nutrients

Rich in fat
Sense of satiety

World Breastfeeding Week is a global campaign celebrated 1-7 August every year. World Breastfeeding Week aims to highlight the benefits that breastfeeding can bring to both the health and welfare of babies, as well as for maternal health. The theme for the year 2022 is "Step Up for Breastfeeding: Educate and Support".

questions.text: Where are owl's eye inclusion bodies seen?
questions.solution:
Owl’s eye inclusion bodies are intranuclear basophilic inclusion bodies seen in CMV infection.

Cytomegalovirus is a type of herpes virus, which causes severe disease in immunocompromised patients. In most other cases, it is inapparent and marked by prolonged latency with intermittent reactivation.

Diagnosis:

  • IgG avidity assay helps in differentiating past and primary infection with cytomegalovirus (CMV). 
  • Avidity level measured by avidity index is used to describe the percentage of IgG bound to the antigen after being treated with denaturing agents.These assays are based on the fact that low avidity IgG antibodies are present during the first few months after the infection and avidity increases over time indicating maturation of the immune response. So the presence of high avidity IgG denotes a past infection rather than a primary one. Low avidity IgG signals a primary infection within the last 3-4 months. 
  • IgM detection can be used as an indicator of acute infection, but it lacks specificity for primary infection. This is because it persists for years in some individuals and is also produced during reactivation.

The predominant pathogen to infect the renal transplant recipients in the period around 1 to 4 months following the transplantation is cytomegalovirus (CMV). The most common CMV presentation in kidney transplant patients is fever (most common), leukopenia, hepatosplenomegaly, myalgia, and arthralgia.

questions.text: Which of the following pathway is the most important source of reducing equivalents for fatty acid synthesis in the liver?
questions.solution:
The most important source of reducing equivalents (NADPH) for fatty acid synthesis in the liver is the hexose monophosphate shunt pathway (HMP).

Since HMP shunt pathway and fatty acid synthesis both occur in the cytosol of the cell, there are no membranes or permeability barriers against the transfer of NADPH. This NADPH is involved as a donor of reducing equivalents in both the reduction of the 3-ketoacyl and of the 2,3-unsaturated acyl derivatives. 

Other sources are:

  • Extramitochondrial isocitrate dehydrogenase (minor source)
  • Malic enzyme

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents with mild ptosis and proximal lower limb weakness. Nerve conduction studies show incremental response following brief exercise. Further investigations reveal antibodies against presynaptic P/Q voltage-gated calcium channels. Which of the following malignancies is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS). It is associated with small-cell lung carcinoma.

It is an autoimmune disorder caused by antibodies that block acetylcholine release by inhibiting a presynaptic calcium channel. In contrast to myasthenia gravis, rapid, repetitive stimulation (muscle activity) results in an increase in muscle response and strength.

Patients typically present with weakness of their extremities. In about half the cases, there is an underlying malignancy; most often, neuroendocrine carcinoma of the lung (Small cell lung carcinoma). The stimulus for autoantibody formation in paraneoplastic cases may be the expression of the same calcium channel in the neoplastic cells.

Patients without cancer often have other autoimmune diseases, such as vitiligo or thyroid disease. Treatment consists of drugs that increase acetylcholine release by depolarizing synaptic membranes (pyridostigmine), plasmapheresis, and immunosuppressive agents, similar to myasthenia gravis.

questions.text: An elderly patient presents to the clinic with complaints of difficulty reading the fine print of magazines. The doctor diagnoses her with hypermetropia. Which of the following lenses can be used in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
Convex lenses are used in the management of hypermetropia.

Hypermetropia/long-sightedness is a refractive state where light is focused behind the retina while accommodation is at rest.

Patients with significant hypermetropia usually complain of defective near vision along with asthenopic symptoms such as tiredness of eyes, frontal headache, watering of eyes, and mild photophobia.

Other options:

Concave lenses are used in the management of myopia while cylindrical lenses are used in the management of astigmatism.
