questions.text: The type of strangulation shown in the given image is:
questions.solution:
The type of strangulation shown in the given image is garrotting.

Tightening of a noose around the neck by twisting a rod within the ligature is known as Garrotting. 

This was a form of judicial execution once employed in Spain. The rod-like object used to tighten the ligature is called a Spanish windlass - this may be a ruler, stick or a screwdriver.

Other options:

  • Burking is a type of homicidal asphyxial death comprising of smothering and traumatic asphyxia. In burking, the assaulter throws the victim to the ground and kneels or sits on the chest of the victim preventing chest movements. He/she then covers the nose and mouth of the victim with his/her hands. 
  • Mugging is a type of strangulation caused by holding the neck of the victim in the crook of the elbow.  Pressure is then exerted either on the front of the larynx or at one or both sides by the forearm and upper arm. In mugging, the attack is usually made from behind. Death occurs due to reflex cardiac arrest or asphyxia. 
  • Lynching - Putting a person to death by mob action for an alleged offence without a legal trial.

questions.text: The fact that packed cell volume (PCV) is raised in venous blood can be explained by means of_____
questions.solution:
Hematocrit (PCV) of venous blood is normally 3% greater than that of the arterial blood because of 2 reasons:

  • Chloride shift
  • A small amount of fluid in the arterial blood returns via the lymphatics rather than the veins.

Chloride shift:

  • Upon entering the red blood cell, CO2 is rapidly hydrated to H2CO3 by carbonic
    anhydrase.
  • H2CO3 is in equilibrium with H+ and its conjugate base, HCO3-.
  • H+ can interact with deoxyhemoglobin, whereas HCO3- can be transported outside of the cell via anion exchanger 1 (AE1 or Band 3).
  • In effect, for each CO2 molecule that enters the red cell, there is an additional HCO3- or Cl- in the cell.
  • Because of this chloride shift, the Cl – content of the red cells in venous blood is significantly greater than that in arterial blood.
  • Note that for each CO2 molecule added to a red cell, there is an increase of one osmotically active particles in the cell - either a HCO 3 – or a Cl – ion. Consequently, the red cells take up water and increase in size. 

Other options:

Bohr's effect - The decrease in O2 affinity of haemoglobin when the pH of the blood falls.

Haldane effect - Increased capacity of deoxygenated haemoglobin to bind and carry CO2.

Causes for the left shift of the oxygen-haemoglobin dissociation curve are:

  • ↑ pH (alkalosis)
  • ↓ PCO2
  • ↓ 2,3-DPG
  • ↓ Temperature 
  • HbF
  • Carboxyhemoglobin

questions.text: A salivary gland tumor with a propensity for perineural invasion is _______.
questions.solution:
A salivary gland tumour with a propensity for perineural invasion is adenoid cystic carcinoma.

Adenoid cystic carcinoma is a slow-growing malignant tumour of major and minor salivary glands. It is composed of both epithelial and myoepithelial cells. It is the second most common malignant tumour of the parotid gland. The histologic types of adenoid cystic carcinoma are tubular, cribriform, and solid. The tubular type has the best prognosis, while the solid type has the worst. 

Adenoid cystic carcinoma has propensity for perineural invasion. Patients will present with slow-growing masses, with the presence of numbness, paraesthesia or pain. Treatment is the removal of the gross tumor, with radiation therapy for the microscopic disease.

Related Pearl: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

  • Most common neoplasm of the salivary gland: Pleomorphic adenoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland
  • Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

questions.text: Which of the following lobes of the lung is affected when there is aspiration in supine position?

choices.text: Upper part of right inferior lobe

questions.solution:
The upper part of the right inferior lobe is prone to aspiration in the supine position. It is commonly seen in alcoholics.

The posterior segment of the right superior lobe and the superior segment of the inferior lobes are the most commonly involved lung sites when aspiration occurs in a recumbent patient.

The location of aspiration depends on the position of the patient since it is gravity-dependent. Aspiration while standing leads to infiltration of bilateral inferior lobes because of larger and more vertical corresponding bronchi, the middle lobes and the lingula.

Aspiration of contents into foreign substances into the bronchial tree, usually oral or gastric contents, produces aspiration pneumonia. Chemical (gastric acid) injury or bacterial infection complicates the condition.

questions.text: Which apoprotein do chylomicrons require in order to enter the lymph?
questions.solution:
Each nascent chylomicron particle has one molecule of apolipoprotein(apo) B-48 with which chylomicrons are released from the cells into the lymphatic system and travel to the blood, where they receive apo C-II and apo E from HDLs.

Chylomicrons are synthesized in intestinal epithelial cells. Their triacylglycerols are derived from dietary lipid, and their major apoprotein (apo) is apo B-48. The production of apolipoprotein (apo) B-48 in the intestine is the result of RNA editing in the intestine, this protein is exclusively found in chylomicrons. Chylomicrons travel through the lymph into the blood. Apo C-II, the activator of lipoprotein lipase, and apo E are transferred to nascent chylomicrons from HDL, and mature chylomicrons are formed.

Lipoprotein Source Main lipid Apolipoprotein
Chylomicron Intestine Triacylglycerol A-I, A-II, A-IV, B-48, C-I, C-II, C-III, D, E
Chlyomicron remnants Chylomicrons Triacylglycerol, phospholipids, cholesterol B-48, E
VLDL Liver Triacylglycerol B-100, C-I,     C-II, C-III
IDL VLDL Triacylglycerol, cholesterol B-100, E
LDL VLDL Cholesterol B-100
HDL Liver, Intestine, VLDL, Chylomicrons Cholesterol, phospholipids A-I, A-II, A-IV, C-I, C-II, C-III, D, E

questions.text: What is the sodium content in oral rehydration solution as per WHO?
questions.solution:
The sodium content in WHO ORS is 75 mmol/L. 

Oral rehydration solution (ORS): It is a solution designed to replace fluids and electrolytes in patients with diarrhoea. The 1:1 molar ratio of glucose and sodium in the WHO ORS is based on the principle of glucose-dependent sodium and water absorption in the gut.

Component (Mmol/L) Standard ORS ReSoMal
Glucose 75 (anhydrous) 125
Sodium 75 45
Potassium 20 40
Chloride 65 76
Osmolarity (mosm/L) 245 300

ReSoMal is oral rehydration salt or ORS for severely malnourished children. It is used in in-patient centres for the treatment of children with severe acute malnutrition. ReSoMal contains more glucose (125 mmol/L) and a lower amount of sodium (45 mmol/L) than the standard WHO-ORS. Other homemade fluids containing salt are also recommended to improve hydration in children.

Drinks sweetened with sugar, carbonated beverages, commercial fruit juices, and sweetened tea cause osmotic diarrhea and hypernatremia and are dangerous in patients with diarrhoea. Fluids with stimulant diuretic or purgative effects such as coffee, medicinal tea with infusions, etc. should also be avoided.

Related Pearl: Comparison between low-osmolar oral rehydration solution and ReSoMal

Composition Low-osmolar ORS (mmol/L) ReSoMal (mmol/L)
Glucose  75 125
Sodium  75  45
Potassium  20  40
Chloride  65  70
Citrate  10  7
Magnesium  ---  3
Zinc  --- 0.3
Copper  --- 0.045
Osmolarity (mOsmol/L) 245 300

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents with pruritic hypopigmented macules and confluent patches over the chest as seen in the image. Which of the following color would you expect on Wood's lamp examination?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of pruritic lesion over the trunk and image showing sharply demarcated multiple hypopigmented macules and coalescing into patches with fine scales is suggestive of pityriasis versicolor or tinea versicolor. On Wood's lamp examination these lesions show pale yellow fluorescence. 

Wood's lamp is a source of ultraviolet rays. All visible rays from this source are excluded by Wood's filter. In fungal infections like pityriasis versicolor, it shows the pale yellow fluorescence as given below.

Pityriasis versicolor is characterized by asymptomatic hypopigmented or hyperpigmented macules and patches and produces fine scales. Azelaic acid produced by Malassezia species competitively inhibits tyrosinase and results in hypopigmentation.

The most commonly affected site is the upper trunk, but there is often spread to the upper arms, neck, and abdomen. Occasionaly it presents as pruritic lesion. The color of the scales may vary from pale ochre to medium brown, and so the term versicolor. Tinea versicolor is usually caused by the lipophilic fungi Malassezia globosa and possibly Malassezia sympodialis and Malassezia furfur.

The image below shows the scales seen in Tinea versicolor.

The characteristic appearance on KOH mount and microscopy has been likened to ‘spaghetti and meatballs’ or ‘bananas and grapes’. 

Besnier's sign (coup d'ongle sign, scratch sign, stroke of the nail) is an important diagnostic clue when the scales are not visible. Here the barely perceptible scales are made to stand out by scratching the lesion with fingernails.

Patients are treated with topical azoles or 1% terbinafine cream twice daily for 2 to 3 weeks or ketoconazole shampoo twice weekly for the same duration. Relapse is very common. 

Other options:

Option A- Coral pink fluorescence is seen in erythrasma.

Option B- Red fluorescence is seen in squamous cell carcinoma of the skin

Option D- Green fluorescence is seen in tinea capitis infections associated with Microspora species and favus.

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's Lamp Examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp. Black light is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

Table: Various diseases and their color on Wood’s lamp examination

Disease

Colour on Wood’s Light

Tinea capitis

 

Microsporum species: blue-green (M. canis, M. audouinii, M. ferrugineum, M. distortum); 

Trichophyton schoenleinii: dull blue.

Most Trichophyton species, with the exception of T. schoenleinii, are non-fluorescent

 

Erythrasma

Coral pink

Scabies

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy presents with abdominal pain, proptosis, features of ataxia, and abnormal bursts of unusual eye movements as shown below. The child is found to have an intra-abdominal mass. What is the most likely diagnosis in this boy?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this boy is neuroblastoma. 

The clinical case shows a young child with abdominal pain, proptosis, ataxia, and abnormal eye movement. All these features point to a diagnosis of neuroblastoma, an intraabdominal tumour. 

Neuroblastoma is a malignant tumour seen in young children (<5 years). It is derived from neural crest cells of the adrenal medulla or the paravertebral sympathetic chain and is most commonly found in the abdomen. Most children have metastatic disease at the time of diagnosis.

The common clinical features are:

  • Intra-abdominal mass
  • Proptosis, periorbital bruising (raccoon eyes) 
  • Painless blue skin lesions (blueberry muffin syndrome)
  • Opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome (rapid nystagmus + involuntary limb spasms)

The diagnosis can be made with a combination of biochemical tests (vanillylmandelic acid [VMA], homovanillic acid [HVA], dopamine, noradrenaline) and imaging studies (CT/MRI). This tumour often crosses the spine in the midline(different from Wilm's tumour which is mostly unilateral in nature).

Neuroblastoma:

  • Neuroblastoma is an embryonal tumour of the sympathetic nervous system. These tumours arise during fetal or early postnatal life from sympathetic cells derived from the neural crest. There­ fore, tumours can originate anywhere along the path which neural crest cells migrate, including:

    • Adrenal medulla
    • Paraspinal sympathetic ganglia
    • Sympathetic para­ ganglia such as the organ of Zuckerkandl.

    Neuroblastoma is the most common extracranial solid tumour of childhood. While brain tumour is the most common solid tumour of childhood.

  • Neuroblastoma is a malignancy of neuroblast cells in the adrenal medulla or sympathetic ganglia and typically presents as an abdominal or paravertebral mass.
  • Raccoon eyes (periorbital ecchymoses) are seen in neuroblastoma due to orbital metastasis.
  • Blue subcutaneous nodules represent skin dissemination of tumour-associated with the "Blueberry Muffin Syndrome".
  • Shimada classification is used for classifying neuroblastoma.

questions.text: What is the instrument shown below?
questions.solution:
The instrument shown is Barany’s noise box, which masks the non-test ear while testing bone conduction.

Other options:

Option A: Meniett device is a small, portable pulse generator that can control vertigo in patients with Ménière's disease.

Option C: A portable audiometer is a device used to screen hearing loss in settings such as small clinics and homes. An image of a portable audiometer is shown below.

Option D: Higginson syringe is used to wash the antrum after an antral puncture is done. This device is shown in the image below.

questions.text: What is the most common site for Thyroglossal Cyst?
questions.solution:
The most common site for thyroglossal cyst is infrahyoid.

The thyroid gland descends early in fetal life from the base of the tongue towards its position in the lower neck. A thyroglossal duct cyst is a congenital midline neck swelling that presents during childhood often noticed after an upper respiratory infection. It represents the persistence of the track of the thyroid gland and can occur anywhere along the migratory course of the duct.

  • Floor of mouth
  • Beneath foramen caecum
  • Suprahyoid
  • Infrahyoid - The most common site 
  • Region of thyroid Cartilages.

 

Clinical features of thyroglossal cyst:

  • Classically the cyst moves upwards on swallowing and on tongue protrusion. This indicates attachment to the hyoid bone. 
  • Swelling is smooth, soft, fluctuant (cystic), nontender, mobile, and shows transillumination.

Sistrunk’s operation is performed to excise the cyst and prevent a recurrence. It involves excision of the whole thyroglossal tract, involving removal of the body of the hyoid bone, and suprahyoid tract.

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida has come with labor pain. On examination, she has effective uterine contractions with cervical dilation of 4 cm. In view of pain, she has requested the obstetrician for a painless, safe labor. If the anesthetist plans to give epidural for the same, which of the following would be preferred?
questions.solution:
A combination of a local anesthetic agent, ropivacaine with an opioid, sufentanil would be preferred.

The doses of local anesthetics can be reduced by the combination of local anesthetics with opioids like fentanyl or sufentanil. The lesser concentration of local anesthetic used leads to greater preservation of motor function and makes ambulation of the patient possible (walking or mobile epidural). Moreover, by reducing the concentration of the drugs, adverse effects like hypotension and drug toxicity are minimized.

Concentrations used for epidural:

Drug Concentrations
  Without opioid With opioid
Bupivacaine 0.25% 0.0625-0.125%
Ropivacaine 0.2% 0.0625-0.2%

The dose of opioid used:

  • Fentanyl : 2–3 mcg/mL 
  • Sufentanil: 0.3–0.5 mcg/mL

Other options:

 A combination of 1.5% lidocaine with 1: 200,000 epinephrine can be used as a test dose before giving the epidural drug mixture.

Epidural opioids, like morphine, can produce satisfactory labor analgesia only at relatively larger doses (>7.5 mg), which can cause respiratory depression. Hence it is not preferred.

When compared with ropivacaine + sufentanil, bupivacaine used alone is less preferred.

questions.text: A 23-year-old food blogger presents with complaints of icterus and abdominal fullness. She returned yesterday from a vacation in Egypt where she tried fava beans. Her peripheral smear is given below. Which of the following drugs is not contraindicated in her condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and blood film showing bite cells (arrows) is suggestive of glucose 6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency. Ceftriaxone is not contraindicated in G6PD deficiency.

G6PD is an enzyme in the hexose monophosphate pathway (HMP) that maintains the cellular levels of NADPH. NADPH then provides reducing equivalents needed for the conversion of oxidized glutathione to reduced glutathione. This reduced glutathione acts as a cofactor in reactions that neutralize compounds such as H2O2, thereby protecting against oxidant injury.  

Thus, G6PD deficiency causes acute hemolysis in conditions of high oxidative stress that are triggered by:

  • infections
  • fava beans (a staple in Egyptian cuisine)
  • certain drugs

Oxidative damage to RBCs leads to crosslinking of reactive sulfhydryl groups on globin chains, which then becomes denatured and form membrane-bound precipitates called Heinz bodies. When these cells on pass through spleen, heinz bodies are plucked by macrophages, giving bite cells.

Clinically, most patients are asymptomatic. When exposed to the triggers, patient develops:

  • Episodic hemolysis, both intravascular and extravascular
  • Hemolytic anaemia
  • Hemoglobinemia
  • Hemoglobinuria

G6PD deficiency is an X-linked recessive (XLR) disorder which is the most common cause of congenital hemolytic anemia due to enzyme deficiency.

 The image below shows the blood picture of a G6PD deficiency patient:

Drugs that carry a risk of clinical hemolysis in persons with G6PD Deficiency:

Drugs

Antimalarials

Primaquine

Chloroquine

Dapsone/chlorproguanil

Sulphonamides/

sulphones

Sulfamethoxazole

Sulfasalazine

Sulfisoxazole

Antibacterial/

antibiotics

Cotrimoxazole

Ciprofloxacin

Chloramphenicol

Nalidixic acid

Norfloxacin

Nitrofurantoin

Others

Naphthalene

Methylene blue

Rasburicase

questions.text: A 35-year-old pregnant female patient complains of hearing loss, which is aggravated during pregnancy. Tympanometry shows As a type of graph. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the tympanometry showing As type of graph are suggestive of otosclerosis. As type of curve indicates that pressure is normal but compliance is reduced which is seen in otosclerosis.

Otosclerosis:

It has an autosomal dominant inheritance and usually presents with bilateral progressive conductive hearing loss. It is known to be initiated or worsened by stress & hormonal variations like during pregnancy, trauma, surgery, menopause. Otosclerosis is a primary disease of the bony labyrinth where foci of irregularly placed spongy bone replace part of the normally dense enchondral layer of the bony otic capsule. Most often, otosclerotic focus involves the stapes region leading to stapes fixation and conductive deafness.

The most common type of otosclerosis is stapedial otosclerosis. Here lesion starts just in front of the oval window in an area called fissula ante fenestram. The patients will have painless bilateral conductive hearing loss, tinnitus, and vertigo. An otosclerotic patient hears better in noisy than in quiet surroundings. This is because a normal person will raise his voice in noisy surroundings. This is called paracusis willisii.

On examination, the tympanic membrane may appear normal. In some patients, a reddish hue over the promontory may be visible through the tympanic membrane. This is called the Schwartze sign.

Tuning fork tests and audiometry will reveal the presence of conductive hearing loss. Bone conduction curve may show a dip, which is maximum at 2000Hz. This is called Carhart’s notch. Tympanogram will show the presence of As type of curve. 

Management:

The treatment of choice is stapedectomy/stapedotomy with the placement of the prosthesis. The fixed otosclerotic stapes is removed and a prosthesis (like Teflon piston, stainless steel piston, platinum–Teflon or titanium–Teflon piston) is inserted between the incus and oval window.

Related Pearl: Types of curves in tympanogram

Type A:

Indicates normal pressure and normal compliance in a normal ear.

 

Type B: 

Flat or dome-shaped graph i.e. reduced compliance. Seen in serous otitis media.

The flat curve is a type of B type curve seen with a perforated tympanic membrane. The volume measurement that is simultaneously performed with tympanometry helps to differentiate between a flat tympanogram suggesting an intact eardrum with middle ear effusion versus a perforated eardrum or ear with a patent ventilating tube.

 

Type C:

Indicates normal compliance but negative pressure due to eustachian tube obstruction.

Seen with a retracted tympanic membrane and in early stages before fluid collects in the middle ear.

 

Type As:

Indicates reduced compliance (‘s’ means stiffness leading to reduced compliance) and normal pressure.

Seen in Otosclerosis or other ossicular fixation and Tympanosclerosis.

 

Type Ad: 

Indicates increased compliance (‘d’ means discontinuity leading to increased mobility) and normal pressure.

Seen in ossicular discontinuity and with thin and lax TM.

questions.text: During a measles epidemic in the community, a 6-month-old child was vaccinated against the same. When should the second dose be administered to this child?

choices.text: The child should be given a second dose as soon as she reaches 9 months of age
The child should be given a second dose after 2 weeks of last dose
The child should be given a second dose after 6 weeks of last dose
The child should be given the second dose of measles at 12 months of age

questions.solution:
An infant immunized between 6-9 months should receive a second dose as soon as the child reaches 9 months of age.

While the scheduled age of receiving the 1st dose of measles vaccine is at 9 months, it can be lowered to 6 months during a measles epidemic in the community. For infants immunized between 6 months to 9 months of age, a second dose should be administered as soon as the child reaches the age of 9 months, provided that 4 weeks have elapsed since the last dose.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a natural source of radiation exposure?
questions.solution:
X-rays are not a natural source of radiation exposure. They are artificially produced by linear accelerators.

Sources of radiation exposure:

Natural:

  • Cosmic rays
  • Environmental - terrestrial and atmospheric
  • Radioactive isotopes - of potassium (K-40) and carbon (C-14)

Man-made:

  • Medical and dental - X-rays, radioisotopes
  • Occupational exposure
  • Nuclear - radioactive fallout

questions.text: An elderly male patient presented with painless, gross hematuria. He was evaluated for the same, and a cystoprostatectomy was done. The gross specimen image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image of the cystoprostatectomy specimen shows a large, fungating growth from the bladder wall involving the entire bladder with the two lobes of the prostate not being much affected. The most likely diagnosis is bladder carcinoma. 

Painless, gross hematuria is the most common symptom that is indicative of a bladder carcinoma until proven otherwise. Subsequent clots and urinary retention can occur. Increased frequency and discomfort during urination may be seen. It can lead to pelvic pain due to extravesical spread, loin pain due to hydronephrosis, and suprapubic pain if the nerve is involved.

Depending upon the depth of invasion, bladder carcinoma is divided into 3 groups:

  • Flat, non-invasive carcinoma in situ (CIS)
  • Non-muscle invasive bladder cancer - does not invade detrusor muscle but can invade lamina propria. It accounts for 70% of cases.
  • Muscle-invasive bladder cancer - invades the detrusor muscle.

Diagnosis and staging are done by cystoscopy and resection of the tumor. A bimanual examination should be performed after the resection of the tumor. Complete urinary tract imaging is required using contrast computed tomography (CT) or magnetic resonance (MR) urography.

Management:

  • Non-muscle invasive bladder cancer - Endoscopic resection and intravesical instillations of mitomycin C/ epirubicin, immunotherapy with regular intravesical instillations of Bacille Calmette-Guerin (BCG)
  • Muscle invasive bladder cancer - Radical cystectomy along with urinary diversion procedure and lymph node dissection +/- neoadjuvant chemotherapy

Other options: 

Option A- Leukoplakia is squamous metaplasia of the bladder characterized by white particles (keratin) in the urine. Diffuse leukoplakia of the bladder is pre-malignant and can lead to squamous cancer of the bladder. It has to be assessed by cystoscopy and localized areas may be resected.

Option C- Prostate carcinoma presents with symptoms only during advanced disease. It causes bladder outlet obstruction, pelvic pain, hematuria, and renal failure. It is surgically managed by radical prostatectomy, which only involves the removal of the prostate and seminal vesicles and preserving the bladder. Unlike the given gross specimen one or more lobes are predominantly involved in prostatic carcinoma.

Option D- Schistosomiasis of the bladder is a parasitic infection by Schistosoma haematobium. Cystoscopy would show nodules, pseudotubercles, ulceration, or sandy patches. Chronic infection can lead to squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder.

 

Related Pearl: Etiological Factors for Bladder Carcinoma

Cigarette smoking
Exposure to aryl amines, particularly 2-
naphthylamine and related compounds (e.g., in diesel exhaust, in paint products)
Schistosoma haematobium infestation
Long-term use of analgesics (phenacetin)
Heavy-dose long-term use of cyclophosphamide
Radiotherapy
Congenital bladder exstrophy

Inherited cancer syndromes:

  • Lynch syndrome
  • Heriditary retinoblastoma
  • Costello syndrome

Acquired genetic mutations in FGFR3, HRAS, P53, RB genes.

questions.text: The fracture seen in the Xray given below is?
questions.solution:
The X-ray reveals an oblique fracture in the lower third of radius with dislocation of the distal radio-ulnar joint, which is suggestive of Galeazzi's fracture. 

In Galeazzi's fracture, the radial bone is fractured at the junction of middle and distal third with subluxation or dislocation of distal radio-ulnar joint. 

Complications include :

  • Malunion
  • Nonunion
  • Entrapment of extensor carpi ulnaris tendon in distal radio-ulnar joint

Option B: Monteggia fracture: It is the fracture of shaft of ulna with dislocation of proximal radio-ulnar joint

Option C: Smith's fracture: It is also known as "Reverse Colle's fracture". It is the fracture of the distal radius with palmar angulation of the distal bone fragment.

Option D: Colle's fracture: It is the fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar displacement.

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius.

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of the ulnar bone.

questions.text: A 35-year-old smoker presents with hoarseness of voice. On laryngoscopy, there is edema of the Reinke’s space. Where is this space located?
questions.solution:
Reinke’s space is seen in the glottis. It is a potential space underneath the epithelium of vocal cords.

It contains scanty subepithelial connective tissue. Edema of this space is commonly seen in smokers and is called Reinke’s edema or smoker’s larynx.

The laryngoscopy image below shows diffuse bilateral edema of the vocal folds or Reinke's edema.

questions.text: Which among the following is used for the measurement of intraocular pressure (IOP) in a scarred cornea?
questions.solution:
Tonopen is used for measuring intraocular pressure (IOP) in a scarred cornea.

  • It is a hand-held electronic contact tonometer (a modified version of the older Mackay–Marg tonometer).
  • Besides portability, its main advantage is the ability to measure IOP reasonably accurately in eyes with distorted or edematous corneas and through a soft contact lens.

Measurement of IOP: Tonometry

Types:

  • Indentation tonometry: Reading depends on scleral rigidity, e.g., Schiotz tonometer  
  • Applanation tonometry: Based on the amount of force needed to flatten or applanate a known area of the cornea, Imbert–Fick principle

Applanation tonometry is of two types:
i) Fixed force: IOP is proportional to the area, e.g., Maklakov, Barraquer
ii) Fixed area and variable force: IOP is proportional to force. The most reliable is Goldmann.

  • Self-measurement: Rebound
  • Non-contact type: Pulse Air, Air-Puff
  • Irregular cornea: Tonopen, MacKay–Marg

Image (above): Fluorescein-stained semicircular mires; right: Correct end-point using mires of appropriate thickness.

questions.text: Identify the finding seen in this hysterosalpingogram:
questions.solution:
Bilateral hydrosalpinx is observed in the given image of hysterosalpingogram.

Hydrosalpinx is often bilateral and occurs following acute salpingitis. The tubes are retort shaped due to dilatation of the ampulla and filled with a clear fluid. The interstitial end of the tube is open whereas the fimbrial end is indrawn and closed. This permits the dye to enter but not exit the tube during hysterosalpingography. 

Retort shaped hydrosalpinx:

questions.text: You observed the following finding in a patient in the OPD. Which among the following conditions is least likely to cause this finding?
questions.solution:
The given image shows digital clubbing. Among the given options, aortic dissection is least likely to cause digital clubbing.

Clubbing is a selective bulbous enlargement of the distal segments of the fingers and toes due to the proliferation of connective tissue, particularly on the dorsal surface.

Causes of clubbing are:

  • Pulmonary
    • Bronchogenic carcinoma
    • Lung abscess, empyema, bronchiectasis
    • Interstitial lung diseases
    • Cystic fibrosis
    • Sarcoidosis
    • Asbestosis
  • GI
    • Inflammatory bowel disease (Ulcerative colitis, Crohn's disease)
    • Sprue, celiac disease
    • Neoplasms - esophagus, liver, bowel
    • Cirrhosis - juvenile and biliary
    • Chronic active hepatitis
  • Cardiovascular
    • Cyanotic congenital heart disease
    • Subacute bacterial endocarditis
    • Aortic aneurysm
    • Arteriovenous fistula
    • Patent ductus arteriosus with right to left shunt
    • Atrial myxoma
  • Endocrine
    • Grave’s disease (thyroid acropachy)
  • CNS
    • Hemiplegia (unilateral clubbing)
  • Skin disease
    • Palmoplantar keratoderma
    • Fischer-Volavsek syndrome.
  • Malignancies
    • Thyroid cancer
    • Thymus cancer
    • Hodgkin disease
    • Disseminated chronic myeloid leukemia.

Note: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) does not cause clubbing. If clubbing is present in a patient with COPD, underlying lung cancer and bronchiectasis must be ruled out.

questions.text: A multigravida woman in the labor room presents with uncontrolled bleeding after delivery of the placenta. What is the most common cause of postpartum hemorrhage(PPH)?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of postpartum hemorrhage is atonic uterus. Uterine atony is responsible for at least 80% of cases of PPH.

Uterine atony is the failure of the uterus to contract sufficiently after delivery. This ineffective uterine contraction prevents mechanical hemostasis from occurring and leads to uncontrollable bleeding from the placental implantation site.

Postpartum hemorrhage is defined as a loss of more than 500 ml of blood after the completion of the third stage of labor (in vaginal delivery). PPH is blood loss of more than 1000 mL from the genital tract following a cesarean section.

Depending upon the amount of blood loss, PPH can be, minor (<1L) or major (>1L). Major is further subdivided into moderate (1L-2L) and severe (>2L).

Types of PPH:

Primary/early PPH: Hemorrhage occurring within 24 hours of childbirth. Causes include

  • Atony: Primi, grand multipara, over distended uterus, hydramnios, precipitate labor, prolonged labor, uterine malformations, fibroid uterus
  • Trauma: Instrumental deliveries, episiotomy, precipitate labor, macrosomia
  • Retained tissues: retained placenta, blood clots
  • Bleeding disorders: Sepsis, Intrauterine death, HELLP syndrome.

Secondary/ late PPH: Hemorrhage occurring after 24 hours and up to 12 weeks postpartum. Causes include 

  • Placental polyp: Retained products undergo necrosis with fibrin deposition and eventually form a placental polyp, which on detachment from the myometrium causes brisk hemorrhage.
  • Abnormal involution of the placental site.
  • Retention of placental cotyledon or products of conception.
  • Uterine artery pseudoaneurysm.
  • Endometritis
  • Coagulopathy

questions.text: A patient is able to recognize a person by name but not face. The lesion, in this case, is in_____
questions.solution:
This condition is prosopagnosia, which occurs in the lesions of the inferior temporal lobe.

In humans, storage and recognition of faces are more strongly represented in the right inferior temporal lobe in right-handed individuals (i.e non-dominant inferior temporal lobe).

Damage to this area can cause prosopagnosia, the inability to recognize faces. Patients with this abnormality can recognize people by their voices, body language, etc. How­ever, they cannot identify the familiar people by seeing their faces. The left hemisphere is also involved, but the role of the right hemi­sphere is primary.

Related Pearl: CNS deficits and site of lesions

Term Defnition Site of lesion
Agnosia Inability to accurately perceive objects through normally functioning sensory mechanisms Posterior parietal cortex

Dyslexia

(word blindness)

Inability to interpret their meanings

(the person may be able to see words and even know that they are words but not be able to interpret their meanings)

 Angular gyrus
Aphasia inability to produce and/or understand language

All components of the language network are interconnected with each other and with

surrounding parts of the frontal, parietal, and temporal lobes. Damage

to this network gives rise to language impairments resulting in aphasia.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presented with jaundice and loose stools. The MRCP image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above MRCP shows multiple areas of intrahepatic narrowing with alternating areas of normal and dilated segments of bile ducts (beading) typical of primary sclerosing cholangitis.

Primary sclerosing cholangitis is an autoimmune condition characterized by inflammatory strictures involving the intra and extra-hepatic biliary tree. It is a progressive condition that leads to secondary biliary cirrhosis.

The common age group of primary sclerosing cholangitis is 30-45 years. Men are affected twice as commonly as women. 2/3 of these cases are associated with ulcerative colitis. It is also associated with Riedel’s thyroiditis and retroperitoneal fibrosis. 10–20% of patients develop cholangiocarcinoma. Clinical features of a patient with PSC include:

  • Intermittent jaundice
  • Fatigue
  • Weight loss
  • Pruritus
  • Abdominal pain

Liver function tests show a cholestatic pattern with an elevation of ALP and GGT and smaller rises in the aminotransferases. Bilirubin values may be variable.

Endoscopic retrograde cholangiography (ERCP) is a gold standard in diagnosis and shows multiple dilatations and strictures (beading) of both intra- and extra-hepatic biliary tree.

Currently, there is no known effective medical therapy. Surgical management involving resection of extrahepatic biliary tree and hepaticojejunostomy has shown reasonable effects. For patients with advanced liver disease, liver transplantation is the only available option.

Related Pearl: Differences between primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) and primary biliary cholangitis (PBC)

  Primary Biliary Cholangitis Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis
Antibodies

Antimitochondrial antibodies positive in most patients

Antinuclear antibodies positive

Antimitochondrial antibodies /AMA typically negative

p-ANCA-positive
Age group 40–60 years 30-45 years
Gender predominance Females Males
Site Intrahepatic bile ducts only Intra- and extrahepatic bile ducts
 Associated with

Sjogren syndrome

Hashimoto's thyroiditis 

CREST syndrome

Rheumatoid arthritis

Celiac disease

Diagnosis Biopsy MRCP/ERCP-strictures 
Biopsy findings  Florid duct lesion (granuloma) Concentric "onion-skin" fibrosis

questions.text:
Match the following with their rate-limiting enzymes:
1- Heme synthesis a- HMG CoA reductase
2- Cholesterol synthesis b- Phosphofructokinase
3- Glycolysis c- ALA synthase
4- Niacin synthesis d- HMG CoA synthase
  e- Quinolinate phosphoribosyl transferase
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1-c, 2-a, 3-b, 4-e.

Heme synthesis ALA synthase
Cholesterol synthesis HMG CoA reductase
Glycolysis Phosphofructokinase
Niacin syntheses Quinolinate phosphoribosyl transferase

Heme is synthesized in the normoblasts except matures erythrocytes. Heme synthesis is partly mitochondrial and partly cytoplasmic. It starts with the condensation of succinyl CoA and glycine by ALA synthase in the presence of pyridoxal phosphate to form delta-aminolevulinic acid (ALA). ALA synthase is the rate-limiting enzyme and is located in mitochondria. 

All nucleated cells including the arterial wall can synthesize cholesterol and the liver, adrenal cortex, testis, ovaries, and intestines are the major sites of cholesterol synthesis. It occurs partly in the endoplasmic reticulum and cytoplasm. it starts with the condensation of two molecules of acetyl CoA to form acetoacetyl CoA synthase. 

The reduction of HMG CoA to mevalonate catalyzed by HMG CoA reductase is the rate-limiting step. it is the rate-limiting enzyme and is located in the endoplasmic reticulum. 

Statin group of drugs like lovastatin are competitive inhibitors of HMG CoA reductase and can be used in clinical practice to reduce cholesterol levels in the blood. 

Glycolysis converts glucose to pyruvate (aerobic condition) or lactate (anaerobic condition) with the production of a small quantity of energy. It takes place in all cells of the body. Phosphofructokinase is the rate-limiting enzyme that converts fructose-6-phosphate to fructose-1-6-bisphosphate.

The rate-limiting enzyme of synthesis of niacin from tryptophan is quinolinate phosphoribosyltransferase. It converts niacin or nicotinic acid to nicotinate mononucelotide.

questions.text:
Match the correct neurocutaneous disorder with its respective clinical spectrum.
Condition Clinical spectrum
1. Neurofibromatosis type 1  A. Subependymal giant cell astrocytoma, ash-leaf spots
2. Sturge-Weber syndrome B. Cerebellar haemangioblastoma, retinal angiomas
3. Von Hippel Lindau disease C. Iris hamartoma, optic glioma
4. Tuberous Sclerosis D. Port-wine birthmark, glaucoma
questions.solution:
Option B is the correctly matched answer to this question. The following table represents each condition matched to its clinical spectrum.

Condition Clinical spectrum
1. Neurofibromatosis type 1 

C. Iris hamartoma/ Lisch nodules, optic glioma
2. Sturge-Weber syndrome D. Port-wine birthmark, glaucoma
3. Von Hippel Lindau disease B. Cerebellar haemangioblastoma, retinal angiomas
4. Tuberous sclerosis

A. Subependymal giant cell astrocytoma, ash-leaf spots

Neurocutaneous disorders are conditions that affect ectodermal derivatives, most commonly the skin and the CNS. 

Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) is due to an autosomal dominant loss-of-function mutation in the NF1 gene. Other characteristic features of NF1 include cafe-au-lait macules, inguinal and axillary freckling, and neurofibromas.

The images below show Lisch nodules, cafe-au-lait macules, and axillary freckling respectively.

Sturge-Weber syndrome is a neurocutaneous disorder characterized by vascular malformations limited to segments. It usually results from a mosaic mutation in the GNAQ gene. Leptomeningeal angiomas are a common finding. Presenting complaints in patients range from developmental delay and headaches to seizures, hemiparesis, and stroke-like episodes. Port-wine marks and glaucoma are characteristic.

Von Hippel Lindau (VHL) is an autosomal dominant condition that arises from a mutation affecting the VHL tumor suppressor gene. Characteristic features of VHL include spinal hemangioblastomas, endolymphatic sac tumor, pheochromocytoma, and cystic lesions of the kidneys, pancreas, and liver.

Tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC) also follows an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance. Other features of TSC also include shagreen patches, cardiac rhabdomyomas, renal angiomyolipoma, facial angiofibroma, and periungual fibromas which are shown in the images below. 

Related Pearl: Cutaneous lesions of Tuberous sclerosis

Tuberous sclerosis (TS) is also known as tuberous sclerosis complex or Bourneville disease. It is a neurocutaneous disorder (phakomatosis) characterized by the development of multiple benign tumors of the embryonic ectoderm (e.g. skin, eyes, and nervous system). It is an autosomal dominant condition.  The mutations are involved in the TSC1 gene that encodes hamartin on chromosome 9 and the TSC2 gene that encodes a protein tuberin on chromosome 16.

Tuberous sclerosis presents in childhood with a triad (Vogt triad). The triad comprises of:

  • Seizures
  • Mental retardation
  • Adenoma sebaceum

Skin lesions in tuberous sclerosis:

Shagreen patch consists of a roughened, raised lesion with an orange-peel consistency, located primarily in the lumbosacral region. Shagreen is shark skin used as a decorative material present in the right image given below.

The typical hypomelanotic ash leaf–type macules on the trunk and extremities are seen in 90% of the patients. It is visualized by the use of a wood ultraviolet lamp.

Facial angiofibromas (adenoma sebaceum) develop between 4 and 6 years of age; they appear as tiny red nodules over the nose and cheeks and are sometimes confused with acne. Later, they enlarge, coalesce, and assume a fleshy appearance.

Periungual fibroma are small fibromas or nodules of skin, which form around fingernails or toenails in some adolescent patients

Confetti skin lesions are seen less commonly as a minor feature of tuberous sclerosis.

questions.text: All structures can be seen in the following x ray view except?
questions.solution:
The above X Ray view is called as ' Caldwell's view'.

Structures seen in Caldwell's view are:

  • Ethmoid sinuses

  • Superior orbital fissure
  • Foramen rotundum (inferolateral to superior orbital fissure)

In Caldwell's view.

  • The nose and forehead are touching the x-ray film
  • The X-ray beam is projected 15 degrees h

questions.solution:
SBP ≥140 mm Hg and DBP <90 mmHg is called as isolated systolic hypertension.

questions.text: An elderly man presents with weakness in his lower limbs. On motor examination, the resident taps on the patellar tendon with a knee hammer and there was a sudden kicking movement of the knee. Which of the following is true about the given reflex?

choices.text: Root value of the reflex is L5 - S2
It is a monosynaptic stretch reflex
Efferent is acted upon γ-motor neurons of the hamstring muscles

questions.solution:
From the given scenario, the resident is performing a knee jerk reflex (patellar reflex) on this patient. 

Knee jerk or patellar reflex is elicited by tapping the patellar tendon resulting in contraction of the quadriceps muscle. It is an example of a deep tendon reflex or myotatic stretch reflex as stretching the muscle causes reflex contraction. 

The reflex arc in the knee jerk reflex consists of only one synapse between afferents and efferents. Hence, it is also an example of a monosynaptic reflex. 

Reflex arc of knee jerk reflex -  

Tapping the tendon causes a stretch of the muscle spindle which is present within the muscle. The muscle spindle is a sensory proprioceptor responsible for identifying the length of the muscle fibers. The Ia afferent sensory fibers in the muscle spindles are activated in response to the stretch. These Ia afferent fibers go to the spinal cord at the dorsal root ganglia and stimulate the alpha-motor neurons. This results in the contraction of the muscle that was initially stretched. The neurotransmitter at the central synapse is glutamate.

The femoral nerve L2-L4 mediates the patellar reflex.

 

Clinical aspect: 

  • Brisk, hyperactive deep tendon reflexes are seen in upper motor neuron lesions affecting the descending spinal tracts like the corticospinal tract. 
  • Hypoactive or absent reflexes are seen in lower motor neuron lesions or the lesions affecting the components of the reflex arc. Absent reflexes can be seen in diabetes, deep sleep, coma, nerve block, spinal anesthesia etc. 
  • The pendular knee jerk, in which tapping the patellar tendon results in to-and-fro movements of the limb is seen in cerebellar lesions. The increased swinging occurs due to hypotonia of both flexors and extensors leading to a lack of restraint on each other.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding the increase in the blood supply of muscles during exercise?
questions.solution:
During exercise, there is increased beta-adrenergic stimulation.

Medullae of the two adrenal glands secrete large amounts of norepinephrine plus epinephrine into the circulating blood during strenuous exercise. The epinephrine often has a slight vasodilator effect because it excites more of the beta-adrenergic receptors of the vessels, which are vasodilator receptors, in contrast to the alpha vasoconstrictor receptors excited especially by norepinephrine.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presented with a mid-tibial swelling, with complaints of severe pain at night which reduces after taking aspirin. What is the best investigation to diagnose the condition?
questions.solution:
A child in 2nd decade which severe night pain and relieved by aspirin (NSAIDs) best explains the condition of osteoid osteoma. 

The nidus of osteoid osteoma is present in the cortex and hence CT scan will be the best investigation to diagnose osteoid osteoma. 

Osteoid osteoma:

  • It is a benign neoplasm most often seen in young men. 
  • The typical patient with an osteoid osteoma has pain that is worse at night and is relieved by aspirin or other nonsteroidal antiinﬂammatory medications. 
  • The nidus of osteoid osteoma is present in the cortex and hence CT scan will be the best investigation to diagnose osteoid osteoma. 
  • It is the most common true benign tumor of the bone. 

Treatment: 

  • NSAIDs 
  • Radiofrequency ablation 
  • Surgical Resection by curettage and en bloc resection (has lower recurrence rate) 
  • MR-guided focused USG (Magnetic resonance-guided focused ultrasound (MRgFUS) ablation is a new technique in which ultrasound waves are focused on the osteoid osteoma. When high-intensity waves are focused on a single point, considerable heat is generated.) 

MRI is used for both localization of the tumor and temperature monitoring. Note: In Osteoblastoma-Pain similar in character as osteoid osteoma(worse at night and relieved by NSAIDs).

questions.text: A 54-year-old female patient presents with abdominal pain and bilious vomiting. She had a history of abdominal hysterectomy 2 years back. On examination, abdomen auscultation revealed hyperechoic bowel sounds. Investigations showed air within the biliary tree. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario showing clinical features of intestinal obstruction along with radiographic features of pneumobilia (air within the biliary tree) is suggestive of a diagnosis of gallstone ileus.

Gallstone ileus is a condition that occurs secondary to the erosion of the gallbladder wall. This erosion causes a fistula to the duodenum. Through this, a large gallstone can pass from the gallbladder to the duodenum. The most common site of impaction of the gallstone is the distal ileum, where it may cause intestinal obstruction.

Patients present with features of mechanical small bowel obstruction such as continuous or intermittent pain abdomen, bilious vomiting, and hyperechoic bowel sounds.

Rigler’s triad is a characteristic radiological feature seen in gallstone ileus and consists of:

  • Pneumobilia - air present in the intestine passes into the biliary tree through the fistula
  • Features of small bowel obstruction
  • Ectopic gall stone - usually in the right iliac fossa

Plain X-rays show air-fluid levels consistent with a small bowel obstruction and pneumobilia can be visualized on CT imaging.

Management: Predominantly surgical management by an explorative laparotomy to relieve the bowel obstruction. The stone is milked away from the site of impacted and then crushed or removed. 

 

Other options: Adhesive intestinal obstruction (Option B) results mostly after any abdominal surgery or any cause for peritoneal irritation, the features are consistent with bowel obstruction but there is no pneumobilia.

Ischaemic colitis (Option B) is usually diagnosed on contrast-enhanced CT abdomen where there may be bowel wall thickening, signs of vascular insufficiency, and pericolic fluid or fat stranding.

Diverticulitis (Option D) is also diagnosed on CT abdomen showing bright bowel outpouching, which may be complicated by infection and abscess formation.

questions.text:
Match the following
  1. Joule Burns
  2. Filigree Burns
  3. Scald injury
  4. Frost bite
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-B, 2-C, 3-A, 4-D.

Arborescent burns/ Filigree burns / Lichtenberg's flowers are superficial, thin, irregular, and tortuous markings on the skin that are indicative of a lightning strike. They resemble the branches of a tree and are usually found over the skin of the shoulders or the flanks.

Scalding is due to exposure to wet heat like hot water or steam. It is an injury that results from the application of liquid above 60°C or from steam i.e moist heat. Redness appears immediately followed by blistering in a few minutes. Removal of the blistered skin leaves a raw, pink surface. Blisters are surrounded by a hyperaemic zone. Scalds appear soddened and bleached but the hair does not get singed. The skin does not get blackened or charred.

Scald injuries are limited to the area of contact and are more severe at the initial point of contact. It can occur through clothing, which worsens damage due to a longer period of contact with the hot liquid and a reduced cooling effect of evaporation.

It can be 

  • Immersion burns: Accidental or deliberate immersion in hot liquid, usually water.  
  • Splash or spill burns: Usually accidental.  
  • Steam burns: Exposure to superheated steam.

Clinical degree of scalding:

  • Erythema (reddening)
  • Vesication (blister formation)
  • Necrosis of the dermis when deeper layers of skin are involved

Joule burns or electric marks occur due to contact with electricity and are found at the point of entry of the current. They are observed as round or oval, shallow craters, having a ridge of skin around their circumference. The floor is lined with pale flattened skin. 

Frost Bite occurs when the body is exposed to cold temperatures. Here, tissue damage results from severe environmental cold exposure or from direct contact with a very cold object. Tissue injury results from both freezing and vascular stasis. It usually affects the distal aspects of the extremities or exposed parts of the face, such as the ears, nose, chin, and cheeks.

Clinical features include decreased sensation (especially for pain, and temperature sensations) in the acral tips and extremities. The affected area appears waxy, mottled, or violaceous. Patients may have a wood-like sensation in the affected area.

Treatment:

  • Initial treatment is by rapid rewarming (or thawing), which is accomplished by immersion of the affected part in a water bath at temperatures of 37°–40°C (99°–104°F) for 30–60 minutes. Rewarming by exercise, rubbing, or friction is not advised. 
  • Analgesics such as ibuprofen are often required during rewarming.
  • Antithrombotics, thrombolytic, and vasodilators such as prostacyclin can be given to improve circulation after rewarming.
  • Frost bites are associated with an increased risk of infections and tetanus. Therefore, the injured area should be cleaned with soap or antiseptic, and sterile dressings should be applied. Tetanus prophylaxis must be given, but, empirical antibiotics are not recommended.
  • The patient must be monitored for the development of compartment syndrome.
  • Elective late amputation after imaging may be required in severe cases.

Image showing frostbite of the toes:

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents with severe abdominal pain radiating to the back.  The patient is a known alcoholic. He is found to have increased serum amylase. On surgical exploration, the appearance of the resected specimen is as shown below. The most likely pathology is ___________.
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is acute pancreatitis with fat necrosis.

Fat necrosis results from the release of activated pancreatic lipases into the substance of the pancreas and the peritoneal cavity.

The fatty acids, so derived, combine with calcium to produce grossly visible chalky-white areas (fat saponification).

Types of necrosis:

Coagulative necrosis Infarcts in all organs except the brain
Caseous necrosis Tuberculosis
Liquefactive necrosis Brain abscess
Fat necrosis Pancreatitis, Breast
Fibrinoid necrosis Vasculitis, Aschoff bodies, malignant hypertension

questions.text: What is the recommended margin for local excision in a patient with malignant melanoma invading up to a depth of 0.08 mm?
questions.solution:
The recommended margin for local excision in a patient with malignant melanoma invading up to a depth of 0.08 mm is 1 cm.

Melanoma is a cancer of melanocytes and can therefore arise in skin, mucosa and retina. Superficial spreading melanoma is the most common type and arises in a pre-existing naevus. Other forms include nodular melanoma, lentigo maligna, and acral lentiginous. 

Macroscopic features in naevi suggestive of malignant melanoma 

  • Change in size, shape, colour and thickness (elevation/nodularity or ulceration)
  • Satellite lesions (pigment spreading into the surrounding area)
  • Tingling/itching/serosanguineous discharge (usually late signs)

The treatment for melanoma is surgery. 

  • Melanoma in situ- wide excision of 5 mm
  • Melanoma <1 mm deep- 1 cm margin
  • Deeper lesions- 2 cm margin(It is recommended, as there is no evidence that wider margins make a difference.)

questions.text: A child is brought to the outpatient department with the following karyotyping image. What are the clinical features most likely to be expected in such children?
questions.solution:
The given karyotyping image shows 47, XXY abnormality, which is seen in Klinefelter syndrome. Gynecomastia and long limbs are seen in this condition.

Klinefelter's syndrome is a sex chromosome abnormality and is the most common cause of infertility and hypogonadism in males.

Other clinical features seen in Klinefelter’s syndrome are: 

  • Tall stature and long limbs
  • Small atrophic testis and small penis
  • Lack of secondary sexual characteristics (due to a decrease in androgen production)
  • Gynecomastia
  • Minor developmental and learning disabilities,
  • Higher risk of breast carcinoma and extragonadal germ cell tumors
  • Type 2 diabetes mellitus

 

Other options:

Options B and C- Low set ears, prominent occiput, and micrognathia are seen in Edwards syndrome.

Option D- Webbing of the neck and lymphedema are seen in Turner syndrome.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with cutaneous bumps on the hand as shown in the image below. These are pink, painless, and sometimes itchy. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image shows shiny, pearly white, umbilicated papules which are suggestive of molluscum contagiosum.

Molluscum contagiosum is caused by a poxvirus named Molluscum contagiosum virus (MCV). The peak incidence is between 2-5 years. The incubation period is around 14 days-6 months. It is mainly caused by type-I molluscum contagiosum virus (MCV-1) in children and type-II (MCV‐2) in adults and HIV patients. New lesions develop along the line of trauma (pseudo-Koebner phenomenon). Sexually transmitted molluscum contagiosum may be present over the genital area.

Microscopic examination of the lesions shows eosinophilic inclusions called Henderson-Patterson bodies. 

The condition is usually self-limiting but treatment is required for non-resolving symptomatic lesions. Destruction with cantharidin, trichloroacetic acid, diluted liquefied phenol, or surgical removal are a few options.

 

Other options: 

Keratoacanthoma is a rapidly evolving tumor of the skin now classified as a well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma. It mostly presents as a solitary firm, rounded, reddish-papule with a horny plug in the center. It may also be covered by a crust covering a keratinized crate. The most frequently affected area is the central part of the face like the nose, cheeks, eyelids, and lips.

The below image shows keratoacanthoma.

Related Pearl: Skin and soft tissue lesions caused by Streptococcus

Streptococcus causes a variety of skin and soft tissue infections. These include:

a. Impetigo- Infection of superficial layers of the skin. It presents as superficial vesicles which break down and are then encrusted by honey-colored scab. It usually occurs in children.

The given image shows impetigo:

 

b. Erysipelas- Infection of the superficial epidermis. It presents as an erythematous raised lesion with sharply demarcated edges that differentiate it from the surrounding skin. 

The given image shows erysipelas- note the clear demarcation at the nasolabial folds seen in facial erysipelas.

 

c. Cellulitis- Infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissue. It presents with erythema and edema. It can be differentiated from erysipelas by - i. Erysipelas is a raised lesion whereas cellulitis is not, ii. Cellulitis is poorly demarcated from the surrounding skin whereas erysipelas is clearly demarcated.

The given image shows cellulitis:

 

d. Necrotizing fasciitis- Infection involving the fascial planes. It presents with dark areas of necrosis, erythema, and edema.

The given image shows necrotizing fasciitis with areas of erythema and necrosis:

 

d. Myositis and myonecrosis- Infection of the muscle.

The given image shows necrotizing myositis:

Related Pearl: Koebner phenomenon

Koebner or isomorphic Phenomenon is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in a previously normal skin. The new lesions have 'iso' (same) and 'morphic' (morphology) as the existing lesions.

The trauma may include mechanical trauma, thermal trauma, allergic or irritant reactants or any treatment procedures.

True Koebner's phenomenon In immune-mediated conditions

Psoriasis

Vitiligo

Lichen planus
False Koebner's phenomenon In infectious diseases

Viral warts

Molluscum contagiosum
Reverse Koebner phenomenon Area of psoriasis clears and heals following injury(trauma)

Psoriasis
Remote reverse Koebner phenomenon

Spontaneous repigmentation of vitiligo patches distant from the autologous skin graft sites (trauma)

Generalized granuloma annulare

Vitiligo

Some rare causes of True Koebner Phenomenon are : Darier's disease, Hailey-Hailey disease, Erythema multiforme, Kaposi's Sarcoma and Lichen sclerosus.

Image: Koebner phenomenon with linear psoriasis patch on the abdomen

questions.text: Spermatogenesis is maintained by which hormone?
questions.solution:
All three of them (testosterone, FSH, LH) are required for spermatogenesis.

Pulses of hypothalamic GnRH stimulate the anterior pituitary to secrete FSH and LH, which then act on the testes

FSH acts on the Sertoli cells to stimulate spermatogenesis and inhibin secretion. LH acts on the Leydig cells to stimulate testosterone secretion. Testosterone, acting locally on the Sertoli cells, is essential for maintaining spermatogenesis.

questions.text:
As per the verbal autopsy report 2010-2013, arrange the most common cause of death among 1-4-year-old children in descending order:
  1. Diarrhea
  2. Pneumonia
  3. Malaria
  4. Injuries
questions.solution:
According to the verbal autopsy report of 2010-2013, the most common cause of death among 1-4 year old children in descending order is Pneumonia > Diarrhea > Injuries > Malaria.

According to the Verbal autopsy report 2010-2013, the top 5 causes of death among children aged 1-4 years are:

  1. Pneumonia
  2. Diarrheal diseases
  3. Injuries
  4. Other non-communicable diseases
  5. Malaria

1-4 year mortality rate also known as the child death rate is the number of deaths of children aged 1-4 years per 1000 children in the same age group in a given year. It thus excludes infant mortality. It is given by the formula,

1-4 year mortality rate (child death rate) = (no. of deaths of children aged 1-4 years during a year x 1000) / Total no. of children aged 1-4 years at the middle of the year.

It is a more refined indicator of the social situation than the infant mortality rate as it reflects adverse environmental health hazards like malnutrition, poor hygiene, infections, and accidents. It is not affected by perinatal hazards. In the 1-4 year group, second year is the period with the highest risk of death (mainly due to childhood infections like measles, whooping cough, diphtheria, diarrhea, and ARI), after which the rates decline progressively.

questions.text: In tetany, hyperexcitability is due to______
questions.solution:
Hypocalcemia causes nervous system excitement and tetany.

When the ECF concentration of Ca2+ falls below normal, the nervous system becomes progressively more excitable because there is increased  membrane permeability to Na+, allowing easy initiation of action potentials. The peripheral nerve fibers become so excitable that they begin to discharge spontaneously, initiating impulses that pass to the skeletal muscles to elicit tetanic muscle contraction.

Tetany occurs usually when calcium concentration reaches 6 mg/dL.

The clinical features of hypocalcemia are:

  • Tetany: Increased peripheral neuromuscular irritability. May include perioral paresthesias, muscle spasms, and cramps.
  • Trosseau's sign: Induction of carpal spasm when the BP cuff is inflated 20 mm Hg over the systolic BP for three minutes or more.
  • Chvostek's sign: Contraction of the ipsilateral circumoral facial muscles when the facial nerve is tapped just anterior to the ear.
  • Severe hypocalcemia can cause seizures, carpopedal spasm, bronchospasm, and laryngospasm.

Treatment of the underlying condition is necessary. The patient should be reassured and rebreathing from a paper bag should be done during acute episodes.

questions.text: Respiratory depression with the following opioids shows a ceiling effect except?
questions.solution:
Respiratory depression with the morphine does not have a ceiling effect.

Morphine is a pure opioid agonist. As the dose of morphine increases, respiratory depression also increases, progressing to respiratory arrest.

On the other hand, pentazocine, nalbuphine, and butorphanol are agonist-antagonist compounds. A ceiling effect occurs at higher doses limiting the progression of respiratory depression.

Related Pearl: Ceiling effect of opioids

Drug Correlation of Respiratory Depression With Dose
Morphine

Increases proportionally with dose (i.e. no ceiling effect)
Buprenorphine

Ceiling effect at 0.15-1.2 mg in adults
Butorphanol

Ceiling effect at 30-60 μg/kg
Nalbuphine

Ceiling effect at 30 mg in adults
Pentazocine 

Ceiling effect suggested

questions.text: An oxygen hemoglobin dissociation curve of a 30-year-old athlete was recorded. If curve 3 represents the dissociation curve during rest, how would the graph shift if he was exercising?
questions.solution:
From the given scenario, during exercise, the oxygen hemoglobin curve shifts considerably towards the right and is denoted by the curve 4.

Curve 3 represents the normal oxygen hemoglobin curve during rest. 

Conditions that cause a right shift (curve 3 to curve 4) in the oxygen hemoglobin curve are: (Conditions with the increased requirement of O2 - metabolically active tissues)

  • Hypoxia and Hypercarbia - Metabolically active tissues utilize O2 and tissues produce CO2
  • ↓ pH - Secondary to increased CO2 production
  • ↑ in temperature, heat
  • ↑ in 2,3-DPG - increased anaerobic glycolysis

Conditions that cause a left shift (curve 3 to curve 2)  in the oxygen hemoglobin dissociation curve are:

  • Decreased carbon dioxide
  • ↑ pH of the blood
  • ↓ in the temperature of the body

Curve 1 represents the Myoglobin-O2 binding curve. It is a rectangular hyperbola (unlike a sigmoid curve of the oxygen-hemoglobin curve). This is because it only has a single oxygen binding site. It is present in muscles in large amounts and can provide oxygen to muscles even at low blood oxygen levels.

questions.text: Which heart sound occurs immediately after the pressure waveform indicated by the arrow?
questions.solution:
The heart sound occurring just after the pressure waveform marked by the arrow is S1. The waveform marked in the image is 'a wave' and it corresponds to atrial contraction.

S1 (first heart sound) is heard in the isovolumetric contraction phase of the cardiac cycle where ventricles contract against closed mitral valves. This occurs after atrial systole, corresponding to an 'a' wave in the jugular venous pressure. Thus, S1 can be heard just after the 'a' wave. 

Jugular venous pressure measured in the internal jugular vein (IJV) is a reflection of the right atrial pressure. IJV is preferred because it is not valved and is in direct line with the superior vena cava and right atrium. 

The waveforms seen in a normal JVP are:

  • a wave corresponds to atrial contraction and occurs just after the P wave (on ECG) and just before the first heart sound.
  • c wave represents the bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during ventricular systole.
  • x descent corresponds to the atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.
  • v wave represents atrial filling during ventricular systole and peaks at the second heart sound.
  • y descent represents passive emptying of the right atrium into the right ventricle after tricuspid valve opening.

The Wiggers diagram given below correlates JVP with other aspects of the cardiac cycle. 

Other options - 

Option A: S4 is heard in the phase of atrial systole where atria contract in the late stage of ventricular filling. This occurs just before S1 and 'a' wave in the JVP. 

Option B: S3 is heard in the passive ventricular filling phase where mitral valves are open. It is seen after the 'v' wave peak in the JVP. 

Option C: S2 is heard due to the closure of aortic and pulmonary valves in the isovolumetric relaxation phase after ventricular systole. It can be heard just before the 'v' wave corresponding to the JVP waveform. 

Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation

 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation
Absent y-descent Cardiac tamponade

questions.text: The following slide is given as a spotter in your microbiology practical examination. Identify the following organism.
questions.solution:
The image shows pink non-branching acid-fast bacilli on a blue background. These findings are consistent with the staining characteristics of mycobacteria. The stain used is the Ziehl-Neelsen stain. 

Nocardia is partially acid-fast and appears as branching filaments.

Actinomyces and Corynebacterium are non-acid-fast.

The image below shows Nocardia stained using an acid fast staining technique.

 

The image given below is of a Gram stained specimen of Actinomyces israelii. 

 

The images below show the staining characteristics of Corynebacterium diphtheriae. 

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains

These include eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, congo red, etc.

Used to stain pathological specimens
Basic stains.

Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in Quellung reaction. 

Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction.
Neutral stains

Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.  

 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contain more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain:  Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid–fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, M. avium, Nocardia etc.
Fluorochrome staining: Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.

C. Special stains:

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify Pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor white staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain calcofluor white. It is especially useful for the identification of mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.  It is also used in staining acanthamoeba
Chance's staining For cell wall demonstration

questions.text: Your friend who is on treatment for glaucoma tells you that she feels her eyes look prettier than before. On examination, you notice increased iris pigmentation and eyelash hypertrichosis. Which of the following drugs is associated with this effect?
questions.solution:
Bimatoprost is a PGF-2 alpha analog. PGF-2 alpha analogs are associated with eyelash hypertrichosis and iris hyperpigmentation.

Bimatoprost is approved for topical application in the treatment of eyelash hypotrichosis.

Related Pearl: Important adverse effects of anti-glaucoma drugs
