questions.text: A 40-year-old man has been diagnosed with solid cancer of the bowel. Urine analysis reveals massive proteinuria a few months after the initial diagnosis of cancer.  What do you think is the likely cause of the development of urinary findings?
questions.solution:
This patient with features of nephrotic syndrome and malignancy most likely has membranous nephropathy

Membranous nephropathy is one of the most common causes of nephrotic syndrome in adults. It occurs commonly in men aged between 30-50 years. The majority of cases are idiopathic/primary that occurs due to the autoantibodies against the renal antigen phospholipase A2 receptor. These autoantibodies are absent in secondary membranous nephropathy.

The various conditions leading to secondary membranous nephropathy are

  • Drugs: Captopril, non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), penicillamine, etc.
  • Infections: Hepatitis B and C, syphilis, malaria
  • Malignancy of lung, colon, and melanoma
  • Autoimmune diseases like SLE, Sjorgen syndrome, sarcoidosis, primary biliary cirrhosis, etc.

Diagnosis:

  • Light microscopy shows diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall without cellular proliferation. Irregular spikes and dome pattern on silver staining(black).
  • Immunofluorescence microscopy shows granular deposits containing IgG and complements proteins along the glomerular basement membrane. 
  • Electron micrograph: electron-dense subepithelial deposits (epi membranous spikes) and effacement of foot processes of podocytes

questions.text: A primigravida presents to you with anemia early in her pregnancy. She is 7 weeks pregnant as seen on ultrasound. Her hemoglobin level is 9 g/dL. When should she start taking iron supplements?
questions.solution:
The iron supplements for the 7-week pregnant mother presenting with anemia should be started at 8 to 10 weeks.

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention defined anemia in pregnant women using a cut-off value. The pregnant mother is said to be anemic when the level of haemoglobin is less than 11 g/dL in the first and third trimesters and less than 10.5 g/dL in the second trimester.

Anemia in the first trimester is treated by oral iron therapy. According to the Anemia Mukt Bharat program, pregnant women with mild and moderate anemia are treated with two iron and folic acid tablets. Each tablet contains 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 mcg of folic acid. These tablets are taken daily and are supplied by the healthcare worker. Hence, in this mother iron supplementation should be started by 8-10 weeks.

Drawbacks of oral therapy are intolerance presenting as epigastric pain, nausea, vomiting, constipation, or diarrhea, and unpredictable absorption rate. The improvement in haemoglobin levels is generally evident within 3 weeks of oral iron therapy.Contraindications to oral therapy are intolerance, and severe anemia in advanced pregnancy. In these patients, intravenous iron therapy may be considered.

The best time to start corrective iron therapy in pregnancy depends on the individual patient's needs and the presence of anemia. For most pregnant women without anemia, it is recommended to start iron supplementation between 12-16 weeks of gestation to meet the increased iron demands during pregnancy.If a pregnant woman has anemia, iron supplementation should be started as soon as diagnosed, regardless of the gestational age.

questions.text: A 60 year old female patient presented with complaints of seeing colored haloes. After the necessary examination, she was diagnosed with acute congestive glaucoma. On examination, her pupil would be _____?
questions.solution:
In acute congestive glaucoma, the pupil is mid-dilated and vertically oval.

It is non-reactive to both light and accommodation.

Acute primary angle-closure glaucoma

The term "angle closure" refers to the occlusion of the trabecular meshwork by the peripheral iris (iridotrabecular contact [ITC]), obstructing aqueous outflow.

Angle closure can be primary, when it occurs in an anatomically predisposed eye or secondary to another ocular or systemic factor.

Classification

  • Primary angle-closure suspect (PACS)
    • Gonioscopy shows posterior meshwork ITC in three or more quadrants but no PAS.
    • Intraocular pressure (IOP), optic disc, and visual field are normal.
    • No peripheral anterior synechiae (PAS) are seen
    • The risk of PACG at 5 years may be around 30%.
  • Primary angle closure (PAC)
    • Gonioscopy shows three or more quadrants of ITC with raised IOP and/or PAS or excessive pigment smudging on the TM.
    • Normal optic disc and field.
  • Primary angle-closure glaucoma (PACG)
    • ITC in three or more quadrants, with glaucomatous optic neuropathy.
    • Optic nerve damage from an episode of severe IOP elevation, such as acute angle closure, may not appear as typical glaucomatous cupping.

Risk factors

  • Age: The average age of relative pupillary block is about 60 years at presentation
  • Gender: Females are more commonly affected than males.
  • Race: Particularly prevalent in Far Eastern and Indian Asians.
  • Family history
  • Refraction: Eyes with "pure" pupillary block are typically hypermetropic.
  • Axial length: Short eyes tend to have a shallow anterior chamber (AC); eyes with nanophthalmos have a very short eye with a proportionally large lens and are at particular risk.

Symptoms: Pain, redness, photophobia, impaired vision, watering

Signs:

  • Corneal edema: colored halos
  • Conjunctiva: congestion, chemosis
  • IOP: elevated 40–70 mm Hg
  • AC very shallow
  • Pupil: vertically oval, mid-dilated
  • Angle: completely closed, Grade 0

Treatment:

  • Immediate: Intravenous mannitol, intravenous acetazolamide followed by oral dose, topical beta-blockers, brimonidine, latanoprost
  • Definitive: Laser peripheral iridotomy, filtration surgery

questions.text: All of the following  are true about Mooren’s ulcer except that ______.

choices.text: It forms a characteristic whitish overhanging edge.
It is a severe inflammatory peripheral ulcerative keratitis.

questions.solution:
Moorens’s ulcer is a superficial ulcer.

Features of Mooren’s ulcer (rodent ulcer/chronic serpiginous ulcer) :

  • Autoimmune
  • Peripheral, superficial ulcer which rarely perforates
  • Associated with undermining of the epithelium and superficial stromal lamellae
  • At the advancing border form a characteristic whitish overhanging edge.
  • 2 clinical forms
    • Benign
    • Virulent
  • It is a diagnosis of exclusion after all systemic disorders predisposing to marginal ulceration are ruled out.
  • Treatment
    • Excision of a 4–7 mm strip of adjacent conjunctiva, which eliminates the conjunctival sources of collagenase and proteoglycanase.  
    • Corticosteroids

Image: The image above shows a perforated Mooren's ulcer

questions.text: The following appearance of gastric mucosa on endoscopy is seen in cases of _______
questions.solution:
The image shows the snake-skin appearance of the gastric mucosa, which is seen in cases of portal hypertensive gastropathy. Portal hypertensive gastropathy is characterized by the diffuse dila­tion of the mucosal and submucosal venous plexus of the stomach associated with overlying gastritis.

Option A: Gastric antral vascular ectasia (GAVE) also known as watermelon stomach is a significant cause of acute or chronic gastrointestinal blood loss in the elderly, characterized endoscopically by watermelon stripes. It is associated with heterogeneous medical conditions, including hepatic, cardiac, and renal diseases; the underlying etiopathogenesis still remains unknown.

 

Option C: Hypoproteinemic hypertrophic gastropathy also known as Menetrier's disease is a rare, acquired premalignant disease of the stomach characterized by massive gastric folds, little or no acid production, and excessive mucous production with resultant protein loss. The disorder is associated with excessive secretion of transforming growth factor-alpha.

 

Option D: Dieulafoy's lesion is a medical condition characterized by a large tortuous arteriole that erodes and bleeds and occurs most commonly in the stomach wall.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with low-grade fever, inspiratory stridor, and barking cough for the past 5 days. His chest X-ray showed the following. Which among the following is not indicated in the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and an X-ray showing the narrowing of the subglottic region of the trachea (steeple sign) are suggestive of croup (laryngotracheobronchitis). Since it is a viral infection, antibiotics like cefotaxime are not indicated in their treatment.

The median age for laryngotracheobronchitis is 3 months to 5 years. It is caused due to viral infection of the glottic and subglottic regions. Parainfluenza virus is a common cause of laryngotracheobronchitis

Clinical features include low-grade fever, hoarseness of voice, and a barking cough. There may be associated inspiratory stridor. Diagnosis is usually clinical. A lateral radiograph of the neck will reveal the steeple sign due to subglottic narrowing (shown below). 

Treatment of croup involves:

  • Racemic epinephrine nebulization - It constricts pre-capillary arterioles in the upper airway mucosa and decreases capillary hydrostatic pressure, leading to fluid resorption from the interstitial space and reduction of edema. The indications for the administration of nebulized epinephrine are:
    • moderate to severe stridor at rest
    • the possible need for intubation
    • respiratory distress
    • hypoxia
  • Oral dexamethasone - Indicated in all the grades of croup. Corticosteroids reduce laryngeal edema through their anti-inflammatory action. IM dexamethasone and nebulized budesonide have an equal clinical effect. Corticosteroids should not be administered to children with varicella or tuberculosis as they may worsen the disease.
  • Severe croup requires urgent hospitalization with oxygen inhalation for hypoxemic child(SpO2 <92 %)
    (A helium-oxygen mixture (heliox) may be considered for severe croup when intubation is being considered)
  • Antibiotics are not indicated.

Most children that have croup can be managed safely at home. Indications for hospitalization:

  • Progressive stridor
  • Severe stridor at rest
  • Respiratory distress
  • Hypoxia
  • Cyanosis
  • Depressed mental status
  • Poor oral intake
  • Need for reliable observation

questions.text: An anxious, young man presented with sudden trouble seeing with his left eye. There was no associated pain or difficulty moving the eyes. The following visual field defect was picked up. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The perimetry result depicts altitudinal hemianopia, which is most commonly seen in anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (AION).

Altitudinal hemianopia can also be seen in suprasellar tumors and occipital lobe lesions, but the frequency is very low compared to that of AION. Hence, AION is the single best answer.

The two types of AION are as follows:

  • Arteritic AION- caused by giant-cell arteritis
  • Non-arteritic AION (NAAION)- more common

Clinical features:

Features AAION

NAAION
Age >70 years

<70 years
Sex F > M

F = M

Headache

Jaw claudication

 Present Absent
Visual loss Marked

Less marked
Optic disc Pale disc edema

Hyperemic disc edema
C reactive protein Raised

Normal 
ESR Highly raised

Raised
FFA

Disc delay and choroidal delay

Only disc delay
Treatment Corticosteroids Levodopa–carbidopa combination for 3 weeks and then double dose for 1 month

Note: Corticosteroids are not proven to be effective in NAAION.


The image given below shows pale disc edema of Arteritic AION.

questions.text: A 50 year old smoker presents with pain along the left arm and ptosis. His chest radiograph shows a soft tissue opacity at the left lung apex with destruction of adjacent ribs. This is suggestive of:
questions.solution:
The clinical picture is suggestive of a pancoast tumour (superior sulcus tumour).

Pancoast syndrome/superior sulcus tumor results from a local extension of a tumor growing in the apex of the lung, with the involvement of C8, T1, and T2 nerve roots, stellate ganglion, and the chest wall. It presents with pain that radiates to the ulnar distribution of the arm, often with the destruction of the 1st and 2nd ribs. Patients with the central or endobronchial growth of the primary tumor may present with a cough, hemoptysis, wheeze, stridor, dyspnea, or post-obstructive pneumonitis.

Regional spread can cause

  • Tracheal obstruction
  • Esophageal compression with dysphagia
  • Recurrent laryngeal paralysis with hoarseness
  • Phrenic nerve palsy with the elevation of the hemidiaphragm and dyspnea
  • Sympathetic nerve palsy with Horner’s syndrome (enophthalmos, ptosis, miosis, and anhydrosis)

questions.text: A 4-year child is brought to the pediatrician for the evaluation of the neck mass. On examination, a painless, soft, fluctuating mass is found on the posterior triangle of the neck as shown in the image below. The slip sign is negative and the swelling is brilliantly transilluminant. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A soft, painless, fluctuating mass found in the posterior part of the neck in a child, is most likely to be a cystic hygroma.

Cystic hygroma is a benign lymph-filled sac that results from obstruction of lymph vessels during development. It is commonly seen during early infancy or diagnosed during prenatal ultrasound. It is present in the lateral part of the neck. It is soft, fluctuating, and brilliantly translucent.

Clinical presentation depends on the anatomical site of the swelling and patients may present with symptoms such as pain, hoarseness, dysphagia, or shortness of breath.

Treatment:

  • Aspiration of the contents, followed by excision once the sac or capsule gets thickened by fibrous tissue.
  • Single cysts can be treated with sclerosing therapy. Commonly used sclerosants include OK–432 or Picibanil, which is a mixture of group A Streptococcus pyogenes strain, pure ethanol, interferon alpha-2a, and doxycycline.
  • Complete excision is done in case of multiple cysts.

Other options: 

Option B: A branchial cleft cyst also presents as soft fluctuant swelling in the lateral part of the neck. It is present in the anterior neck and at the junction of the upper third and middle third of the sternocleidomastoid muscle.

Option C: Lipomas present as a painless, slow-growing, soft and mobile mass of the subcutaneous tissue. They do not transilluminate. The swelling is non-fluctuant and when palpated, the edge slips under the finger. This is known as the slip sign.

Option D: Cervical lymphadenopathy is the most common cause of a neck mass in a child. It is due to infections of oral and nasal cavities, pharynx, larynx, ear, and scalp or face. It can be found laterally or in the midline. On palpation, they are firm, tender and can become fluctuant in case of an abscess.

questions.text: Contraceptive failure while on oral contraceptive pills is unlikely to occur with which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
Contraceptive failure in patients on the oral contraceptive pill is unlikely to occur with valproate. It is an enzyme inhibitor that inhibits the degradation of OCPs and increases their duration of action.

Rifampicin, phenytoin, and phenobarbitone are enzyme inducers and can cause increased metabolism of OCPs leading to contraceptive failure.

Enzyme inducers Enzyme inhibitors

Mnemonic: CRAP GPS

  • Carbamezepine
  • Rifampicin
  • Alcohol (chronic)
  • Phenytoin
  • Griseofulvin
  • Phenobarbitone
  • Sulfonylureas

Mnemonic: RED VICK

  • Ritonavir
  • Erythromycin
  • Diltiazem
  • Verapamil, Valproate
  • Itraconazole
  • Clarithromycin, Cimetidine
  • Ketoconazole

questions.text: The dead body of a child was recovered from a river with froth around his mouth, which reappeared even after wiping it off. Which postmortem finding is not seen in this case?

choices.text: High concentration of arsenic from shaft of hair
Cadaveric spasm with mud in closed fist

questions.solution:
The above case scenario with frothing is suggestive of antemortem drowning. High concentration of arsenic in the shaft of hair is seen in patients with chronic arsenic poisoning.

 Given below are the features of antemortem drowning.

  • Froth - The presence of copious amounts of fine, shaving-lather-like froth at the mouth and the nostrils is the most characteristic finding of antemortem drowning. It is caused by the vigorous agitation of the tracheal and bronchial mucous secretions, edema fluid, and alveolar surfactant during respiratory efforts. 
  • Cutis anserina - The contraction of the erector pilorum muscles causes puckering and a grainy appearance of the skin. This resembles goose skin; hence, it is called cutis anserina.
  • Emphysema aquosum - overinflation of the lungs
    Paltauf’s spots - subpleural hemorrhages that reflect hemolysis within intra-alveolar hemorrhages
  • Washerwoman’s hand - Maceration of the skin on the palms and soles gives a wrinkled, sodden, and bleached appearance due to submersion.
  • Cadaveric spasm - Gravel, weed, soil, grass, etc. is firmly held in the clenched hands due to cadaveric spasm. This is a vital sign of antemortem drowning. The material also indicates the place of submersion.
  • Rigor mortis - This appears early in cases of a violent antemortem struggle.
  • Face - It is bloated and discolored, with cyanosis.
  • Eyes - Conjunctiva are suffused and pupils dilated.
  • Tongue - It may be swollen and protruded.
  • Antemortem injuries - These may be sustained by striking objects, such as rocks, during the fall into the water body. Examination for such injuries must be performed only after the body is dry.

Internal findings:

  • Lungs - They appear voluminous and distended show ballooning. The cut section will exude copious amounts of frothy, bloodstained fluid.
  • Larynx, trachea, and bronchioles - The presence of sand, silt, and aquatic vegetation in the trachea and lower respiratory tract are characteristic findings of antemortem drowning.
  • Heart and blood vessels- Gettler test can be done to estimate the chloride content in the right and left sides of the heart to differentiate between freshwater and saltwater drowning. 
  • Diatom test- Diatoms are microscopic algae. Their presence in the organs, particularly in the bone marrow, is suggestive of antemortem drowning.
  • Stomach and small intestines- These organs may contain water in some cases. Water present in the small intestine is positive evidence of death by drowning.
  • Middle ear - The presence of water in the middle ear is highly suggestive of antemortem drowning.
  • Brain - It is congested, and edematous, with loss of gray-white junction.

Related Pearl: Differentiating features between Antemortem amd Postmortem drowning

       Antemortem drowning       Postmortem drowning
Foam/froth at nostrils or mouth Not present
Cadaveric spasm Not present
Lungs usually are voluminous, bulky, water-logged and over-inflated ,called as emphysema aquosum. Passive collection of water  in the lungs without any formation of columns of froth,has been called as oedema aquosum.
Presence of foam, fluid, debris, weeds, vegetation, etc. in the bronchi and bronchioles. Foreign matter may passively find access only to the upper respiratory passage.
Demonstration of diatoms in the lungs, liver, brain, bone marrow, etc. Diatoms may reach the lungs but not to the distant organs because of absence of circulation.
Stomach may contain water and foreign material like sand, weed, dirt etc which may be swallowed while struggling for life. Water could enter the stomach. However, quantity of foreign matter may become the decisive issue.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male was diagnosed with a submandibular gland tumour and posted for surgical removal of the gland along with its duct. Following surgery, he developed loss of general sensation in the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. However, the taste sensations are present. Which of the following nerves is likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
General sensation from the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue is carried by lingual nerve, which is likely to be inujured in this case.

In the anterior two-thirds of the tongue,

  • General sensation is carried by the lingual nerve.
  • Taste sensation is carried by chorda tympani branch of the facial nerve.

In the posterior one-third of the tongue,

  • Both general and taste sensations are carried by the glossopharyngealnerve.

Valleculae is supplied by the internal laryngeal branch of the vagus nerve.

Related Pearl: Sensory Innervation of Tongue

Area

General sensory

Special sensory

Anterior 2/3rds

Lingual nerve (CN V)

Chorda tympani (CN VII)

Posterior 1/3rd

Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX)

Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX)

Posterior most tongue (vallecullae, epiglottis)

Internal laryngeal nerve (CN X)

Internal laryngeal nerve (CN X)

questions.text: A patient underwent a coronary bypass graft with the great saphenous vein. The patient now complains of paresthesia and sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be involved?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette in a patient with paresthesia and sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot is suggestive of injury to the saphenous nerve.

Injury to the saphenous nerve is common following venous cut down for access to the great saphenous vein, in this case for coronary bypass graft.

Saphenous nerve:

It is the longest and largest cutaneous branch of the femoral nerve and is the longest nerve in the body. It arises from the posterior division of the femoral nerve. It then enters the adductor canal and exits it by piercing the fascia lata between the gracilis and sartorius and supplies the skin over the patella. The saphenous nerve then descends along the medial border of the tibia along with the great saphenous vein (anterior to the vein) and supplies the skin on the medial side of the knee, leg, and foot as far as up to the first metatarsophalangeal joint.

Saphenous nerve injury:

When the great saphenous vein is being harvested for coronary bypass graft, injury to the saphenous nerve is common as it closely travels with the great saphenous vein. Sensory loss over the medial side of the knee, leg, and foot is observed in saphenous nerve injury. 

Other options: 

Option A: Superficial peroneal nerve injury causes sensory loss over the lateral aspect of the leg and the dorsum of the foot.

Option C: Femoral nerve gives rise to anterior cutaneous branches, the saphenous nerve, and motor supply to the quadriceps and sartorius. Anterior cutaneous branches supply the skin on the anterior thigh and knee. If the saphenous nerve was not an option in the question, the femoral nerve would have been the next best answer. 

Option D: Sural nerve injury causes sensory loss over the posterior and lateral aspects of the distal third of the leg and lateral side of the foot and fifth toe. It is often used as an autologous peripheral nerve graft as it is readily identified and easy to harvest.

questions.text: How many spinal nerves are present in the cervical region?
questions.solution:
There are 8 pairs of spinal nerves in the cervical region.

The cerebrospinal nervous system includes 12 pairs of cranial nerves and 31 pairs of spinal nerves.

The 31 pairs of spinal nerves are distributed as follows:

  • Cervical nerves - 8 pairs
  • Thoracic nerves-12 pairs
  • Lumbar nerves-5 pairs
  • Sacral nerves-5 pairs
  • Coccygeal nerves-1 pair

questions.text: Which of the following is the best indicator of chronic malnutrition?
questions.solution:
Height for age is the best indicator of chronic malnutrition.

Nutritional status is often assessed in terms of anthropometry:

  • Low weight for height, or wasting, indicates acute malnutrition. 
  • High weight-for-height indicates overweight.
  • Low height for age, or stunting, indicates chronic malnutrition. This is the best indicator of long-term nutritional status in the pediatric population.
  • Low weight for the age indicates acute or chronic malnutrition. It does not differentiate between wasting and stunting. Hence, it has limited clinical significance.

Mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) is an age-independent parameter used for the screening of wasting in children.

Related Pearl: World Health Organization (WHO) classification of nutritional status of infants and children

Nutritional status
Criteria (from birth to 5 years)

Obese

Weight-for-height/length >3 SD

BMI-for-age >3 SD
Overweight

Weight-for-height/length >2 SD and ≤3 SD

BMI-for-age >2 SD and ≤3 SD
Moderately underweight Weight-for-age <–2 SD and ≥–3 SD
Severely underweight Weight-for-age <–3 SD
Moderate acute malnutrition

Weight-for-height/length ≤–2 SD and ≥–3 SD

BMI-for-age ≤–2 SD and ≥–3 SD

Mid-upper arm circumference ≥115 mm and <125 mm
Severe acute malnutrition

Weight-for-height/length <– 3 SD

BMI-for-age <– 3 SD

Mid-upper arm circumference <115 mm

Bilateral pitting edema
Moderately stunted (or) moderate chronic malnutrition Height/Length-for-age ≤–2 SD and ≥–3 SD
Severely stunted (or) severe chronic malnutrition Height/Length-for-age <–3 SD
Moderately wasted Weight-for-height/length ≤–2 SD and ≥–3 SD
Severely wasted Weight-for-height/length <-3 SD

SD - Standard deviation (from the median)

questions.text: A young male patient presents with pain during defecation along with the presence of blood-streaked stools. He has had a history of constipation for 5 months. On examination, a sentinel tag is present at the anal orifice. Due to extreme pain, a digital rectal examination is avoided. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This case scenario with a history of chronic constipation, and the presence of sentinel tags on examination, suggests a diagnosis of anal fissure.

An anal fissure is a longitudinal split in the anoderm of the distal anal canal. A chronic anal fissure frequently is associated with :

  • Sentinel tag externally
  • Hypertrophied anal papillae internally
  • Anal ulcer overlying the internal sphincter

Anal fissures are usually seen in the young but they can occur at any age with equal sex predilection. Severe pain associated with defecation resolves spontaneously and reappears during the next evacuation. It may even be associated with the passage of fresh blood. 

Most of the fissures are located in the posterior midline followed by the anterior midline. Fissures located anywhere around the anal circumference can be possible due to other diseases like HIV, tuberculosis, syphilis, Crohn's disease, or carcinoma.

Treatment of anal fissure:

  • The focus is to normalize bowel habits. Bowel softeners, dietary fibres, and adequate water should be recommended.
  • Medical therapy involves the topical application of glyceryl trinitrate. It releases nitric oxide and relaxes the internal anal sphincter. This reduces spasms, and pain and improves vasculature to promote healing.
  • Surgical therapy is recommended for chronic fissures that have failed medical therapy. Lateral internal sphincterotomy is the procedure of choice where a portion of the internal sphincter is divided away from the fissure. 

Other options:

Option A: Anal fistula is usually associated with pain and intermittent purulent discharge. On examination, an external opening in the perineum can be found which opens internally in the anal canal.

Option C: Hemorrhoids are enlargements of anal cushions which occur commonly due to raised intra-abdominal pressure(e.g. constipation and pregnancy). They present with bright-red painless bleeding, pruritus, mucus discharge, and prolapsed hemorrhoids. Pain is not a common feature and is present if haemorrhoids are thrombosed.

Option D: Rectal prolapse presents as a mass protruding out of the anal canal. It is seen more commonly in females and may be associated with faecal incontinence.

questions.text: Identify the test shown below.
questions.solution:
The image shows a tear strip placed in the lower lid of the eye. This is the Schirmer test.

Schirmer's test is used for the assessment of aqueous tear production by measuring the amount of wetting of a special filter paper (no. 41 Whatman). <10 mm of wetting after 5 minutes without anesthesia is considered abnormal. However, a single Schirmer test should not be used as the sole criterion for diagnosing dry eye.

Dry eye disease occurs as a result of inadequate tear volume and function which results In unstable tear film and ocular surface disease. The causes are: 

  • Sjögren syndrome
  • Ocular rosacea
  • Vitamin A deficiency
  • Follicular conjunctivitis
  • Age-related dry eye 
  • Wearing contact lenses 
  • Trachoma

Related Pearl: Tear film tests used for the diagnosis of dry eye

Schirmer test

Inference 

  • 15 mm: Normal
  • 5-10 mm: Moderate keratoconjunctivitis sicca (KCS)
  • < 5 mm: Severe KCS

Tear film break up test (TBUT)

Inference 

  • 15-35 seconds: Normal
  • < 10 seconds: Unstable tear film

Rose Bengal staining

Inference

  • A pattern: Confluent staining → Severe KCS
  • B pattern: Extensive staining → Moderate KCS
  • C pattern: Fine punctate stains → Mild KCS

Tear osmolarity test

Abnormal osmolarity is defined by 

  • An elevated reading, >300 mOsm/L, indicating loss of homeostasis, or
  • When the inter-eye difference is >8 mOsm/L, indicating instability of the tear film.

questions.text: A person has a vision of 6/60  in his right eye and  3/60 in his left eye. He is unable to count fingers from a distance of 6 meters. What type of blindness does he have?
questions.solution:
Since the patient has a vision of 3/60 and a limitation in counting fingers from a distance of 6 meters, he has economic blindness.

Type of Blindness Description
Social Blindness Presenting distance visual acuity of less than 3/60 (20/400) in the better eye and limitation of the field of vision to be less than 10 degrees from the center of fixation
Economic blindness The inability of a person to count fingers from a distance of 6 meters
Manifest blindness Vision 1/60 to just perception of light
Absolute blindness No perception of light
Curable blindness That stage of blindness where the damage is reversible by prompt management, e.g., cataract
Preventable blindness Loss of vision that could have been completely prevented by the institution of effective preventive or prophylactic measures e.g.,  xerophthalmia, trachoma, and glaucoma 
Avoidable blindness The sum total of preventable and curable blindness is often referred to as avoidable blindness.

questions.text: Which of the following steps is not included in the STEP approach of WHO?
questions.solution:
Therapeutic assessment is not included in the WHO's STEP approach. 

The STEP approach of WHO is a survey methodology developed to assess risk factors of non-communicable diseases(NCD). It helps countries establish an NCD surveillance system. The steps include the following:

  • Questionnaires contain questions about behavioral risk factors like tobacco use, alcohol use, diet, and physical activity. 
  • Physical measurements contain blood pressure, height, weight, and waist size
  • Biochemical measurements contain blood glucose, blood lipids, urinary sodium, and creatinine.  

Note: Mental health and suicide are included in optional behavioral risk factors (step 1). Hence, psychological assessment is also included in the STEP approach. 

Related Pearl: Sentinel Surveillance

  • Sentinel surveillance is used to augment the notification systems used in surveillance of diseases.
  • It detects the total case load and is used to identify the missing cases that are not notified among the old and new cases.
  • Sentinel data from the same is extrapolated to the entire population and the prevalence can be commented on.
  • Advantages: Bias in reporting is minimized and the feedback is simplified.

questions.text: Magnesium does not have a role in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Magnesium has no role in copper metabolism.

Magnesium is a major intracellular cation required for the function of various enzymes such as hexokinase, phosphofructokinase, alkaline phosphatase, enolase, etc.

The role of magnesium can be seen in the following processes:

  • Calcium homeostasis: One-half of the total body magnesium is located in bone. Magnesium is important for PTH secretion which controls serum Ca2+ level.
  • Neuromuscular function: Hypomagnesemia may cause generalized alterations in neuromuscular function including tetany, tremor, seizures. Hypermagnesemia is known to cause symptoms of neuromuscular blockade such as hypoactive tendon reflexes, GI hypomotility, paralysis, etc
  • Maintenance of cardiac rhythm: Hypomagnesemia can lead to supraventricular and ventricular arrhythmias. Hypermagnesemia can cause bradycardia, heart block, and asystole.

questions.text:
Match the following microscopic findings to the disease conditions in which they are seen.
Microscopic findings Lung disease
1. Coal-laden macrophages  A. Silicosis
2. Golden-brown fusiform rods  B. Hypersensitivity pneumonitis
3. Non-necrotizing granulomas  C. Anthracosis
4. Nodules of whorled collagen fibers D. Asbestosis
questions.solution:
The correct match is Option 2: 1-C, 2-D, 3-B, 4-A.

Anthracosis/ coal workers' pneumoconiosis is a pulmonary condition seen in coal miners. It is caused due to the phagocytosis of the inhaled carbonaceous pigment by the alveolar or interstitial macrophages and its subsequent accumulation in the connective tissue spaces. With continued exposure, lung tissue undergoes progressive massive fibrosis. The upper lobes and upper zones of the lower lobes of the lungs are commonly involved.

Microscopic features consist of coal-laden macrophages, black pigment, and dense collagenous interstitial fibrosis (in advanced stages), as shown in the image below.

 

Asbestosis occurs due to the inhalation of crystalline hydrated silicates (asbestos). It is characterized by diffuse parenchymal interstitial fibrosis. It usually begins in the lower lobes of the lungs. Other asbestos-related diseases include pleural plaques, recurrent pleural effusions, lung carcinoma, and mesothelioma.

Hallmark microscopic findings are golden brown, fusiform or beaded rods called asbestos bodies, as shown in the image below. These are formed when the asbestos fibers phagocytosed by the macrophages are coated by iron-containing proteinaceous material derived from phagocyte ferritin. Pleural plaques of dense collagen that may be calcified are the most common manifestation of asbestos exposure. They involve the anterior and posterolateral aspects of the parietal pleura and the diaphragmatic domes.

 

Hypersensitivity pneumonitis is an immunologically mediated granulomatous disease that occurs in response to continuous exposure to inhaled organic antigens (mold, hay dust, bird proteins, thermophilic bacteria in air-conditioning units). Pathological changes in response to such exposures are mediated by the CD4+ and CD8+ T-lymphocytes (type IV hypersensitivity reactions) and proinflammatory chemokines.

Microscopic findings include interstitial pneumonitis (lymphocytes, plasma cells, and macrophages) and non-necrotizing granulomas, as shown in the image below. Chronic disease gives rise to obliterative bronchiolitis and honeycombing.

 

Silicosis occurs due to inhalation of crystalline silicon dioxide (silica) as seen in individuals employed in concrete work and sandblasting. Macrophages incorporate inhaled silica particles, thereby activating and releasing inflammatory mediators (IL-1, IL-8) that cause fibroblast recruitment. Subsequently, collagen is deposited in the interstitium. Upper lung zones and hilar lymph nodes are commonly involved.

Microscopy reveals coalescent nodules of whorled collagen fibers surrounded by a peripheral zone of silica-laden macrophages, as shown in the image below. As the disease progresses, these nodules coalesce into scars. Sometimes, thin sheets of calcification can occur in hilar lymph nodes, giving an eggshell appearance.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis from the image given below?
questions.solution:
The fundus shows a pale waxy disc, attenuated arteries, and bony spicules, which implies retinitis pigmentosa (RP).  

Retinitis pigmentosa (RP) is a dystrophy of rods and cones, with rods being primarily affected. It is a genetic disease. The non-hereditary/sporadic type is most common, and among the hereditary type, it can occur in an autosomal dominant (AD), autosomal recessive (AR), or X-linked recessive (XLR) pattern. AD disease generally has the best prognosis.

The presenting feature is night blindness.

Investigations:

  • Perimetry: Initial stage will have ring scotoma, which further develops into tunnel vision.
  • Electroretinography reveals a decreased amplitude of both "a" and "b" waves.

There is no effective treatment for RP.

questions.text: A female patient with fever and malar rashes was found to have vegetations on either side of the heart valves. What is the likely type of endocarditis seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The vegetations on both sides of the valves along with the history suggestive of systemic lupus erythematosus are consistent with Libman Sacks Endocarditis.

Summary of salient features of vegetations in different endocarditis:

  Rheumatic heart disease Infective endocarditis Non-bacterial thrombotic or marantic endocarditis Libman Sacks endocarditis
Etiology Rheumatic heart disease Infective endocarditis Malignancy (M3-AML, pancreatic carcinoma),
deep vein thrombosis,
Trousseau syndrome		 Systemic lupus erythematosus
Vegetations Small, warty, Firm, Friable Large, Bulky, friable, destructive Small, single, or multiple, non-destructive Small to medium-sized, flat, verrucous
Site Along lines of closure Cusps of valves, mural endocardium Line of closure Either or both sides of the valve leaflets.
Sterile/Infective Non-sterile Non-sterile Sterile Sterile
Embolization Uncommon Very common common Uncommon

Related Pearl: Vegetations in Various Types of Endocarditis

questions.text: A farmer presents with a swollen foot and multiple sinuses as shown in the below image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis here is Mycetoma which is caused by Eumycetoma.

Mycetoma:-

  • Mycetoma is a chronic, granulomatous infection of the skin, subcutaneous tissues, fascia and bone, which most often affects the foot or the hand. It is, therefore, commonly known as Maduramycosis or Madura foot. Mycetoma occurs worldwide.
  • Etiology:  It can be divided into three types, eumycetomas, actinomycetomas and botryomycosis.

Pathogenesis:-

  • Triad of symptoms: Infection follows traumatic inoculation of the organism into the subcutaneous tissue from soil or vegetable sources, usually on thorns or splinters and results in tumefactions, deformities and draining sinuses discharging fungal colonies called grains or granules (triad of symptoms). 
  • Subcutaneous tissues of the feet, lower extremities, hands, and exposed areas are most often involved.
  • Grains: Within host tissues the organisms develop to form compacted colonies (grains) 0.5–2 mm in diameter, the color of which depends on the organism responsible.

Laboratory Diagnosis

  • A. Direct Examination: The presence of grains in pus collected from draining sinuses or in biopsy material is diagnostic.
  • B. Culture Samples should also be cultured, at both 25–30°C and 37°C, on brain-heart infusion agar or blood agar for actinomycetes and on Sabouraud agar (without cycloheximide) for fungi.

Treatment:-

The management of eumycetoma is difficult, involving surgical debridement or excision and chemotherapy. Actinomycetoma responds well to rifampicin in combination with sulfonamides or cotrimoxazole.

questions.text: A patient with a fungal infection was started on amphotericin B. Within a few days he started complaining about decreased urine output. On examination, it revealed muddy brown casts in urine. What could be the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Muddy brown casts are seen in acute tubular necrosis which is a type of intrinsic renal failure. Epithelial casts and granular casts can also be seen in acute tubular necrosis.

Casts in Urine

  • Hyaline cast: Normal physiological conditions, fever, exercise, prerenal failure
  • RBC cast: Glomerular injury
  • WBC cast: Pyelonephritis, interstitial nephritis
  • Muddy-brown granular cast: Acute tubular necrosis
  • Broad cast: Chronic renal failure

Related Pearl: Urinary Casts and Their Significance

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient came with complaints of excessive lacrimation. Ocular examination showed an abnormality similar to what is shown below. Which of the following organism is likely to cause this condition?
questions.solution:
The above image shows Herbert's pits. This finding is seen in trachoma which is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis, more specifically the TRIC (trachoma inclusion conjunctivitis) serovars A, B, Ba, C. 

Trachoma is a form of chronic infective conjunctivitis and is one of the leading causes of blindness. It has an ‘active’ inflammatory stage and a ‘cicatricial’ chronic stage.

The active inflammatory stage is more prevalent in children and presents with nonspecific symptoms of ocular irritation, foreign body sensation, and discharge (often mild symptoms). Examination findings at this stage show: 

  • Conjunctival follicles containung Leber cells (multinucleated lymphocytes)
  • corneal Herbert's follicles (similar to conjunctival follicles)

Cicatricial chronic stage is seen in middle age. And when the chronic infection with sequelae sets in, the patient complains of pain, lacrimation, photophobia and later blurring, and finally loss of vision. Conjunctiva shows concretions (whitish deposits of inspissated mucus in depressions called glands of Henle). Corneal signs include: 

  • Herbert pits (pitted scars in the limbal which are remnants of healed of Herbert follicles)
  • corneal opacity is seen in later stages.

There can be associated trichiasis ( when at least one eyelash rubs the eyeball) and entropion.

At present WHO grading with `FISTO’ is in use.

Trachoma is treated according to the WHO classification using the SAFE strategy (Surgery, Antibiotics, Facial hygiene, and Environmental improvement). Azithromycin is the antibiotic of choice, and surgery involves the correction of trichiasis and entropion. In case of significant corneal scarring, penetrating keratoplasty is done.

Related Pearl: WHO Programme to Control Trachoma: SAFE Strategy

  • S—Surgery: Trichiasis and entropion correction surgery → 3° prevention.
  • A—Antibiotics: Oral azithromycin, topical 1% tetracycline, topical 1% azithromycin → 2° prevention
  • F—Facial hygiene → 1° prevention.
  • E—Environmental cleanliness → primordial prevention

Strategy depends on the prevalence of trachoma follicle in children (1–9 yrs)

  • Prevalence >10% → SAFE
  • 5 to 10% → FE
  • < 5% → NO intervention

Related Pearl: WHO classification of trachoma (FISTO)

WHO grading of trachoma

  • TF = trachomatous inflammation (follicular): five or more follicles (>0.5 mm) on the superior tarsal conjunctiva.
  • TI = trachomatous inflammation (intense): diffuse involvement of the tarsal conjunctiva, obscuring 50% or more of the normal deep tarsal vessels; papillae are present
  • TS = trachomatous conjunctival scarring: easily visible fibrous white tarsal bands
  • TT = trachomatous trichiasis: at least one lash touching the globe
  • CO = corneal opacity sufficient to blur details of at least part of the pupillary margin

questions.text: A 10 year old girl has just started menstruating. She will be provided with a pack of sanitary napkins by the ASHA in her village under:
questions.solution:
The girl will be provided with a pack of 6 sanitary napkins for 6 Rupees (called Freedays) by the ASHA under the Menstrual Hygiene Scheme which is a part of the Rashtriya Kishor Swasthya Karyakram (RKSK).

Rashtriya Kishor Swasthya Karyakram:

  • Development of adolescent population (10-19 years).
  • Weekly Iron and Folic Acid supplementation (60mg Fe + 500 mcg Folic Acid)
  • Menstrual hygiene: A pack of 6 sanitary napkins for 6 Rupees (called Freedays) by the ASHA
  • It also includes enhancement of mental health and prevention of substance abuse and violence.

The LAQSHYA initiative is for improving the quality of labour rooms and providing Respectful Maternity Care. It also includes expanding the obstetric ICUs at government medical college hospitals.

The Pradhan Mantri Surakshit Matritva Abhiyaan (PMSMA) ensures quality antenatal care so that a pregnant woman receives at least 1 check up in her 2nd or 3rd trimester by a doctor in the PMSMA clinic, on the 9th of every month.

Recent update: Department of Pharmaceuticals under ministry of Chemicals and Fertilizers has recently launched ‘Suvidha’ 100% Oxo-biodegradable Sanitary Napkin, under the Pradhan Mantri Bhartiya Janaushadhi Pariyojana (PMBJP) on 28-05-2018 (World mentrual hygiene day). ‘Swachhta, Swasthya and Suvidha’ will be available for Rs.1 per pad over 3200 Janaushadhi Kendra for the underprivileged women of India.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presents to the emergency department with violent shaking of arms and legs for the past 15 minutes. The patient’s relatives report that he is a known epileptic and was prescribed Valproate 3 years back after a similar episode. He has not taken any medication for the past 48 hrs. Which drug would you administer to him now?
questions.solution:
This scenario is suggestive of status epilepticus and lorazepam should be administered immediately.

Status epilepticus refers to continuous seizures typically more than 5 min, or repetitive, discrete seizures without regaining consciousness in between the seizures. It is an emergency and must be treated immediately

In any patient with an ongoing seizure, the first drug used is a benzodiazepine like lorazepam or diazepam. An IV antiseizure drug is added later on. The management of status epilepticus is shown below.

questions.text: A 45 year old female presented with abnormal uterine bleeding. The images below shows transverse section of uterus and histology of the specimen. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The gross specimen shows thickened myometrium with spongy, trabeculated surface, with focal areas of haemorrhage. The histopathology specimen shows endometrial glands and the surrounding stroma within the uterine myometrium. These findings are suggestive of adenomyosis.

Adenomyosis is a condition caused by the ingrowth of the endometrial tissue into the uterine wall. The presence of endometrial glands and stroma with the uterine myometrium eventually leads to the thickening of the uterine wall.

Women present with menorrhagia, progressively increasing dysmenorrhea, pelvic discomfort, backache and dyspareunia. Clinical examination revealinf a painful, symmetrical enlargementy of the uterus should suggest adenomyosis. On bimanual examination, the uterus is softened and tender. This is known as Halban's sign. 

TVS findings include the salt-and-pepper appearance of the myometrium and the presence of sub-endometrial striations producing the Venetian blind appearance (shown in the image below). 

MRI can also be done for diagnosis. However, the only definitive mode of diagnosis is histopathological examination.

Since most women affected by the condition are past the childbearing age, total hysterectomy is the treatment of choice. Localized excision/Levonorgestrel containing IUCD can be tried in younger women.

questions.text: In the given graph of a normal menstrual cycle, the mark 'X' represents levels of which of the following hormones?
questions.solution:
In the given menstrual cycle graph, the mark 'X' represents levels of progesterone.

The menstrual cycle consists of three phases: The proliferative phase, the secretory phase, and the menstrual phase.

The proliferative phase is estrogen-dominant and lasts from the end of menstruation to ovulation. It results in the proliferation of endometrial glands and thickened endometrium.

The secretory or progestational phase is progesterone dominant which converts the thickened, estrogen-primed endometrium to a richly vascularized, glycogen-filled tissue for early nourishment of a developing embryo. If fertilization and implantation do not occur, the corpus luteum degenerates and a new follicular phase and menstrual phase begin again.

The menstrual phase is characterized by the discharge of blood and endometrial debris from the vagina due to the withdrawal of progesterone and the degeneration of the corpus luteum (CL).

questions.text: Which of the following drugs will not be useful in the management of a patient with acne?
questions.solution:
All the above agents are useful in the treatment of acne except topical fluocinolone (topical steroid). Corticosteroids may provoke an acneform reaction irrespective of their route of administration.

Acne is a chronic inflammatory disease of the pilosebaceous unit. It commonly presents in the age group of 10-13 years in both genders. It can vary from very mild comedonal acne to severe aggressive pustular acne. These eventually may lead to scarring, post-inflammatory macules, and pigment changes.

Acne results from the combination of:

  • Increased sebaceous gland activity under the influence of androgens - oily skin
  • Abnormal follicular differentiation with increased keratinization- hyper cornification of the duct due to increased IL-1
  • Microbial hyper colonization of the follicular canal leading to its inflammation.

Management-

  • Mild comedonal acne is treated with a topical retinoid. Mild papular and pustular acne is treated with topical retinoids and topical antibiotics.
  • Moderate papular/pustular acne and moderate nodular acne are treated with oral antibiotic + topical retinoid with or without benzoyl peroxide. 
  • Severe nodular and conglobate acne is treated with oral isotretinoin.

Tazarotene is a retinoid which is available for the treatment of comedonal and severe acne.

Related Pearl: Global Alliance Algorithm for Acne Treatment

Global Alliance Algorithm for Acne Treatment

Image: Global Alliance Algorithm for Improving Outcomes in acne

BPO - Benzoyl peroxide

Related Pearl: Key Chart to help differentiate lesions on face

Key Chart to help Differentiate Lesions on face

 

The following images show the findings in -

  • Melasma

 

  • Rosacea

 

  • Butterfly-shaped malar rash in SLE 

 

  • Acne

 

  • Nevus of Ota

 

  • Portwine stain

 

  • Infantile hemangioma

questions.text: Calculate maintenance dose for a drug M with 100% oral bioavailability which needs a target concentration of 2 mg/L and clearance of 20L/hr and dosed QID.
questions.solution:
Maintenance dose= Cp*CL*Dosing interval/F

  • Target plasma concentration (Cp) = 2 mg/L
  • Clearance (CL) = 20L/hr
  • Assuming dosing interval for QID = every 6th hour = 6* (since the clearance stated is per hour)
  • Bioavailability (100%) = F= 1

Maintenance dose = 2 * 20 *6/ 1 = 240 mg 

*Note: QID corresponds to 4 times a day.Hence, the dosing interval is 24/4 = 6 hours.

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida presents with painless vaginal bleeding in the first trimester. On examination, the cervical os is open and uterine size is normal. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with an open cervical os is suggestive of an inevitable abortion. 

It is the clinical type of abortion where the changes have progressed to a state where continuation of pregnancy is impossible. The patient presents with a bloody vaginal discharge or bleeding and abdominal pain. Examination reveals dilated internal os of the cervix through which the products of conception are felt. 

Management includes accelerating the process of expulsion. This is done using oxytocin or dilatation and evacuation followed by curettage of the uterine cavity by blunt curette.

Related Pearl: Clinical classification of Spontaneous Abortion

Clinical type Description/ Clinical picture Cervical os  USG
Threatened 

bloody vaginal discharge or bleeding appears through a closed cervical os.

 Closed 

The gestational sac/ pseudo-gestational sac
Inevitable 

A gush of vaginal fluid, bleeding, cramping, or fever.

 Gross rupture of the membranes along with cervical dilatation Low lying sac with oligohydramnios
Incomplete 

Bleeding that follows partial or complete placental separation and dilation of the cervical os.

The expulsion of the entire pregnancy has completed before the woman presents to the hospital

A history of heavy bleeding, cramping, and passage of tissue or a fetus is common

Minimally thickened endometrium without a gestational sac
Missed /early pregnancy failure or loss

Dead products of conception that were retained for days, weeks or even months in the uterus with a closed cervical os

Defined currently based on results of serial serum β-hCG assays and transvaginal sonography

 Cervical os closed

A large anechoic sac consistent with an anembryonic gestation
Septic 

1 to 2 percent of women with threatened or incomplete miscarriage develops a pelvic infection and sepsis syndrome
