questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of bias in a case-control study?
questions.solution:
Hawthorne bias is not seen in case-control studies. This bias occurs when the subjects change their attitude/ actions while under observation. This distorts the results of the cohort or experimental studies.

The bias that are seen in the case-control study are:

  1. Confounding
  2. Recall bias
  3. Selection bias
  4. Berkesonian bias
  5. Interviewer's bias

Related Pearl: Bias in Epidemiological Studies

  • Bias due to confounding: It can be removed by matching.
  • Memory or recall bias as cases and controls may not be able to recall specifics about their history.
  • Selection bias: Cases and controls may not be representative of the population or there may be systematic differences between both.
  • Berkesonian bias: This type of selection bias occurs in hospital cases and controls as the admission rates for people with different diseases may differ.
  • Interviewer’s bias: If the interviewer knows the hypothesis and who the cases are, he/she may interview the cases more thoroughly than the controls. It can be eliminated by double blinding.
  • Neyman’s bias or prevalence-incidence bias: It is due to the selective survival in prevalent cases usually seen in fatal diseases. For example, a case-control study is carried out to study the relation between tobacco smoking and acute myocardial infarction (AMI), being cases interviewed one week after the coronary attack. If smoker patients with AMI die more frequently, the living cases will show lower frequency of smoking, undervaluing the association between smoking and AMI. It has been shown that the bias occurs only if the risk factor influences mortality from the disease being studied.

questions.text: A 24-year-old patient presents with a high-grade fever, headache, and weakness for 5 days. He gives a history of blood transfusion 4 months back. The microscopic examination of the thin blood smear is given below. What is the most probable causative agent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the microscopy showing Maltese crosses or tetrads are suggestive of babesiosis caused by Babesia microti.

The definitive host for babesia are ixodid ticks whereas the intermediate host is man.

On microscopic examination, babesia trophozoites appear as intraerythrocytic round or pyriform or ring form. The ring form is the most common and it lacks the central hemozoin deposit which differentiates it from P. falciparum.

Other distinguishing features are the absence of schizonts and gametocytes and the presence of tetrads/Maltese crosses, which are pathognomic of B. microti or B. duncani.

The below image shows Maltese cross appearance of Babesia microti.

Plasmodium falciparum and Plasmodium malariae cause malaria, presenting as high-grade fever and weakness but the fevers follow a pattern with falciparum being a tertian fever recurring every 3 days and malariae being a quartan occurring every four days.

Erythrocytes in P. falciparum initially will show a marginal ring form known as accole. Binucleate rings (double chromatin) resembling stereo headphones are commonly seen. The infected erythrocyte is normal in size and shows a few brick-red dots known as Maurer's cleft. Basophilic stippling also can be noted. 

The blood smear in P. falciparum will show multiple ring forms in the erythrocytes as shown below.

. 

Plasmodium malariae targets old erythrocytes. The peripheral blood contains band forms and spherical gametocytes similar to that seen in P. vivax, but smaller

Plasmodium knowlesi is known to cause infection in rhesus monkeys. Although they can cause experimental infection in humans and other primates, there is no evidence of natural infections

questions.text: Stimulation of which of the following regions promotes a 'sense of reward' in human beings?
questions.solution:
Major reward centers are located along the course of the medial forebrain bundle, especially in the lateral and ventromedial nuclei of the hypothalamus.

It is interesting to note that in the lateral nucleus of hypothalamus, weak stimulus produces a sense of pleasure whereas a strong stimulus produces rage. This phenomenon occurs in many areas where a weak stimulus produces a sense of reward while stronger ones produce a sense of punishment.

questions.text: You are asked to perform a quick bedside scoring test to assess the patient's risk of developing sepsis. It utilizes 3 components. Which of the following is not considered as a component while performing this test?
questions.solution:
The bedside scoring test that utilizes 3 components to assess the patient's risk of developing sepsis is the qSOFA (quick sequential organ failure assessment) score. The quick sequential organ failure assessment (qSOFA) scoring system does not rely on the heart rate.

It is a bedside scoring system that identifies patients who are at risk of poor outcomes from sepsis, without reliance upon laboratory or imaging studies. It uses three criteria.

  • Low blood pressure: SBP≤100 mmHg
  • High respiratory rate: ≥22 breaths per min
  • Altered mental status

The qSOFA suggests potentially life-threatening sepsis when at least two of the parameters are met.

The primary method to evaluate the risk of organ dysfunction (sepsis) in patients with suspected infection is by determining the  sequential (sepsis-related) organ failure assessment (SOFA) score; which includes an assessment of:

  • Circulation - Systolic BP & need for vasopressors; platelet count
  • Respiration - PaO2/FiO2 & need for mechanical ventilation
  • Mentation - Glasgow coma score (GCS)
  • Hepatic function - Bilirubin
  • Renal function - Creatinine

Organ dysfunction is identified by a SOFA score of ≥ 2

The SOFA score is limited by its requirement of multiple laboratory tests which makes it complex and time-consuming. In order to simplify the scoring process, the "Sepsis - 3" task force recommended the quick sepsis-related organ dysfunction assessment "qSOFA" score.

questions.text: Source of progesterone during normal menstrual cycle______
questions.solution: Progesterone is a C21 steroid secreted by the corpus luteum, the placenta, and (in small amounts) the fol­licle.

questions.text: Parents of a child with febrile seizures are concerned about the relapse, complications, and treatment of this condition. All of the following are true regarding the risks and management of this case, except:

choices.text: Antipyretics do not reduce the risk of a recurrent febrile seizure
Clobazam or clonazepam help reduce recurrence of febrile seizures
Anti-epileptic therapy can decrease the risk of future epilepsy
Pre-existing neurodevelopmental abnormality increases the risk of febrile seizures

questions.solution:
All of the above statements are true, except for option C: Antiepileptic therapy can decrease the risk of future epilepsy. The risk of future epilepsy does not change with or without antiepileptic therapy.

Febrile seizures are seizures that:

  • Occur between the age of 6 months and 5 years
  • Occur at a temperature of 38°C (100.4°F) or higher
  • Are not due to any CNS infection or any metabolic imbalance
  • Occur without a history of prior afebrile seizures
  • Occur with no post-ictal neurological deficit.

Antipyretics do not reduce the risk of recurrent febrile seizures.

Types of febrile seizures:

Simple febrile seizures Complex (atypical) febrile seizures
Occurs within 24 hours of the onset of fever Can occur at any time during a fever
 Generalized seizures Focal seizures
Duration is <15 min Prolonged
No recurrence within 24 hrs of seizures Recurrent
Chances of going into epilepsy 1% Chances of going into epilepsy are 6%

Investigations:

  • In first episode of febrile seizure, lumbar puncture is indicated in cases of clinically suspected meningitis.
  • EEG and neuroimaging are advised for children with atypical febrile seizures.

Treatment:

An acute episode of seizure is terminated by intravenous lorazepam or midazolam. Antipyretics and proper hydration.

Prophylaxis:

  • In children with risk factors for recurrence or those with frequent recurrences (≥3 in 6 months or ≥4 in one year),give intermittent prophylaxis for 3 days during the fever episode to reduces recurrences.

Note:

  • Antipyretics can decrease the discomfort of the child but do not reduce the risk of having a recurrent febrile seizure.
  • Intermittent oral nitrazepam, clobazam, and clonazepam help reduce but do not eliminate, the risks of recurrence of febrile seizures.
  • The risk of future epilepsy does not change with or without antiepileptic therapy.
  • Pre-existing neurodevelopmental abnormality increases the risk of febrile seizures.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with primary hyperoxaluria is most likely to have a deficiency of which of the following amino acids?
questions.solution:
A patient diagnosed with primary hyperoxaluria is most likely to have a glycine deficiency.

The defect in primary hyperoxaluria type I is the deficiency of the alanine glyoxalate aminotransferase in liver peroxisomes causing failure to catabolize glyoxylate formed by the deamination of glycine. This leads to a gross overproduction of oxalate, leading to the formation of oxalate stones and subsequent kidney damage.

The FDA recently approved Lumasiran, RNA interference therapeutic targeting glycolate oxidase as the first treatment for primary hyperoxaluria type 1 (PH1), a rare genetic disorder.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis from the image given below ?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis from the above image is pterygium. 

Pterygium:

It is a subconjunctival fibrovascular tissue encroaching the cornea.

It is a degenerative condition of the sub-conjunctival tissue.

It is a connective tissue disorder and is never inflammatory. 

It is made up of three parts:

  • a "cap" (an avascular halo-like zone at the advancing edge),
  • a head,
  • a body.

Occurs due to exposure to radiation: UV-B.

The most common site is nasal.

Clinical features:

  • Astigmatism with the rule, usually
  • Stocker's line - deposition of iron on the advancing edge.
  • Fuchs islets are small, discrete, whitish flecks consisting of clusters of pterygial epithelial cells, often present at the advancing edge.

Treatment: Excision

To prevent recurrence:

Mitomycin C or 5 fluorouracil

  • Auto-grafting: Conjunctival limbal autograft (CLAG) from the superior limbal conjunctiva is the best method.
  • Bare sclera technique has high recurrence rate of 30 to 80%.
  • PERFECT surgery (Pterygium Extended Removal Followed by Extended Conjunctival Transplant) has zero rate of recurrence.

questions.text: Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) is secreted by:
questions.solution:
Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) is secreted by the syncytiotrophoblast.

hCG is a glycoprotein, produced by the syncytiotrophoblast of the placenta and secreted into the blood of both mother and fetus. It can be detected in the maternal serum as early as 7–9 days postfertilization, with the help of radioimmunoassay. hCG concentrations double approximately every 2 days in the 1st trimester

Functions of hCG:

  • Stimulates the secretion of progesterone by the corpus luteum: Rescue and maintenance of the corpus luteum till 6 weeks of pregnancy(major biological function of hCG).
  • Stimulate Leydig cells of the male fetus to produce testosterone.
  • Stimulates both adrenal and placental steroidogenesis.
  • Stimulates the maternal thyroid because of its thyrotropic activity.
  • Promotes secretion of relaxin from the corpus luteum.

High levels of hCG for that particular gestational age are due to incorrect dating of pregnancy(most common), multiple pregnancies, hydatidiform mole or choriocarcinoma, and in pregnancy with a trisomy 21 fetus (Down’s syndrome). It is low in cases of incorrect dating of pregnancy, ectopic pregnancy or abortion.

The placenta consists of:

  • An inner mononuclear cellular layer called cytotrophoblast or Langhans layer is made of Langhans cells.
  • An outer layer of a multinucleated syncytium called syncytiotrophoblast.

The below image shows a chorionic plate (fetal component) consisting of (1) amnion, (2) extraembryonic somatic mesoderm, (3) cytotrophoblast, and (4) syncytiotrophoblast. 

Related Pearl: Beta hCG in pregnancy

The pattern of beta hCG :

First detectable in plasma 7 to 9 days post-LH surge
          ⇓
Doubles every 2 days
          ⇓
Peaks at 8 to 10 weeks of gestation(~100 IU/mL)
          ⇓
Begins to decline at 10 to 12 weeks
          ⇓
Plateau at 16 weeks till term
 
  • Higher maternal plasma hCG levels- Multifetal pregnancy, erythroblastosis fetalis, gestational trophoblastic disease, Down syndrome.
  • Lower hCG plasma levels -early pregnancy wastage and ectopic pregnancy.

questions.text: By what age is the milestone shown in the image typically attained?
questions.solution:
The milestone shown in the image is a mature pincer grasp, which is seen at the age of 12 months. It is identified as a mature pincer grasp as the object is secured between the opposed thumb and the tip of the index finger.

Developmental progression of the grasp:

  • At 6 months, the infant reaches and holds a larger object in a crude manner using the ulnar aspect of his hand (Ulnar palmar grasp). At 8-9 months, the object is grasped by the radial side of the palm (radial palmar grasp).
  • At 9 months, the immature pincer grasp develops. The object is secured between the adducted thumb and the extended index finger.
  • At 12 months, the mature pincer grasp develops. The object is secured between the opposed thumb and the tip of the index finger.

Related Pearl: Fine motor milestones

 
Age Milestone
4 months Reaches out for objects with both hands (Bidextrous reach)
6 months
Reaches out for objects with one hand (Unidextrous reach) and transfers objects
9 months Immature pincer grasp
12 months Mature pincer grasp
15 months Imitates scribbling and builds a tower of 2 blocks
18 months Scribbles and builds a tower of 3 blocks
2 years Builds a tower of 6 blocks
3 years Builds a tower of 9 blocks and copies a circle
4 years Builds a bridge with blocks and copies a cross
5 years Copies a triangle and builds a gate with blocks

questions.text:
A young patient presents with a history of increased urinary frequency, nocturia, and excessive thirst. Her laboratory investigations are given below. Brain MRI shows the absence of a bright spot in the pituitary. Her past medical history includes an episode of viral encephalitis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Urine osmolarity <300 mOsm/L
Urine output >50 ml/kg/day
Random blood glucose 150 mg/dl
Antidiuretic hormone level (ADH) Decreased
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the lab results indicating increased urine output with low urine osmolarity and decreased ADH levels suggest a diagnosis of central diabetes insipidus. 

Diabetes insipidus can be of two types - central or peripheral (nephrogenic). Central DI occurs due to a deficiency of ADH. 

Central diabetes insipidus (DI) is a disorder of the posterior pituitary. It is characterized by decreased ADH leading to large volumes of urine production. Patients present with excessive thirst, nocturia, and urinary frequency. The urine is dilute with an osmolarity of < 300 mOsm/L. The 24-hour urine volume is >40 ml/kg and the basal plasma ADH is <1 pg/ml.

Central DI occurs due to damage to the neurohypophysis in the posterior pituitary. It can be congenital or acquired. In this patient, it is likely that her prior episode of viral encephalitis has led to the development of DI. 

Central DI can be treated with desmopressin, an ADH analog. Nephrogenic DI requires treatment with a thiazide diuretic, amiloride, a low sodium diet, and indomethacin. 

Other options:

Option A: In nephrogenic DI, ADH levels may be normal or increased because the kidney has become resistant to its effects. The two can be differentiated by the water deprivation test. (Option A)

Option B - Primary polydipsia would have a bright spot on the brain MRI. Primary polydipsia presents with an excessive thirst that reduces the serum osmolarity. There is a compensatory increase in free water excretion that offsets the increased intake to maintain a normal serum sodium level. 

Option D - Syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion would have increased ADH secretion, concentrated urine, and hyponatremia. 

Related Pearl: Causes of Central Diabetes insipidus

  • Neoplasms: 
    • Pituitary adenomas (most common)
    • Meningioma
    • Metastasis from lung and breast cancers
  • Infiltrative: 
    • Sarcoidosis
    • Langerhans cell histiocytosis
  • Genetic: 
    • Wolfram syndrome
    • Hand-Schuller-Christian disease 
  • Infections: 
    • Chronic meningitis
    • Viral encephalitis
    • Toxoplasmosis
  •  Inflammatory:
    • Granulomatosis with polyangiitis
    • Lupus erythematosus
    • Scleroderma
  •  Vascular:
    • Sheehan’s syndrome
    • Aneurysm (internal carotid)
  • Head injury (closed and penetrating) including pituitary surgery
  • Snakebite
  • Lymphocytic hypophysitis

 

Related Pearl: Water Deprivation test in Diabetes Insipidus

Procedure: Start the test at 4 am by checking the baseline urine osmolality. Deprive the patient of water till 12 pm (8 hours), and then re-check urine osmolality. 

  Urine osmolality before water deprivation Urine osmolality after water deprivation Urine osmolality after desmopressin administration
Normal  Normal  Increases No change
Central DI Low No change >50% increase from baseline
Nephrogenic DI Low No change <10% increase from baseline
Primary polydipsia Low Increases No change


Note: Normal urine osmolality- 500-850 mOsm/L

questions.text: The vascular lesion shown below is characteristic of all of the following except:
questions.solution:
The given image shows hyaline arteriosclerosis. It is not a characteristic lesion of severe hypertension.  

Hyaline arteriosclerosis occurs in the following conditions:

  • Elderly patients who are normotensive
  • Benign hypertension- due to chronic hemodynamic stresses
  • Diabetes mellitus- due to hyperglycemia-induced endothelial dysfunction. Hyaline arteriosclerosis is a common feature of diabetic microangiopathy.

The characteristic vascular lesion of severe hypertension is hyperplastic arteriosclerosis as seen in the image below.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents with headache, vomiting, and altered sensorium for the past 6 hours. His wife gives a history of falling in the bathroom and hitting his head 4 weeks ago. On evaluation, the following funduscopic findings are noted. What will be your provisional diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and fundus examination are most probably suggestive of chronic subdural hematoma(SDH). The fundoscopic image shows dilated veins with a blurred disc margin which is suggestive of papilledema.

Chronic SDH is a common cause of acute neurological deterioration in older adults. Due to ageing-related cerebral atrophy, the cortical–dural bridging veins are stretched and vulnerable to rupture. It leads to a haematoma that can expand over days or weeks by osmosis, ultimately producing symptoms of raised ICP or focal deficits. Usually, there is a history of recent head trauma. Antiplatelet or anticoagulant medication can cause SDH with trivial impacts. Patients may present with headaches, seizures, confusion, contralateral hemiparesis, or coma. 

Acute hematomas are bright white (hyperdense) on CT scan for approximately 3 days, after which they fade to isodensity with the brain, and then to hypodensity after 2 to 3 weeks. A chronic SDH will be nearly as dark as CSF on CT.

A chronic SDH >1 cm or any symptomatic SDH should be surgically drained.

Nomenclature

Time

Acute  SDH

<3 days

Subacute SDH

4–21 days

Chronic SDH

> 21 days

 

Related Pearl: Intracranial haemorrhage

questions.text: You are posted as a medical officer in a rural Health and Wellness Center - Primary Health Center (HWC-PHC). According to the IPHS 2022 guidelines, which of the following is incorrect regarding the essential manpower required for this PHC?
questions.solution:
Specialists like ophthalmologists are not included as essential manpower for a PHC. Specialists for medicine, obstetrics & gynecology, pediatrics, ophthalmology, etc. are essential manpower included under polyclinics.

According to the Indian Public Health Standards (IPHS) 2022 guidelines, a total of 12 staff is considered essential manpower for a PHC. They include 1 Medical Officer (MBBS), 2 staff nurses, 1 pharmacist, 1 health worker female/ANM, 1 health worker/health assistant (male), 1 health assistant (female)/lady health visitor, 1 laboratory technician, 1 data entry operator, 1 dresser, 1 accountant, and 1 sanitation staff. 

Related Pearl: Primary Health Centres-PHC

  • HWC-PHCs: Population of 30000 in plains, 20000 in hilly/tribal areas
  • Urban HWC-PHCs: Population of 50000
  • Specialist UPHC/Polyclinic (urban): Population of 2.5- 3 lakh

PHC’s and UPHC’s can be further extended to 24X7 PHC’s/UPHC’s

Bed distribution: 

HWC-PHC HWC-UPHC 24X7 HWC-PHC/UPHC
Essential: 2 beds Essential: 2 daycare beds Essential: 6 beds
Desirable: 4 beds Desirable: 4 daycare beds Desirable: 4 beds

The twelve packages envisaged under Comprehensive Primary Healthcare services (CPHC): 

  1. Care in Pregnancy and Childbirth 
  2. Neonatal and Infant Health Care Services
  3. Childhood and Adolescent Health Care Services
  4. Family Planning, Contraceptive Services, and other Reproductive Health Care Services
  5. Management of Communicable Diseases: National Health Programmes
  6. General Out-patient Care for Acute Simple Illnesses and Minor Ailments
  7. Screening, Prevention, Control and Management of Non-communicable Diseases
  8. Care for Common Ophthalmic and ENT Problems
  9. Basic Oral Health Care
  10. Elderly and Palliative Health Care Services
  11. Emergency Medical Services including Burns and Trauma
  12. Screening and Basic Management of Mental Health Ailments.

IPHS 2022 normal for manpower at PHC:

Essential manpower for:

1) PHC: 12   2) UPHC: 16   3) Polyclinic: 22   4) 24x7 PHC: 23   5) 24X7 UPHC: 27

questions.text: A female patient presents with nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, and loss of smell. On examination of the nose, she has roomy nasal cavities, foul-smelling discharge, and dry greenish crusts. She is also found to have merciful anosmia. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of merciful anosmia, foul-smelling discharge, and roomy nasal cavities, with dry greenish crusts, points to a diagnosis of atrophic rhinitis.

Atrophic rhinitis is a chronic inflammation of the nose characterized by atrophy of nasal mucosa and turbinate bones. The exact etiology of this condition is not known. It is more common in females and starts around puberty. 

Clinically patients present with nasal obstruction, foul odor, and merciful anosmia. Merciful anosmia is when the patient has marked anosmia and is unable to smell the foul odor coming from their nose.

On examination of the nose, greenish or greyish crusting of the nasal passage, pale nasal mucosa, atrophied nasal turbinates, and epistaxis following the removal of the crusts. The roomy nasal cavity is seen due to the resorption of bones of the turbinates.

Treatment:

  • Nasal irrigation - using warm saline or an alkaline solution composed of sodium bicarbonate 1 part, sodium biborate 1 part, and sodium chloride 2 parts in 280 mL of water
  • Local antibiotics - Kemicetine antiozaena solution containing chloromycetin, oestradiol, and vitamin D2. 
  • 25% glucose in glycerine, estradiol spray, systemic use of streptomycin, potassium iodide, and placental extract.
  • Surgical management:
    • Young's operation.
    • Modified young operation.
    • Narrowing of the nasal cavity can be done by submucosal injection of Teflon paste, or by insertion of fat, cartilage, or Teflon strips under the mucoperiosteum.

Other options:

Option B: Nasal polyps are non-neoplastic masses of the edematous nasal or sinus mucosa. Nasal polyps can be antrochoanal polyps or ethmoidal polyps. They present with a polypoid mass in the nose.

Option C: Allergic rhinitis is associated with inferior turbinate hypertrophy and can cause chronic nasal obstruction. It is characterized by watery nasal discharge, sneezing, and itching in the nose.

Option D: Foreign body nose is commonly seen in children. The child presents with unilateral, foul-smelling nasal discharge.

Related Pearl: Clinical Features of Atrophic Rhinitis

  • More common in females 
  • Usually starts at puberty
  • It is a bilateral condition
  • Symptoms:
    • Foul smell from the nose
    • Nasal obstruction in spite of roomy chambers due to large crusts filling nasal cavity
    • Epistaxis on removing of the crusts
    • Anosmia due to degeneration of nerve elements (merciful anosmia)
  • Signs:
    • Greenish or greyish black dry crusts covering the turbinates and septum
    • After removal of crusts, nasal cavities appear roomy with atrophy of turbinates
    • Nasal mucosa appears pale

questions.text: The organ of Rosenmuller is a remnant of the_______.
questions.solution:
The organ of Rosenmuller, also known as epoophoron, is a remnant of the mesonephric tubule in females.

The mesonephric tubules gives rise to the following structures and remnants:

  • Females: epoophoron and paroophoron
  • Males: efferent ductules (ductuli efferentes or vasa efferentia), lobules of the head of the epididymis, and paradidymis.

questions.text: Which of the following helps in bacterial adhesion?
questions.solution:
Fimbriae help in bacterial adhesion.

Fimbriae, also called pili are hair-like surface appendage that projects from the cell surface as straight filaments. Fimbriae are classified based on the function as ordinary pili and sex pili.

Functions of pili:

  • Adhesion of symbiotic and pathogenic bacteria to host cells.
  • They help in resistance to phagocytosis.
  • It is made up of antigenic pilin proteins that are responsible for the immune response.
  • Pili gives twitching motility to bacteria.
  • Sex pili help in bacterial conjugation through which transfer of genetic material occurs.

questions.text: A young man presents with intense pruritus and has painful, red streaks between his fingers and in the groin area. He states that the itchiness is worse at night. Other members of his family also present with similar complaints. A dermoscopy of his skin is shown below. Which of the following can be used for the treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing a magnified view of a burrowing trail are suggestive of scabies. 5% permethrin cream is used in the management of this patient.

Scabies is an ectoparasitic infestation caused in humans by the Sarcoptes scabiei var. hominis. The characteristic symptoms of a scabies infection include intense itching and superficial burrows. 

Burrow is the characteristic lesion of scabies. They present as slightly raised brownish tortuous lesions. It is created by the excavation of the adult mite in the epidermis. In most people, the trails of the burrowing mites are linear in the skin.

Typical locations of lesions are the finger webs, the flexor surfaces of the wrists, the elbows, the axillae, the buttocks and genitalia, and the breasts of women.

The treatment options are the topical application of 5% permethrin cream, 1% lindane lotion, benzyl benzoate, esdepalletrin (bioallethrin), crotamiton, and precipitated sulfur, and oral prescriptions like ivermectin.

All family members, even if asymptomatic need to be treated simultaneously for this condition to prevent reinfection and the clothing needs to be disinfected simultaneously.

Other options:

Option B: Oral albendazole is used in the treatment of larva currens and cutaneous larva migrans. They present as pruritic erythematous papules at the site of penetration of the hookworms with an erythematous serpiginous larva track.

The image below shows cutaneous larva migrans:

The image below shows larva currens:

Option D: Topical corticosteroids are used in certain cases of bed bugs. They present as pruritic maculopapular lesions with a visible hemorrhagic punctum in the center. Three or four lesions may be arranged in a line or a curve pattern which is called breakfast‐lunch‐dinner alignment. 

The image below shows bed bug bites:

Related Pearl: Difference between classic and neonatal scabies

  Classic scabies Neonatal scabies
Site of involvement Interdigital webs, trunk, genitals, flexors, sparing of palms and soles, and skin above neck Face, scalp, palm, and soles
Morphology of Lesion Papules, pustules, excoriation, eczematization, burrow Vesicles, pustules, bullae, erosions, and ulcerations
Burrows Present Usually absent

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of MEN2 syndrome?
questions.solution:
Pituitary adenoma is not a characteristic feature of the symptom complex of MEN2 and its variants, but it is observed in MEN1 syndrome.

Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia (MEN) refers to a group of inherited syndromes including various benign and malignant tumors of endocrine glands. There are four types - MEN 1-4. They have an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance and can also be sporadic.

Related Pearl: MEN 1 Syndrome Features

Chromosome 11q13 / MEN1 gene

Also known as Wermer’s syndrome

Characteristic tumors seen in:

  • Parathyroid adenoma – 90 % - Most common overall
  • Entero pancreatic tumors - Most common functioning tumor is gastrinoma (most common site is duodenum)
  • Pituitary adenoma – Most common is prolactinoma
  • Mnemonic – Par Pan Pit – in decreasing order of frequency

Associated tumors are:

  • Angiofibroma
  • Collagenomas
  • Adrenal cortical tumors
  • Lipoma
  • Neuroendocrine tumors - gastric, thymic, lungs
  • Meningioma
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Carcinoid tumors, usually of the foregut

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon

questions.text:
A patient with impaired RFTs was given a substance 'x' whose clearance is 20mL/min and the urinary concentration is 100mg/mL. If the urine flow is 2mL/min, calculate the plasma concentration of the substance 'x'.

RFT - Renal function test
questions.solution:
The calculated plasma concentration of the substance 'x' in the above patient is 10mg/mL.

It is calculated using the formula -

C = [U]x x V / [P]x 

Where,

  • C is the clearance (mL/min) = 20mL/min
  • [U]x is the urine concentration of substance x (mg/mL) = 100mg/mL
  • V is the urine flow rate (mL/min) = 2mL/min
  • [P]x is the plasma concentration of substance x (mg/ml)

The steps of calculation are shown in the image below -

questions.text: After how many days is the polymorphic rash of Varicella not contagious?
questions.solution:
Chicken pox or Varicella caused by Varicella zoster virus becomes non-contagious after the lesions have crusted.

  • Varicella zoster virus is an α Herpes virus (Human Herpes Virus 3).
  • Over half of primary infections occur before the age of 5 and 85% before puberty.
  • The lesions are polymorphic - present at different stages in each site.
  • In 2–4 days, a dry crust forms and soon separates, to leave a shallow pink depression which, in the absence of secondary infection, heals without scarring.
  • Most common complication is secondary bacterial infection.
  • Varicella confers lasting immunity and second attacks are uncommon.
  • In histopathology, keratinocytes show ballooning degeneration creating multinucleated giant cells called Tzanck cells.

Characteristics of rash of chicken pox

  • Superficial
  • Pleomorphic
  • Centripetal
  • Unilocular
  • Symmetrical
  • Spares palms and soles, affects flexor surfaces and axilla
  • Rapid evolution
  • Dew drop on Rose-petal appearance

questions.text: A 36-year-old farmer came to the clinic with cough, chest pain for one week, and fatigue for a month, and his Chest X-ray was taken which is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The chronic history, the frequent exposure to animals as he is a farmer, and the chest x-ray which shows a cystic lesion in the right lung are suggestive of Hydatid disease.

  • The causative organism of hydatid disease is Echinococcus granulosus and it belongs to the class cestodes.
  • It is a tape-like, segmented worm. It infects man accidentally, giving rise to hydatid cysts.
  • Dogs are the definitive hosts of E. granulosus.
  • Sheep are the usual intermediate hosts, but humans are accidental intermediate hosts. Humans are end-stage hosts of the parasite since there is no human to human transmission

The hydatid cyst wall consists of 3 layers:

  • Pericyst- the outer dense fibrous capsule that is formed as a result of host inflammatory response.
  • Ectocyst- the intermediate layer consisting of acellular, chitinous, laminated hyaline material.
  • Endocyst- the inner germinal layer that is cellular and consists of a number of nuclei embedded in protoplasmic mass and is extremely thin. It is the vital layer of the cyst and it is the site of asexual reproduction giving rise to brood capsules with scolices.

The clinical features of hydatid disease of the lung are breathlessness, cough, hemoptysis, and chest pain.

Treatment includes wedge resection or lobectomy and administration of albendazole.

Other options:

  • Asbestosis presents as pleural plaques, irregular opacities, ground-glass appearance particularly present at the lower lung fields. HRCT will show the presence of pleural plaque, subpleural curvilinear lines 5–10 mm in length that appears to be parallel to the pleura.
  • Silicosis is an occupational disease and is caused by exposure to silica. It is seen in people who work in mining, stone cutting, sandblasting, and quarrying. It presents as small rounded opacities in the upper lobe. There may be calcification of hilar lymph nodes which leads to the appearance of eggshell calcification. HRCT will show a characteristic crazy paving pattern.
  • Byssinosis is an occupational disease due to chronic exposure to cotton dust as in yarns of textile and rope-making industries. In the early stage of the disease, patients complain of occasional chest tightness towards the end of the first day of the workweek termed as monday chest tightness. As the day progress, the chest tightness may recur or persist throughout the week. Chest X-ray shows hyperlucency, diaphragmatic flattening, and emphysema. A chest CT demonstrates ground glass opacities largely distributed in then basal fashion with centrilobular nodules. 

 

Related Pearl: Indications and contraindications of puncture, aspiration, injection, and re-aspiration (PAIR) in hydatid cyst

Indications:

  • Relapse cyst, infected cyst, cyst >5 cm in different liver segments
  • Patients who refuse surgery or where surgery is contraindicated
  • Pregnant women, children < 3 years of age
  • WHO - type CE1 and type CE3a.

Contraindications:

  • Cysts in lung
  • Cysts communicating with bile duct
  • Cysts with multiple septae—honeycomb cysts
  • Inaccessible cysts
  • Hyperechogenic cysts
  • Calcified cysts

questions.text: The National Suicide Prevention Strategy aims to reduce suicide mortality by _______ in the country by 2030.
questions.solution:
The National Suicide Prevention Strategy (NSPS) aims to reduce suicide mortality by 10% in India by 2030. It is a multisectoral approach that will involve national and international government ministries, families, communities, and educational institutes to help prevent suicide.

India has a high burden of suicide. It is the leading cause of death among individuals between 15-29 years of age.

Epidemiology

  • Young and middle-aged adults between 18-45 years
  • Males more than females
  • Daily wage earners and people who earn <1,00,000 per annum
  • Individuals with family issues and illnesses

Hanging and poisoning were the most common methods of suicide. It accounts for >3/4th of all suicides.

Risk factors for suicide

  • Psychiatric illnesses- Depression, BPD, schizophrenia, and anxiety disorders
  • Alcohol and other substance abuse disorders
  • Major physical illness
  • Job or financial loss
  • Relationship or social loss
  • Domestic violence or abuse
  • Lack of social support 
  • The stigma associated with help-seeking behavior of mental disorders
  • Lack of social support and sense of isolation.

In the past 3 years, the suicide rate in India has increased from 10.2 to 11.3 per lakh population.i.e. 1 in 3 Women & 1 in 4 Men dying from suicide worlwide, is from India. In order to address this MOHFW has recently rolled out the first National Suicide Prevention Strategy, formulated in accordance with WHO's South East Asian regional strategy on suicide prevention.

questions.text: According to the CEAP classification, what will be the C stage in this patient?
questions.solution:
The image above shows dilated, tortuous veins of the lower limb or varicose veins, and is classified as C2 according to the CEAP classification for chronic venous disorders. 

According to the CEAP (Clinical-Etiology-Anatomy-Pathophysiology) classification, the clinical classification of venous disease is as follows: For clinical classification:

  • C0: no signs of venous disease
  • C1: telangiectasia or reticular veins
  • C2: varicose veins
  • C3: edema
  • C4a: pigmentation or eczema (including malleolar flare)
  • C4b: lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche.  Lipodermatosclerosis (LDS) refers to chronic inflammation and fibrosis of the skin and subcutaneous tissues. This is seen as a tight, contracted, 'woody leg' on examination. Atrophie blanche refers to localized areas of white, atrophic skin surrounded by telangiectasia and pigmentation.
  • C5: healed venous ulcer
  • C6: active venous ulcer

Each clinical class is further characterized depending on whether the patient is symptomatic (S) or asymptomatic (A).

  • Image A - tortuous dilated veins - C2
  • Image B - Atrophie blanche - C4b
  • Image C - fan-shaped telangiectasia - C4c
  • Image D -  venous ulcer with active crusts - healing venous ulcer - C5.

 

The images below show C5 and C6 - healed and active venous ulcers respectively.

Varicose veins refer to a condition in which there is tortuous dilatation of subcutaneous veins due to venous insufficiency. Patients complain of a sensation of heaviness, burning, and aching over the affected area or whole limb, that increases throughout the day or on prolonged standing. Compression and elevation relieve the symptoms.

Diagnosis is mainly using duplex ultrasound. MR venography or intravenous ultrasound(IVUS) may be used occasionally.

Treatment is achieved using modalities such as compression, laser ablation, endothermal ablation, radiofrequency ablation, endovenous glue, ultrasound-guided foam sclerotherapy, open surgery, etc.

Related Pearl: Classification of Chronic Lower Extremity Venous Disease

CEAP (Clinical-Etiology-Anatomy-Pathophysiology)

Clinical classification (C)*

C0

No visible or palpable signs of venous disease

C1

Telangiectases or reticular veins

C2

C2r

Varicose veins

Recurrent varicose veins

C3

Edema

C4

Changes in skin and subcutaneous tissue secondary

to chronic venous disease

C4a-Pigmentation or eczema

C4b-Lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche

C4c-Corona phlebectatica

C5

Healed ulcer

C6

C6r

Active ulcer

Recurrent active venous ulcer

Etiological classification (E)

Ec

Congenital (Klippel-Trenaunay syndrome)

Ep

Primary

Es

Secondary (postthrombotic syndrome, trauma)

En

No venous cause identified

Anatomic classification (A)

As

Superficial

Ad

Deep

Ap

Perforator

An

No venous location identified

Patho-physiologic classification (P)

Pr

Reflux

Po

Obstruction, thrombosis

Pr,o

Reflux and obstruction

Pn

No venous pathophysiology identified

*The descriptor A (asymptomatic) or S (symptomatic) is placed after the C clinical class.

Telangiectases are less than 1 mm, reticular veins are between 1 and 3 mm, and varicose veins are greater than 3 mm measured in the upright position.

questions.text: A 38 year old married female comes to the family planning OPD for IUD insertion. Which of the following history given by the patient is not considered as significant before IUD insertion?
questions.solution:
History of cardiac disease is not a contraindication in IUD usage, whereas all the other options are absolute contraindications for IUD usage.

 

IUD Usage
Absolute contraindications Relative contraindications

suspected pregnancy,

PID,

vaginal bleeding of unknown etiology,

Carcinoma cervix/uterus/adnexa/other pelvic tumors,

previous ectopic pregnancy.

anemia,

menorrhagia,

history of PID since the last pregnancy,

purulent cervical discharge, distortions of the uterine cavity due to fibroids,

uterine malformations,

unmotivated person. 

IUD can be :

  • First generation IUD – inert or non-medicated devices like Lippes loop.
  • Second generation IUD - medicated with metallic elements like Copper eg:  Cu-T-220 C, Nova T, Multi-load Cu-250, Multi-load Cu-375
  • Third generation IUD – hormone containing IUD – progestasert, Mirena (LNG-20).

Mechanisms of action of IUDs include:

  • Cause cellular and biochemical changes in the uterus and endometrium.
  • Prevent sperm penetration due to change in mucus consistency.
  • Prevent implantation by making uterus hostile to it.

questions.text: A single mutation in a nucleotide base pair resulting in a termination codon is known as?
questions.solution:
A single mutation in a nucleotide base pair resulting in a termination codon is known as a nonsense mutation. 

A codon is a sequence of three bases present on the mRNA (messenger RNA), and it codes for amino acids. Out of the 64 codons possible, only 61 code for the 20 amino acids. Three codons, UAA, UAG, and UGA  do not code for any of the 20 amino acids. These are known as nonsense/punctator/termination/stop codons and function as translation termination signals. The UGA codon is traditionally considered a stop codon, but it codes for selenocysteine (21st amino acid).

The tRNA (transfer RNA) contains the anticodon which recognizes specific codons present on the mRNA. The sequence of the anticodon is complementary to the codon. The pairing between the codon and anticodon can wobble at the third base. For example, GGU, GGC, and GGA all pair with the anticodon CCI. The wobble phenomenon along with degeneracy reduces the effect of mutations.

A mutation involving a single nucleotide base is known as a point mutation. A nonsense mutation is a type of point mutation where a codon previously coding for an amino acid is changed to a stop codon. This results in premature termination of translation and the formation of a truncated protein. mRNA containing premature stops are removed by the nonsense-mediated degradation pathway.

Other options:

Option A: A missense mutation is a type of point mutation where the new codon, formed by the changed base, codes for a different amino acid.

Option C: Stop mutation is a term that can be used interchangeably with nonsense mutation. Here, nonsense mutation is the best answer.

Option D: Silent mutations are point mutations where the new codon formed still codes for the same amino acid as the codon before the mutation.

Related Pearl: Start and stop codons

Start codon: AUG - Methionine

Stop codons:

  • UGA- Selenocysteine (21st Amino acid )
  • UAG- Pyrrolysine (22nd Amino acid)
  • UAA

questions.text: Which of the following determines the severity of the Tetralogy of Fallot?
questions.solution:
The determining factor for the severity of TOF (Tetralogy of Fallot) is pulmonary stenosis. Due to pulmonary stenosis, prolonged reduction of pulmonary blood flow occurs, resulting in severe systemic hypoxia.

TOF is a cyanotic congenital heart disease with the following four components:

  • Obstruction to right ventricular outflow (pulmonary stenosis)
  • Malalignment type of ventricular septal defect (VSD)
  • Dextroposition of the aorta so that it overrides the ventricular septum (overriding of the aorta), and
  • Right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH)

The severity of symptoms depends on the degree of the right ventricular outflow obstruction. In mild degrees, the symptoms become pronounced as the baby grows due to RV infundibular hypertrophy and may present with heart failure. In severe degrees, pulmonary blood flow predominantly depends on the ductus arteriosus. As soon as the duct closes, the baby presents with cyanosis and circulatory collapse in the neonatal period.

The image given below shows the cardinal features seen in TOF:

Clinical features include significant hypercyanotic spells in infants which are characterized by hyperpnea, cyanosis, and gasping followed by syncope. The spells occur most frequently in the morning on initial awakening or after episodes of vigorous crying. These spells are due to a prolonged reduction of pulmonary blood flow resulting in severe systemic hypoxia and metabolic acidosis.

Older children present with exertional dyspnea and assume a squatting position to relieve the dyspneic episode after which the child is able to resume the activity.

The below image shows a boot-shaped cardiac silhouette. This is due to the right ventricular hypertrophy and upward shift of the cardiac apex. The hilar areas and lung fields are relatively oligemic due to diminished pulmonary blood flow. the chest X-ray findings

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in some congenital heart defects

Boot shaped heart - Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)

 

Egg on string appearance - Transposition of Great Arteries (TGA)

 

Snowman's heart appearance or Figure of 8 appearance - Supracardiac TAPVC

 

Box Shaped Heart - Ebstein's Anomaly

questions.text: What is the investigation of choice in a 55-year-old woman who presents with post-menopausal bleed?
questions.solution:
Endometrial biopsy is the investigation of choice in a case of post-menopausal bleed, as the chances of endometrial cancer are quite high.

For those who undergo TVUS (transvaginal USG) and have an EEC (endometrial echo complex) >4 mm, localized thickening, or an indistinct or nonvisible EEC, endometrial sampling is a reasonable next step.

Investigations for endometrial carcinoma include:

  • Endometrial aspiration biopsy is the first investigation for abnormal uterine bleeding, especially in females >35 years.
  • Dilatation and fractional curettage was the best method to diagnose but now it is not used.
  • Hysteroscopy and biopsy: The investigation of choice for endometrial cancer.
  • Transvaginal USG is used as an adjunct to endometrial biopsy.
  • A Pap smear is not reliable to diagnose endometrial carcinoma. It is more useful as a screening tool rather than a diagnostic tool.

If symptoms of postmenopausal bleeding persist, imaging of the endometrial cavity should be performed with one or a combination of the following: TVUS, contrast sonography, or hysteroscopy.

Note: Surgical staging is the gold standard investigation for staging endometrial carcinoma.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of Plummer-Vinson syndrome?
questions.solution:
Plummer-Vinson syndrome also known as Paterson-Brown-Kelly syndrome is a rare condition commonly affecting middle-aged women with long-standing anaemia. Gastroesophageal reflux disease is not associated with this condition. 

Clinical features in Plummer-Vinson Syndrome/ Patterson-Kelly-Brown Syndrome include:

  • Iron-deficiency anaemia
  • Esophageal webs
  • Dysphagia
  • Glossitis
  • Cheilosis

Oesophagal webs are most common in the upper oesophagus (post-cricoid area), where they are generally semi-circumferential, eccentric lesions that protrude less than 5 mm and have a thickness of 2 to 4 mm. Microscopically, webs are composed of fibrovascular connective tissue and overlying epithelium.

The main symptom of webs is dysphagia associated with incompletely chewed food and regurgitation of food. It is a premalignant condition. Plummer-Vinson syndrome is a known risk factor for post-cricoid hypopharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma.  

Treatment includes correcting iron-deficiency anaemia which may improve dysphagia and pain. Oesophagal bougies can be used during upper endoscopy to dilate the post-cricoid webs and allow normal swallowing and passage of food.

The image below shows the endoscopic appearance of the post-cricoid web. 

The barium swallow below shows the oesophagal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Oesophagal webs are thin membranes of normal oesophagal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. The translucent part denotes the oesophagal web.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is Bone Anchored Hearing Aid (BAHA) used?
questions.solution:
Bone Anchored Hearing Aid (BAHA) is useful in congenital external auditory canal atresia.

Bilateral aural atresia presents with failed audiological testing and requires early bone conduction hearing aids, one of which is BAHA, which combines a sound processor with a small titanium fixture implanted behind the ear and allows the bone to transfer sound to a functioning cochlea rather than via the middle ear – a process known as direct bone conduction.

It consists of three parts:

  • An innermost titanium fixture in the bone
  • A middle abutment 
  • An outer hearing aid fixed to the abutment

Bone-anchored Hearing Aids are used:

  • When air-conduction (AC) hearing aid cannot be used:
    • People who have chronic inflammation or infection of the ear canal are associated with discharge and cannot wear standard “in the ear” air-conduction hearing aids.
    • Children with malformed or absent outer ear and ear canals as in microtia or canal atresia.
  • In Conductive or mixed hearing loss, e.g. otosclerosis and tympanosclerosis where surgery is contraindicated
  • In single-sided deafness

questions.text: A 35 year old female complains of increased anxiety and repetitive thoughts of her hands being contaminated and engages in repeated washing of her hands. Her thoughts are distressing but she is not able to overcome them. If she tries to hold herself from washing, it further aggravates her anxiety. Treatment of choice is ____________
questions.solution:
Repetitive thoughts of contamination of hand and repeated washing is suggestive of obsessive-compulsive disorder(OCD). Treatment of choice in OCD is cognitive behaviour therapy.

The most common form of obsessive-compulsive disorder is contamination where they have repeated thoughts of their hands being contaminated and want to wash their hands repeatedly. The patients are aware of this, but if they try to resist, it leads to anxiety.

Note: Both SSRIs and psychological therapy(CBT) are first-line treatment modalities of OCD. However, the NICE guideline mentions that psychological therapy is more effective than pharmacological therapy and should be used as first-line where possible. 

Obsessive-compulsive and related disorders are:

  • Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder
  • Body Dysmorphic Disorder
  • Hoarding Disorder
  • Hair-Pulling Disorder (Trichotillomania)
  • Excoriation (Skin-Picking) Disorder

questions.text: A man regularly derives sexual gratification by inflicting pain upon his partner. He would often produce cuts and cigarette burns on his partner's arms. This is best described as?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of sexual sadism. It is seen more commonly in men. It develops due to early experiences of brutality in sex.

The sadist may bite, beat, whip, produce cuts or cigarette burns etc on their sexual partner. In extreme cases, the victim's nipples may be bitten off, items such as a bottle or sticks are inserted into the vagina. Blunt trauma causing fractures and rupture of internal organs may also be seen.

Other options:

Option A - Voyeurism - It is the act of obtaining sexual gratification by observing an unsuspecting person who is naked, disrobing or engaging in sexual activity.

Option B - Fetishism - It is a form of sexual behaviour in which gratification is associated with an abnormal stimulus which may be an object, activity or part of the body.

Option D - Masochism - This is opposite to sadism. Sexual gratification is obtained by suffering the pain.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to you with complaints of 18 episodes of loose stools in the last 24 hours and vomiting twice in the last 4 hours. The child is irritable but drinking fluids. The optimal therapy for this child is______

choices.text: Intravenous fluid initially for 4 hours followed by oral fluids

questions.solution:
Oral rehydration therapy is the first line of treatment used in treating acute diarrheas due to all aetiologies, in all age groups, and in all countries and the recommended fluid is ORS.

Recommended formulation: Reduced osmolarity ORS solution, which has a reduced concentration of sodium (75 mmol/liter) and glucose (75 mmol/liter) helps in reducing the adverse effect of hypertonicity on net fluid absorption.

Related Pearl: Symptoms associated with different levels of dehydration

Symptoms No or minimal dehydration Mild to moderate dehydration Severe dehydration
Loss of body weight <3% 3–9% >9%
Mental status Well; alert Fatigued or irritable Lethargic or unconscious
Thirst Drinks normally Thirsty; eager to drink Drinks poorly
Heart rate Normal Normal to increased Tachycardia
Quality of pulse Normal Normal to decreased Weak, thready or impalpable
Skin turgor test Instant recoil Recoil in <2 sec Recoil in >2 sec
Capillary refill Normal Prolonged Prolonged

Related Pearl: Treatment of dehydration based on severity

Plan A: For no dehydration or minimal dehydration. ORS is administered after each loose stool.

Age Amount 
<2 years 50–100 mL
2-10 years 100–200 mL
>10 years As much fluid as they want

Plan B: For moderate dehydration.

The amount of oral rehydration solution (ORS) to be given is 75 mL/kg body weight (wt × 75).

Plan C: Severe dehydration

Age First, give 30 mL/kg in Followed by 70 mL/kg in Total 100 mL/kg in
Infants (under 12 months) 1 hr 5 hrs  6 hrs
Older 30 min 2½ hrs  3 hrs

Note: Ringer lactate (ideal) or normal saline is used as intravenous fluids.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presented with severe pain in the lower back radiating to the pubic symphysis. Ultrasonography revealed a stone in the left ureter, measuring 3 mm in size. The stone is most likely to be lodged in which of the following sites?
questions.solution:
Vesicoureteric junction is the narrowest part of the ureter.

This is the reason why stones as small as 2 to 3 mm get arrested in the vesicoureteric junction.

The ureter is constricted at 5 places:

  1. At the pelvi-ureteric junction
  2. At the brim of the lesser pelvis (as it crosses the common iliac artery)
  3. At the site of crossing of the ureter by ductus deferens or broad ligament of the uterus.
  4. Vesico-ureteric junction
  5. At its opening in the lateral angle of the trigone

These are regarded as surgical constrictions of the ureter. However, the anatomical constrictions are only three of them (1, 2, and 4).

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to the clinic with ascites. The serum ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) in the patient is found to be 1.4g/dL. Which among the following is the most likely cause of ascites in this patient?
questions.solution:
The serum-ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) ≥ 1.1g/dL suggests portal hypertension as the cause of ascites.

Serum ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) = Serum albumin - Ascitic fluid albumin. 

It helps distinguish ascites caused by portal hypertension from other causes of ascites. 

 

SAAG ≥ 1.1g/dL - Ascites due to portal hypertension SAAG <1.1g/dL- Ascites due to nonportal causes
Ascitic protein <2.5g/dL Ascitic protein >2.5g/dL
  • Nephrotic syndrome
  • Pancreatitis
  • Peritoneal TB
  • Peritoneal carcinomatosis
  • Biliary leak. 
 
  • Cirrhosis
  • Late Budd Chiari syndrome
  • Massive liver metastases
  • Heart failure or constrictive pericarditis
  • IVC obstruction
  • Sinusoidal obstruction syndrome
  • Early Budd Chiari syndrome

questions.text: Identify the drugs marked as A, B, and C.

choices.text: A - Aspirin, B - Eptifibatide, C - Vorapaxar
A - Aspirin, B - Eptifibatide, C - Prasugrel
A - Aspirin, B - Prasugrel, C - Eptifibatide

questions.solution:
The drugs marked A, B and C are aspirin, eptifibatide, and vorapaxar, respectively.

Aspirin causes inhibition of cyclooxygenase-1 (COX-1), which would inhibit the formation of thromboxane A2. Thromboxane A2 is an inducer of platelet aggregation and is a potent vasoconstrictor. Hence, inhibition of its formation is responsible for antiplatelet action.

Aspirin is a non-competitive, irreversible inhibitor of the cyclooxygenase (COX) enzyme. It is a nonselective COX inhibitor and inhibits both COX-1 and COX-2. 

Abciximab, tirofiban, and eptifibatide act by blocking Gp IIb/IIIa receptors. They are mainly used during percutaneous coronary intervention for acute coronary syndrome. They carry a high risk of bleeding and can cause thrombocytopenia.

Vorapaxar primarily inhibits platelet aggregation caused by thrombin. PAR-1 activation by thrombin contributes to platelet aggregation. Vorapaxar is a competitive antagonist of protease-activated receptor-1 (PAR-1). Vorapaxar is indicated in combination with aspirin and/or clopidogrel to reduce thromboembolic events in patients with MI or peripheral vascular disease.

Prasugrel is an irreversible P2Y12 inhibitor and lasts for the entire lifetime of a platelet.

Prasugrel is a prodrug that is used in patients with acute coronary syndrome who have undergone percutaneous coronary intervention. It reduces the rate of thrombotic cardiovascular events in such patients. 

Related Pearl: Classification of anti-platelet drugs

Class Drugs
Cyclooxygenase- I inhibitors Aspirin
Irreversible P2Y12 inhibitors

Ticlopidine, Clopidogrel, Prasugrel
Reversible P2Y12 inhibitors Ticagrelor, Cangrelor
GpIIb/IIIa inhibitors Abciximab, Eptifibatide, Tirofiban
Thrombin (PAR-1) receptor antagonist Vorapaxar 
Phosphodiesterase inhibitors

Dipyridamole

questions.text: A middle-aged farmer, presents to your OPD with complaints of decreased vision, redness, blurring of the eye, photophobia, and lacrimation. The patient reveals that a few days before the symptoms he had sustained an injury to the same eye with a vegetative matter. Slit-lamp examination reveals the following finding with anterior chamber involvement. What is the likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette with the image depicting a corneal ulcer with arrowheads pointing towards satellite lesions and a thick hypopyon is suggestive of fungal keratitis.

Mycotic or fungal keratitis is seen in tropical countries and in immunocompromised individuals usually due to infection with Aspergillus, Fusarium, or Candida albicans. Injury by vegetative matter is a predisposing factor. Patients may present with pain, watering, and photophobia, but symptoms are usually milder in comparison to a bacterial ulcer.

Salient features that point toward the diagnosis of fungal corneal ulcers are:

  • Dry-looking ulcer with feathery margins.
  • Sterile circular corneal infiltrates - Wessley immune ring due to the deposition of immune complexes. 
  • Satellite lesions.
  • Thick, non-sterile hypopyon.

Topical drugs such as natamycin, voriconazole, amphotericin B, and nystatin can be used. Systemic antifungal agents such as ketoconazole are used if the ulcers are severe/perforated. 

Related Pearl: Clinical differential diagnosis of corneal ulcer

  Bacterial Fungal Viral Parasitic
Risk factors

Contact lens wear

Trauma

Chronic steroid use

Anesthetic cornea

Dry eyes

Exposure keratopathy

 Trauma with vegetable matter

Low immunity

Recurrent attacks

Contact lens wear
