Clinical features

Hypopyon is fluid and mobile

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is likely to have a rapid course, with deep corneal necrosis.

Less pain and watering compared to the extent of vision loss and signs. 

Tend to be indolent but progressive

Hypopyon is thick, immobile.

Relatively more pain and watering compared to the extent of vision loss and signs. 

Recurrences are characteristic.

Disproportionately severe pain is a characteristic feature.

Indolent course and in initial stages, often mistaken to be viral/ fungal infection, leading to a delay in diagnosis

questions.text:
Match the following cells with their locations.
1. Kupffer cells a. Stomach
2. Parietal cells b. Liver 
3. Dust cells c. Alveoli
4. Clara cells d. Bronchioles
questions.solution:
The correctly matched set of the cells and their locations is 1-b, 2-a, 3-c, 4-d.

Kupffer cells are a component of the mononuclear phagocytic system and are located in the liver.

Parietal cells, also called oxyntic cells, are found in the upper half of the gastric glands. They have numerous mitochondria and are actively involved in the secretion of hydrochloric acid and intrinsic factor - a glycoprotein that aids in the absorption of vitamin B12 from the ileum. 

Dust cells are macrophages in the walls of the alveoli. They phagocytose dust particles in the alveoli. In CHF these macrophages phagocytose erythrocytes that escape from the capillaries. The cells acquire a brick-red color and are called heart failure cells.

Clara cells are non-ciliated cuboidal epithelial cells that secrete important defense markers and serve as stem cells after injury. These cells make up a larger portion of the epithelial lining in the later portions of the conducting airway.

questions.text: A patient undergoes reconstruction surgery after removal of a tumor from the right breast. Which of the following is incorrect about the flap used in the patient, which is shown in the image?

choices.text: It is based on the deep inferior epigastric artery.
Increased risk of abdominal wall weakness.
No muscle is taken in this technique.

questions.solution:
The given image is of a muscle-sparing transverse rectus abdominis myocutaneous flap (ms-TRAM). There is a reduced risk of abdominal wall weakness.

The ms-TRAM flap is a variant of the transverse rectus abdominis myocutaneous (TRAM) flap. It is a free flap, in which the vascular pedicle is divided and reconnected to the recipient vessels in the chest using a microsurgical technique. It is based on the deep inferior epigastric artery. Here no muscle is taken and the perforating vessel is dissected out. As muscle is spared in ms-TRAM, there is a reduced risk of abdominal wall weakness, postoperative bulge and hernia, and other associated complications.

Examples of pedicled flaps include TRAM flap and latissimus dorsi (LD) flap:

The TRAM flap is either based on the superior or inferior epigastric artery or both (supercharged TRAM).

 

Latissimus dorsi (LD) flap is an axial flap based on the thoracodorsal pedicle.

questions.text: A patient with HIV has a CD4 count of 170/ μL. He complains of breathlessness for the past week. The patient's chest radiograph is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image shows symmetric interstitial infiltrates mainly in the perihilar region. This finding along with the CD4 count of 170 cells /μL makes pneumocystis pneumonia the most likely diagnosis.

Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP) is an opportunistic infection in immunocompromised patients. It usually occurs when the CD4 count falls below 200 cells/μL.

Patients usually present with fever and nonproductive cough with progressive shortness of breath. It can also affect other organs like lymph nodes, spleen, and liver. The classic radiographic appearance consists of diffuse bilateral symmetric interstitial infiltrates that are perihilar. CT will show diffuse ground-glass opacities.

Giemsa stain, toluidine blue, methenamine silver, and calcofluor white stains demonstrate trophozoites. The cyst wall appears black with Gomori's methenamine silver stain. Shown below is an image of the Gomori’s methenamine silver staining showing crescent-shaped cysts resembling the crushed ping-pong balls of P. jirovecii.

Other options

Option A- Mycobacterium avium complex infection is generally seen when the CD4 count falls less than 50 cells/μL. CT scan of the infected lung will show peribronchial inflammation, which gives rise to a tree in a bud appearance (small round structures attached to linear structures). In severe cases, there might be bronchiectasis and cavity formation.

Below image- Tree in bud appearance which is indicated by an arrowhead.

Option B- Histoplasmosis occurs when the CD4 count falls below 150 cells/μL and high risk populations in endemic areas or those with occupational exposure. Chest radiograph shows the signs of pneumonitis with prominent hilar or mediastinal adenopathy.

Option D- Pneumococcal pneumonia commonly appears as lobar or segmental consolidation. In some, it can involve more than one lobe. It can have pleural effusion and empyema in severe cases.

Below image- Consolidation in a streptococcal pneumonia

Related Pearl: AIDS-defining opportunistic infections and neoplasms found in patients with HIV infection

Infections

  • Protozoal and Helminthic Infections
    • Cryptosporidiosis or Isosporiasis (cystoisosporiasis) - Chronic intestinal
    • Toxoplasmosis (pneumonia or CNS infection)
  • Fungal Infections
    • Candidiasis (esophageal, tracheal, or pulmonary)
    • Cryptococcosis (CNS infection)
    • Coccidioidomycosis (disseminated)
    • Pneumocystosis (pneumonia or disseminated infection)
    • Histoplasmosis (disseminated)
  • Bacterial Infections
    • Mycobacteriosis (“atypical,” e.g., Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare) disseminated or extrapulmonary
    • Mycobacterium tuberculosis (pulmonary or extrapulmonary)
    • Nocardiosis (pneumonia, meningitis, disseminated)
    • Salmonella infections, disseminated
  • Viral Infections
    • Cytomegalovirus (pulmonary, intestinal, retinitis, or CNS infections)
    • Herpes simplex virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Varicella-zoster virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy

Neoplasms

  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Primary lymphoma of brain
  • Invasive cancer of uterine cervix 

 

One-liners about HIV

  • Sexual contact is the least efficacious yet most common mode of spread of HIV infection
  • ELISA is used for the detection of antibodies against viral proteins. This is the most sensitive and the best screening test for the diagnosis of AIDS.
  • Western blot is the most specific or the confirmatory test for HIV.
  • Candidiasis is the most common fungal infection in patients with AIDS.
  • Cytomegalovirus (CMV) chorioretinitis exclusively in patients with CD4+ T cell counts less than 50 per microliter.
  • Toxoplasma gondii causes encephalitis and is responsible for 50% of all mass lesions in the central nervous system.
  • John Cunningham virus (JC virus) is a human papovavirus that causes progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy.
  • Persistent diarrhea in AIDS is caused by Cryptosporidium, Isospora belli, or microsporidia.
  • AIDS-dementia complex is the most common neurological manifestation of HIV infection.
  • Inflammatory myopathy is the commonest skeletal muscle disorder in HIV.

questions.text:
Which of the following couples are likely to have a case of rhesus alloimmunization?

Note-The columns in the given table indicate the Rhesus blood groups of the husband and wife.

Couple Husband Wife
A Rh+ve  Rh-ve 
B Rh+ve Rh+ve
C Rh-ve Rh-ve
D Rh-ve Rh+ve
questions.solution:
The couples likely to have a case of rhesus alloimmunization are Couple A.

Rh alloimmunization occurs when an Rh-negative mother produces antibodies to Rh antigens to an Rh-positive fetus. Rh+ve fetus and Rh alloimmunization are likely to arise only when a husband is Rh+ve with the wife being Rh-ve.

Alloimmunization is defined as a production of immune antibodies in an individual in response to foreign red cell antigen derived from another individual of the same species.

Option B-The fetus will be Rh+ve as both parents are Rh+ve, but because the mother is also Rh+ve hence Rh alloimmunization does not occur.

Option C-The fetus will be Rh-ve as both parents are Rh-ve.

Option D-The fetus can be Rh+ve/-ve, but because the mother is Rh+ve hence Rh alloimmunization does not occur.

questions.text:
The histological images of four brain tumours are given below. Pick out the correct match.
  1. Schwannoma
  2. Oligodendroglioma
  3. Glioblastoma multiforme
  4. Medulloblastoma
questions.solution:
The correct option is C: A-2, B-1, C-3, D-4

Image A -

The histological image shows fried egg appearance of cells is seen in oligodendroglioma.

  • These are infiltrating gliomas comprised of cells that resemble oligodendrocytes.
  • Common in the fourth and fifth decades.
  • The lesions are found mostly in the cerebral hemispheres, with a pre­dilection for white matter.
  • The tumors are composed of sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm giving a fried egg appearance. Tumor cells infiltrating the cerebral cortex often collect around neurons (perineuronal satellitosis).

Image B - 

The image shows verocay bodies which are seen in schwannoma. These are nuclear-free zones that lie between nuclear palisading.

It consists of dense areas called Antoni A area, and loose areas called Antoni B area.

  • The dense eosinophilic Antoni A areas contain spindle cells that are arranged into cellular intersecting fascicles. Palisading of nuclei is seen, with the nuclear-free zones between them, called Verocay bodies.
  • The Antoni B areas contain spindle-shaped cells that are loosely arranged and separated by prominent myxoid extracellular matrix.

Image C - 

The image shows pleomorphic cells characteristic of glioblastoma multiforme.

Grossly, glioblastomas are found infiltrating the brain tissue and are poorly delineated. They have grayish tumor cells with central yellowish necrosis and multiple areas of hemorrhages.

  • They are composed of poorly differentiated pleomorphic astrocytic cells with nuclear atypia and high mitotic activity.
  • Necrosis and florid microvascular proliferation are characteristic.
  • They exhibit pseudopalisading—dense arrangement of tumor cells lining up around the foci of tumor necrosis, which is characteristically seen in this image above

Image D -

The image shows a densely cellular medulloblastoma

  • These tumors will have sheets of anaplastic cells. The individual cells are small, with scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped
  • Mitosis is abundant and markers of cellular proliferation are abundant
  • The tumour may express neuronal (neurosecretory) granules, form Homer-Wright rosettes and express glial markers (GFAP)
  • There are two variants - nodular desmoplastic and the large cell variant. The nodular desmoplastic variant has areas of stromal response, marked by collagen and reticulin deposition and nodules forming pale islands. The large cell variant has irregular vesicular nuclei, prominent nucleoli and apoptotic cells 

 

Note:

Fried eggs in pathology:

  • Oligodendroglioma on histopathology
  • Hairy cell leukemia on bone marrow biopsy
  • Seminoma/Dysgerminoma on light microscopy
  • Mycoplasma pneumonia fried egg colonies on Eaton agar

questions.text: A patient who is a teacher by profession presents to the clinic with hoarseness of voice. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of a vocal nodule.

Vocal nodules are also known as singer’s or screamer's nodes. It occurs at the mid-membranous portion of the vocal cords at the free edge. It is the area of maximum vibration of the cord and thus is subjected to maximum trauma. It presents as bilateral swellings in the vocal cords.

Vocal nodules occur due to vocal trauma when a person speaks in a loud voice for prolonged periods. They mostly affect teachers, actors, vendors, or pop singers.

Symptoms of vocal nodules are hoarseness, vocal fatigue, and pain in the neck on prolonged phonation.

Treatment includes educating the patient on proper use of voice. Surgery is reserved for patients who remain symptomatic despite voice therapy.

Option A: Vocal polyp is caused by sudden shouting which results in hemorrhage and edema of the vocal cord.Affected individuals present with hoarseness of voice and diplophonia(double voice). Other factors associated with it are allergy and cigarette smoking. It presents as a benign swelling on the free edge of the vocal cord. 

Option B: Vocal cysts are retention cysts due to blockage of seromucinous glands of the laryngeal mucosa. They occur in the false vocal cords.

Option D: Reinke's edema is the collection of fluid in Reinke's space. Affected individuals present with diffuse swelling of the vocal cords. Treatment involves the removal of gelatinous collection by a longitudinal incision on the vocal cord.

Related Pearl: Muscles of larynx

Remember 2 exceptions:

  • All muscles are adductors, except PCA (an abductor)
  • All muscles are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve, except cricothyroid (superior laryngeal nerve)
Action
Muscle
Opening of the inlet of larynx
Thyroepiglotticus
Closing of the inlet of larynx
Aryepiglotticus, Interarytenoids
Abductor of vocal cords
Posterior cricoarytenoid
Adductor of vocal cords
Lateral cricoarytenoid
Tensor of vocal cords
Cricothyroid
Relaxer of vocal cord
Thyroarytenoid
Modulator of larynx
Vocalis

Safety muscle of larynx: Posterior cricoarytenoid

Safety muscle of tongue: Genioglossus

The muscle of whispering: Lateral cricoarytenoid

Vocalis is known as the modulator of larynx because, the anterior part of the vocalis muscle can tense the vocal cord, and its posterior part can relax the vocal cord.

questions.text: Identify the defect in the ultrasound of a 12 week primigravida.
questions.solution:
The given ultrasound image shows absence of cranial calvaria, prominent orbits resembling the face of a frog points to a diagnosis of anencephaly. 

Anencephaly results from incomplete closure of the neural tube. It is one of the earliest detectable congenital defects that can be detected as early as 10 to 11 weeks of gestation.  Screening can also be done by serum estimation of maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (MSAFP). The following are the radiological signs seen in anencephaly. 

  • Frog eye sign - Absence of cranial calvaria, prominent orbits thereby resembling the face of a frog. 
  • Shower cap sign - The absence of the cranium could lead to the protrusion of a disorganized mass of brain tissue. This resembles a shower cap giving rise to a characteristic triangular facial appearance. 

The image given below shows frog eye sign seen in Anencephaly.

 

Option B: The image given below shows an ultrasound image of the fetus suggestive of an Omphalocele (asterix). Omphalocele is a midline anterior abdominal wall defect through which the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel may herniate. The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac. 

 

Option C: The image given below shows cystic hygroma on the neck of a newborn and in the fetus respectively. Cystic hygroma is a congenital multiloculated lymphatic lesion that is classically found in the posterior triangle of the neck. It occurs as a result of sequestration or obstruction of developing lymph vessels. This defect can be picked up in a first-trimester ultrasound. 

 

Option D: The image given below shows a newborn with encephalocele. Encephalocele is caused due to defects in the skull through which the meninges and/or neural tissue herniate. The squamous part of the occipital bone is the most frequently affected bone.

questions.text: Which is the best confirmatory method to ensure that the central line is in the jugular vein?
questions.solution:
A chest X-ray is the best method to confirm the position of the central line in the jugular vein.

The position of the catheter is confirmed by radiological confirmation with an X-ray. Comparison of the blood’s color or PaO2 with an arterial sample can also be done, however, they can be misleading or inconclusive, and more than one confirmation method should be used. In cases where transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) is used, the guidewire can be seen in the right atrium, confirming venous entry.

Central line catheterization:

Indications:

  • monitoring central venous pressure (CVP)
  • administration of fluid to treat hypovolemia and shock
  • infusion of caustic drugs and total parenteral nutrition
  • gaining venous access in patients with poor peripheral veins.

Contraindications:

  • tumors or clots
  • tricuspid valve vegetations that could be dislodged or embolized during cannulation
  • site-related complications-subclavian vein cannulation is relatively contraindicated in patients who are receiving anticoagulants(due to the inability to provide direct compression in the event of an accidental arterial puncture), avoid central venous cannulation on the side of a previous carotid endarterectomy due to the possibility of unintentional carotid artery puncture.

Sites:

  • the subclavian vein is associated with a greater risk of pneumothorax, but a reduced risk of other complications during prolonged cannulations 
  • right internal jugular vein provides a combination of accessibility and safety
  • left-sided internal jugular vein catheterization has an increased risk of pleural effusion and chylothorax
  • the external jugular veins can also be used as entry sites, but due to the acute angle at which they join the great veins of the chest, are associated with a slightly increased likelihood of failure to gain access.
  • femoral veins can also be cannulated, but are associated with an increased risk of line-related sepsis.

Risks:

  • site infection, bloodstream infection, air or thrombus embolism
  • arrhythmias (indicating that the catheter tip is in the right atrium or ventricle), hematoma, pneumothorax, hemothorax, hydrothorax, chylothorax
  • cardiac perforation, cardiac tamponade, trauma to nearby nerves and arteries

questions.text: Which type of dysmenorrhea has cramping pain starting at the onset of menses and more pronounced in the first two days of menstruation?
questions.solution:
Cramping pain at the onset of menses and more pronounced in the first two days of menstruation is suggestive of spasmodic dysmenorrhea.

Dysmenorrhoea is defined as cramping pain accompanying menstruation.

It can be classified as:

A. Etiological:

  • Primary dysmenorrhoea: This is not associated with any identifiable pelvic pathology. It affects more than 50% of post-pubescent women in the age group of 18 to 25 years, with ovulatory cycles. This is due to excessive myometrial contraction, ischaemia, excessive prostaglandin production. It is associated with nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, headache, and fatigue. Management includes reassurance, analgesics like NSAIDs, antispasmodics, and OC pills.
  • Secondary(Acquired) dysmenorrhoea: It is associated with the presence of organic pelvic pathologies such as fibroids, adenomyosis, PID, and endometriosis. It is associated with dyspareunia, infertility, and menstrual disorders. Treatment is directed to the cause

B.  Clinical:

  • Spasmodic dysmenorrhoea: It is the most prevalent and manifests as cramping pain, right before or at the start of the menstrual period, and is most pronounced on the first and second days of menstruation.
  • Congestive dysmenorrhoea: It presents as increasing pelvic discomfort and pelvic pain, a few days before menses begin. Thereafter, the patient experiences rapid relief of the symptoms. This variety is commonly seen in PID, IUCD users, varicosities of pelvic veins, pelvic endometriosis, and fibroids.
  • Membranous dysmenorrhoea: It is a special group, in which the endometrium is shed as a cast at the time of menstruation. The passage of the cast is associated with painful uterine cramps. It is the rarest variety.

questions.text: A woman presents to the outpatient department with complaints of amenorrhoea for the past year. She has a history of postpartum hemorrhage and lactational failure. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of Sheehan's syndrome. 

Sheehan syndrome also called post-partum pituitary necrosis refers to the necrosis of the pituitary gland following significant post-partum bleeding, hypovolemia, and shock. It may present acutely as an endocrine emergency or present chronically.The late presentation has the following features:

  • Lactation failure - due to prolactin deficiency
  • Amenorrhea - due to anovulation caused by reduced gonadotropin activity
  • Hypothyroidism - due to decreased TSH secretion 
  • Adrenal insufficiency - due to low ACTH

Option B: Hyperthyroidism can cause oligomenorrhoea and amenorrhea but is likely to have symptoms of hyperthyroidism like weight loss, palpitations, tremors, heat intolerance, dyspnea on exertion, diarrhoea and muscle weakness.

Option C: Prolactinoma or pituitary adenoids is the condition of hyperprolactinemia diagnosed by a prolactin level >200 μg/L. It usually presents with infertility, amenorrhea, and galactorrhea.

Option D: Pituitary apoplexy is a condition in which there is a haemorrhage or infarction of the pituitary gland. This disorder commonly occurs in a pre-existing pituitary adenoma. This patient does not have any signs of adenoma and a history of PPH makes Sheehan syndrome more likely.

questions.text: For cells of islets of Langerhans, which of the following is correctly matched?
questions.solution:
The correctly matched pair is F-Pancreatic polypeptide. 

Cells of the endocrine pancreas are divided into: 

Cell type

What they secrete

A (alpha)

Glucagon

B (beta)

Insulin and amylin

D (delta)

Somatostatin

F or PP

Pancreatic polypeptide

The close interrelations among these cells allow direct control of secretion of some of the hormones by the other hormones. Ex: Insulin inhibits glucagon secretion, amylin inhibits insulin secretion, and somatostatin inhibits secretion of insulin and glucagon.

questions.text: A 57-year-old male patient with hypertension presented with a sudden tearing type of chest pain. A  CECT chest was done and is given below. What is the preferred treatment option for this patient?

choices.text: Medical management with blood pressure control
Further diagnostic workup with transesophageal echocardiography

questions.solution:
The patient seems to be having an aortic dissection and CT chest indicates a Stanford Type A aortic dissection from the aortic root. He requires urgent surgical management.

The Stanford classification is used to separate aortic dissections into those that need surgical repair, and those that usually require only medical management. The Stanford classification divides dissections by the most proximal involvement.

Type A is when ascending aorta and arch are affected. It requires urgent surgical management and may result in:

  • Coronary artery occlusion
  • Aortic incompetence
  • Rupture into the pericardial sac with resulting cardiac tamponade

Type B begins beyond brachiocephalic vessels and dissection commences distal to the left subclavian artery affecting only the descending aorta. In these patients, initial treatment is medical management with blood pressure control.

The DeBakey classification divides dissections into:

  • Type I: involves ascending and descending aorta ( Stanford A)
  • Type II: involves ascending aorta only ( Stanford A)
  • Type III: involves descending aorta only, commencing after the origin of the left subclavian artery ( Stanford B)

Further diagnostic workup with TEE(transesophageal echocardiography) or MRA (magnetic resonance angiography) is not required as CT is showing ascending aorta dissection.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding Foley catheter?

choices.text: French in foleys catheter refers to external circumference
Silicone foleys can be kept for maximum of 2 weeks
Three way foleys is used for instrumentation
If there is peri-urethral leakage of urine after inserting a foleys, first deflating the balloon is tried

questions.solution:
French with respect to Foley catheter refers to the external circumference of the catheter.

Option B: Latex Foley catheter can be kept for one week whereas silicone Foley catheter can be kept for up to 6 weeks (some studies say 2-3 months).

Option C: Three-way Foley catheter, shown below, is used for irrigation and helps in preventing clot retention following surgeries like TURP.

Option D: If there is peri-urethral leakage of urine after inserting a Foley, inflating the balloon slightly more or using a larger-sized Foley are the corrective measures.

Related Pearl: Foley's catheter

A Foley catheter is a thin, sterile tube inserted into the bladder to drain urine. Because it can be left in place in the bladder for a period of time, it is also called an indwelling catheter.

French scale corresponds to the external circumference in millimetres. French size divided by 3 will give the outer diameter of the catheter. 

Fr. size = 3 x d, where d is the outer diameter in mm. 

A 3 Fr. catheter will have a circumference of approximately 3 mm and a diameter of 1 mm. 

Note:

Colour of the foleys is the colour at the baloon port as shown in the figure below

questions.text: A young woman was suspected to have bacterial vaginosis. Which of the following statements is false about this condition?

choices.text: Gardnerella vaginalis is a causative agent
Amsel’s criteria is used for diagnosis
Oral metronidazole is given for treatment

questions.solution:
The false statement about bacterial vaginosis among the following is 'vaginal itching is prominent'.

Bacterial vaginosis is a condition associated with alteration in the normal vaginal flora. There is a decrease in the number of lactobacilli in the vaginal discharge and an increase in other anaerobic bacteria mainly, Gardnerella vaginalis (Mobiluncus and Myco­plasma hominins are others organisms). It is not sexually transmitted. 

About half of the women having bacterial vaginosis are asymptomatic. Symptomatic women mostly present with a profuse, fishy vaginal discharge. It does not cause pruritus, dysuria, and dyspareunia.

Bacterial vaginosis is diagnosed by the Amsel criteria. At least three of the four are needed to confirm the diagnosis

  • White, milky, nonviscous discharge adherent to the vaginal wall.
  • The pH of the discharge more than 4.5. (pH 5-7).
  • Amine or Whiff test-Fishy odour when discharge is mixed with 10% KOH  
  • Presence of clue cells - the epithelial cells have a fuzzy border due to adherence of bacteria.

Oral metronidazole (500 mg twice daily for 7 days) or oral clindamycin (300 mg twice daily for 7 days) is given for the treatment of bacterial vaginosis. Partners do not need to be treated. Metronidazole may be avoided in first trimester.

questions.text: A primigravida was admitted in labor at 38 weeks of gestation. In view of the prolonged second stage of labor, a mediolateral episiotomy was given to aid instrumental delivery.  It is usually angled at ______
questions.solution:
The mediolateral episiotomy is angled at 60°.

Episiotomy is a surgically planned incision on the perineum and the posterior vaginal wall during the second stage of labour. It is done to 

  • To enlarge the vaginal introitus so as to facilitate easy and safe delivery of the fetus.
  • To minimize overstretching and rupture of the perineal muscles and fascia
  • To reduce the stress and strain on the fetal head.

It is given during crowning when the head is visible. There are many types like median, mediolateral, lateral and j shaped. Among these, mediolateral episiotomy is preferred.

The mediolateral episiotomy begins at the midline of the fourchette and is directed to the right or left at an angle 60 degrees off the midline. This angle accounts for stretch distortion of perineal anatomy during crowning. After delivery and distortion resolution, it ultimately yields an incision 45-degrees from the midline.

 

Related Pearl: Mediolateral Episiotomy

It begins within 3 mm of the midline in the posterior fourchette and is directed laterally at an angle of at least 60 degrees from the midline. This yields an incision of 45 degrees off the midline.

It is essentially an inflicted second-degree perineal tear.

Structures cut in mediolateral episiotomy:

  • Posterior vaginal wall
  • Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles, bulbospongiosus and part of levator ani
  • Fascia covering those muscles
  • Transverse perineal branches of pudendal vessels and nerves
  • Subcutaneous tissue and skin

Advantage: Lesser risk of anal sphincter laceration, hence it is preferred over median episiotomy.

Disadvantage: Increased blood loss and causes more perineal pain and dyspareunia.

questions.text: Which of the following has the highest oxygen concentration in fetal circulation?
questions.solution:
Inferior vena cava has the highest oxygen concentration in fetal circulation.

The blood gets oxygenated in the placenta and this passes to the umbilical vein. From the umbilical vein, 50% of the blood enters the hepatic circulation and 50% bypasses the liver to enter the inferior vena cava. From here, the blood enters the heart via the right atrium. The right atrium also receives deoxygenated blood from the superior vena cava. This mixed blood is distributed to the body via aorta. 

Therefore, inferior vena cava has the highest concentration of oxygen in the fetal circulation.

Related Pearl: Concepts of Fetal Circulation

Concept 1:

Oxygenated blood from placenta to the fetus via the left umbilical vein.

Concept 2:

Most of the umbilical venous blood shunts via the ductus venosus to the inferior vena cava and gets mixed with deoxygenated blood from the lower part of the body and liver.

Concept 3:

One-third of blood from the inferior vena cava is directly pumped to the left atrium across the foramen ovale; then to the left ventricle; and ejected from there into the ascending aorta, where it supplies the upper body and the brain.

Concept 4:

A major portion of blood enters the right ventricle, mixes with blood from the superior vena cava, and ejects into the pulmonary trunk.

Concept 5:

Ductus arteriosus bypasses the lungs, and hence, a major portion pumps into the descending aorta to perfuse the lower part of the body and the umbilical arteries carry blood to the placenta for oxygenation.

The total fetal cardiac output at term is approximately 450 mL/kg/min.

questions.text: In a 10-year-old school child, which of the following vaccines is given as a part of the immunization programme?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, a ten-year-old schoolchild will be administered the TT/Td vaccine according to the National Immunization Schedule.

The Tetanus and adult diphtheria (Td) vaccine is a combination of tetanus and diphtheria with a lower concentration of diphtheria antigen (d) as recommended for older children and adults. The MoHFW recommends the replacement of TT vaccine with Td vaccine for all age groups, including pregnant women. A dose of 0.5ml is administered in the intramuscular route in the upper arm.

Scheduled to be administered at 10 and 16 years of age.

For pregnant women :

  • Td-1: early in pregnancy
  • Td-2: 4 weeks after Td-1
  • Td (Booster): if pregnancy occurs within 3 years of last pregnancy and 2 Td doses were received.

Other options:

Option A - According to the National Immunization Schedule, BCG should be given at birth or as early as possible up to 1 year of age. It provides protection against CNS and disseminated TB. A dose of 0.1 ml is administered intradermally in the left upper arm.

Option B - Measles/MR is given at 9 completed months (1st dose) and a second dose is given at 16-24 months. Measles can be given till 5 years of age. A dose of 0.5ml is administered subcutaneously in the right upper arm.

Option D - DPT vaccine is administered as a part of the pentavalent vaccine at the 6th, 10th and 14th weeks of life. DPT booster doses are administered at 16-24 months (first booster) and 5-6 years (second booster). It can be administered until 7 years of age (with booster doses). A dose of 0.5ml is administered in the anterolateral aspect of the mid-thigh. The 2nd booster dose can be administered in the upper arm.

questions.text: A patient has profuse bleeding after the removal of an IV cannula. He underwent a small bowel resection and was given broad-spectrum antibiotics during his hospital stay. His lab investigations show an elevated prothrombin time (PT). The deficiency of which of the following vitamins is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The deficiency of vitamin K is responsible for this condition.

Vitamin K deficiency in adults may be seen in patients with chronic small-intestinal diseases like celiac disease, Crohn’s disease, obstructed biliary tracts, and after small-bowel resection. Additionally, broad-spectrum antibiotics can precipitate Vitamin K deficiency by reducing the number of gut bacteria, which synthesize menaquinones.

It is a fat-soluble vitamin that has two natural forms: Vitamin K1, also known as phylloquinone, from vegetable sources, and vitamin K2, or menaquinones, which are synthesized by bacterial flora and found in hepatic tissue.

Vitamin K is required for the posttranslational carboxylation of glutamic acid, which is necessary for calcium binding to γ-carboxylated proteins such as

  • prothrombin (factor II)
  • factors VII, IX, and X
  • protein C, protein S

Patients with vitamin K deficiency usually present with a history of bleeding either at venipuncture sites or minor trauma.

It is diagnosed on the basis of an elevated prothrombin time or reduced clotting factors. It is treated with supplementation by oral or IV route.

Other options:

Option A: Riboflavin or Vitamin B2 deficiency manifests as angular stomatitis, magenta tongue, seborrhea, corneal vascularization. It is seen in alcoholism, and individuals with a poor diet and decreased intake of dairy products.

Option B: Vitamin E deficiency manifests as peripheral neuropathy, spinocerebellar ataxia, skeletal muscle atrophy, and retinopathy. Usually seen with fat malabsorption or genetic abnormalities of vitamin E metabolism.

Option C: Niacin deficiency manifests as pellagra, which includes symptoms of diarrhea, a pigmented rash over sun-exposed areas, bright red tongue, memory loss, and altered sensorium. Alcoholism, vitamin B6 deficiency, riboflavin, and tryptophan deficiencies predispose to this condition.

questions.text: The method shown in the image is:
questions.solution:
The image shows marshall burns technique used in the delivery of aftercoming head in breech delivery.

Technique:

  • Baby is allowed to hang by its own weight till the nape of neck is visible
  • When the nape of neck is visible under the pubic arch, baby is grasped by the ankles
  • Baby is swung in an arc in an upward and forward direction towards the mother's abdomen

Other Options: 
Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique is another method that can be used in the delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.
Pinard’s maneuver used for delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.
Ritgen maneuver is used for controlled delivery of head in normal labor.

questions.text: The maneuver depicted in below given diagram is ________
questions.solution:
The image shows Trotter’s method in which the patient is made to sit, leaning a little forward over a basin to spit any blood and breathe quietly from the mouth. It is the first step to control epistaxis.

Option a: Epley’s maneuver is used in the treatment of BPPV (Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo).

Option c: McGovern’s technique is used in choanal atresia - A feeding nipple with a large hole provides a good oral airway.

Option D: Valsalva maneuver is performed by forceful attempted exhalation against a closed nose and mouth. It is used as a test of cardiac function and autonomic nervous control of the heart, or to clear the ears and sinuses.

questions.text: What is the level of prevention when a person receives penicillin injections for the treatment of rheumatic heart disease?
questions.solution:
Receiving penicillin injections for the treatment of rheumatic heart disease is Secondary prevention.

Secondary prevention includes early disease detection, and its target is healthy-appearing individuals with subclinical forms of the disease. This is defined as the action which halts the progress of the disease at its incipient stage and prevents complications.

Levels of Prevention : 

1. Primordial prevention:

  • Involves the prevention of the emergence or development of risk factors in countries or population groups in which they have not yet appeared.
  • Examples include adult health problems like obesity and hypertension, which have an early onset due to lifestyles like smoking, eating patterns and physical exercise, which are discouraged from early childhood
  • The main intervention in primordial prevention is through individual and mass education.

2. Primary prevention:

  • These are defined as "action taken prior to the onset of disease, which removes the possibility that a disease will ever occur''
  • It signifies intervention in the pre-pathogenesis phase of a disease or health problem
  • Primary prevention is accomplished by measures promoting general health and well-being, and the quality of life of people by specific protective measures.
  • They include two strategies:
  • Population (mass) strategy: Where the target group is the whole population
  • High-risk strategy: Where the target group is limited to the people who are most at risk of developing a particular disease
  • Examples: immunity, sanitation, and protection of food.

3. Secondary prevention :

  • This is defined as "action which halts the progress of the disease at its incipient stage and prevents complications.".
  • The specific interventions are early diagnoses like screening tests and adequate treatment.
  • The main aim of secondary prevention is to arrest the disease process.
  • Secondary prevention is largely the domain of clinical medicine and health programs initiated by governments.
  • It is an imperfect tool in the control of the transmission of disease. It is often more expensive and less effective than primary prevention.

4. Tertiary prevention :

  • Measures to reduce the duration of mental illness and family and community stresses to prevent further breakdown and disruption.
  • Disability limitation belongs to tertiary prevention.

Related Pearl: Levels of Prevention

Level

Primordial

Primary

Secondary

Tertiary

Phase of disease

Underlying socio-economic & environmental conditions leading to causation

Specific causal or risk factors

Early stage of disease

Late stage of disease

Aim

Establish and maintain conditions that minimize hazards to health

Reduce the incidence of disease

Reduce prevalence by shortening duration

Reduce number and impact of complications

Actions

Inhibition of emergence of socio-economic, environmental and behavioural conditions

Protection of personal and community health by eliminating risks

Early detection and intervention to minimize disability

Soften the impact of long-term disease and disability, minimize suffering

Modes of Intervention

Health education

Health promotion and specific protection

 

Diagnosis and treatment

Disability limitation and rehabilitation

Targets

Total population or select groups

Total population or high risk individuals/groups

 

Individuals/ Patients

Patients

questions.text: The insecticide shown below is used to eliminate the larval form of
questions.solution:
The above image shows Paris green which is a commonly used larvicide against Anopheles larvae. Paris green mainly kills larvae who are surface feeders which include Anopheles larvae.

Paris green (Copper acetoarsenite) is an insecticide, which is a green powder that has 50% arsenious oxide. It is a stomach poison and to be effective, it must be ingested by the larvae. 

Other commonly used larvicides are:

  • Mineral oils - diesel oil, kerosene, fractions of crude oils, mosquito larvicidal oil
  • Synthetic insecticides - Fenthion, Chlorpyrifos, and Abate

Larvicides that are not recommended include organochlorine compounds like DDT and HCH. This is because they have a long residual effect, and contaminate water. Vector mosquitoes may also develop resistance to these compounds.

The larvae of Anopheles lie parallel to the surface of the water. They don't have a siphon tube. In their larval stage, they are surface feeders. In contrast, Culicine larvae like Aedes, Culex, Mansonia have a siphon tube that helps them to suspend in water with their head downwards.

The image below shows Laraval forms of different mosquitoes.

questions.text: What attaches at the 3' end of the transfer RNA (tRNA) cloverleaf structure?
questions.solution:
The sequence CCA attaches at the 3' end of the transfer RNA (tRNA) cloverleaf structure.

Transfer RNA is a type of RNA that helps to transport amino acids from the cell cytoplasm to the ribosome where protein synthesis is taking place. Since they are soluble in nature, they are also known as soluble RNA (sRNA). They undergo internal base-pairing (represented by the black dotted lines in the image below) to form the secondary cloverleaf structure.

Each part of the cloverleaf structure serves a different purpose. The parts of the cloverleaf include:

  • Anticodon loop
  • Acceptor arm
  • D loop
  • TΨC loop
  • Variable loop

 

The anticodon loop shown is where the anticodon triplet codons are present that make a tRNA specific. This anticodon will base pair with the complementary codon on the mRNA (messenger RNA) strand undergoing translation.

The acceptor arm is at the 3' end. This 3' end of the tRNA has the CCA sequence. The hydroxyl group on the A of the CCA sequence gets charged by accepting the amino acid specific to the codon (on the mRNA) that pairs with the anticodon loop. This then gets added to the elongating polypeptide chain. 

The D loop, TΨC loop, and variable loop are involved in defining the specific tRNA and ensuring accurate codon-anticodon base pairing.

Other options-

Option (A): The guanyl cap is not a part of tRNA. it is a molecule of 7-methyl guanosine triphosphate at the 5' end of mRNA. 

Option (B): The anticodon is present at the anticodon loop as shown in the above image. The anticodon is complementary to the codon present on the mRNA strand.

Option (D): The codon refers to sequences of base triplets on the mRNA strand. These codons base pair with the corresponding anticodons on the anticodon arm of the tRNA. This allows the correct amino acid at the 3' end of the tRNA structure to get added to the elongating polypeptide chain.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding carpal tunnel syndrome?

choices.text: Pain and paresthesia are worse at night time
Paresthesia over the skin of thenar eminence is prominent
No artery passes through the tunnel

questions.solution:
Parastheisa over skin of thenar eminence is not seen in carpal tunnel syndrome since the median nerve gives off the palmar cutaneous branch, that supplies the thenar eminence before it enters the carpal tunnel.

Carpal tunnel syndrome :

  • Caused by compression of the median nerve due to the reduced size of the osseofibrous carpal tunnel.
  • Due to inflammation or thickening of the synovial sheaths of the flexors tendons (tenosynovitis) due to stress injury (eg. data entry).
  • Inflammation of the flexor retinaculum, or arthritic changes in the carpal bones (particularly rheumatoid arthritis).
  • The pain and paresthesia are worse at night and on gripping objects.

Structures passing through the carpal tunnel: 

  • Tendons of FDS, FDP, FPL and the median nerve. 
  • No artery passes through the tunnel.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male has pain and swelling in the knee joint.  Synovial fluid on polarized light microscopy demonstrated positively birefringent rhomboid-shaped crystals. This is due to the deposition of _______
questions.solution:
The given case is suggestive of pseudogout and in the study of synovial aspirate on polarized light, the crystals appear as positively birefringent rhomboid-shaped crystals is due to the deposition of calcium pyrophosphate crystals.

Crystals on Polarised Microscopy
Gout Pseudogout

questions.text: A 45-year-old teacher comes to you with complaints of dryness, tightness, and soreness in the throat. He says these symptoms appear after long hours of talking in class. He is also unable to hold long conversations. On direct laryngoscopy, the following is seen. What is his possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Phonasthenia is the condition seen in this patient. The clinical scenario of voice overuse and keyhole appearance of glottis point to this diagnosis. Here, both thyroarytenoid and inter arytenoid muscles are involved.

Phonasthenia is the weakness of voice due to fatigue of laryngeal muscles. This leads to a phonatory gap. The shape of the gap depends on the muscle involved:

  • Thyroarytenoid alone: elliptical space
  • Interarytenoid alone: triangular space
  • Both thyroarytenoid and interarytenoid: keyhole appearance

questions.text: What is the diagnosis based on the image shown below?
questions.solution:
The X-ray gives the diagnosis of bladder stones. The tip of a catheter can also be seen in the Xray.

Primary bladder stone:

  • Develops in sterile urine in the absence of any known functional, anatomic, or infectious factors and does not necessarily imply that stones have formed de novo in the bladder.
  • Most common in children younger than 10 years of age
  • Most vesical calculi are mixed
  • Ammonium acid urate, calcium oxalate, uric acid, and calcium phosphate are the most common components of primary bladder calculi

Secondary bladder stone: Forms during infection, due to bladder outflow obstruction, impaired bladder emptying, or the presence of a foreign body.

Types:

  • Calcium oxalate stones
  • Uric acid stones - occur in patients with gout but are also observed in patients with ileostomies or with bladder outlet obstruction
  • Cystine stones - in cystinuria
  • Triple phosphate stones - occur in urine infected with urea-splitting organisms

questions.text: The reason for long left recurrent laryngeal nerve is due to the persistence of which arch artery?
questions.solution:
The long left recurrent laryngeal nerve is due to the persistence of the left 6th arch artery.

  • During the development, the laryngeal nerves initially arise below the 6th arch artery and cross here to innervate the intrinsic muscles of the larynx.
  • As the larynx moves cranially relative to the aortic arch arteries, the recurrent laryngeal nerves on right and left sides are caught under the 6th arch arteries.
  • Now, on the right side, the distal 6th arch artery disappears, and since there is no 5th arch artery, the right recurrent laryngeal nerve is caught under the 4th arch artery which becomes the future right subclavian artery.
  • On the left side, the 6th arch artery persists, which develops into ductus arteriosus, which later forms ligamentum arteriosum. Due to the persistence of the 6th arch artery, the left recurrent laryngeal nerve is caught under it and therefore, has a relatively long course.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used for the maintenance of opioid dependence as a substitute therapy?
questions.solution:
Methadone is used for the maintenance of opioid (heroin) dependence as a substitute therapy because of its good oral bioavailability and long half-life. 

Methadone is substituted for opioids during detoxification to avoid withdrawal symptoms. Once stabilized, the dose is gradually reduced and the drug is stopped slowly over days.

Treatment for opioid dependence - 

Maintainance phase: to decrease the severity of withdrawal symptoms.

  • Long-acting opioid agonist: methadone is given to prevent the withdrawal symptoms.
  • Partial agonist: buprenorphine can also be used.
  • Clonidine, lofexidine: alpha-2 agonist acts as sympatholytic and reduces the withdrawal symptoms.

Relapse prevention phase:

  • Naltrexone: an opioid antagonist that blocks opioid effects.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl is brought with a history of impaired vision. On examination, she has light hair, light skin color, and pale blue iris. The child has a normal IQ.  You suspect a disorder due to a deficiency of an enzyme tyrosinase. What is the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical features along with the deficiency of the enzyme tyrosinase point to the diagnosis of albinism.

The first step in melanin synthesis involves the oxidation of L-tyrosine to DOPA by the enzyme tyrosinase. Tyrosinase again acts on DOPA to form dopaquinone, which undergoes a series of reactions to form melanin. Mutations in the tyrosinase gene lead to a complete inability to produce melanin.

Albinism is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern. Oculocutaneous albinism (OCA) is characterized by a reduction or complete lack of melanin pigment in the skin, hair, and eyes. This manifests as white hair, white skin, and iris appearing blue-gray in oblique light. Ocular manifestations include photophobia, nystagmus, and decreased visual acuity. The IQ of the child will be normal.

Given below is an image of a young child with albinism showing white hair, skin, and pale iris:

Other options:

Option B: Phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency leads to phenylketonuria. This defect results in the impaired conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine. Infants appear normal at birth. They gradually develop hyperactivity, agitation, low IQ, and hypopigmentation (due to tyrosine deficiency), Phenylacetate gives rise to the characteristic mousy odor in the body sweat, and urine.

Option C: The metabolic defect in alkaptonuria is a defective homogentisate oxidase. Patients typically will have dark urine or urine that turns dark on standing, ochronosis(bluish-black pigmentation in connective tissue), arthritis, the pigment in the sclera, and ear cartilage.

Option D: Tyrosinemia type 2 (oculocutaneous type) is caused due to the deficiency of the enzyme tyrosine transaminase. Clinical findings include palmoplantar keratosis, painful corneal erosions with photophobia, and learning disability.

questions.text: A young man develops slurred speech and an unsteady staggering gait after drinking heavily at a party. What could be his blood alcohol level?
questions.solution:
The alcohol level in a patient with slurred speech and staggering gait would approximately be 150-200 mg/100 mL.

The behavioral changes with respect to the amount of alcohol in the blood are as follows :

  • >30 mg/100 mL causes impairment of driving skills.
  • 30 - 50 mg/100 mL leads to definite deterioration of driving ability.
  • 50 - 100 mg/100 mL starts showing objective signs such as loud rambunctious talking and laughing, progressive loss of social inhibitions, and some sensory disturbance.
  • 100 - 150 mg/100 mL causes ataxia, impaired memory, sleepiness, and slowed reaction time.
  • 150 - 200 mg/100 mL leads to obvious drunkenness, staggering gait, and nausea.
  • 200 - 300 mg/100 mL causes stupor, vomiting, and maybe even lead to coma.
  • 300 - 350 mg/100 mL can lead to stupor/ coma with a risk of aspiration of vomit.
  • >350 mg/100 mL can cause respiratory center paralysis leading to death.

Acute alcohol intoxication can be treated with the evacuation of stomach and bowel contents and gastric lavage with an alkaline solution. 1L of normal saline with 10% glucose, 100 mg thiamine, and 15U insulin may be useful. If the coma progresses deeper, stimulants like strychnine and caffeine can be used. Patients should be started on artificial respiration if there is respiratory depression or difficulty breathing. 

Chronic alcohol intoxication can be treated with disulfiram (daily dose of 250 mg OD), conditioned reflex treatment, hypnosis, and psychotherapy.

The alcohol content in common alcoholic drinks :

  • Rum, liquor - 50-60%.
  • Whisky, vodka, gin, brandy - 40-45%.
  • Port, sherry - 20%.
  • Wine, champagne - 10-15%.
  • Beer - 4-8%

According to the Motor Vehicles (Amendment) Act 2019, whoever while driving, or attempting to drive, a motor vehicle, has, in his blood, alcohol exceeding 30 mg/100 mL of blood, detected in a test by a breath analyzer is punishable by law.

questions.text: A schizophrenic patient was started on an antipsychotic drug that decreased his hallucinations significantly. 3 days after starting the medication, he developed torticollis and orofaciolingual movements. This effect is due to which of the following actions?
questions.solution:
The patient is suffering from acute dystonia. Acute dystonia is seen due to the D2(Dopamine receptor) blocking effect of the antipsychotic.

Acute dystonia is an extrapyramidal side effect of antipsychotics that occurs within 1-5 days of intake.It is characterized by spasms of the muscles of the tongue, face, neck and back.

Amongst extrapyramidal symptoms of antipsychotics, acute muscular dystonia is the earliest appearing symptom and akathisia is the most common one.

Other options:

Option A: Alpha blockade results in hypotension and sedation.
Option B: H1 blockade results in an antiemetic effect and causes sedation
Option C: Antimuscarinic effect result in dry mouth, dilated pupils, and urinary retention.

Related Pearl: Extrapyramidal side effects of antipsychotic drugs

Adverse reactions
Time of onset
Features
Treatment
Acute dystonia
1 to 5 days
Spasm of muscles of tongue, face, neck, back
Diphenhydramine or benztropine
Akathisia
5 to 60 days
Restlessness
Propanolol, lorazepam, diphenhydramine, benztropine
Parkinsonism
5 to 30 days
Bradykinesia, rigidity, tremors
Dose reduction, change medication, antiparkinsonian agents
Tardive dyskinesia
Months to years
Orofacial dyskinesia (may be reversible with early recognition and drug discontinuation)
VMAT-2 inhibitors valbenazine and deutetrabenazine
Neuroleptic malignant syndrome
Weeks to months
Extreme rigidity, fever, unstable blood pressure
Dantrolene

questions.text: A child presents with hepatitis and progressive neurological degeneration. A picture of his eye has been provided below. Which among the following investigation would help in this child's diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario and Kayser-Fleischer (KF) ring seen in the image suggest Wilson's disease. The initial step regarding investigations done for the diagnosis is the measurement of serum ceruloplasmin levels.

The gold standard for diagnosis is a liver biopsy with quantitative copper assays. Other investigations that are used for diagnosis are reduced serum ceruloplasmin, elevated urine copper, elevated liver copper, elevated aminotransferases, and positive ATP7B mutation. The role of total serum copper in the diagnosis of Wilson's disease is limited. Measurement of serum ceruloplasmin and urinary copper is preferred.

Lab investigations in Wilson's disease would show:

Lab markers Change in Wilson's disease Reason
Serum ceruloplasmin ↓↓↓ ATP7B deficiency results in reduced bound copper
24h urinary copper ↑↑ Excess free copper excreted in urine
Total serum copper ↓ Due to marked reduction in ceruloplasmin

questions.text: A  woman presents with sudden onset of fever, altered mental status, confusion, and petechiae over both lower limbs. Laboratory reports were suggestive of acute kidney injury. Peripheral smear showed thrombocytopenia and schistocytes. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP).

Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) is thrombotic microangiopathy. It results from antibodies to metalloprotease ADAMTS13, which normally cleaves multimers of vWF. Failure to cleave these multimers results in excessive platelet adhesion and aggregation. This leads to platelet thrombi and fibrin deposits at various sites. These thrombi result in the classic pentad of: 

  • Microangiopathic hemolytic anaemia
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Renal failure
  • Neurologic findings
  • Fever

The platelet thrombi narrow the vessel lumen, causing shearing stress on the red blood cells that are passing through. This results in microangiopathic hemolytic anemia. On peripheral smear, these fragmented red cells appear as schistocytes or helmet cells, as shown in the image below:

They are treated using plasma exchange therapy. Glucocorticoids can also be used along with this therapy. In refractory cases, rituximab, vincristine, cyclophosphamide, and even splenectomy can be tried. 

Other causes of microangiopathic hemolytic anaemia include:

  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) (Most common)
  • Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS)

Other options-

Option (A): Immune thrombocytopenic purpura occurs as a chronic disease in adults with several episodes over time, usually following infections. It presents with mucocutaneous bleeding and very low platelet counts. These patients have otherwise normal peripheral blood pictures.

Option (B): Disseminated intravascular coagulation refers to the widespread intravascular clot formation, commonly due to sepsis, trauma, and obstetric complications. These patients present with petechiae, ecchymoses, oozing from venipuncture sites, etc. They do not display the classic pentad seen in TTP. Schistocytes may be present on peripheral smear. Deranged clotting parameters are seen only in DIC and not in TTP.

Option (C): Hemolytic uremic syndrome is a disorder seen predominantly in children, following an episode of bloody diarrhea. Escherichia coli O157:H7 is most commonly the cause of this diarrhea. It can also present with acute renal failure, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, and thrombocytopenia, but neurological manifestations are less common. ADAMTS13 levels are normal in a majority of patients. It can be low in some rare cases.

Related Pearl: Differences between TTP and HUS

Features

TTP

HUS

Causative agent

A deficiency of, or antibodies to the metalloprotease ADAMTS13

E. coli (O157: H7)

GI prodrome

Uncommon

Often

Age group affected

Adults

Children

Sex affected

Females

No sex predilection

Relapses

Common

Rare

Renal impairment

Usually mild

Often severe

Severe thrombocytopenia

Often

questions.text: All of the following statements regarding Marjolin's ulcer are true except
questions.solution:
Marjolin’s Ulcer is avascular.

Related Pearl: Marjolin’s Ulcer

  • Low-grade cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma arising from
    • Long-standing ulcer like venous ulcer
    • Post-burn scar
    • Chronic osteomyelitis
    • Post-radiation ulcer.
  • Slow progression to malignancy (SCC) since it is relatively avascular.
  • Painless due to the absence of nerves in scar tissue.
  • No secondary deposits since there are no lymphatics in scar tissue.
  • Radioresistant due to avascularity.

questions.text: Substrate level phosphorylation occurs in which of the following steps of the TCA cycle?

choices.text: Alpha keto glutarate to succinyl CoA

questions.solution:
Succinyl-CoA is converted to succinate by the enzyme succinate thiokinase or also called as succinyl-CoA synthetase.

GTP formation takes place in this step, and hence this is the one and only example of substrate-level phosphorylation in the TCA cycle.

Related Pearl: Steps involved in TCA cycle

Step 1

Acetyl CoA + Oxaloacetate → Citrate

     (2C  + 4C  =   6C)

Enzyme: Citrate Synthase

Irreversible, Exothermic reaction
Step 2

Citrate → Cis –aconitate  → Isocitrate 

( 6C    →          6C →             6C)

Enzyme:   Aconitase

Cofactor:   Fe2+

The Reaction occurs in 2 steps:         

1st step:  Dehydration      

2nd step:  Rehydration

Inhibited by: Fluoroacetate (Non- Competitive)
Step 3

Isocitrate →[Oxalosuccinate]→α- Keto glutarate

        (6C) →         [6C]         →         (5C)

Enzyme:  Isocitrate Dehydrogenase

Cofactor:   Mn2+ or Mg2+

Reaction:  Oxidative  Decarboxylation

Intermediate:   Oxalosuccinate [ Unstable]

Release:    1 NADH and CO2
Step 4

α- Keto glutarate → Succcinyl Co A 

       (5C             →         4C)

Enzyme: α- Ketoglutarate Dehydrogenase(Multienzyme complex)

Reaction:  Oxidative Decarboxylation

Inhibited by: Arsenite  (Non – Competitive)

Physiologically unidirectional step.

Release: 1 NADH and CO2
Step 5

Succinyl- CoA  → Succinate

      ( 4C          →         4C )

Enzyme:  Succinate Thiokinase

Cofactor: Mg2+

Release:  1 ATP / GTP

Substrate level phosphorylation
Step 6

Succinate  →   Fumarate

( 4C          →         4C )

Enzyme:  Succinate Dehydrogenase (Part of 2nd complex ETC)

Cofactor:  FAD and Fe-S protein 

The only enzyme of TCA cycle attached to the inner mitochondrial membrane.

Inhibited by: Malonate ( competitive)

Release: FADH2
Step 7

Fumarate  →   Malate

( 4C         →     4C )

Enzyme:  Fumarate Hydratase

Reaction: Hydration
Step 8

Malate  →  Oxaloacetate  

( 4C     →        4C )

Enzyme:  Malate Dehydrogenase

Release:  1 NADH

Oxaloacetate is regenerated.

questions.text: What is the common type of degeneration seen in fibroids during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The common type of degeneration seen in fibroids during pregnancy is red degeneration.

Red degeneration is a complication of uterine myomas that develops most frequently during pregnancy. It is also seen in cases of painful fibroids in women older than 40 years. The myoma becomes tense and tender and causes severe abdominal pain with constitutional upset and fever. The fibroid assumes a peculiar purple-red colour and develops a fishy odour. Some of the large veins in the capsule and the small vessels in the substance of the tumour will be found thrombosed.

In calcareous degeneration, phosphates and carbonates of lime are deposited in the periphery along the course of the vessels. These are seen in old patients with long-standing fibroids. They are like womb- stones in graveyards.

 

Related Pearl: Secondary changes and complications in fibromyomas

  • Hyaline change, cystic degeneration and atrophy

  • Calcareous degeneration, osseous degeneration

  • Red degeneration

  • Sarcomatous change

  • Torsion, hemorrhage

  • Infection/ ulceration, particularly in the dependent part of a submucous polyp

  • Inversion of the uterus

  • Endometrial carcinoma associated with fibromyoma

  • Endometrial and myohyperplasia

  • Accompanying adenomyosis

  • Parasitic fibroid

questions.text: A young male patient presents with ptosis which reportedly worsens in the evening and improves in the morning. He also complains of excessive fatiguability towards the end of the day which improves with rest. Placing an ice pack over his eyes significantly decreases the ptosis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
From the given clinical picture, myasthenia gravis is the most likely diagnosis. This patient has symptoms of ptosis, progressive weakness, and excessive fatiguability which improves with rest. 

Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune neuromuscular junction disorder that is characterized by weakness and fatigability of skeletal muscles. It is due to the autoantibody-mediated destruction of the acetylcholine receptors (AChRs) at the post-synaptic membrane. This consequentially leads to a decreased transmission at the neuromuscular junction. Failure of transmission results in muscle weakness.

Females are more commonly affected than males and the disease tends to occur in middle age.

Clinical features of myasthenia gravis include muscle weakness and fatigue increasing with repeated use or late in the day and may improve following rest or sleep. Cranial muscles, particularly the lids and extraocular muscles, are involved early in the course causing diplopia and ptosis.

Myasthenic crisis is an acute exacerbation of muscle weakness especially intercostal and diaphragmatic muscles resulting in ventilatory failure. It is most commonly due to infection and anticholinesterase medication overuse. Myasthenia gravis is associated with thymoma and other autoimmune diseases such as Hashimoto's thyroiditis, Grave's disease, neuromyelitis optics, systemic lupus erythematosus, etc.

Diagnosis is with the ice-pack test, Anti-AChR antibodies, Anti-MuSK antibodies, and Anti-LRP4 antibodies. The repetitive nerve stimulation test shows a decremental response. Edrophonium chloride or Tensilon test.

Treatment is with anticholinesterase drugs like pyridostigmine, thymectomy, immunosuppression therapy with glucocorticoids, azathioprine, tacrolimus, rituximab, etc and plasmapheresis and intravenous immunoglobulin.

Other options:

Option B: Huntington's disease (HD) also known as Huntington chorea is associated with CAG repeats and anticipation. It has an adult-onset and is associated with the degeneration of striatal neurons. Features such as chorea and dementia are commonly seen in these patients. The characteristic features of HD include involuntary movements, dementia, and behavioural changes.

Option C: ALS (Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis ) is the most common progressive motor neuron disease. The pathologic hallmark of ALS includes the involvement of lower motor neurons of the ventral/ anterior horn of the spinal cord, cranial nerves innervating the bulbar muscles, and the afferent corticospinal upper motor neurons in layer five of the motor cortex. Progressive upper motor neuron (UMN) palsy (exaggerated reflexes, extensor plantar), lower motor neuron (LMN) palsy (muscle weakness, atrophy, fasciculations), and pseudobulbar palsy (dysarthria, tongue spasticity), with normal bladder, bowel and sensory function are suggestive of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).

Option D: The classical presentation of ptosis with progressively declining ocular movement is characteristic of chronic progressive external ophthalmoplegia (CPEO). CPEO may occur in isolation, in association with Kearns-Sayre syndrome (mitochondrial myopathy associated with mitochondrial DNA deletions), or oculopharyngeal dystrophy.

questions.text:
Which of the following is true regarding CORADS?

CORADS- COVID-19 Reporting and Data System

choices.text: Pleural thickening is typical of COVID-19
Lobar consolidation is typical of COVID-19

questions.solution:
Among the given options, CORADS-5 is typical of COVID-19 is the true statement.

COVID-19 Reporting and Data System (CO-RADS) is a categorical assessment for pulmonary involvement of COVID-19 on chest CT.

CO-RADS Category Summary
CO-RADS 0 Scans are incomplete or of inferior quality
CO-RADS 1 Normal or non-infectious
CO-RADS 2 Typical features of other infections but not of COVID-19
CO-RADS 3  Features compatible with COVID-19 but also with other diseases
CO-RADS 4  Suspicious for COVID-19
CO-RADS 5  Typical for COVID-19
CO-RADS 6  Proven COVID-19 by positive RT-PCR test

 

CO-RADS categories:

  • CO-RADS 0: Not interpretable - Technically insufficient to assign a score: Scans are incomplete or of inferior quality.
  • CO-RADS 1: Very low level of suspicion for pulmonary involvement by COVID-19. Mild or severe emphysema, perifissural nodules, lung tumors, or fibrosis.
  • CO-RADS 2: Low level of suspicion for pulmonary involvement by COVID-19. Includes infectious etiology that is not compatible with COVID-19 such as bronchitis, bronchiolitis, bronchopneumonia, lobar pneumonia, abscess.
  • CO-RADS 3: Equivocal findings for pulmonary involvement by COVID-19. Findings overlap with other viral or infectious etiologies. Could include perihilar ground-glass, homogenous extensive ground-glass with or without sparing of secondary pulmonary lobules.
  • CO-RADS 4: High level of suspicion for pulmonary involvement by COVID-19. Findings are similar to CO-RADS 5 but are not present in the typical locations. Findings may also be superimposed on severe pre-existing pulmonary abnormalities.
  • CO-RADS 5 based on typical CT findings. It requires the presence of at least one confirmatory pattern (mentioned below).
  • CO-RADS 6: Proven COVID-19 by positive RT-PCR test.

CT features typical of pulmonary involvement in COVID-19 include:

  • Obligatory features
    • Ground glass opacities, with or without consolidation in areas close to the visceral pleural surface, including the fissures.
  • Confirmatory features
    • Ground glass regions
    • Crazy paving pattern
    • Organizing pneumonia compatible patterns 
    • Thickened vessels with parenchymal abnormalities

questions.text: A 50 year old man got stuck inside a building on fire. He died of suffocation due to smoke. What is the cause of death?
questions.solution:
Victims of smoke inhalation are affected by carbon monoxide poisoning and the cause of death in this patient with carbon monoxide poisoning is anemic hypoxia.

CARBON MONOXIDE POISONING: 
Carbon monoxide has a higher affinity to hemoglobin compared to oxygen and forms a stable compound known as 'carboxyhemoglobin' (COHb) and hence the amount of hemoglobin available for oxygen transport is markedly reduced, thus producing ' anemic hypoxia'.

An additive factor influencing the toxicity of CO is the fact that the presence of COHb shifts the oxygen-  hemoglobin dissociation curve to the left, thereby increasing the bondage of Hb with oxygen and reducing its release to the tissues. 

It is important to note that in the case of anemic hypoxia, O2 content is low but dissolved O2 is within normal limits so it does not stimulate peripheral chemoreceptors.

Poisoning by CO is mostly accidental. The decrepit, the diseased, the drugged and the drunk are more often involved in accidental poisoning.

The human fetus is particularly sensitive to CO because,

  1. Greater concentrations of Hb leading to greater  COHb in the fetus rather than in the mother.
  2. Partial pressure of oxygen in the fetal blood is lower than the adults.
  3. The fetal oxygen - hemoglobin dissociation curve lies to the left of the adult curve, leading to greater tissue hypoxia at equivalent COHb concentrations.

Patients recovering from CO poisoning may suffer neurological sequelae including

  • Tremors 
  • Personality changes 
  • Memory impairment 
  • Monoplegia 
  • Hemiplegia 
  • Psychosis 
  • Peripheral neuropathy 
  • Visual loss 
  • Inability to concentrate and 
  • Parkinsonism within 2-4 weeks.

Symptoms of chronic poisoning of CO include: 

  • Head ache 
  • Confusion 
  • Weakness 
  • Paresthesias 
  • Hypertension 
  • Hyperthermia 
  • Visual disturbances 
  • Palpitations 
  • Atrial fibrillation 
  • AV block 
  • Decreased cognitive ability 
  • Parkinsonism, etc.,

TREATMENT:

  1. Remove the patient to fresh air immediately. If he is conscious and breathing, no treatment is required.
  2. Any patient with COHb levels greater than 25% should be treated. 
  3. Provide 100% oxygen with a tight fitting mask.
  4. CO2 should not be given.
  5. Gastric lavage.
  6. Whole blood transfusion.
  7. Mannitol, steroids and fluid restriction to treat cerebral edema.
  8. Prophylactic antibiotics
  9. Complete rest for 48 hours.
  10. Avoid stimulant drugs.

POST-MORTEM APPEARANCE:

Typical ' cherry red' discolouration of skin and mucous membrane is seen.

Note: Carbon monoxide poisoning causes both anemic (due to CO-Hb) and histotoxic (due to inhibition of cyt c oxidase) hypoxia. But the main cause of death is due to anemic hypoxia.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy was brought to the OPD following a sting on his toe. He had tachycardia, hypertension, and his pupils were dilated. The wound was mildly erythematous. The agent responsible for the sting is shown below. Which of the following drugs is used to counteract these effects?
questions.solution:
The clinical stem with the image showing a scorpion points to a scorpion bite, for which Prazosin acts as a physiological antidote counteracting the symptoms of tachycardia, hypertension, and mydriasis. 

Most scorpion stings cause pain at the site of the bite. Systemic toxicity occurs in <10% of stings but is more commonly seen in infants and children. The venom is a clear, colorless toxalbumen and is generally classified as either hemolytic or neurotoxic. 

The venom is a potent autonomic stimulator resulting in the release of massive amounts of catecholamines from the adrenals. It also has a direct effect on the myocardium.

It can present as neurotoxicity with restlessness or seizure-like activity, abnormal oculomotor function, loss of pharyngeal muscle control leading to respiratory compromise. Tongue fasciculations and hypersalivation are also common. Cardiovascular toxicity from systemic envenomation includes tachycardia, hypertension, pulmonary edema, and cardiogenic shock.

If the scorpion has hemolytic venom, the reaction is mainly local, with edema, pain, and reddening. This usually lasts for one to two hours. 

Treatment:

  • Pain- Paracetamol, NSAIDs, or opioids 
  • Sedation for agitation, oculomotor abnormalities, uncoordinated neuromuscular activity, muscle spasms- Benzodiazepines 
  • Hypertension and pulmonary edema- Prazosin counteract the adrenergic surge that can lead to these effects
  • Cardiogenic shock- Antivenom, prazosin, nitroglycerin, dobutamine
  • Cholinergic effects- Atropine
  • Supportive care, wound care

questions.text: A middle-aged man who is a chronic alcoholic presented to the casualty with confusion, ataxia, and diplopia. What is the protocol to treat this patient?

choices.text: Vitamin B1 injection followed by glucose infusion

questions.solution:
The above clinical history is suggestive of Wernicke's encephalopathy. The current standard of treatment for patients with symptoms of Wernicke's encephalopathy is to give thiamine 100 mg intravenously before administering glucose-containing IV fluids.

Thiamine deficiency leads to the following:

  1. Wernicke’s encephalopathy: It is more commonly seen in alcoholics with chronic thiamine deficiency. It is characterized by:
    • Global confusion
    • Truncal ataxia
    • Ophthalmoplegia
    • Horizontal nystagmus 
  2. Korsakoff psychosis: symptoms in addition to those of Wernicke's encephalopathy include:
    • Memory loss
    • Confabulation
  3. Beriberi: It can present with:
    • Dry beriberi: sensorimotor peripheral neuropathy, muscle weakness
    • Wet beriberi: tachycardia, cardiomegaly, high-output cardiac failure

Related Pearl: Vitamin Deficiency States (Water-soluble Vitamins)

Vitamin

Deficiency State

Thiamine (B1)

Relatively unknown
