Ecchymosis, bleeding gums, poor wound healing, fatigue, joint effusion, Scorbutic rosary

questions.text:
The device shown in the image given below is used in.

HDR - High dose rate
questions.solution:
The device shown in the image is a remote afterloader. Remote afterloading is related to brachytherapy.

Brachytherapy is a method of treatment in which sealed radioactive sources are used to deliver radiation at a short distance by interstitial, intracavitary, or surface application.

The following isotopes are used in brachytherapy:

  • I-125 and Iridium-192 - used in low dose rate (LDR) brachytherapy. 
  • Cobalt-60 - is used for high dose rate (HDR) brachytherapy.

Afterloading is the process of placing the radioactive material into the target region. This is either done manually by the oncologist, or by using remote afterloading devices.

Remote afterloading devices enable us to eliminate direct contact with radioactive sources while administration. It provides protection from radiation exposure to healthcare professionals by securing the radiation source in a shielded safe manner.

questions.text: Which among the given features is not a major physiological change in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Among the given features hypothyroidism is not a major physiological change in pregnancy.

The α-subunits of hCG and TSH are identical. An increase in hCG during pregnancy stimulates thyroid and leads to a decrease in TSH levels. The thyroid undergoes enlargement and boosts the production of hormones. This is accompanied by increased production of thyroid-binding globulin(TBG). All these changes increase total T4 and T3 in the first trimester. But the physiologically important free T4 and T3 levels remain unchanged. Hence, physiologically pregnant women remain euthyroid.

Option A: Normal pregnancy is characterized by insulin resistance and hyperinsulinemia. Human placental lactogen(hPL) secreted during pregnancy, helps in adaptation to fetal energy requirements. Insulin resistance causes prolonged hyperglycemia and glucose flow to the fetus. It also favours protein synthesis. To counterbalance the increased insulin resistance and prevent maternal hyperglycemia, maternal insulin levels are increased.

Option B: By the 3rd trimester, there is an increase in the maternal basal metabolic rate by 10 to 20% in comparison to a nonpregnant woman.

Option D: During normal pregnancy, mean arterial pressure and vascular resistance decrease, while blood volume and cardiac output rate increase. This helps in meeting metabolic demands of the enlarged uterus, provide nutrients to rapidly growing placenta and fetus, safeguard mother against the effects of parturition-associated blood loss.

questions.text: In a leprosy case, the microbiologist documents the bacterial index according to Ridley's logarithmic scale and notes the value as 4+ for one of the smears. This value corresponds to:

choices.text: 10-100 bacilli, on average, in each oil-immersion field
100-1000 bacilli, on average, in each oil-immersion field
More than 1000 bacilli, on average, in each oil-immersion field
1-10 bacilli, on average, in 10 oil immersion fields

questions.solution:
In a leprosy split skin smear, according to Ridley's logarithmic scale, 4+ would mean 10-100 bacilli, on average, in each oil-immersion field.

The Bacteria Index(BI) is calculated by adding the index from each site examined and dividing the total by the number of sites examined.

 For Eg: If the bacilli found on each site are as:

  • Right ear: 5+
  • Left ear: 6+
  • Back: 4+
  • Chin: 5+

BI=(5+6+4+5)/4

BI=20/4

therefore, BI=5+

The given image is the emblem of the National Leprosy Eradication Programme(NLEP)

Characteristics of NLEP emblem :

  • The lotus in the NLEP Emblem symbolizes beauty and purity.
  • A partially affected thumb; a normal fore-finger and the shape of house symbolize that leprosy can be cured and a patient with leprosy can be a useful member of the society.
  • The rising sun symbolizes hope and optimism.
  • The Emblem captures the spirit of hope and positivity in the eradication of Leprosy.

The National Leprosy Eradication Programme is a centrally sponsored Health Scheme of the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Govt. of India.

Leprosy work is not merely medical relief; it is transforming frustration of life into joy of dedication, personal ambition into selfless service- Mahatma Gandhi.

 

Related Pearl: Ridley's logarithmic scale in determining Bacterial Index

Bacterial Index(BI) indicates the density of the leprosy bacilli in smears and includes both living and dead bacilli.

According to Ridley's logarithmic scale, the range is from 0 to 6+ and is based on the number of bacilli seen in an average microscopic field of the smear using an oil-immersion objective.

0

No bacilli in any of the 100 oil-immersion field

1+

1-10 bacilli, on average, in 100 oil-immersion field

2+

1-10 bacilli, on average, in 10 oil-immersion field

3+

1-10 bacilli, on average, in each oil-immersion field

4+

10-100 bacilli, on average, in each oil-immersion field

5+

100-1000 bacilli, on average, in each oil-immersion field 

6+

More than 1000 bacilli, on average, in each oil-immersion field 

BI is calculated by adding up the index from each site examined and dividing the total by the number of sites examined.

questions.text: Fenestrated capillaries are absent in_________
questions.solution:
Fenestrated capillaries are absent in the lungs.

Fenestrated capillaries have gaps between endothelial cells. They are present in certain tissues that allow the passage of larger molecules such as the renal glomeruli, endocrine glands, intestinal mucosa, and pancreas.

questions.text: Identify the type of suturing shown below.
questions.solution:
The image shows the technique of interrupted Sutures. Here each suture should reach into the depths of the wound and be placed at right angles to the axis of the wound.

Option B: Mattress suture produce an accurate approximation of wound edges, especially when the edges to be anastomosed are irregular. The initial suture is inserted as for an interrupted suture, but then the needle either moves horizontally or vertically and traverses both edges of the wound once again as seen in the picture below.

Option C: Continuous Suture: For a continuous suture, the first suture is inserted in an identical manner to an interrupted suture, but the rest of the sutures are inserted in a continuous manner until the far end of the wound is reached.

Option D: Subcuticular Sutures: Small bites of the subcuticular tissues are taken on alternate sites of the wound and then gently pulled together thus approximating the wound edges without the risk of the cross-hatched markings of interrupted sutures. This technique is used in the skin where a cosmetic appearance is important and where the skin edges may be approximated easily.

questions.text: Which of the following nerve injury causes neurotrophic keratopathy?
questions.solution:
Neurotrophic keratopathy is due to loss of trigeminal nerve innervation resulting in partial or complete loss of sensation.

Causes:

  • Trigeminal ganglion surgical ablation for neuralgia
  • Stroke
  • Tumour
  • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Herpes simplex and herpes zoster keratitis (sectoral sensation loss)

Stages:

Stage 1: intrapalpebral epithelial irregularity, oedema and tiny focal deficits

Stage 2: Large persistent epithelial defects with rolled and thickened edges, assuming a punched out configuration

Stage 3: Stromal melting

Treatment: Topical lubricants, protection of the ocular surface with tarsorrhaphy, therapeutic silicone contact lenses, amniotic membrane patching.

 

Exposure keratopathy is caused by paralysis of the facial nerve.  

Exposure keratopathy

  • It is the result of incomplete lid closure (lagophthalmos), with the drying of the cornea despite normal tear production.
  • Causes 
    • Neuroparalytic, e.g., facial nerve palsy
    • Reduced muscle tone as in parkinsonism
    • Mechanical such as lid scarring
    • Proptosis

questions.text: A woman complained of excessive vomiting and mild vaginal bleeding for two weeks at a period of amenorrhea of 12 weeks. USG was done and a diagnosis of the complete mole was made.  Which of the following is true?

choices.text: 2% of the cases develop a Gestational Trophoblastic Neoplasia

questions.solution:
Diffuse trophoblastic hyperplasia is associated with complete mole.

46XX or 46XY is the karyotype of complete mole.

Embryo/fetus  will be absent in a complete mole.

15-20 % of complete moles develop Gestational Trophoblastic Neoplasia (GTN) later on.

Amnion, fetal erythrocytes Often present Absent

questions.text: A patient who underwent surgery for a lipoma 5 weeks back, now presents with a scar at the incision site that is limited to the original wound boundaries. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is of a hypertrophic scar as it stays within the confines of the original wound. Hypertrophic scars rise above the skin level but stay within the confines of the original wound and often regress over time.

Accumulation of excessive amounts of collagen during repair may give rise to hypertrophic scar or keloid. The accumulation of excessive amounts of collagen→ raised scars known as a hypertrophic scars. If the scar tissue grows beyond the boundaries of the original wound and does not regress → keloid formation. Formation of excessive amounts of granulation tissue, which protrudes above the level of the surrounding skin and blocks re-epithelialization → Exuberant granulation

Inadequate formation of granulation tissue or formation of a scar → wound dehiscence and ulceration. The contraction in the size of a wound is an important part of the normal healing process. An exaggeration of this process gives rise to contractures, which are particularly prone to develop on the palms, the soles, and the anterior aspect of the thorax and are commonly seen after serious burns.

Difference between keloid and hypertrophic scar:

Features Hypertrophic scar Keloid
Genetic predisposition Not familial Maybe familial - Autosomal dominant with incomplete penetration
Age Children Adolescents. Middle age
Sex Equal in both More common in females
Race No predilection African American, Asian, Hispanic
Site Anywhere (more common on flexor surface) Neck, chest, ear lobes, shoulders, upper back
Timings 4–6 weeks postinjury Symptom-free interval; may appear years after injury
Symptoms Raised, some pruritus, respects wound confines Pain, pruritus, hyperesthesia, growth beyond wound margins
Regression Frequent spontaneous No
Contracture Frequent Rare
Histology Parallel orientation of collagen fibers Hypocellular, thick, wavy collagen fibers in random orientation

 

Other options:

Option A: Keloid- are also raised scars resulting from excessive collagen production, they characteristically grow beyond the boundaries of the original wound. Here, the scar is "limited to the original wound boundaries," so this rules out keloid formation.

Option B: Exuberant granulation- involves excessive granulation tissue that protrudes above the surrounding skin and impedes re-epithelialization. 

Option D: Granulation tissue- is normal in the wound healing process, but it doesn't typically result in a raised scar limited to the original wound boundaries.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the characteristic pattern of varicella (chickenpox) lesions?

choices.text: Lesions appear in crops and show different stages simultaneously on the same area of skin.
The most concentrated distribution of lesions is typically found on the extremities rather than the trunk.
New lesions typically cease to form after fever resolution.
The lesions appear simultaneously across all affected areas.

questions.solution:
Different stages of lesions present simultaneously on the same area of skin, appearing in "crops" over several days is the hallmark of chickenpox (varicella).

The rash appears 24-48 hours after the prodromal symptoms as intensely pruritic erythematous macules first on the trunk. The distribution of the rash is predominantly central or centripetal, with the greatest concentration on the trunk and proximally on the extremities (Option B). The rash rapidly spreads to the face and extremities while it evolves into papules, fluid-filled vesicles and pustules. 

The rash lasts 3-7 days and leaves behind hypopigmented or hyperpigmented macules that persist for days to weeks. The period of infectivity lasts from 24-48 hours before the rash until all the vesicles are crusted and the scabs are not infective. Hence the child should not attend school until no new lesions appear and all lesions have crusted.

Other Options:

Option C: New lesions cease to form after fever resolution is incorrect because new lesions can continue to appear for several days after the fever subsides.

Option D: Chickenpox lesions specifically do not appear simultaneously. They emerge in successive crops over 3-4 days, with new lesions forming while older ones are crusting.

Related Pearl: Viral infections associated with rash

Viral infection  Rash characteristics 
Chickenpox Appears 1st day of fever, centripetal, pleomorphic, dewdrops on rose petal appearance
Measles Appears on the 4th day over the face and retroauricular origin
Rubella Rash on day 1 over the face

Erythema infectiosum

 Rash on cheeks (slapped cheek appearance), moves to trunk and extremities
Exanthem subitum Macules or maculopapular rash
Infectious mononucleosis Associated with maculopapular rash

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient presented with breathlessness and fatigue for 5 months. Chest X-ray showed left atrial enlargement with straightening of the left cardiac border. Echocardiogram showed reduced opening of the mitral valve during diastole with thickening of the valve leaflets. Which among the following findings can be heard during auscultation?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of mitral stenosis (MS), and a mid-diastolic murmur can be heard during auscultation.

MS is a valvular heart disease, most commonly caused by rheumatic fever. Other causes include:

  • Mitral annular calcification with leaflet involvement
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus, rheumatoid arthritis
  • Left atrial myxoma
  • Infective endocarditis with large vegetation

Chronic inflammation causes the thickening of the valve leaflets and the shortening and fusion of chordae tendineae, leading to the formation of a funnel-shaped or fish-mouth valve. Calcification immobilizes the leaflets and narrows the valve further. Thrombi are also commonly formed from the calcified valve or dilated left atrium (in atrial fibrillation).

Patients present with dyspnea and cough in the early stages. But as the disease progresses, daily activities are limited and the patient develops orthopnea and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. Hemoptysis can occur due to the rupture of pulmonary-bronchial venous connections as a result of pulmonary venous hypertension.

Important auscultatory findings of MS include:

  • Mid-diastolic murmur following OS:
    • Low-pitched, rumbling
    • Heard best at the apex with the patient in the left lateral position
    • Accentuated by mild exercise
    • Duration of the murmur correlates with the severity of the stenosis
    • Reappears or becomes louder during atrial systole in patients with sinus rhythm (presystolic accentuation)
  • Opening snap (OS) of the mitral valve following the aortic component of S2 (A2)
  • Accentuated and slightly delayed first heart sound (S1)

When the cardiac output is severely reduced, the typical auscultatory findings may not be heard. This is known as silent MS. Hepatomegaly, pedal edema, ascites, and pleural effusion, may occur in patients with right ventricular failure.

Other associated murmurs include:

  • Pansystolic murmur of functional tricuspid regurgitation:
    • Occurs with severe pulmonary hypertension
    • Audible along the left sternal border
    • Louder during inspiration and reduces during forced expiration (Carvallo’s sign)
  • Graham Steell murmur of pulmonary regurgitation:
    • High-pitched, diastolic, decrescendo-blowing murmur
    • Audible along the left sternal border
    • Occurs with severe pulmonary hypertension

Other options:

Option B:

An ejection mid-systolic murmur can be auscultated in aortic stenosis. It begins after S1, increases in intensity toward the middle of ejection, and ends just before aortic valve closure. It is low-pitched, rough, and rasping in character. It is best heard at the base of the heart, most commonly in the second right intercostal space.

Option C:

A pansystolic murmur of at least grade III/VI intensity can be auscultated in chronic severe mitral regurgitation. It is heard best at the apex and radiates to the axilla. Ruptured chordae tendineae may produce a murmur with a cooing or “seagull” quality, whereas a flail leaflet may produce a murmur with a musical quality. 

S1 is generally absent or soft. 

Option D:

An early diastolic murmur can be auscultated in chronic aortic regurgitation. It is high-pitched and blowing in character. It is best heard in the third intercostal space along the left sternal edge. It may be accompanied by a mid-systolic ejection murmur in isolated AR or the Austin Flint murmur in severe AR. The latter is a soft, low-pitched, rumbling, mid-to-late diastolic murmur produced by the displacement of the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve by the AR stream.

A2 is usually absent.

questions.text: Quarantine measures were implemented for the first time to prevent the spread of:
questions.solution:
Quarantine was introduced for the first time to prevent the spread of the plague, also known as the black death. 

Quarantine began as a practice in the 14th century to protect coastal cities from the plague. Ships arriving from infected ports were required to wait in anchor for a minimum duration before they were allowed entry.

Quarantine is the restriction on the movement of people, animals, and goods that may have been exposed to a communicable disease. It is intended to prevent the spread of communicable diseases.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the tympanogram shown below is true?

choices.text: Normal compliance and a negative pressure

questions.solution:
The tympanogram shown suggests that the tympanic cavity has increased compliance and the intratympanic pressure is normal. It is a type AD curve.

The differential diagnosis for the above tympanogram is:

  • Ossicular discontinuity
  • Thin/lax tympanic membrane

Related Pearl: Types of curves in tympanogram

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient came with a history of a hip fracture with surgical intervention four months back. He walks into the outpatient unit with the following gait. Which of the following nerves is most likely damaged in this patient?
questions.solution:
The above GIF shows a positive Trendelenburg's sign (Trendelenburg's gait), which is seen in paralysis of gluteus medius and gluteus minimus muscles which are supplied by the superior gluteal nerve. Injury to the left superior gluteal nerve results in Trendelenburg's gait.

The superior gluteal nerve supplies the gluteus medius and gluteus minimus.

Mechanism of actions of gluteus medius and minimus: 

  • When the leg on one side is lifted off the ground, the gluteus medius and minimus muscles, on the opposite supported side, exert traction on the hip bone by acting from the femur. This action results in the slight raising of the pelvis on the unsupported side, which helps maintain the trunk in the upright position.
  • When the gluteus medius and minimus are paralyzed, the pelvis sinks down on the unsupported (normal) side, when the patient tries to stand on the affected limb.

Identifying the side affected in the given GIF:

When the person lifts up his right leg and tries to stand on the left leg, the right pelvis tilts down. This shows that the left side abduction mechanism is paralyzed and the right side is normal. The left superior gluteal nerve is injured in this case since it supplies the left gluteus medius and minimus.

Note: These patients can also have a characteristic lurching gait.

Inferior gluteal nerve supplies the gluteus maximus muscle.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male was brought to the emergency room with a history of RTA. GCS progressively declines over hours and MRI shows multiple small hypointense lesions at corticomedullary junction and basal ganglia, what is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Axial T2 -weighted MR image demonstrates numerous foci of haemorrhage not seen on CT, manifesting as multiple hypointense punctate foci within the subcortical and deep white matter of both hemispheres and within the corpus callosum. It is suggestive of diffuse axonal injury.

Diffuse axonal injury (white matter shearing) is the result of shearing forces, typically from rotational acceleration.

Diffuse axonal injury is characterised by multiple focal lesions with a characteristic distribution:

  • Typically located at the grey-white matter junction, in the corpus callosum and in more severe cases in the brainstem.
  • CT may be normal.
  • MRI is the modality of choice for assessing suspected diffuse axonal injury even in patients with entirely normal CT of the brain.

questions.text: The drug of choice for the management of hyperthyroidism in the third trimester of pregnancy is?
questions.solution:
The drug of choice for the management of hyperthyroidism in the third trimester of pregnancy is methimazole.

Hyperthyroidism in pregnancy:

Pre-pregnancy and first trimester: Propylthiouracil 

2nd, 3rd trimester + post-pregnancy:

  • Methimazole
  • Partial thyroidectomy (in 2nd trimester if methimazole is not effective)

Methimazole and its prodrug (carbimazole) are usually avoided in the first trimester due to teratogenic risk. However, methimazole is used for the remainder of the pregnancy due to the concern for PTU-associated liver failure. 

Subtotal thyroidectomy can be performed during the mid-trimester.

Radioactive iodine crosses the placenta and causes the destruction of the fetal thyroid. Therefore, it is contraindicated during pregnancy and lactation.

Propranolol will help with her heart rate (is the patient is symptomatic), but will not help with the overactive thyroid.

If a pregnant woman is on propylthiouracil in her first trimester, she should be switched to methimazole in her 2nd trimester.

Note (in pregnancy):

  • Lowest possible dose should be prescribed
  • Radioiodine therapy contraindicated
Trimester Treatment for thyrotoxicosis
First trimester
  • Propylthiouracil
Second trimester
  • Methimazole
  • Subtotal thyroidectomy
Third trimester
  • Methimazole

Abnormalities associated with methimazole (when used in 1st trimester):

  • Choanal atresia
  • Aplasia cutis
  • Fetal goiter
  • Esophageal atresia
  • Scalp defects

Related Pearl: Teratogenic drugs and the birth defects

Drugs Adverse effects
Penicillamine Cutis laxa syndrome
Lithium Ebstein anomaly
Isotretinoin Facial-ear anomalies, heart disease, CNS anomalies
Progesterone Masculinization of the female fetus
Quinine Abortion, thrombocytopenia, deafness
Topiramate Cleft lip
Valproate Spina bifida, limb defects, autism spectrum disorder, facial and cardiac anomalies, Coarctation of the aorta, Aortic stenosis, Pulmonary atresia, Ventricular Septal Defect. 
Vitamin D Supravalvular aortic stenosis
Warfarin Fetal bleeding, hypoplastic nasal structures
Statins Vertebral, anal, cardiac, tracheoesophageal fistula, renal, arterial, limb (VACTERAL) defects
Phenytoin Ventricular septal defect, Atrial Septal Defect, Coarctation of the aorta, Patent Ductus Arteriosus
Alcohol Atrial Septal Defect, Ventricular Septal Defect

questions.text: A 7-year-old child post-tonsillectomy comes to you with complaints of snoring, palpitations, mouth breathing and a slight decrease in hearing. On examination, you notice a high-arched palate. His school performance has deteriorated as well. His mother is worried. What is the next line of management for this child?
questions.solution:
The patient is suffering from serous otitis media secondary to adenoid hypertrophy causing eustachian tube obstruction. The best line of management is adenoidectomy with grommet insertion.

Serous otitis media is also known as secretory otitis media or mucoid otitis media or glue ear. It is characterized by the accumulation of nonpurulent effusion in the middle ear cleft. 

Glue ear is thought to happen due to either malfunctioning (adenoid hyperplasia, chronic sinusitis or tonsillitis or rhinitis, palatal defects, tumors of nasopharynx) or increased secretory activity of the eustachian tube (allergy, unresolved otitis media, viral infections).

It is often seen in children 5-8 years of age. They present with hearing loss not exceeding 40 dB, which is insidious in onset. Speech may be delayed and defective due to hearing loss. Mild earaches with a history of upper respiratory tract infection are usually seen. 

On otoscopy, 

  • Dull and opaque tympanic membrane with loss of light reflex
  • Thin leash of vessels along the handle of the malleus 
  • If the tympanic membrane is transparent fluid levels and air bubbles can be seen

 

The tuning fork test reveals a conductive type of hearing loss. X-ray mastoid reveals clouding of air cells. 

Treatment is mainly aimed at the removal of fluid and preventing recurrence. 

  • Medical management includes decongestants, antihistamines, antibiotics, and middle ear aeration techniques. 
  • Surgical management includes myringotomy and aspiration of fluid, grommet insertion, tympanotomy, or cortical mastoidectomy.

questions.text: The false statement regarding the modified WHO partograph is?

choices.text: Right side of alert line indicates immediate referral to First Referral Unit (FRU)
Alert and action line are separated by a difference of 4 hours
Each small square in the partograph is equal 1 hour
Partograph recording should be started once the cervical dilatation reaches 4 cm

questions.solution:
The incorrect statement is each small square in partograph is equal to 1 hour. It is equal to 30 minutes. 

Partograph is a composite graphical record of key data (maternal and fetal) during labor, entered against time. The alert line starts at 4 cm of cervical dilatation and ends at 10 cm dilatation (at the rate of 1 cm/hr). The action line is drawn 4 hours to the right and parallel to the alert line. In normal labor, the graph should be either on the alert line or to the left of it.

When it falls on the right of the alert line(zone-2), it is abnormal and needs to be critically assessed. When it falls to the right of the action line (zone 3) case should be reassessed by a senior person and specific management decisions (for example- referral to a higher centre or performing an intervention like cesarean section) should be made.

Clinically, the active phase of labour is considered from ≥6 cm of cervical dilatation. However, we begin plotting the partograph from 4 cm of cervical dilatation (in accordance with the modified WHO Partograph).

Related Pearl: Partograph

Partograph types:

WHO Modified Partograph (2000)

  • No latent phase
  • Vaginal examination: This should be done no less than every 4 hours to assess cervical dilatation, descent of the fetal head, and moulding of skull bones. More frequent examination is only undertaken if indicated.
  • Charting starts at 4 cm of cervical dilation.
  • Colour of liquor mentioned as C-clear, B-blood stained, M-meconium stained.
  • Moulding mentioned:
    • bones are separated and sutures can be easily felt - (0)
    • bones touching (1+)
    • bones overlapping but can be reduced(2+)
    • bones severely overlapping and irreducible ( 3+).
  • Alert line reflects the average rate of cervical dilation of the slowest quintile of term primigravidas, if dilation slows or ceases, the partograph plot will cross the alert line.
  • Alert line: at 4 cm dilation and expected dilation of 1 cm/hour.
  • Action line is 2–4 hours after the alert line, which prompts interventions to accelerate labor or perform cesarean delivery.
  • Higher rates of perinatal mortality are associated with delays of 4 hours or more after the alert line.
  • Contractions measured for a span of 10 min (duration noted) and measured every 30 min (1 square = half hour).
  • Pulse: record every 30 minutes and mark with a dot (•).
  • Blood pressure: record every 4 hours and mark with arrows, unless the patient has a hypertensive disorder or pre-eclampsia, in which case record every 30 minutes.
  • Temperature: record every 4 hours.

WHO Composite Partograph: It is same as modified except for it has latent phase and charting done at 3 cm.

WHO Simplified Partograph: WHO further modified the partograph for use by skilled attendants in health centers. This simplified partograph is colour coded.

  • The area to the left of the alert line in the cervicograph is coloured green, representing normal progress.
  • The area to the right of the action line is coloured red, indicating dangerously slow progress in labour.
  • The area in between the alert and action line is coloured amber, indicating the need for greater vigilance.

questions.text: Which among the following is a contraindication for induction of labor?
questions.solution:
Active genital herpes is a contraindication for induction of labor. 

The fetus becomes affected by the virus shed from the cervix or lower genital tract during vaginal delivery. The risk of fetal infection is high in primary genital HSV due to high virus shedding compared to a recurrent infection. Caesarian delivery is indicated in an active primary HSV infection where the membranes are intact or recently ruptured.

Abruptio placentae, oligohydraminos and Rh-isoimmunization are indications for induction of labor.

Related Pearl: Indications & contraindications for induction of labor

Indication:

  • Gestational hypertension
  • Chronic hypertension
  • Pre-eclampsia
  • Post-term pregnancy
  • Abruption placentae
  • IUGR(intra-uterine growth restriction)
  • IUD(Intra-uterine death)
  • Oligohydramnios

Contraindication:

  • Contracted pelvis & CPD
  • Cord prolapse
  • Abnormally implanted placentae
  • Previous classical cesarean/ hysterotomy
  • Active genital herpes
  • Appreciable macrosomia
  • Severe hydrocephalus
  • Malpresentation
  • Pelvic tumor & Ca cervix
  • Overdistention or complete transection of the uterus
  • Two or more previous low transverse caesarean sections

questions.text: Iron absorption takes place in which part of intestine?
questions.solution:
Almost all the iron absorption occurs in the duodenum.

Most of the iron in the diet is in the ferric (Fe3+) form, whereas it is the ferrous (Fe2+) form that is absorbed.

NOTE:

Carbohydrates, proteins, lipids are absorbed in the entire small intestine. Bile acids in the entire small intestine but active absorption occurs only in the ileum. Folate in the upper small intestine (duodenum and jejunum).

questions.text: A 34 year old male presents with a history of progressive lower backache and early morning stiffness for the past 6 months. His symptoms are more severe in the morning and improve on exercise. He is a known case of ulcerative colitis. An X-ray of his lumbar spine is taken and is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and X-ray image are suggestive of ankylosing spondylitis The clinical presentation of a young male with progressive lower backache, morning stiffness, a symptomatic improvement on exercise, and the X-ray showing the classical bamboo-spine appearance are features supportive of the diagnosis. It is an extraintestinal manifestation of ulcerative colitis.

Ankylosing spondylitis is a chronic inflammatory disease affecting the spine and sacroiliac joint. It is more common in young males and has a strong association with HLAB27.

Clinically, patients present with recurring backache which worsens in the early morning or with inactivity and improves with exercise. Later they develop fatigue, pain, joint swellings, and heel pain. Extra-articular manifestations include uveitis, aortic incompetence, carditis, and apical lobe fibrosis. Examination findings include loss of lumbar lordosis, increased thoracic kyphosis, diminished spinal movements, and decreased chest expansion.

X-ray findings:

  • Erosion of sacroiliac joints - earliest sign
  • Periarticular sclerosis (option B) in later stages 
  • Squaring of vertebrae due to flattening of normal anterior concavity of the vertebral body is the earliest vertebral change
  • Bamboo spine appearance (option C) due to bridging of adjacent vertebrae
  • Wedging of the vertebra (option D) leading to hyperkyphosis

Diagnostic criteria for ankylosing spondylitis:

  • Insidious in onset
  • Morning stiffness 
  • Symptoms begin early at the age <40 years
  • Improvement with exercise
  • Persistence for > three months 

Treatment consists of maintaining posture and preserving mobility. Pain and stiffness can be controlled with anti-inflammatory drugs. In severe cases, TNF inhibitors are used. Surgery can be considered to correct the deformity.

questions.text: The image given below shows neuromuscular monitoring of the patient after anesthesia. What is the most commonly used nerve for monitoring?
questions.solution:
The following image shows neuromuscular monitoring and the most commonly used nerve for monitoring is the ulnar nerve.

The mechanosensor with electrodes is placed over the region of the ulnar nerve. This assesses the contraction of the adductor pollicis muscle to monitor neuromuscular activity.

Monitoring of neuromuscular blockade is required to monitor the blockade intraoperatively, ensure its complete reversal postoperatively, and prevent residual blockade. To monitor the neuromuscular function, a peripheral motor nerve is supramaximally stimulated and the response of the muscle is assessed.

The most commonly assessed nerve-muscle unit is the ulnar nerve-adductor pollicis muscle. This is because it is easily accessible, has the lowest risk of direct muscle stimulation, and the response can be evaluated visually, by tactile methods, or by objective methods. To stimulate the ulnar nerve, the electrodes are best applied to the volar aspect of the wrist.

Other nerve-muscle units that can be assessed include:

  • Posterior tibial nerve- flexor hallucis brevis muscle
  • Facial nerve- orbicularis oculi muscle
  • Facial nerve- corrugator supercilii muscle

Many methods can be used for objective monitoring of neuromuscular function:

  • Mechanomyography (MMG)
  • Electromyography (EMG)
  • Acceleration of the muscle response (AMG)
  • Kinemyography (KMG)
  • Cuff pressure modality (CPM)
  • Compressomyography (CMG)
  • Phonomyography (PMG)

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient with benign prostatic hypertrophy underwent TURP.  An hour later, he was found to have an altered sensorium and had several bouts of vomiting. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
The most probable cause for the above-mentioned symptoms is water intoxication also known as transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP) syndrome. 

Absorption of water into the circulation at the time of transurethral urethral resection can lead to :

  • Hyponatremia, which may manifest as confusion, nausea, and vomiting
  • Congestive cardiac failure
  • Hemolysis 

It is managed by fluid restriction.

The use of isotonic glycine for irrigation during resection reduces the incidence of water intoxication.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is admitted with fever and polyarthritis. His ESR on admission was 80mm/hr. There was no clinical/subclinical carditis. A diagnosis of acute rheumatic fever was made and treatment was initiated. How long will you put the patient on secondary prophylaxis?

choices.text: 5 years or until 21 years of age
10 years or until 21 years of age
10 years or until 40 years of age

questions.solution:
For a patient with rheumatic fever without carditis, the duration of secondary prophylaxis is 5 years or until 21 years of age (whichever is longer)

Secondary prophylaxis is given to patients with acute rheumatic fever (ARF) and rheumatic heart disease (RHD). These patients are at a higher risk of developing a further episode after a group A streptococcal infection. Hence they should receive long-term penicillin prophylaxis to prevent recurrent infections. 

The antibiotics that can be given for secondary prophylaxis are:

  • Benzathine penicillin G (1.2 million units) given every 4 weeks (Best antibiotic)
  • Oral penicillin V (250 mg) given twice daily (less effective than benzathine penicillin G)
  • Erythromycin (250 mg) twice daily (For patients allergic to penicillin)

Related Pearl: American Heart Association (AHA) recommendation for duration of secondary prophylaxis of rheumatic fever

Category

Duration after the last attack

Rheumatic fever without carditis

  

5 years or until 21 years of age (whichever is longer)

Rheumatic fever with carditis but no residual heart disease (no valvular disease)

  10 years or until 21 years of age (whichever is longer)

Rheumatic fever with carditis and residual heart disease (persistent valvular disease)

10 years or until 40 years of age (whichever is longer), sometimes lifelong prophylaxis

questions.text: An infant demonstrates lethargy, vomiting, and convulsions after a few sessions of breastfeeding. Laboratory tests show elevated levels of ammonia. It is found that the infant has a defect in an enzyme activated by N-acetyl glutamate. Identify the enzyme.
questions.solution:
N-acetyl glutamate is an allosteric activator of carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I (CPS I). CPS I catalyzes the rate-limiting step in the urea cycle and is present in the mitochondria. This reaction uses up two molecules of ATP to generate one molecule of carbamoyl phosphate. Its defect leads to hyperammonemia type 1.

The clinical symptoms of urea cycle disorders include vomiting, intermittent ataxia, irritability, lethargy, severe mental retardation, hypothermia, and apnea due to high plasma ammonia levels.

Option A: Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase II is the rate-limiting enzyme in pyrimidine synthesis. It is inhibited by UTP (uridine triphosphate) and activated by ATP and PRPP (phosphoribosyl pyrophosphate).

CPS I  CPS II
Rate-limiting enzyme of urea cycle Rate limiting step of pyrimidine synthesis
Found in mitochondria Found in cytosol
Uses ammonia as a source of nitrogen Uses glutamine as a source of nitrogen
Requires N-acetyl glutamate as a positive allosteric activator Does not require N-acetyl glutamate

Option C: Ornithine transcarbamoylase combines carbamoyl phosphate with ornithine to form citrulline. Deficiency causes elevated glutamine levels in the blood, CSF, and urine.

Option D: Argininosuccinate synthetase leads to the synthesis of argininosuccinate from citrulline and aspartate.

Related Pearl: Urea Cycle and its disorders

questions.text:
A 6-year-old child is brought to the clinic with a daily fever for the last 2 months. She has not been playful during the daytime but appears to get better in the evening. The girl also complains of wrist and knee pain for the last two months which worsens with movements. There is a faint salmon-pink rash on the trunk. What is the most appropriate diagnosis?

TLC - 15,000 cells/cu.mm 

ESR - 40 mm/hr
questions.solution:
A young child with pain in the joints, daily fever spike that reduces spontaneously, salmon-pink rash on the trunks, and elevated ESR and WBC count is likely suggestive of systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA).

Systemic JIA - Arthritis in ≥1 joint + fever of at least 2 weeks in duration that is documented to be daily (quotidian fever) for at least 3 days and accompanied by ≥1 of the following:

  • Evanescent (nonfixed) maculopapular truncal rash
  • Generalized lymph node enlargement
  • Hepatomegaly or splenomegaly or both
  • Serositis

JIA is defined as arthritis in ≥1 joint with onset <16 years of age and persisting for at least 6 weeks. It can be classified as systemic, oligoarthritis, polyarthritis with rheumatoid factor (RF) positive or negative, psoriatic arthritis, and enthesitis-related arthritis.

  • Chronic arthritis ≥6 weeks and age of onset ≤16 years is essential for the diagnosis of JIA
  • Oligoarthritis JIA - ≤4 joints involved
  • Polyarthritis JIA -  ≥5 joints involved
    • RF positive - Symmetric involvement is seen in >8 years of age 
    • RF negative - Asymmetric involvement is seen in <8 years of age
  • Psoriatic JIA - Features of psoriasis with dactylitis,pitting of nails and 1st degree relative to psoriasis
  • Enthesitis-related JIA - Arthritis + Enthesitis

Treatment options include NSAIDs (non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs) for symptomatic management and disease-modifying anti-rheumatic drugs (DMARDs) such as methotrexate. DMARDs should be started in all children with polyarthritis. Systemic glucocorticoids are usually reserved for children with severe unremitting arthritis, systemic manifestations (serositis, vasculitis), and rapidly progressive disease.

questions.text: An epidemiologist gives a lecture on pandemics. He cites the influenza pandemic as an example of which of the following?
questions.solution:
The influenza pandemic is an example of a cyclical trend.

A cyclical trend is a type of periodic fluctuation. It occurs in cycles that are spread over short periods of time. This can be days, weeks, months, or even years. Influenza pandemics are known to occur at intervals of 7- 10 years, due to antigenic variations. Some non-infectious conditions can also display cyclical trends. An example of this is road traffic accidents occurring more frequently on the weekends. Knowledge of the cyclical pattern of diseases can be used to protect communities against the same.

Other options:

Option A: Seasonal trend is a type of period fluctuation which refers to seasonal variation of diseases. Examples of diseases that follow this trend include measles, malaria, and upper respiratory tract infections. It can be related to environmental conditions such as temperature and humidity. Some non-infectious conditions which follow this trend are sunstroke, hay fever, and snakebite.

Option B: Secular or long-term trend signifies the changes seen in the occurrence of a disease over a long period of time. It implies a consistent change in a particular direction such as a progressive increase or decrease. Examples of conditions that follow this pattern are coronary heart disease and lung cancer which have shown a consistent upward trend. A decline in the occurrence of diseases such as tuberculosis and diphtheria has been noted in developed countries. 

Option C: Point-source epidemic is a type of common-source epidemic. In this type of epidemic, there are no secondary waves and the epidemic curve rises and falls rapidly. There is a clustering of cases within a narrow interval of time. All the cases develop within one incubation period of the specific disease.

Related Pearl: Epidemics and its Types

Epidemics and its Types

An epidemic is an occurrence in a community or region of cases of an illness that is clearly in excess of normal expectancy.

Types

Common source epidemics

  • Single exposure or 'point source' epidemics
  • Multiple or continuous exposure epidemics

Propagated epidemics

  • Person to person
  • Arthropod vector
  • Animal reservoir

Slow or modern epidemics

  • Non-communicable diseases

questions.text: A 5-year-old child requires bronchodilator therapy. You attach the device shown below to the pressurized metered-dose inhaler for ease of use. Which of the following is false about this device?

choices.text: Decreases the deposition of drug on the oropharynx
Increases the delivery of drug to lower airways
Increases the incidence of oropharyngeal candidiasis
Systemic absorption of drugs is unaffected

questions.solution:
The given image is of a spacer device. It decreases the incidence of oropharyngeal candidiasis and other propellant-mediated oropharyngeal adverse effects like dysphonia that occur with the use of a pMDI.

Spacers reduce the velocity and size of particles entering the upper airways. This reduces the amount of drug that impinges on the oropharynx and increases the proportion of drug inhaled into lower airways. The systemic absorption is unchanged by the use of a spacer.

Spacer devices are useful in delivering inhaled drugs to children who are not able to use a pMDI alone but can also be used by adults for better drug delivery. The image below shows the use of a spacer device with a face mask which is preferred in children younger than 3 years of age.

The various devices used for the delivery of inhalational drugs are:

  • Pressurized metered-dose inhalers - Drugs are propelled from a canister in the pMDI with the aid of a propellant. These devices are convenient, portable, and typically deliver 50–200 doses of a drug
  • Dry powder inhalers - these devices scatter the drug into a fine powder that is dispersed by air turbulence on inhalation. DPIs have been developed to deliver drugs such as insulin, but the dosing is inconsistent. Children <7 years find it difficult to use a DPI. 
  • Nebulizers: Two types of nebulizer are available -
    • Jet nebulizers that are driven by a stream of gas (air or oxygen)
    • Ultrasonic nebulizers that use a rapidly vibrating piezoelectric crystal and thus do not require a source of compressed gas.

The nebulizers deliver much higher drug doses as compared pMDIs. These are useful in:

  • Treating acute exacerbations of asthma and COPD
  • Extreme airway obstruction (severe COPD)
  • Delivering inhaled drugs to infants and small children who cannot use the other inhalation devices
  • Administering drugs such as antibiotics in relatively high doses

questions.text: Angular conjunctivitis is caused by _______.
questions.solution:
Moraxella species,which are gram negative diplobacillus are involved in causing angular conjunctivitis.

Angular conjunctivitis: Inflammation of the inner and outer canthi with excoriation of skin and collection of dirty-white, foamy discharge at the angles.

Causes: 

  • Moraxella axenfeld
  • Moraxella lacunata
  • Moraxella catarrhalis
  • Staphylococcus aureus (rare) 

Source of infection: Nasal tract of healthy people and the nasal discharge of patients with angular conjunctivitis

Mode of spread: From the nasal cavity to the eye by contaminated hands and handkerchief

Treatment

  • Oxytetracycline for 10 to 14 days 
  • Zinc oxide inhibits proteolytic ferment.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman who is a known smoker presents with slit-like retraction of the right nipple. She gives a history of chronic greenish discharge from the same site previously. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history of chronic greenish discharge followed by slit-like retraction of the nipple in a middle-aged woman is suggestive of duct ectasia.

Duct ectasia is the dilatation of major breast ducts. It is a common cause of nipple discharge in non-lactating women. This disease's initial stage consists of dilating one or more lactiferous ducts. These ducts fill with stagnant brown or green-coloured secretions, and discharge from the collection may occur.

In the later stages, fluid accumulation in the lactiferous ducts leads to inflammation causing periductal mastitis. If the condition does not resolve, it can lead to the formation of a subareolar mass or abscess, and even mammary duct fistulas. The persistence of this condition eventually leads to fibrosis, which can cause slit-like retraction of the nipple.

Initial episodes can be managed with antibiotics. Recurrent episodes of the disease are best managed by Hadfield operation. This operation consists of the excision of all the major lactiferous ducts.  If a single duct is involved, then a microdochectomy is performed.

The mammography image of broken-needle calcification seen in duct ectasia is seen below.

Other options:

Option A: Intraductal papilloma is a benign condition wherein a wart-like growth occurs within the mammary ducts. They are made up of glandular and fibrous tissue and vascular vessels. It is associated with blood-stained discharge.

Option C: Fibroadenoma presents as a breast lump in women aged 15–25 years. The ultrasound image depicts a well-circumscribed oval mass with uniform hypoechogenicity as given in the image below.

Option D: Paget’s disease is a type of in-situ carcinoma arising in the nipple characterized by nipple erythema and irritation. It is associated with pruritus and slowly destroys the nipple and the areola. The image below shows Paget's disease of the breast.

questions.text:
The hyperpigmentation associated with Addison's disease is due to which of the following?

POMC: pro-opiomelanocortin

GnRH: gonadotropin-releasing hormone

TSH: thyroid-stimulating hormone
questions.solution:
The hyperpigmentation associated with Addison's disease is due to increased serum levels of POMC (pro-opiomelanocortin).

Addison's disease is a primary adrenal insufficiency in which the adrenal is unable to secrete adequate amounts of cortisol (glucocorticoid), aldosterone (mineralocorticoid), and sex hormones. The most common cause of Addison's disease is autoimmune adrenalitis. 

Inadequate adrenal hormone secretion will result in positive feedback to the pituitary, leading to increased ACTH (adrenocorticotropic releasing hormone) secretion. ACTH happens to be derived from a precursor compound known as POMC (pro-opiomelanocortin). POMC breaks down to form ACTH and MSH (melanocyte-stimulating hormone). This MSH is responsible for the hyperpigmentation seen in Addison's disease.

  

The image below shows a woman before (right) and after (left) developing Addison's disease. You can see how she has lost weight, become anorexic, and developed hyperpigmentation of the skin-

 

The diagnosis of primary adrenal insufficiency can be made with the short cosyntropin test. Elevated ACTH levels help to differentiate it from secondary causes, which would show low ACTH levels. Primary adrenal insufficiency will also have a compensatory elevation in renin levels due to decreased aldosterone in the body.

Treatment is with a combination of glucocorticoid, mineralocorticoid, and sex hormone replacement depending on the patient's symptoms and requirement.

Other options-

Option (B): GnRH has no relation to ACTH or MSH production.

Option (C): Cortisol levels will be low in Addison's disease. This is the cause for feedback elevation in ACTH, not the cause for hyperpigmentation.

Option (D): TSH does not cause hyperpigmentation. However, in Grave's disease, the hyperthyroid state results in faster cortisol metabolism. This results in an elevated ACTH due to positive feedback, which can again lead to hyperpigmentation by the production of MSH from POMC by the same mechanism described above.

questions.text: A house surgeon sustained a needlestick injury while disposing a needle used to sample the blood of a patient who is HIV positive. A decision is taken to offer him post-exposure prophylaxis. Which one of the following statements is true regarding HIV post-exposure prophylaxis?

choices.text: It can be given upto 5 days after exposure
2 drug regimen is preferred over 3 drug regimen
Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Dolutegravir  is given for 4 weeks

questions.solution:
Recommended Post-exposure prophylaxis(PEP) is a three-drug regimen which includes Lamivudine 300mg, Tenofovir 300mg and Dolutegravir 50mg. A regimen for post-exposure prophylaxis for HIV with two ARV drugs is effective, but three drugs are preferred. The PEP must be initiated ideally within 2 hours and certainly within 72 hours. WHO and NACO recommended PEP regimen :

        Drugs combination   Recommendation for PEP         Duration
Tenofovir (TDF) + Lamivudine(3TC) + Dolutegravir (DTG)          Once daily          4 weeks

If the Preferred Regimen is not available or contraindicated, Tenofovir +Lamivudine+ Lopinavir/Ritonavir or Tenofovir +Lamivudine+Efavirenz can be used as an alternative.

The protocol followed is: Exposure within 72 hours --> Assess exposed individual --> Assess exposure source --> Determine the risk of transmission --> Counselling and support --> 28-day prescription with drug information --> HIV test at 3 months after exposure.

questions.text: The newly discovered salivary glands are predominantly present over

choices.text: Posterior ⅔ rd of the tongue

questions.solution:
The newly discovered salivary glands are predominantly present over torus tubarius. Torus tubarius is the anatomical structure formed by the cartilage that supports the entrance of the auditory tube.

The proposed name of these newly identified glands is tubarial salivary glands. These glands extend caudally to the pharyngeal wall and cranially to Rosenmuller's fossa.

Positron emission tomography/computed tomography with radio-labeled ligands to the prostate-specific membrane antigen (PSMA PET/CT) can visualize these salivary glands with high sensitivity and specificity.

Clinical significance:

It has been reported that radiotherapy over the location of these glands has led to xerostomia and dysphagia. Sparing these glands, thus, might improve the quality of life of patients receiving radiotherapy.

questions.text: Gas shadow is present in the great vessels of a fetus in the case of intrauterine demise. What is this sign called?
questions.solution:
Gas shadow in the great vessels of a fetus in intrauterine death is called the Roberts sign. It is the earliest sign and is seen within 12 hours of death. The gas shadow may be present within the chambers of the heart or in large vessels of the fetus.

Signs of intrauterine death:

  • Earliest sign - reddening of the skin with peeling in 12 hours
  • Robert's sign - radiographic finding showing gas in the great vessels like the aorta in 12 hours
  • Large blebs containing a red serous or serosanguineous fluid appear at around 24 hours 
  • Serous cavities may contain a turbid reddish fluid after 48 hours
  • Spalding's sign (Option B) radiographic finding is seen as a loss of alignment and over-riding of bones of the cranial vault. This occurs due to shrinkage of the brain after death. It is seen 7 days after fetal death.
  • A sweetish and disagreeable odor
  • Sodden and coppery red/purplish skin (never greenish as with putrefaction) with blisters, and cuticle peeling. The skin detaches easily and leaves moist and greasy areas
  • Distended abdomen and thick, red, and soft umbilical cord
  • Abnormally mobile or flexible joints
  • Soft, edematous, and loss of morphology of the organs or viscera (lungs and uterus remain unaffected for long period)
  • The body is soft and pliable and flattens out when placed on an even surface

Option C: Ball sign is hyperflexion of the spine with crowding of ribs seen in intrauterine death.

Option D: Halo sign is a radiological sign of intrauterine fetal death showing an increase in soft tissue width between subcutaneous fat and the cranial vault. 

Related Pearl: Radiological features of IUD

Radiological features of Intrauterine Death

  • Robert sign - The presence of a gas shadow within the chambers of the heart or the greater vessels like aorta, in cases of foetal death in utero.
  • Spalding’s sign - Loss of alignment and over-riding of bones of cranial vault and overlapping of skull bones due to shrinkage of brain after death.
  • Deuel’s halo sign – Increased pericranial fat.
  • Hyperflexion of spine and crowding of ribs.

questions.text: Which of the following transporter is inhibited primarily by loop diuretics and is present in the ascending loop of Henle?
questions.solution:
Thick ascending limb of loop of Henle has Na+ - 2Cl- - K+ co transporter that co transports one Na+, one K+, and 2Cl– from the tubular lumen into the tubu­lar cells and is primarily inhibited by loop diuretics.

Mechanism:

  • Na+ is transported out of the cell into the interstitium by Na, K ATPase in the basolateral membrane of the cell.
  • Cl– exits in basolateral ClC–Kb Cl– channels. Barttin, a protein in the cell membrane, is essential for normal ClC–Kb function.
  • K+ moves from the cell to the interstitium and the tubular lumen by ROMK(renal outer medullary potassium channel) and other K+ channels.
  • This is an example of secondary active trans­port.

Loop diuretics inhibit Na+/ K+/ 2Cl- symport present primarily in thick ascending limb of loop of Henle. 

Na+/Cl- symport is inhibited by thiazide diuretics .

 

 

Clinical correlation:

Bartter syndrome is caused by loss-of-function mutations in the gene for any of four key proteins: the Na–K–2Cl co-transporter, the ROMK K+ channel, the ClC–Kb Cl– channel, or Barttin.

It is characterized by

  • Chronic Na+ loss in the urine, with resultant hypovolemia
  • Hypokalaemia
  • Alkalosis

Related Pearl: Site and mechanism of action of diuretics

Diuretics  Site of action  

Enzyme/receptor/transporter inhibited 
Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors   Proximal tubule   Carbonic anhydrase  
Loop diuretics  Thick ascending loop of Henle  Na+- K+- 2Cl- symporter
Thiazides Distal convoluted tubule  Na+- Cl- symporter
Epithelial sodium channel inhibitors  Late distal tubule and collecting ducts   ENaC 
Aldosterone antagonists  Late distal tubule and collecting ducts  Mineralocorticoid receptors (indirectly ENaC)

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome?

choices.text: Prolonged PR interval is seen on ECG
AV nodal delay is not seen
Delta wave is seen on ECG
Bundle of Kent is the cause of it

questions.solution:
Prolonged PR interval is not seen in Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome (WPW syndrome), a shortened PR interval can be seen instead.

It is a form of atrioventricular reentry phenomenon characterized by the presence of accessory conducting pathways between the atria and ventricles that are separate from the AV node and Purkinje tissue. 

The tachycardia is usually produced by the conduction of a normal impulse from the ventricles to the atria via the accessory pathway (bundle of Kent). This is the orthodromic pathway. Less often, a premature atrial beat travels down the accessory pathway (while AV Node is still in refractory period) leading to premature ventricular activation. This is the antidromic pathway.

The classic ECG features in WPW are as follows:

  • A shortened PR interval (typically <120 ms)
  • A slurring and the slow rise of the initial upstroke of the QRS complex (delta wave)
  • A widened QRS complex (total duration >0.12 seconds)
  • ST-segment–T wave (repolarization) changes, generally directed opposite the major delta wave and QRS complex, reflecting altered depolarization 

 

Related Pearl: Wolff Parkinson White Syndrome

Wolff Parkinson White Syndrome (WPW) is characterized by an abnormal accessory pathway in the heart leading to arrhythmias.

Pathology- Born with an accessory pathway, the bundle of Kent which connects the atria and ventricle. The electrical impulses from the SA node reach the ventricles earlier via the accessory pathway as there is no AV nodal delay in this pathway. This leads to the preexcitation of the ventricle and initiation of ventricular contraction. This ventricular contraction is prolonged when the impulse via the AV nodal pathway reaches the ventricles.

Most common location of the accessory pathway- between the left atrium and free wall of the left ventricle

ECG changes:

Shortened PR interval- because of the early initiation of ventricular depolarization

Prolonged QRS duration- because of the AV nodal impulse reaching the ventricles after the aberrant impulse.

Delta waves- slurred upstroke of QRS complex

The given ECG shows delta waves marked with red arrows:

Treatment:

  • Catheter ablation is the treatment of choice.
  • Anti-arrhythmic drugs like procainamide, amiodarone, quinidine, propafenone, dofetilide are used in slowing conduction in the accessory pathway (prolong refractory period).
  • IV procainamide is the drug of choice in a hemodynamically stable WPW presenting with atrial fibrillation.
  • DC cardioversion is done in hemodynamically unstable patients.

questions.text: An intern observed that a patient in the ward was unresponsive, and an ECG which was performed urgently showed a rhythm as depicted below. DC shock was delivered but the arrhythmia persisted and the patient is still unresponsive. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient is in cardiac arrest and the rhythm shown is that of ventricular fibrillation. Since DC shock was given and the patient is still unresponsive, CPR has to be given for 2 minutes after which the rhythm should be assessed again. 

The management of ventricular fibrillation and pulseless ventricular tachycardia is the same. Chest compressions are to be started following defibrillation.

Defibrillation involves delivering an electrical current between two pads placed on the chest so as to interrupt the disorganized cardiac activity and restore an organized cardiac rhythm. The energy that must be applied is

  • Monophasic defibrillator: 360 J
  • Biphasic defibrillator: 120-200 J

It is of utmost necessity to defibrillate at the earliest because the chances of survival decrease by 7-10% every minute without defibrillation.

Related Pearl: Adult Basic Life Support (BLS) Algorithm (Updated as per 2020 guidelines)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a complication of massive blood transfusion?
questions.solution:
Hypercalcemia is not a complication of a massive blood transfusion. Massive blood transfusion results in hypocalcemia

Massive transfusion is defined as the transfusion of at least 10 units of red cells in 24 hours or 4 units in 1 hour.

Large amounts of citrate are given with massive blood transfusion since blood is anticoagulated with sodium citrate and citric acid. This citrate chelated calcium from the blood and causes hypocalcemia. The complications of citrate infusion are:

Electrolyte abnormalities:

  • Hyperkalemia: RBC leakage during storage
  • Hypocalcemia: citrate chelates calcium 
  • Hypomagnesemia: Citrate binds magnesium
  • Metabolic alkalosis: each mmol of citrate generates 3 mEq of bicarbonate. As a result, metabolic alkalosis occurs. 

Related Pearl: Complications of massive transfusion: The concept behind It

Massive transfusion (MT) is defined as transfusion of 10 units of pRBCs in 24 hours or more than 4 units of pRBCs in one hour.

Complications from massive transfusion include:

  • Hypothermia
  • Alkalosis/Acidosis
  • Coagulopathy
  • Hypocalcemia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Hyperkalemia

Understanding the concept:

  1. Hypothermia: Blood products are normally stored between 1°C and 6°C, and rapid transfusion of large quantities will lead to hypothermia.
  2. Coagulopathy: MT with PRBCs alone causes a dilutional coagulopathy, whereas massive hemorrhage causes a consumptive coagulopathy. However, the incidence of coagulopathy can be minimized by the infusion of fresh frozen plasma, platelets, and RBCs in a 1:1:1 ratio. 
  3. Alkalosis: As citrate is metabolized to bicarbonate, patients who require MT frequently develop a metabolic alkalosis. 
  4. Acidosis: Due to tissue hypoperfusion
  5. Hyperkalemia & late Hypokalemia: Initially, the patient develops hyperkalemia on massive transfusion. Later, red blood cells begin active metabolism and intracellular potassium uptake. This increased uptake along with metabolic alkalosis (resulting from citrate administration), lowers the serum potassium.
  6. Hypocalcemia: Binding of calcium to citrate (which is used in the anticoagulation of the stored blood).
  7. Hypomagnesemia: Binding of magnesium to citrate

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is admitted to the hospital with severe pancreatitis. The next day he develops sudden onset breathlessness and severe hypoxia. Below is the chest X-ray obtained. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history of severe pancreatitis and the chest X-ray findings of B/L diffuse alveolar opacities are suggestive of ARDS.

Acute respiratory distress syndrome is a clinical syndrome characterized by acute onset, severe dyspnea, tachypnea, hypoxemia, and pulmonary infiltrates leading to respiratory failure. Etiological factors can be divided into direct and indirect causes of lung injury as follows:

Direct lung injury-

  • Pneumonia
  • Aspiration of gastric contents
  • Near drowning
  • Toxic inhalation injury
  • Pulmonary contusion
  • COVID-19

Indirect lung injury-

  • Sepsis
  • Severe trauma like burns, flail chest, head trauma, multiple bone fractures
  • Transfusions
  • Drug overdose
  • Multiple transfusions
  • Pancreatitis
  • Drug overdose

There are three stages in the development of ARDS:

Exudative phase: Occurs for the first 7 days of the illness. The alveolar-capillary endothelial cells and type I pneumocytes are injured, with a breach in the tight alveolar barrier. Proinflammatory cytokines like IL-8, IL-1, TNF-α, and LT-B4 lead to the recruitment of neutrophils and the development of a hyaline membrane in the alveoli.

Proliferative phase: Occurs from day 7-21. Recovery from mechanical ventilation is seen in most patients. Some patients may develop pulmonary fibrosis in this stage. Histological recovery is seen in this phase with a shift to lymphocyte predominant infiltrates. Type II pneumocytes proliferate and secrete surfactant with subsequent differentiation to Type I pneumocytes.

Fibrotic phase: Is associated with increased mortality. Extensive alveolar duct and interstitial fibrosis are seen.

Chest X-ray features in ARDS:

Chest x-ray features usually develop 12-24 hours after initial lung insult as a result of proteinaceous interstitial edema. Within one week, hyaline membrane occurs due to type 1 pneumocyte damage. There are diffuse bilateral coalescent opacities consistent with pulmonary edema. 

Severity classification of ARDS:

Mild: 200 mmHg < Pao2/Fio2 ≤ 300 mmHg
Moderate: 100 mmHg < Pao2/Fio2 ≤ 200 mmHg
Severe: Pao2/Fio2 ≤ 100 mmHg

Management includes :

  • Mechanical ventilation with low tidal volume and high-PEEP.
  • Prone ventillation
  • Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation
  • Early neuromuscular blockade

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presented with rigidity, frequent falls, slow movements, tremors, and a short stepping gait when he entered the doctor's room. Which of the following areas is most likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Parkinson's disease, which is associated with the degeneration of substantia nigra (marked as "C").

Substantia nigra is pigmented due to the presence of neuromelanin granules, which help in the synthesis of dopamine. In Parkinson's disease,  there is an absence/reduced pigmentation of the substantia nigra.

Postural instability along with bradykinesia, rigidity, and resting tremor are cardinal features of Parkinson's disease. Because of motor disability, it is also referred to as paralysis agitans.

Notable gait abnormalities are:

  • Short stepped gait- parkinsonism
  • Scissoring gait- spasticity i.e. UMN lesion
  • High-stepped, slapping gait- posterior column or peripheral nerve disease
  • Waddling gait- proximal muscle weakness
  • Wide stepping gait - cerebellar dysfunction

questions.text:
Match the following:
1. Workshop

A. Series of lectures on a subject by experts after which the audience is allowed to ask questions
2. Symposium B. Incorporates a variety of methods like speeches, and discussions, and may last for half a day to a week.
3. Roleplay C. Series of meetings emphasizing individual work within the group
4. Seminar

D. Dramatization of social situations for health education
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-C, 2-A, 3-D, 4-B

A workshop is a series of meetings with an emphasis on individual work within the group. External consultants or experts may be involved.

A symposium is a series of lectures on a selected subject by experts after which the audience is allowed to ask questions (no discussion is involved).

Role play is the dramatization of social situations for health education by those taking part in it.

Seminars are similar to conferences and incorporate a variety of methods like speeches, and discussions for health education, which may last for half a day to a week.

Methods of Health Communication    
Individual approach Group approach Mass approach
  1. Personal contact
  2. Home visits
  3. Personal letters
  1. Lectures
  2. Demonstrations

    • Panel discussion
    • Symposium
    • Workshop
    • Conferences
    • Seminars
    • Roleplay
  1. TV
  2. Radio
  3. Newspaper
  4. Printed material
  5. Direct mailing
  6. Posters
  7. Health museums
  8. Health exhibitions
  9. Folk method
  10. Internet

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about chemical synapses?
questions.solution:
Unidirectional conduction is a feature of chemical synapses. 

There are two types of synapses:

Chemical synapse:

The first neuron secretes a neurotransmitter at its nerve ending synapse, which acts on receptors of the next neuron to excite, inhibit, or modify its sensitivity. Conduction is unidirectional (one-way conduction). This one-way signal ensures that the signal is directed towards a specific goal. A synaptic cleft of 200-300 Å or 20-30nm separates the neurons.  The presynaptic membrane contains transmitter vesicles that contain the neurotransmitter. It does not have gap junctions. Examples of neurotransmitters is acetylcholine, norepinephrine, epinephrine, histamine, gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA), and glycine. 

Electrical synapse:

The cytoplasms of adjacent cells are directly connected by clusters of ion channels called gap junction channels. There is free movement of ions from one cell to the next cell. The conduction is bidirectional and the intercellular gap is 20-40Å or 2-4nm. The bidirectional transmission of electrical synapses permits them to coordinate the activities of large groups of interconnected neurons. Electrical synapses are present in the cardiac uscles and visceral smooth muscles.

questions.text: Which of the following parasites has a direct life cycle?
questions.solution:
Enterobius vermicularis has a direct life cycle.

Direct life cycle: Parasite requires a single host to complete its development.

Examples:

Protozoa

  •  Entamoeba histolytica, 
  • Giardia lamblia, 
  • Trichomonas vaginalis, 
  • Balantidium coli, 
  • Cryptosporidium parvum, 
  • Cyclospora cayetanensis, 
  • Isospora Belli, 
  • Microsporidia.

Helminths

  • Ascaris lumbricoides, 
  • Enterobius vermicularis, 
  • Trichuris trichura, 
  • Ancylostoma duodenale, 
  • Necator americanus, 
  • Hymenolepsis nana.

Indirect life cycle: Parasite requires two or more hosts to complete its development. Example: Malarial parasite.

questions.text: A 70 year old male presents with neck nodes. Examination of left ear reveals a dull tympanic membrane, deafness and tinnitus. On tympanogram, a Type B curve is obtained. Most probable diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

Points in favour:

  • 70yr old with neck nodes pointing towards malignancy (can be either due to infection but no other signs of infection given plus the age points more towards malignancy).
  • On examination ear shows dull tympanic membrane and audiometry shows curve B which means  fluid is present in left ear ruling out option d (Sensorineuronal hearing loss).
  • Type B tympanogram seen in serous otitis media. Presence of unilateral serous otitis media in an adult should raise the suspicion of a nasopharngeal growth.
  • Age of the patient (most common age 5th -7th decade).
  • sex of the patient (most common in males).

Other options:

Option a: On examination either cholesteotoma granulation or perforation will be seen.

Option b: On examination, otoscopy shows a red reflex through intact tympanic membrane. “Rising sun” appearance is seen when tumour arises from the floor of middle ear.

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma:

  • Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is also called Guangdong tumor.
  • Commonest site of origin of nasopharyngeal carcinoma is the fossa of Rosenmüller.
  • Epstein–Barr Virus (EBV) is closely associated with nasopharyngeal cancer.
  • Presenting symptoms and signs of nasopharyngeal cancer in order of frequency are:
    • Cervical lymphadenopathy (most common) (60–90%)
    • Hearing loss
    • Nasal obstruction
    • Epistaxis
    • Cranial nerve palsies -Cranial nerves V and VI are the most commonly involved among all the cranial nerves. (V more than VI)
    • Headache
    • Earache
    • Neck pain
    • Weight loss

 Nasopharyngeal cancer can cause:

  • Conductive deafness (eustachian tube block)
  • Ipsilateral temporoparietal/facial neuralgia (involvement of CN V) and
  • Palatal paralysis (CN X)

This is collectively called Trotter’s triad.

Radiotherapy is the treatment of choice for nasopharyngeal cancer.

  • Stage I and II are treated by radiotherapy alone.
  • Stage III and IV require concomitant radiation and chemotherapy or radiation followed by chemotherapy.

questions.text: A patient’s ABG was consistent with the curve X in the nomogram given below. His serum electrolytes were Na: 138 mEq/L, Cl: 121 mEq/L and HCO3-: 08 mEq/L. Which of the following can be a differential diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario shows a normal anion gap (hyperchloremic) metabolic acidosis, characteristic of RTA (renal tubular acidosis).

This patient has a pH of 7.25 suggestive of acidosis. The bicarbonate levels are low suggestive of metabolic cause. The pCO2 is reduced(10) suggestive of respiratory compensation. All the above factors point to a diagnosis of metabolic acidosis with respiratory compensation. 

The normal anion gap ranges from 6 to 12 mmol/L, with an average of 10 mmol/L. The anion gap in this patient can be calculated as

Na+ – (Cl- + HCO3-) = 138– (121+9) = 138 - 129 = 9.

This means the patient is having normal anion gap acidosis. Among the given options, only renal tubular acidosis is associated with normal anion gap. All of the other options cause high anion gap metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the fifth stage of the demographic cycle?

choices.text: Birth rate falls below death rate

questions.solution:
In stage 5 of the demographic cycle, the birth rate falls below the death rate.

In this stage, the death rate attains a low stable rate while the birth rate keeps declining. Thus, the curve of the birth rate will cross the curve of the death rate in a graph of the demographic cycle and falls further below. 

The demographic gap is negative and the population is declining. So, this stage is known as the declining stage.

Related Pearl: Demographic Process and Cycle

  • Demographic process
    • Fertility
    • Mortality
    • Marriage
    • Migration
    • Social Mobility
  • Demographic cycle
    • Stage 1 : High stationary 
      • High birth rate and high death rate render the population stationary.
      • Narrow demographic gap.
    • Stage 2 : Early expanding 
      • Death rate declines and birth rate remains unchanged
      • Demographic gap starts increasing and then becomes maximum
    • Stage 3 : Late expanding
      • Death rate decline further and birth rate falls
      • India is in this stage, currently
      • Demographic gap starts declining
    • Stage 4 : Low stationary 
      • Low birth rate and low death rate renders the population stationary
      • Narrow demographic gap
    • Stage 5 : Declining 
      • Population begins to decline as birth rate is lower than death rate
      • Demographic gap is negative

questions.text: Cardiotoxicity is an adverse effect of which of the following anti-cancer drugs?
questions.solution:
Cardiotoxicity is a unique adverse effect of doxorubicin. It is an anthracycline group of anticancer antibiotics.

Anthracyclines:

They work by interacting with DNA directly and affecting transcription and replication. They have the potential to create free radicals which cause irreversible cardiotoxicity and cardiomyopathy which is dose-dependent.

Adverse effects:

  • Cardiomyopathy is the most common adverse effect and it can be either acute, in the form of myocardial damage("pericarditis-myocarditis syndrome"), or a chronic form of dose-dependent cardiomyopathy leading to heart failure.
  • Alopecia, anemia, amenorrhea, leukopenia, nausea, vomiting.
  • Mucositis, diarrhea, thrombocytopenia.
  • Less common: acute lymphoid leukemia,acute myelogenous leukemia,atrioventricular block,esophagitis,hyperpigmentation,myelodysplastic syndrome

Anthracycline-induced cardiomyopathy takes two forms:

  • Acute: pericarditis-myocarditis syndrome, arrhythmias, ST and T wave changes in ECG.
  • Chronic: dilated cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: Which of the following steps of disaster management is in correct order?
questions.solution:
Disaster Management includes three aspects:

1. Disaster impact and response: 

  Involves immediate management of mass casualties

  • Search, rescue, and first-aid
  • Field care
  • Triage
  • Tagging
  • Identification of dead

2. Rehabilitation or recovery:

   Involves restoration of the pre-disaster conditions

  • Water supply
  • Basic sanitation and personal hygiene
  • Food safety
  • Vector control

3. Mitigation: Measures designed either to prevent hazards from causing disaster or to reduce the effects of the disaster. This also includes preparedness for any impending disasters or in disaster-prone areas.

questions.text:
Match the following mucopolysaccharidoses with the defective enzyme in each case:
Mucopolysaccharidosis Defective enzyme
1. Hunter syndrome A. α-l-Iduronidase
2. Morquio syndrome B B. Iduronate sulfatase
3. Hurler syndrome C. Heparan sulfate-N-sulfatase
4. Sanfilippo syndrome A D. β-galactosidase
questions.solution:
The option showing 1-B, 2-D 3-A, 4-C  is correctly matched.

Mucopolysaccharidosis Defective enzyme
1. Hunter syndrome B. Iduronate sulfatase
2. Morquio syndrome B D. β-galactosidase
3. Hurler syndrome A. α-l-Iduronidase
4. Sanfilippo syndrome A C. Heparan sulfate-N-sulfatase

 

Glycosaminoglycans (GAGs) or mucopolysaccharides are complex carbohydrates made up of amino sugars and uronic acids. When they are attached to a protein they are referred to as proteoglycans. These proteoglycans make up a large part of the extracellular matrix and connective tissue.

Defects in the enzymes that degrade GAGs result in the mucopolysaccharidoses mentioned above. These defects are commonly inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern. Accumulation of GAGs in the tissue can result in organomegaly, cartilage and bone abnormalities, facial abnormalities, problems with mental development, etc.
