questions.text: All the passengers coming to India were screened for COVID-19 at the airport. Which type of screening is done in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The type of screening done for the immigrants to a country is prospective screening. 

Prospective screening is done for disease control. People are examined for the benefit of others. It may lead to an early diagnosis and permit more effective treatment. It also reduces the spread of infectious diseases in the community, thereby reducing the mortality associated with the disease.

Other examples of prospective screening:

  • Screening of immigrants from infectious diseases such as tuberculosis and syphilis to protect the home population.
  • Screening for streptococcal infection to prevent rheumatic fever.

Other options:

Option A: Prescriptive screening is done for case detection. People are examined for their own benefit. Screening is initiated by medical and public health personnel and is not requested by a patient. It may lead to an early diagnosis of an unrecognized disease. Hence, appropriate treatment can be initiated immediately to arrest disease progression.

Examples of prescriptive screening:

  • Screening of infants for phenylketonuria
  • Screening of school children for visual and auditory defects.

Option B: Multiphasic screening is the combined application of two or more screening tests to a large number of people at one time. It is not cost-effective and has shown no benefit in reducing the morbidity and mortality of the population. Examples include a pregnant woman undergoing various screening tests (VDRL, HIV, HBV, etc) at a time.

Option D: Selective screening is done in high-risk groups. It is one of the most productive screening tests. Examples include MRI screening of the breast done annually in a 25-year-old woman with a first-degree relative having BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutation.

questions.text: A young girl is brought by their parents due to concern about her height. On evaluation, growth hormone levels are found to be high, and insulin-like growth factor levels are low. Which among the following is the likely diagnosis in this child?
questions.solution:
The presence of high GH levels and low insulin-like growth factor (IGF-1) levels point towards Laron dwarfism. 

It is caused by end-organ resistance to growth hormone(GH insensitivity) due to a mutation in the GH receptor. It is an autosomal-recessive disorder with clinical features like those seen in pituitary dwarfism.

Here, growth hormone is produced but is unable to act on the target tissues. Thus, the resting and stimulated GH levels are high and IGF-1 levels are low.

Patients with Laron syndrome present with features such as:

  • Growth failure
  • Small head circumference
  • Characteristic facies with saddle nose and prominent forehead
  • Short limb length compared with trunk
  • Osteopenia
  • Obesity
  • In some cases mild to moderately impaired intellect may be seen

Other options

Option A: In Turner's syndrome, loss of the short arm of the X chromosome is implicated in dwarfism. The short stature occurs due to a state of GH resistance, relative deficiency, and decreased utilization.

Option B: Pituitary dwarfism is a condition with GH deficiency.

Option D: Maternal deprivation dwarfism is due to psychosocial causes such as emotional deprivation and neglect. There is an inadequate response to GH stimulation tests. The mechanism is not fully understood. No history suggestive of disturbed maternal or family relationships rules this out.

questions.text: A patient started on an antihypertensive presented with the following picture. Which of the following drugs is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
The image shows edema over the lips and face and its occurrence following intake of an antihypertensive is suggestive of drug-induced angioedema. Lisinopril, an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor (ACE inhibitor), is most likely responsible for this condition.

Angioedema with ACE inhibitors:

In very few patients(0.1%-0.5%), ACE inhibitors cause rapid swelling in the nose, throat, mouth, glottis, larynx, lips, or tongue. Once the drug is stopped symptoms improve drastically over hours. Angioedema of the intestine can occur very rarely. 

ACE inhibitor-associated angioedema is a class effect, and patients who develop this adverse event should not be prescribed any other drugs within the ACE inhibitor class.

Other adverse effects of ACE inhibitors:

  • A sudden fall in blood pressure can occur following the first dose of ACE inhibitors.
  • It can produce a bothersome dry cough due to the accumulation of bradykinin, substance P, or prostaglandins in the lungs. The cough usually disappears within 4 days of the stoppage of the drug.
  • Hyperkalemia due to K+ retention can occur.
  • Acute renal failure can occur with ACE inhibitors in patients with bilateral renal artery stenosis, stenosis of the artery to a single remaining kidney, heart failure, or volume depletion due to diarrhea or diuretics.
  • It should be discontinued in pregnant women as it can cause developmental defects.
  • It can also cause maculopapular skin rash in some cases.

Other options:

Option B: Nifedipine is a calcium channel blocker. Common adverse effects include headache, flushing, and dizziness. Peripheral edema (pedal edema) may rarely occur.

Option C: Atenolol is a beta-1 selective antagonist. Bradycardia, fatigue, and cold extremities are common adverse effects. CNS side effects like nightmares and depression are less frequent with atenolol than other beta-blockers.

Option D: Clonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist. The main adverse effects of clonidine are dry mouth and sedation. Bradycardia and sexual dysfunction are other effects.

questions.text: The image below shows the life cycle of a virus. Which of the following drugs acts at step 5?
questions.solution:
Step 5 in the given life cycle shows the integration of the viral DNA into the host genome. Raltegravir is an integrase inhibitor and is active against both HIV-1 and HIV-2. It can be used in adults and children >1 month old. 

It is advised for patients to consume antacids and sucralfate, 6 hours before or 2 hours after raltegravir intake.

It may cause headaches, nausea, weakness and fatigue. Rarely, it can lead to drug reactions with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome.

The steps involved in the lifecycle of HIV as given in the image are described as follows:

  • Step 1: Binding of HIV-1 to the cell membrane of a CD4+ cell
  • Step 2: HIV-1 enters the cell via interaction with the membrane glycoproteins
  • Step 3: Reverse transcription of the viral genetic material using the virus' reverse transcriptase enzyme
  • Step 4: The HIV-1 genome travels into the nucleus
  • Step 5: The viral genome integrates into the host's DNA through the integrase enzyme
  • Step 6: The HIV-1 proviral genome undergoes transcription with the host DNA
  • Step 7: The viral messenger RNA (mRNA) undergoes translation to produce new viral proteins
  • Steps 8 and 9: Assembly and maturation of the virion

Other options:

Option B: Enfuvirtide acts at step 2 in the given image. It blocks gp41 of the cell membrane and blocks the entry of the virus into the cell. It prevents the free viral particles from invading new CD4+ cells. It is effective against HIV-1.

Option C: Tenofovir acts at step 3 in the given image. It is a nucleotide reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) that is effective against HIV-1,2 and hepatitis B infections. It is used in adults and children >2 years old. It can also be used for pre-exposure prophylaxis. 

Option D: Zidovudine also acts at step 3 in the given image. It is an NRTI and is effective against HIV-1,2 and Human T-cell Lymphoma Virus (HTLV). It can be used in adults and children. It can also be used to prevent mother-to-child transmission.

Related Pearl: Classification of antiretroviral drugs

CLASS DRUGS
Nucleoside Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitors Zidovudine, Stavudine, Lamivudine, Abacavir, Emtricitabine, Didanosine
Nucleotide Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitors Tenofovir
Non-nucleoside Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitors Nevirapine, Efavirenz, Delavirdine
Protease Inhibitors Saquinavir, Indinavir, Ritonavir, Nelfinavir, Lopinavir, Atazanavir, Tiprinavir, Darunavir
Entry Inhibitors Enfuvirtide, Maraviroc
Integrase Inhibitors Raltegravir, Elvitegravir, Dolutegravir

 

 

Related Pearl: NACO ART Guidelines- 2021

ART regimen

First-line for:

Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Dolutegravir
  • All PLHIV who are age >10 years and body weight >30 kg with HIV-1, HIV-2, HIV 1&2 co-infection who have not received any ART 
  • Those with HIV-TB and HIV hepatitis co-infections
  • Pregnant women, pregnant women presenting in active labour and breastfeeding women

Abacavir + Lamivudine + Efavirenz
  • All PLHIV with abnormal serum creatinine values 
  • All PLHIV with bodyweight less <30 kg

Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Efavirenz /Lopinavir /Ritonavir
  • Women of childbearing age group who do not wish to take Dolutegravir
  • All PLHIV who were on the previous recommended regime (Tenofovir+Lamivudine+Efavirenz) to be counselled to switch to new regime. Continue older regime if response is good
  • Women in child-bearing age group to be counselled about Dolutegravir with opt-out option before switching to new regime

*PLHIV: People living with HIV

questions.text: A 24-year-old male is brought to the ER after he was hit by a motorbike as he was crossing the road. He sustained injuries over his abdomen with visible bruising. His blood pressure is 80/50 and IV fluids are immediately instituted. What is the next best step for this patient?
questions.solution:
In this patient with a blunt abdominal injury who is hemodynamically unstable, the next best step is to do FAST-focused abdominal sonography in trauma.

Management of blunt abdominal injury: Primary assessment (ie, the primary survey) follows the ABCDE pattern: Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability (neurologic status), and Exposure.

Further management depends on the hemodynamic condition of the patient as shown below.

FAST-focused abdominal sonography in trauma is a rapidly obtainable ultrasound examination that assesses for intraperitoneal fluid. The regions visualised are

  • Right upper quadrant: Assess for right liver injuries, right kidney injury, and Morison's pouch.
  • Left upper quadrant: Assess for splenic injury and left kidney injury.
  • Suprapubic region: Assess the bladder and pouch of Douglas. 

Extended FAST(eFAST) is becoming a common investigation when a thoracic injury is also suspected. An additional region visualised here is

  • Subxiphoid view: Assess for pericardial effusion, cardiac tamponade, free blood and air in the hemithoraces and left lobe liver injuries.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common type of squint seen in children?
questions.solution:
Accommodative esotropia is the most common type of squint seen in children.

Most common type of squint overall: accommodative esotropia

Second most common overall: congenital/Infantile esotropia

Most common type of exotropia: primary exotropia

questions.text: The ultrasound of a young woman with infertility is suggestive of a uterine anomaly. Which of the following is used to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Hysteroscopy with laparoscopy is used to confirm the diagnosis of the likely uterine anomaly

For infertility evaluation, hysteroscopy and laparoscopy can detect müllerian anomalies, screen for co-existent endometriosis, and exclude other tubal or uterine cavity pathology. Hysteroscopy combined with laparoscopy can confirm both the internal and the external contour of the uterus.

This approach can differentiate between a septate and a bicornuate uterus. On laparoscopy, the presence of a uterine fundus indicates that the uterus is septate, while absence indicates it is bicornuate. The capacity of each horn in a bicornuate uterus and the depth and thickness of uterine septum prior to surgical resection can also be assessed. 

MR imaging is the preferred imaging technique as it is highly accurate in the evaluation of müllerian anomalies. It clearly delineates both the internal and external uterine anatomy. Complex anomalies and common associations like renal or skeletal anomalies can be evaluated concurrently using MRI.

Other options:

Option A: Hysterosalpingography (HSG) provides information about the interior contour of the uterine cavity but cannot accurately visualize the external contour of the uterus. 

Option C: Laparoscopy alone as a diagnostic procedure cannot visualize the interior contour of a hollow viscus like the uterus. This can be done only with the help of hysteroscopy or imaging such as sonography, HSG, or MRI.

Option D: Transvaginal sonography is used for the initial detection of uterine anomalies causing infertility or spontaneous abortions. Complete evaluation of these anomalies is done by MR imaging.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best measure of the standard of living?
questions.solution:
Human development index (HDI) is the best measure of the standard of living of a population.

The physical quality of life index (PQLI) measures the quality of life.

Related Pearl: HDI vs. PQLI

 

Human Development Index

[HDI]

Physical Quality of Life Index [PQLI]

Components

1.   Longevity (Life expectancy at birth)

2.  A decent standard of living (Real GNI per capita in PPP US$)

3.      Knowledge (Mean years of schooling; Expected years of schooling)

 

1.      Life expectancy at 1 year of age

 

2.      Infant Mortality rate

 

3.      Literacy rate

Range

0 to +1

0 to 100

 India currently ranks 132 (HDI is 0.633) on the 2021-2022 Human developmental Index.

questions.text: A doctor is teaching an Intern on how to do the knee reflex properly and a demonstration is done. The intern is asked to do learn the skill as it is very important in clinics.What type of learning is this?
questions.solution:
This type of learning a skill is called psychomotor learning.

The types of learning are cognitive, affective, and psychomotor learning.

Learning:

  • Learning is any relative or permanent change in behavior as a result of practice or experience.
  • It includes acquiring knowledge and skills, formation of habits, and development of perception.
  • The conditions that affect learning are as follows:
    • Intelligence
    • Age
    • Learning situation
    • Motivation
    • Physical and mental health
  • Types of learning:
    • Cognitive learning – knowledge
    • Affective learning – attitudes
    • Psychomotor learning – skills
  • Theories of learning:
    • Learning by conditioned reflex
    • Trial and error
    • Learning by observation and imitation
    • Learning by doing
    • Learning by remembering
    • Learning by insight
    • Demonstration
    • Field experience
    • Problem-solving

questions.text: What is the stage of the breast cancer shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The image shows Peau d'orange appearance of breast which is T4b according to the TNM staging.

Tumour of any size with overlying skin involvement(Peau d'orange appearance) is T4b.

The peau d'orange appearance of the breast occurs due to blockade of sub-dermal lymphatics.The lymphatic blockade gives rise to edema in the breast and tries to swell up. Since the infiltrated skin is tethered to the ligaments of Cooper, the swelling is restricted. The resultant edema deepens the mouth of the sweat glands and hair follicles giving rise to the typical orange peel appearance.

Related Pearl: TNM Staging of carcinoma breast

questions.text: The deformity shown in the following image below is characteristically seen in ___________
questions.solution:
The image given above shows windswept deformity (combination of valgus deformity of one leg with varus deformity of the other leg), which is characteristically seen in rickets.

However, it may also be seen in rheumatoid arthritis.

Clinical Features of Rickets:

General:

  • Failure to thrive
  • Listlessness
  • Protruding abdomen
  • Muscle weakness (especially proximal)
  • Fractures

Head:

  • Craniotabes
  • Frontal bossing
  • Delayed fontanel closure
  • Delayed dentition
  • Craniosynostosis

Chest:

  • Rachitic rosary
  • Harrison groove
  • Respiratory infections and atelectasis

Back:

  • Scoliosis, kyphosis, lordosis

Extremeties:

  • Enlargement of wrists and ankles
  • Valgus or varus deformities
  • Windswept deformity
  • Anterior bowing of the tibia
  • Coxa vara

Related Pearl: Important Clinical Features of Rickets

Related Pearl: Radiological features of rickets

Radiological features of rickets:

  • Delayed appearance of the epiphysis.
  • Widening of growth plate: normal width of growth is 2-4mm. It is increased in cases of rickets due to excessive accumulation of uncalcified osteoid at the growth plate.
  • Cupping of metaphysis: normally metaphysis meets epiphysis as a smooth line of sclerosis. But in rickets the line is absent and the metaphyseal ends appear irregular and the cartilage accumulating in the growth plate creates a depression in the metaphysis causing cupping.
  • Fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis
  • Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices.
  • Loss of provisional zone of calcification (becomes denser in healing rickets, known as the white line of Frenkel).

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient presents to the OPD with high fever, chest pain, dyspnoea, and hemoptysis. The patient also complains of watery diarrhea. The direct fluorescent antibody stain image of his pleural fluid is given below. Identify the most likely etiologic organism:
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and direct fluorescent antibody (DFA) stain image suggest the diagnosis of Legionnaire's disease, caused by Legionella pneumophila.

Two distinct clinical patterns have been identified and designated as Legionnaires' disease and Pontiac fever, together known as legionellosis

Legionnaires' disease presents with fever, non-productive cough and dyspnea, rapidly progresses to pneumonia if left untreated, diarrhea and encephalopathy is also common. 

Pontiac fever is a milder, non-fatal, influenza like illness with fever, chills, myalgia and headache.

questions.text: All of the following organisms can cause croup except ___?
questions.solution:
Croup can be caused by parainfluenza types 1, 2,3, RSV(Respiratory syncytial virus), and influenza viruses and it cannot be caused by Rhinovirus.

Croup or laryngotracheobronchitis:

  • It is an inflammatory condition of the larynx, trachea, and bronchi i.e. subglottis.
  • Mostly, it is a viral infection (parainfluenza type I, II, III) and less frequently by RSV and influenza viruses.
  • Affects children between 6 months and 3 years of age.
  • Male children are more often affected.
  • On X-ray: Steeple/Church top/pencil top sign (obstruction in subglottis) is seen as below:
  • Management:
    • Racemic epinephrine nebulization leads to rapid improvement of upper airway obstruction. 
    • Epinephrine constricts pre-capillary arterioles in the upper airway mucosa and decreases capillary hydrostatic pressure, leading to fluid resorption and improvement in airway edema.
    • Dexamethasone is indicated in all grades of croup.
    • Oxygen should be administered to children who are hypoxemic (SpO2 <92 %). 
    • Antibiotics are not indicated in croup.

questions.text: At which vertebral level is the celiac trunk seen?
questions.solution:
The celiac trunk is at T12 vertebral level.

Other options:

T9/T10: The xiphoid process of the sternum.

L1: The transpyloric plane passes through the lower border of L1. The portal vein's origin, the spinal cord's lower limit in adults, and the origin of the superior mesenteric artery are present on this plane.

questions.text:
Which of the following epithelia are correctly matched with their site?
Epithelium - Site
A. Transitional epithelium - Prostatic urethra
B. Stratified squamous epithelium - Membranous urethra
C. Pseudostratified columnar epithelium with stereocilia - Epididymis

D. Ciliated columnar epithelium - Fallopian tube
questions.solution:
Options A, C, and D are correctly matched.

Pseudostratified columnar epithelium lines the membranous urethra.

The following are various parts of the urethra in males and their lining epithelium:

  • Pre-prostatic & Prostatic urethra - Transitional epithelium
  • Membranous urethra - Pseudostratified columnar epithelium
  • Penile/ Spongy urethra - proximally, Pseudostratified columnar; distally, stratified squamous.

The epididymis contains pseudostratified columnar epithelium with stereocilia which help to increase the surface area for absorption.

The ciliated columnar epithelium is found in most of the respiratory tract, the uterus, and the uterine tube (oviduct), efferent ductules of the testis, parts of the middle ear and auditory tube; the ependyma lining the central canal of the spinal cord and the ventricles of the brain.

Related Pearl: Various Types of Epithelium, Their Location and Functions

questions.text: Which of the following would not be seen in Samter's triad?
questions.solution:
Epistaxis is not a feature of Samter's triad.

Samter's triad is also known as aspirin-induced asthma or aspirin-sensitive asthma. It consists of:

  • Nasal polyposis
  • Bronchial asthma
  • Aspirin intolerance

Patients with Samter's triad will have persistent nasal congestion, rhinorrhea, anosmia, nasal polyps, and recurrent chronic rhinosinusitis. Asthma and aspirin intolerance develop later.

Acute asthma attacks usually occur 3 hours after intake of aspirin or NSAIDs. Severe rhinorrhea, conjunctival injection, facial flushing, and periorbital edema are also seen. Aspirin-induced hypersensitivity reactions also may occur. 

Patients should avoid aspirin and NSAIDs that inhibit COX-1. Treatment may involve aspirin desensitization and endoscopic sinus surgery.

Related Pearl: Extrinsic vs Intrinsic asthma

Component Extrinsic asthma Intrinsic asthma
Onset Childhood Adult
Clinical features H/o atopy associated with allergic rhinitis and dermatitis Samter's triad - Intrinsic asthma + Nasal polyposis + Aspirin sensitivity
IgE levels Type 1 Hypersensitivity with increased IgE levels IgE levels within normal limits
Most common trigger Dermatophagoides (House mite)

Superantigen - 
S. aureus enterotoxin
Prognosis Good Bad

questions.text: The image below depicts the examiner eliciting ___________
questions.solution:
The image shows the examiner pressing in the popliteal fossa to elicit sciatic pain which is known as Bowstring sign. 

Important tests for inter-vertebral disc prolapse:

1. Straight Leg Raising Test (SLRT) or Lasegue sign

This is done to assess nerve root irritation in the lumbosacral area.  The patient is made to lie on the back with the head extended, with hips and legs in the neutral position. The affected leg is then passively and slowly raised by the ankle with the knee fully extended. The examiner stops further leg elevation when pain is elicited. Normally it should be possible to raise the limb to 80–90 degrees. The SLRT test is positive if the patient develops pain when the leg is between 30 and 60/70 degrees from horizontal. The pain should be radicular type and radiating to the back of the thigh or to the calf.

2. Bragard test (or Sciatic stretch test or Flip test)

Perform SLRT. At the point where the patient experiences discomfort, the leg is lowered a little. The stretching and pain become less. At this angle, the ankle is passively dorsiflexed. If the pain at the back of the thigh or in the calf is felt again, the test is positive. This is also called reinforcement positive or Bragard’s sign positive.

3. Crossed SLRT (or well-leg raising test or Fajersztajn sign)

When SLRT is performed on the unaffected side, the patient may feel pain on the affected side. This is termed a contralateral positive SLRT or crossed SLRT positive. It is a very specific sign of root compression. It becomes positive usually when there is severe compression due to a centrally located prolapse.

4. Bowstring sign (or popliteal compression test)

The ‘bowstring sign’ is even more specific for disc prolapse than SLRT. Perform SLRT until the patient experiences sciatic pain. Without reducing the amount of lift, bend the knee so as to relax the sciatic nerve. Buttock pain is immediately relieved. The examiner then presses the popliteal fossa to stretch the lateral popliteal nerve behind the lateral tibial condyle. This will tighten the nerve like a bowstring and re-induce the pain. 

5. Femoral stretch (reverse Lasegue test or Mackiewicz sign)

The patient lies prone. The examiner flexes the knee to the thigh and the hip is passively extended. The test is positive if the patient experiences anterior thigh pain. This test is usually positive for L2-L3 and L3-L4 (high lumbar) protrusions.

questions.text: The peripheral smear of a patient with suspected acute leukemia shows the following characteristic finding. What is the structure marked by the arrow known as?
questions.solution:
The above image shows Auer rods, which are characteristically seen in acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

Auer rods are clumps of azurophilic granular material that appear as elongated needles, in the cytoplasm of leukemic blasts.

They can be seen in the leukemic blasts of AML and acute promyelocytic leukemia.

questions.text: A middle age male patient presented with complaints of palpitations. The patient's ECG tracing is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient with ECG showing irregularly irregular rhythm is atrial fibrillation.

Atrial fibrillation (AF) is a type of cardiac arrhythmia characterized by disorganized, rapid, and irregular atrial activation. It is common in men and risk factors are age, underlying cardiac disease, hypertension, diabetes, family history of AF, and obesity.

Features include heart rate typically ranging from 110-160 beats/minute. It is irregular and rapid. Presyncope and syncope can be seen. Thrombus formation can occur and thromboembolic events can take place.

Typically, ECG shows an irregularly irregular rhythm with absent p waves.

Management is mainly by controlling rate and rhythm, avoiding the thromboembolism risk and modifying risk factors. 

Related Pearl: ECG patterns of various ventricular arrhythmias

Ventricular tachycardia

 

Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia associated with QTc prolongation- Torsades de pointes

 

Ventricular flutter

 

Ventricular fibrillation

questions.text: A psychotic patient developed voluntary purposeless movements and was once observed to be standing still for hours with waxy flexibility and negativism. What is the appropriate medical management?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of a catatonic disorder. Benzodiazepines such as lorazepam are effective in the treatment of catatonia.

Catatonia is a syndrome characterized by striking behav­ioral abnormalities such as motoric immobility or excite­ment, negativism, or echolalia (mimicry of speech), or echopraxia (mimicry of movement).

The clinical picture may include three or more of the following features

  • Stupor: Absence of psychomotor activity and not actively relating to the environment.
  • Catalepsy: Passive induction of a posture held against gravity.
  • Waxy flexibility: Slight, even resistance to positioning by examiner.
  • Mutism: Very little or no verbal response to instructions or external stimuli.
  • Negativism: Opposition or no response to instructions or external stimuli.
  • Posturing: Spontaneous and active maintenance of a posture against gravity.
  • Mannerism: Odd, circumstantial caricature of normal actions.
  • Stereotypy: Repetitive, abnormally frequent, non-goal-directed movements
  • Agitation, not influenced by external stimuli
  • Grimacing
  • Echolalia: Mimicking another's speech.
  • Echopraxia: Mimicking another's movement.

Catatonic disorder may occur due to an underlying medical condition such as neurologi­cal disorders (e.g., nonconvulsive status epilepticus, and head trauma), infections (e.g., encephalitis), and metabolic disturbances (e.g., hepatic encephalopathy, hyponatremia, and hypercalcemia). It may also occur due to some drugs like corticoste­roids, immunosuppressants, and antipsychotic (i.e., neurolep­tic) agents.

It is mostly seen in patients with advanced mood or psychotic illnesses.

  • Electroconvulsive therapy is the definitive treatment in cases of life-threatening catatonia (if the patient is unable to eat) or if the patient has developed malignant catatonia.

questions.text: A 1 week-old neonate was brought to the tertiary care hospital with the following findings and a head circumference less than -3SD. The mother informs that she has been taking a drug for a neurological condition, for the last 4 years. Which of the following drugs is likely to be implicated in this case?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of an intrauterine growth restriction, with a history of drug intake for neurological conditions and the image showing a cleft lip, the most likely drug implicated is phenytoin.

The mother would have been taking phenytoin during pregnancy which can cross the placenta and cause fetal hydantoin syndrome as shown in the image.

In fetal hydantoin syndrome, the child may be small at birth with increased hair on the body and face facial features include a flat nasal bridge, an underdeveloped vertical groove in the center of the upper lip (philtrum), malformed ears, downward-slanting eyes, which are spaced widely (hypertelorism), strabismus, ptosis and epicanthic folds. Other features include microcephaly and growth deficiencies like underdeveloped fingers and toes, and malformed nails.

The child would have varying degrees of developmental delay and the risk of an affected child having neurological deficits, cleft lip, cleft palate, and heart defects is very high. They may be at increased risk of the occurrence of benign or malignant tumors, such as neuroblastoma and Wilms tumor.

Side effects of phenytoin include:

  • Hirsutism
  • Hypersensitivity reactions
  • Osteomalacia
  • Megaloblastic anemia
  • Fetal hydantoin syndrome 

Dose-related toxicity of phenytoin causes the following:

  • Ataxia, vertigo, diplopia, and nystagmus (most characteristic)

Other options:

Option A: Maternal use of Lithium leads to Ebstein's anomaly where there is downward displacement of an abnormal tricuspid valve into the right ventricle and macrosomia.

Options B and D: Levetiracetam and Lamotrigine are relatively safe in pregnancy and do not seem to cause neural tube defects.

questions.text: A young HIV-positive patient presents with complaints of fever and neck stiffness. The patient's cerebrospinal fluid sample when stained with India ink reveals the following finding. The organism responsible for this infection is transmitted by which of the following methods?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Cryptococcosis which is caused by Cryptococcus neoformans. This organism is usually transmitted through inhalation but occasionally also through skin and mucosa.

Cryptococcus neoformans is a round/ovoid budding cell with a prominent polysaccharide capsule. This capsule can be visualized with the assistance of the India ink stain.

Cryptococcal meningitis and meningoencephalitis are opportunistic infections seen in patients with acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS). Patients present with symptoms such as fever/headache. Patients are treated with a combination of Amphotericin with flucytosine.

Other options:

Option A: Diseases such as Lyme disease and Q fever are transmitted by the bite of ixodid ticks.

Option B: Cat scratch disease is caused by Bartonella henselae. It presents as a febrile illness with lymphadenopathy following a cat scratch.

Option D: Primary amoebic meningoencephalitis caused by Naegleria fowleri is acquired by swimming in freshwater rivers or ponds. 

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains These include Eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, Congo red, etc. and are mostly used to stain pathological specimens.
Basic stains.

1.    Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in counterstaining in quellung reaction of streptococcus pneumoniae.  

2.    Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction of anthrax bacilli
Neutral stains

1.    Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

2.    Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and some other spirochete and protozoan blood parasites.  

 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contains more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: Used to distinguish cells by cell-wall type. To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain: Used to distinguish acid-fast bacteria from non-acid-fast cells. Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid – fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia.
Fluorochrome staining: Used for rapid scanning of the smear, where the AFB appear fluorescent green against a black background Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.

C. Special stains

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "Chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (Anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–Starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor White Staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain Calcofluor white, which greatly enhances visibility of fungal element in tissue or other specimens. It is especially useful for the identification of Mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.   It is also used in staining acanthamoeba
Chance's staining For Cell wall demonstration

questions.text: A replacement surgery was conducted on a patient, as he had malfunctioning of the instrument shown in the below image. According to biomedical waste management, which of the following colored boxes should the instrument be disposed of in?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a metallic pacemaker and it should be discarded in the blue color box.

All metallic body implants except metallic sharps are discarded in the blue box. Metallic sharps are discarded in white color or translucent boxes.

Other wastes discarded in the blue box are:

  • Glassware- broken or discarded
  • Contaminated glass including medicine vials and ampoules except those contaminated with cytotoxic wastes.

All items contaminated with cytotoxic drugs along with their glass or plastic ampoules and vials are discarded in the yellow boxes along with the cytotoxic drugs.

Treatment or disposal options of wastes in the blue box are:

  • Disinfection with detergent and sodium hypochlorite treatment, or
  • Autoclaving, or
  • Microwaving, or
  • Hydroclaving 

They are then sent for recycling.

Different colored bins used in biomedical waste management are yellow, red, white, and blue.

questions.text: A male child delivered via cesarean section at term was found to have apnea and hypotonia at birth. What is the immediate next step in the management of this baby?
questions.solution:
The immediate next step in the management of a just-delivered newborn with apnea and hypotonia is the clearing of airway secretions.

As soon as a baby is born, the tone, cry, breathing efforts, and respiratory efforts are assessed. If the tone is poor or if the baby is not breathing, the following measures are done immediately.

  • Warming to maintain the normal temperature 
  • Proper positioning of the baby's airway, i.e. sniffing position with the head slightly extended.
  • Clearing of airway secretions
  • Tactile stimulation

If the heart rate is < 100 beats/min or the baby remains apneic after these steps, positive pressure ventilation (PPV) can be initiated with a bag and mask ventilation with a pulse oximeter and ECG leads connected. 

Signs of effective ventilation:

  • Adequate chest rise
  • Symmetric breath sounds
  • Improved pink color
  • Heart rate >100 beats/ min
  • Improving oxygen saturation
  • Spontaneous respiratory efforts
  • Improved tone

If there are no signs of effective ventilation even after 30 seconds of PPV, corrective steps MRSOPA should be performed to improve ventilation. MRSOPA includes mask readjustment, repositioning of the head, suction of mouth and nose, opening the mouth, pressure increase, and establishing an alternative airway.

After 60 seconds of PPV with ventilation correction steps, if the heart rate is < 60 beats/min, endotracheal intubation or laryngeal mask airway should be established. Even after intubation if the heart rate is <60/min, chest compressions should be initiated at the ratio of 3:1 (90 compressions:30 breaths).

After 60 seconds of intubation with chest compressions, if the heart rate is <60 beats/min, epinephrine (1:10,000 solution at 0.1–0.3 mL/kg intravenously or 0.5–1 mL/kg intratracheally) should be administered. The dosage can be repeated every 3–5 minutes. Persistent bradycardia may signify inadequate ventilation or severe cardiac compromise.

The resuscitation can be stopped if the heart rate is not detected even after 10 minutes of continuous adequate resuscitation.

questions.text: A patient undergoing chemotherapy was given an antiemetic, after which he developed symptoms like acute dystonia, bradykinesia, and tremors. Which of the following drugs would have caused these symptoms?
questions.solution:
In the above scenario, the patient has developed extrapyramidal adverse effects like acute dystonia, bradykinesia, and tremors. This is likely due to the antagonist action on dopamine receptors by metoclopramide.

Metoclopramide is a prokinetic and antiemetic. It has the following pharmacological actions:

  • Dopamine receptor antagonist 
  • Serotonin (5HT4) receptor agonist 
  • Serotonin (5HT3) antagonist
  • Sensitization of muscarinic receptors on smooth muscle. This results in increased lower esophageal sphincter tone and stimulates gastric antral contractions.

Metoclopramide acts on both the gastrointestinal system and central nervous system. It is used as an upper antiemetic for many types of vomiting, especially migraine, drug-induced, and chemotherapy-induced. It is also used as a prokinetic in gastroparesis to increase gastric emptying.

Adverse effects of metoclopramide are mainly extrapyramidal effects, and these include acute dystonia, Parkinson-like symptoms (tremors, bradykinesia, rigidity), tardive dyskinesia, galactorrhea due to hyperprolactinemia, and methemoglobinemia in neonates.

Extrapyramidal symptoms can be treated by discontinuation of metoclopramide and administration of anticholinergics or antihistaminics.

Other options:

Option A: Ondansetron is a 5-HT3 receptor antagonist. It blocks impulses at the peripheral origin in GIT. It is most commonly indicated for the treatment of postoperative and chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting. Headache and dizziness are the common adverse effects.

Option C: Meclizine is a long-acting H1 antihistaminic drug. It is used for seasickness. It is less sedative and less anticholinergic.

Option D: Scopolamine (hyoscine) is a muscarinic antagonist. It blocks neural pathways from the vestibular apparatus in the inner ear to the emetic center in the brainstem. A transdermal patch of scopolamine is used as an antiemetic in motion sickness. Constipation, drowsiness, dry mouth, and blurred vision are the common adverse effects.

questions.text: Hematogenous spread of carcinoma prostate occurs predominantly to the______.
questions.solution:
The hematogenous spread of carcinoma prostate occurs predominantly in the bones and is typically osteoblastic.

Batson venous plexus is a valveless vertebral venous plexus communicating with the prostatic venous plexus. Carcinoma of the prostate metastasizes to the bone usually by the bloodstream through this Batson plexus. The bones most frequently involved are the pelvic bones and the lower lumbar vertebrae. The femoral head, ribcage and skull are other common sites. Other routes of spread of prostate carcinoma are local spread to the seminal vesicles, bladder neck, trigone, and lymphatic spread.

Carcinoma of the prostate is the most common malignancy in men above 65 years. The clinical features of prostate cancer are bladder outlet obstruction, pelvic pain, hematuria, arthritis, anaemia, and renal failure. Per rectal examination reveals a hard, nodular, irregularly indurated gland. 

Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) is useful in assessing the follow-up. PSA >10 ng/mL is suggestive of cancer and levels >35 ng/mL are diagnostic of advanced prostate cancer. The prostatic biopsy is indicated when there is a raised PSA level or suspicion of prostate cancer.

Localized cancer is treated by radical prostatectomy and radiation therapy, while in advanced cancer palliative and hormone ablation should be carried out. 

Related Pearl: Types of metastasis(osteoblastic or osteolytic) and their primary:

Predominantly osteoblastic:

  • Prostate cancer
  • Osteosarcoma 
  • Medullary carcinoma thyroid

Mixed osteoblastic and osteolytic:

  • Breast cancer(preponderance toward osteolytic)
  • Lymphoma
  • Urothelial carcinoma 
  • Lung cancer

Predominantly osteolytic:

  • Renal cell carcinoma
  • Multiple myeloma 
  • Thyroid carcinoma(except medullary carcinoma thyroid)
  • Gastrointestinal tract carcinoma
  • Malignant melanoma

questions.text: A patient is brought to the casualty following a road traffic accident. The patient is in respiratory distress and his X-ray is shown below. What is the next best step of management?

choices.text: Tube thoracostomy at 5th intercostal space anterior to mid-axillary line
Needle decompression at 5th intercostal space anterior to mid-axillary line
Needle decompression at 5th intercostal space in the mid-clavicular line
Needle decompression at 2nd intercostal space anterior to mid-axillary line

questions.solution:
Immediate management of a tension pneumothorax is done with needle decompression or needle thoracostomy i.e. insertion of a wide-bore needle in the 5th ICS anterior to the midaxillary line

Definitive management - tube thoracostomy or chest tube insertion in the 5th ICS in the triangle of safety.

Triangle of safety:

The boundaries are 

  • Anteriorly - lateral border of the pectoralis major
  • Posteriorly- latissimus dorsi
  • Inferiorly- a line perpendicular to the nipple going to the back

For pediatric patients, needle decompression is done at the midclavicular line in the 2nd intercostal space.

The images below show the triangle of safety and technique of chest drain insertion.

questions.text:
Match the following syndromes with their respective karyotypes.
Condition Karyotype
1. Turner's syndrome A. 46 + XX
2. Sweyer's syndrome B. 46+ XY
3. Androgen insensitivity syndrome C. 46+ XY
4. MRKH - Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser syndrome D. 45 + XO
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1-D, 2-C, 3-B, 4-A.

MRKH syndrome (Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser)/ MURCS (Mullerian agenesis, renal aplasia, and cervicothoracic somite dysplasia)is a condition where the testes are absent. It has a Karyotype of 46 XX. So, the gonads present are ovaries (in contrast to androgen insensitivity syndrome where the testes are present). Vagina in its upper 2/3rd are absent but lower one-third is present as it develops from the urogenital sinus.

Complete androgen insensitivity syndrome/testicular feminizing syndrome:

In this syndrome, the karyotype is XY and thus, the patient is a genotypic male. Pathology is due to the defective response of the androgen receptors to androgens. Findings include:

  • Primary amenorrhea → Due to the absence of uterus and cervix.
  • Normally developed breasts → Due to the conversion of the excessive androgens into estrogen.
  • Swelling in the inguinal region → Suggestive of an underdeveloped ectopic testis, caused by loss of action of testosterone on its receptor.
  • Absence of uterus and cervix → Due to the production of Mullerian inhibiting substance from the Sertoli cells of the testis.

Note:

There is some discrepancy among authors on this topic. Androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS) with XY karyotype may have mostly female external sexual characteristics. According to William's Textbook of Obstetrics 25th edition page 40, breast development occurs due to peripheral aromatization of testosterone to estrogen whereas the pubic and axillary hair remains scant or absent. But as per Shaw's Textbook of Gynecology, XY females with AIS have normal secondary sexual characteristics. 

Sweyer syndrome or pure gonadal dysgenesis occurs as a result of a mutation in the SRY gene. This leads to underdeveloped, dysgenetic gonads that fail to produce androgens or anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH). The following features are seen: 

  • Normal prepubertal female phenotype- Absent or poorly developed secondary sexual characteristics.
  • Normal Müllerian system development due to the absence of AMH. (Uterus and cervix present)
  • Female external genitalia
  • Presence of dysgenetic testes that cannot produce AMH or sex hormones. They have a risk of malignant transformation.

As there is gonadal dysgenesis in a patient with 46 XY karyotype, they are actually determined to be males and are a type of male pseudohermaphrodite. They present with primary amenorrhoea, absence of secondary sex characters, and female external genitalia.

Turner's syndrome is a chromosomal abnormality with partial or complete monosomy of the X chromosome (45+XO). In Turner's syndrome, gonadal dysgenesis causes primary ovarian failure that is hypogonadism. The clinical picture of amenorrhea, short stature, webbed neck, low hairline at the back of the neck, widely spaced nipples, and lack of secondary sexual characteristics is seen in Turner's syndrome.

Related Pearl: Disorders of Sexual Development

Disorder

Complete androgen insensitivity

Mullerian agenesis

Turner syndrome

Complete XY dysgenesis (Swyer syndrome)

Cause

X-linked mutation of androgen receptor

Hypoplastic or absent Mullerian ductal system

Also called Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome

Complete or partial absence of one X chromosome

SRY gene mutation on the Y chromosome

Reproductive organs

Absent uterus and upper vagina, cryptorchid testis

Absent or rudimentary uterus and upper vagina, normal ovaries

Normal uterus and vagina, streak gonads

Normal uterus and vagina, streak gonads

Breast

Yes

Yes

Variable

No

Normal

Normal

Karyotype

Note: 

Turner's syndrome have different chromosomal anomalies:

  • 45 XO which is seen in 40-50% patients 
  • 45 X mosaicism (eg, 45,X/46,XX or 45,X/47,XXX, or 45,X mosaics with the X chromosome anomalies)

questions.text: Features of competitive inhibition include ________
questions.solution:
Vmax remains constant in competitive inhibition reactions.

Properties of Competitive inhibition on enzyme dynamics:

  • Vmax remains constant
  • Km increases (MNEMONIC: In competition, we run for KILOMETRES i.e. Km; Hence remember as Km increases in Competitive inhibition)
  • Reversible
  • The inhibition can be overcome by increasing the concentration of the substrate.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient presents to the OPD with complaints of shortness of breath and tiredness for weeks. On examination, there were engorged neck veins and jugular venous pressure showed prominent x and y descent. The chest radiograph is seen below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and X-ray showing calcification of the pericardium are suggestive of constrictive pericarditis.

Constrictive pericarditis is a condition in which granulation tissue formation in the pericardium results in loss of pericardial elasticity leading to restricted ventricular filling. It is usually a chronic condition.

The leading cause worldwide is tuberculosis. Other common causes include viral infections, SLE and idiopathic. Patients who have undergone cardiac surgery or radiation therapy are also at an increased risk of developing this condition.

Clinically patients present with symptoms such as dyspnea, orthopnea and fatigue. On physical examination, the jugular venous pressure (JVP) is usually elevated with a prominent x and y descent. JVP does not decrease with inspiration, and this is known as Kussmaul's sign. 

ECHO is used to make a diagnosis and patients may demonstrate pericardial calcification on chest radiographs. Pericardiectomy is the only definitive management.

questions.text: A child presented with cola-colored urine, hypertension, and puffiness of eyes. Creatinine was 2.5 mg/dl. Treatment was started and despite treatment, the patient did not improve for the next 3 weeks. The creatinine value increased to 4.5mg/dl. Which among the following electron microscopic findings will be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the above clinical scenario is post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis. Subepithelial deposits will be seen on electron microscopy.

Poststreptococcal GN is uncommon before the age of 3 years and most prevalent in kids between the ages of 5 and 12. The patient typically develops an acute nephritic syndrome following:

  • 1 to 2 weeks after streptococcal pharyngitis or
  • 3 to 6 weeks after streptococcal pyoderma

From asymptomatic microscopic hematuria with normal renal function to gross hematuria with acute renal failure, the severity of kidney involvement varies. Patients may experience different levels of edema, hypertension, and oliguria depending on the extent of the renal involvement.

Laboratory findings: More than 90% of patients see a considerable reduction in serum C3 levels during the acute phase, which lasts 6 to 8 weeks before returning to normal. 
In order to confirm the diagnosis, evidence of preceding streptococcal infection is required. The antistreptolysin O titer frequently rises following pharyngeal infections. The anti-deoxyribonuclease B level is the most effective single antibody titer to demonstrate cutaneous streptococcal infection.

Microscopic Findings in PSGN:
  • Light microscopy: Enlarged, hypercellular glomeruli with diffuse mesangial and endothelial proliferation and leukocyte infiltration.
  • Immunofluorescence: Granular deposits of IgG and complement C3 along the glomerular basement membrane(GBM)and in the mesangium. 
  • Electron microscopy: Primarily subepithelial humps are seen. Subendothelial deposits in early disease stages can be seen.

Below is the image showing light microscopy findings of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old pregnant woman at 36 weeks gestation comes with a history of multiple episodes of convulsions at home. The diagnosis of eclampsia is made. What is the next step of management?
questions.solution:
The next step in the management of eclampsia is the administration of MgSO4 + Intravenous labetalol.

The first step in the management of eclampsia is maintaining the airway and preventing aspiration.

The immediate measures in the medical management of eclampsia include the following steps:

  • Call for extra help (Communication)
  • To put the patient in a left lateral recumbent position and maintain oral airway
  • O2 inhalation 
  • Secure IV lines: 1 or 2 wide bore cannulas and start fluids.
  • Catheterize the patient with a Foley's catheter and an urometer
  • Control of seizures: MgSO4 (IV/IM regimens)
  • Control of hypertension: Labetalol
  • Oropharyngeal suction
  • Diuretics administration for pulmonary edema, if present.

The definitive management of eclampsia is always the termination of pregnancy irrespective of gestational age. If labor does not start and the seizures are controlled, a mature baby is vaginally delivered by induction of labor. If the baby is premature, steroids are given(<34 weeks) and delivery is conducted. In case of obstetric contraindications for a vaginal delivery, a cesarean section should be done to deliver the fetus.

Intravenous labetalol is the first-line agent for control of BP in pregnancy. It is a nonselective β blocker and vascular α blocker It has a rapid onset of action. It should be avoided in patients with asthma and congestive heart failure due to bronchoconstriction.

MgSO4 is used for the management of eclampsia and as prophylaxis in severe pre-eclampsia. Magnesium is mainly used in preeclampsia due to its specific anticonvulsant action and neuroprotective action on the cortex. MgSO4 acts as a membrane stabilizer. It reduces motor endplate sensitivity to acetylcholine and blocks neuronal calcium influx. It is not used to treat hypertension, although it shows some hypotensive action by decreasing vascular response to vasopressors.

The therapeutic level of magnesium in eclampsia is 4-7mEq/L. The two regimens commonly used are Pritchard and Sibai regimen.

Regimen    Loading Dose    Maintenance Dose
Intramuscular (Pritchard)  4g (20% solution) IV over 3-5 minute
 followed by 10g (5O%), deep IM
 (5 gm in each buttock)		  5g (5O%) IM 4 hourly in the   alternate buttocks
Intravenous (Zuspan or Sibai)  4g IV slow over 15-20 minute  1-2g/h IV infusion

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with bilateral adnexal masses and ascites. Histopathological examination of the resected specimen shows sheets of mucin-producing signet-ring cells. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis with the above clinical interpretation is metastatic signet-ring carcinoma called Krukenberg tumor.

Krukenberg tumor is a metastatic ovarian malignancy with the primary site is in the gastrointestinal tract or breast. It is often bilateral. Primary sites include the stomach (70%); carcinoma of the colon, appendix, and breast (mainly invasive lobular carcinoma). Numerous signet-ring cells are seen in the Krukenberg tumor. Signet ring cells are mucin-producing cells with the appearance of a signet ring often originating from the gastric mucosa.

The image below shows signet-ring cells in the Kruckenberg tumor.

questions.text: Following feature (Image A) is characteristic of a certain disease. On investigation, the lady was found to have the following immunofluorescence pattern (Image B). Positivity of which of the given antibody would predict a higher risk of interstitial lung disease in her?
questions.solution:
Image A is a classical fish mouth (microstomia) appearance seen in systemic sclerosis/scleroderma. Image B shows the nucleolar pattern (some spots of fluorescence within the nucleus and it represents antibodies to RNA). The pattern is most often seen in systemic sclerosis. Anti-scl-70 positivity in this disease is useful in predicting those at higher risk for interstitial lung disease.

Scleroderma or Systemic Sclerosis (SSc) is an autoimmune rheumatic disease in which there is a 4:1 female predominance.

A wide spectrum of clinical features are seen in Scleroderma:

  • Severe pruritus
  • Initially, scleroderma patients experience puffiness and non-pitting edema of fingers
  • The skin later becomes indurated, thickened, and fixed to underlying structures resulting in sclerodactyly
  • Vasospasm and Digital ulceration
  • Around 90% of patients suffering from scleroderma, have dysphagia, and GERD at the level of esophagus
  • Mask like facies is seen due to the waxy nature of skin and lack of wrinkles, expressionless facies, mat‐like telangiectases, microstomia, perioral furrowing and beak‐like nose.The intense sclerosis of organs and primarily the fibrosis of the skin has devastating effects on the affected patients .
  • Anti-topoisomerase I (Scl-70) and anti RNA polymerase III are seen in Diffuse Cutaneous Systemic sclerosis  which can have pulmonary manifestation as interstial lung disease.

Other options:

  • Anti centromere antibody is most specific for CREST syndrome.
  • Anti U1-RNP is seen in mixed connective tissue disease.
  • Anti U3-RNP (Antifibrillarin) autoantibodies are associated with patients of Afro-Caribbean origin and can identify patients with SSc who are younger at disease onset and display a higher prevalence of myositis.

questions.text: A middle-aged obese man has presented with acute pain around his left first metatarsophalangeal joint. He had similar episodes in the past. The X-ray is given below. Which drug is commonly used as the initial treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and the X-ray showing Martel's sign point towards a diagnosis of acute on chronic presentation of gout. Indomethacin is commonly used in the initial treatment of gout.

In addition to inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis, indomethacin and other NSAIDs also inhibit urate crystal phagocytosis.

Other options:

Option A: Aspirin, an NSAID (Nonsteroidal Anti-inflammatory Drug), covalently acetylates the catalytic subunits of the COX-1 and COX-2 dimers, irreversibly inhibiting cyclooxygenase enzyme (COX) activity. Aspirin is not used in acute gout because it causes renal retention of uric acid at low doses. It is uricosuric only at higher doses that are poorly tolerated. 

Option C: Allopurinol is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor indicated in prophylaxis of gout. The adverse effects include hepatotoxicity, diarrhea, joint pain, and rash. A flare in the gout attack can be seen during the initiation of therapy due to a decrease in serum uric acid levels that results in the mobilization of uric acid from tissue deposits.

Option D: Colchicine acts by inhibiting microtubule and spindle formation. Side effects are nausea, vomiting, myelosuppression, aplastic anemia, and rhabdomyolysis. NSAIDs are selected over colchicine because of troublesome diarrhea associated with colchicine.

Related Pearl: Drugs precipitating Gout

Drugs that precipitate gout are-

Cyclosporine or cancer drugs
Aspirin (low dose)
Niacin
Thiazide
Lasix (furosemide)
Ethambutol
Alcohol
Pyrazinamide

Mnemonic for drugs precipitating gout is 'CANT LEAP'

questions.text: Which of the following radioisotopes is used in a PET-CT scan?
questions.solution:
18F-FDG is the radioisotope used in a PET-CT scan.

Positron emission tomography - CT (PET-CT):

  • PET imaging is based on the detection of an injected positron-emitting radioactive tracer.
  • It relies on the coincidence detection of the annihilation photons (γ), which are released when a positron combines with an electron.
  • A glucose analog called FDG (fluorodeoxyglucose) is used in PET imaging. FDG is taken up by metabolically active cells, where it undergoes phosphorylation to form FDG-6-phosphate. Unlike glucose, FDG-6-phosphate cannot undergo further metabolism and becomes trapped within the cell. (So, the patient must be fasted for 4-6 hrs prior to imaging).
  • The trapped FDG-6-phosphate is detected by the PET scanner. 
  • Before injecting FDG, the blood glucose level should be measured. It should be < 150 mg/dL. Good blood glucose control is essential as FDG uptake is competitively inhibited by glucose.
  • Imaging is started 60 minutes following FDG injection.

Indications of PET-CT:

  • PET-CT is used in oncology imaging to detect malignant cells as they demonstrate increased glucose metabolism relative to normal tissues.
  • It is indicated for the differentiation of a malignant from a benign lesion.
  • It is indicated in tumor staging and evaluation of tumor recurrence.

Areas of normal physiological uptake in PET CT:

  • Brain tissue
  • Skeletal muscle, especially after strenuous activity, and laryngeal muscles following speech
  • Myocardium
  • Gastrointestinal tract, e.g. intestinal wall
  • Genitourinary tract (FDG is excreted via the renal system and passes into the collecting systems)
  • Brown fat (FDG accumulates here as glucose and ATP are required for heat production)
  • Thymus
  • Bone marrow

questions.text: True statement regarding the image is -

choices.text: Metaphysis of distal femur is common location
Diaphysis of humerus is most common location

questions.solution:
The image shows lateral radiograph of the tibia demonstrating lesion with poorly marginated edges in diaphysis of the bone. The lamellated periosteal reaction in diaphysis is suggestive of Ewing’s sarcoma which is a highly radiosensitive tumour.

Ewing sarcoma:

  • Is a malignant bone tumor characterized by primitive round cells without obvious differentiation.
  • It accounts for 6% to 10% of primary malignant bone tumors.
  • Ewing sarcoma follows osteosarcoma as the second most common group of bone sarcomas in children.
  • Approximately 80% of affected patients are younger than 20 years. Boys are affected slightly more frequently than girls.
  • Usually, the tumor arises in the diaphysis of long tubular bones, especially the femur and the flat bones of the pelvis.
  • Fever, elevated sedimentation rate, anemia, and leukocytosis may be seen.
  • Plain radiographs show a destructive lytic tumor with permeative margins that extends into the surrounding soft tissues.
  • The characteristic periosteal reaction produces layers of reactive bone deposited in an onion-skin fashion.
  • It arises in the medullary cavity. Ewing sarcoma usually invades the cortex, periosteum, and soft tissue.

Related Pearl: Radiosensitive and Radioresistant Tumors

Highly radiosensitive tumors are

  • Lymphoma
  • Seminoma
  • Myeloma
  • Ewing’s sarcoma
  • Wilm’s tumour

 Highly radioresistant tumors are

  • Melanoma
  • Osteosarcoma
  • Pancreatic carcinoma
  • Hepatic carcinoma
  • Renal cell carcinoma

questions.text: MRI rooms are shielded completely by a continuous sheet or wire mesh of copper to shield the imager from external electromagnetic radiation. It is called ______
questions.solution:
MRI rooms are shielded completely by a continuous sheet or wire mesh of copper called Faraday cage, which provides RF shielding.

Radiofrequency shielding in MRI is crucial to prevent both external radiofrequency pulses from interfering with the detector and the radiofrequency pulses generated by the scanner from interfering with the external environment.

questions.text: Postmortem diagnosis of rabies infection can be done by:
questions.solution:
Postmortem diagnosis of rabies infection can be done by demonstration of Negri bodies in the hippocampus.

Negri bodies are eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions in neurons that are composed of rabies virus proteins and viral RNA. These are commonly observed in Purkinje cells of the cerebellum and in pyramidal neurons of the hippocampus. Their presence is a characteristic pathologic finding in rabies.

Rabies is a fatal infection of the central nervous system transmitted by the bite of a rabid animal. It is caused by rhabdoviruses. These viruses are enveloped, rod or bullet shaped, and contain single-stranded RNA.

Clinical features of rabies can be categorized into three phases: prodromal, encephalitic phase, and coma. Prodromal phase is characterised by malaise, anorexia, headache, and irritability. This is followed by the encephalitic stage characterized by abnormal behavior and seizures. They develop hydrophobia. Attempts to drink liquids cause painful spasms of the pharynx and larynx, producing a choking sensation. Therefore, the patients develop a phobia of even the sight or sound of water. Finally, seizures, coma, and death occur.

Laboratory diagnosis of rabies is performed by the following methods:

  • Antigen detection by Direct immunofluorescence (IF) from specimens of :
    • Skin biopsy from the nape of the neck including hair follicles. Rabies antigen is present in cutaneous nerves at the base of hair follicles. It is the most sensitive and specific test.
    • Corneal smears were previously used. They are not used anymore as they are of low diagnostic yield.
  • Viral isolation- Intracerebral inoculation in mice can be attempted from the brain, CSF, and saliva.
  • Antibody demonstration from serum and CSF.
  • Viral RNA detection by RT-PCR.
  • Postmortem examination of brain tissue samples- demonstration of Negri bodies.

questions.text: Incorrect statement about buerger's disease from the following is:

choices.text: Affects small and medium sized arteries
Thrombophlebitis of the superficial or deep veins
Usually occurs in age group of 60’s

questions.solution:
Incorrect statement about Buerger's disease is it 'usually occurs in the age group of 60’s '.

Buerger's disease (thromboangitis obliterans) is a progressive nonatherosclerotic segmental inflammatory disease that most often affects small- and medium-sized arteries, veins, and nerves of the lower extremities. It is characterized by occlusive disease of small- and medium-sized arteries, thrombophlebitis of the superficial or deep veins, and Raynaud’s syndrome. 

Clinical features:

  • Common in male smokers below 40 years of age group
  • Intermittent claudication in foot and calf progressing to rest pain, ulceration, and gangrene.
  • Recurrent migratory superficial thrombophlebitis.
  • Absent/feeble pulses distal to proximal; dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial, popliteal, femoral arteries.
  • It may present as Raynaud’s phenomenon. Raynaud's phenomenon is episodic vasospasm. It leads to a sequence of clinical features called Raynaud’s syndrome comprising local syncope, local asphyxia, and local recovery.

 Investigations:

  • Arterial doppler and duplex scan (doppler + B-mode U/S).
  • Transfemoral retrograde angiogram through the Seldinger technique shows blockage—sites, extent, and severity
    • The corkscrew appearance of the vessel is due to the dilatation of the vasa vasorum.
    • Inverted tree/spider leg collaterals.
    • Severe vasospasm causing corrugated/rippled artery. 
    • Distal runoff is the amount of dye filling in the main vessel distal to the obstruction through collaterals. If the distal run-off is good then ischemia is compensated. If the distal run-off is poor then ischemia is decompensated.

Treatment:

  • Cessation of smoking is the definitive management. 
  • Drugs to improve circulation include
    • Pentoxifylline
    • Aspirin
    • Clopidogrel
    • Statins 
    • Cilostazol- Phosphodiesterase inhibitor is ideally used to improve circulation in the collaterals formed.
    • Vasodilators and anticoagulants have no role in the treatment.
  • Care of limb with Buerger’s exercise and positioning 
  • Surgical management may include lumbar sympathectomy and amputation according to the presenting features.
