questions.text: All of the following statement regarding ranula are true except

choices.text: It is a mucous extravasation cyst
It arises from submandibular salivary gland
It presents as a bluish, translucent, cystic swelling in the floor of mouth
Treatment includes excision of the gland

questions.solution:
The incorrect statement regarding ranula is it arises from the submandibular salivary gland. It is a mucous extravasation cyst occurring as a result of obstruction of one of the sublingual salivary glands in the floor of the mouth.

They are translucent, bluish, soft, cystic fluctuant swelling in the anterior floor of the mouth. They are usually painless unless infected. It resembles the belly or air sac of a frog. It pushes the tongue upwards and medially thus interfering with speech, mastication, respiration, and swallowing. They can remain localised or occur beyond the confines of the floor of the mouth through the mylohyoid muscle to present as a submental swelling called a plunging ranula. 

Management: Both simple and plunging ranulas should be excised along with the cyst wall and the sublingual gland. Incision, drainage and marsupialisation (unroofing the cyst and tacking the edges of the cyst to adjacent tissues) have low success rates as this gland has multiple ducts and ranulas can recur if the gland is left behind.

The image of oral ranula is given below.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with a throbbing unilateral headache of severe intensity, which is aggravated by movement and is associated with photophobia. Calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) receptor antagonists were found to be effective in the management of her headache. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of throbbing unilateral headache responsive to CGRP antagonists indicates a diagnosis of migraine headache.

Migraine is the second most common cause of headaches, after tension headaches. It is characterized by unilateral and throbbing headaches of moderate to severe intensity. Other features of migraine include deep-seated pain and sensitivity to environmental and sensory stimuli. The headache can be triggered by glares, bright lights, sounds, hunger, stress, physical exertion, hormonal fluctuations during menses, lack of or excess sleep, or alcohol.

Management of migraine includes nonpharmacologic management and pharmacologic measures. Triggers unique to the patient should be avoided. Lifestyle modifications to avoid excessive caffeine and alcohol, and to maintain a healthy sleep cycle are necessary.

Pharmalogical treatment can be divided into abortive treatment of acute attackes and prophylaxis to prevent actue attacks. Acute attack can be treated with acetaminophen, aspirin NSAIDs, antiemetics and triptans. Triptans (Sumatriptan, Zolmitriptan) are used in moderate to severe migraine or when simple analgesics have not been effective. Prophylaxis with beta blockers like propranalol, valproate, topiramate.

Migraine is associated with the release of calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) within the trigeminal nucleus. Hence, newer therapies using CGRP antagonists and monoclonal antibodies to CGRP and its receptor are effective in treating and preventing migraine. They are considered to be as effective as triptans and are better tolerated. 

Other options:

Option A - Cluster headaches are deep, retro-orbital, unilateral, excruciating headaches. They are characterized by attacks at the same time every day. 

Option B - Temporal arteritis or giant cell arteritis is a vasculitis. It affects medium to large-sized arteries. It is characterized by fever, anemia, high erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and headaches in people over the age of 50. 

Option D - Trigeminal neuralgia is characterized by excruciating pain in the area of the trigeminal nerve. It lasts for a few seconds to a minute and can recur. 

Related Pearl: Simplified diagnostic criteria for migraine

Repeated attacks of headache lasting 4-72 h in patients with a normal physical examination, no other reasonable cause for the headache, and

At Least 2 of the following features

  • Unilateral pain
  • Throbbing pain
  • Aggravation by movement
  • Moderate or severe intensity

Plus at Least 1 of the following features

  • Nausea/vomiting
  • Photophobia and phonophobia

questions.text: A 26-year-old male with a history of respiratory tract infection 4 weeks ago is unable to stand or walk for the past 2 weeks and the weakness is progressive, ascending and symmetrical in nature. The lower limbs were involved before and gradually the upper limbs were also affected. On examination, you note areflexia and the speech is slurred. Which of the following would you administer to him as the initial therapy?
questions.solution:
This patient with progressive symmetric ascending weakness is suggestive of Guillain Barre syndrome (GBS). The initial therapy is high-dose intravenous immune globulin (IVIg).

GBS is an acute autoimmune neuropathy. It results from the autoimmune destruction of nerves in the peripheral nervous system causing weakness that can progress to paralysis. It is associated with Campylobacter jejuni gastrointestinal infections, vaccines and respiratory illnesses. The antibodies target peripheral nerves and cause demylenation. Hence the preferred treatment is to neutralize these autoantibodies using IVIg (I.V. immunoglobulins) or plasmapheresis. IVIg is often the initial therapy chosen because of its ease of administration and good safety record.

IVIg is also preferred over plasma exchange (PE) for the AMAN and MFS variants of GBS.

GBS manifests as a rapidly evolving motor paralysis with areflexia (or hyporeflexia), with or without sensory disturbance. It is an ascending paralysis that affects the lower limbs more than the upper limbs. Areflexia or hyporeflexia is usually present. It can also affect the cranial nerves, leading to features of bulbar paralysis like difficulty articulating words and excessive drooling. Respiration is compromised when it involves respiratory muscles. In such cases, ventilatory support is needed.

Note: Steroid therapy is used in Chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy and not useful in GBS. Physostigmine is used to treat mysthenia gravis which present initially with occular symptoms like ptosis and diplopia.

Related Pearl: Antibodies seen in Guillian Barre syndrome

Type Antibody
AIDP Anti GM1
AMAN Anti GD1a
AMSAN Anti GD1a
Miller Fisher syndrome Anti GQ1b
  • AIDP-Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy 
  • AMAN-Acute motor axonal neuropathy 
  • AMSAN-Acute motor sensory axonal neuropathy

questions.text: What level of serum potassium rise is considered as hyperkalemia?
questions.solution:
Hyperkalemia is an increase in the levels of serum potassium >5.5 mM. 

Common causes of hyperkalemiainclude acidosis, the use of angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors, and β2-antagonists. It can be seen as a manifestation of chronic kidney disease, and after a massive blood transfusion.

Features include cardiac arrhythmias which include sinus bradycardia, sinus arrest, ventricular tachycardia, ventricular fibrillation, and asystole.

ECG shows tall and peaked T waves, widening of QRS complexes, loss of P waves and sine wave pattern.

It is a medical emergency and has to be treated when ECG changes are present or severe hyperkalemia (serum K >6.5) without ECG changes. 

Management is as follows 

  • Intravenous infusion of 10 ml of 10% calcium gluconate for 2-3 minutes with cardiac monitoring. It helps to antagonise the cardiac effects.
  • Intravenous regular insulin 10 units followed by 50mL of 50 % dextrose. This helps in shifting the plasma K+ into the cells
  • Nebulisation with β2 agonists such as albuterol or salbutamol are effective. 
  • Cation exchange resins, diuretics and or dialysis are useful to remove the potassium.

questions.text: Where is the headquarters of the following organization located?
questions.solution:
The given image is the logo of the World Health Organization, WHO that has its headquarters located in Geneva, Switzerland.

WHO is a specialized, non-political health agency of the United Nations. It came into force on the 7th of April 1948. Its prime objective is the attainment by all people of the highest level of health. The structure of the WHO comprises the World Health Assembly, the Executive Board, and the Secretariat. 

 The responsibility of the WHO is in the following broad areas:

  1. Prevention and control of specific diseases
  2. Development of comprehensive health services
  3. Family health
  4. Environmental health
  5. Health statistics
  6. Biomedical research
  7. Health literature and information
  8. Co-operation with other international organizations

The headquarters of regional offices of WHO are:

  • The Southeast Asian regional office (SEARO) is in New Delhi, India
  • The African regional office is in Brazzaville, Republic of Congo.
  • The American regional office is in Washington D. C., USA.
  • The European regional head office is in Copenhagen, Denmark.
  • The Eastern Mediterranean regional office is in Alexandria, Egypt.
  • The Western Pacific regional office is in Manila, Philippines.

The headquarters of other important organizations are:

  • The headquarters of UNICEF and UNDP is in New York, USA.
  • The headquarters of the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) is in Rome, Italy.

Note: Other organizations that have headquarters in Geneva are the International Labor Organization (ILO) and the International Red Cross Society.

questions.text: A 40 year old male chronic smoker comes with acute epigastric discomfort for the past one hour. ECG shows ST segment elevation in the inferior leads. What is the immediate intervention?
questions.solution:
In the above-mentioned scenario, immediate intervention is the administration of aspirin.

Aspirin is the first drug given in acute coronary syndromes. 

The following protocol must be followed in the management of patients with acute coronary syndrome:

  1. Stabilization of airway, breathing and circulation.
  2. Administration of O2
  3. Give aspirin 325 mg and clopidogrel 
  4. History and examination, assess cardiac biomarkers.
  5. Give up to three sublingual nitroglycerin tablets each 5 min apart till the pain subsides. Add IV nitroglycerin for the persistence of symptoms.
  6. Treat left heart failure if present with an after-load reducing agent or loop diuretic.
  7. Give beta blockers if there is no features of heart failure.
  8. Give morphine for the persistence of anxiety and discomfort related to MI.
  9. In patients with STEMI - Reperfusion with Percutaneous coronary intervention(PCI) or fibrinolysis (if PCI is unavailable within 120 min). is followed by antiplatelet and anticoagulant therapy. In patients with NSTEMI - antiplatelet and anticoagulant therapy is indicated.

questions.text: A baby was brought to the clinic with symptoms of diarrhea, failure to thrive, and hair loss. On examination, the following findings are noted. Identify the mineral deficiency leading to this condition.
questions.solution:
The clinical features shown in the images are periorificial dermatitis and alopecia. These features in a young child are suggestive of acrodermatitis enteropathica, which is seen with zinc deficiency.

Acrodermatitis enteropathica is a condition that occurs due to zinc deficiency and presents after weaning. Clinical features include failure to thrive, anorexia, diarrhea, recurrent infections, alopecia, male hypogonadism, and neurological manifestations like tremor, nystagmus, photophobia, hypogeusia, irritability, etc.

Skin manifestations such as vesiculobullous dermatitis on the extremities and periorificial (perianal, perigenital, perioral) regions are commonly seen as shown below. Affected infants require long-term supplementation with zinc.

Other options:

Option A: Niacin deficiency leads to Pellagra which is characterized by diarrhea, dermatitis, and dementia. Dermatitis is seen in sun-exposed areas and presents as hyperpigmentation around the neck known as Casal's necklace. An image of Casal's necklace is shown below.

Option C: Riboflavin deficiency manifests as glossitis, cheilitis, magenta-colored tongue, angular stomatitis, and circumcorneal vascularization, as shown below.

Option D: Selenium deficiency is implicated in keshan disease (Endemic cardiomyopathy) and kashin-Beck disease (Chronic, endemic osteoarthropathy).
